Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 26, 1951  BELL, Bill    He is tense, - a very tense pitcher. Everything he does while pitching is of tremendous importance to him. That is good enough to be complimentary about if, indeed, he were able to relax, - let down we call it, while he is pitching. He is so extremely conscientious about his work and, of course, that makes him wild.    He has a world of stuff. Indeed, he has the basic foundation of four distinctive pitches, - great speed when he wants it, corking curve, and both changes. Big, strong, fine in every way. It seems to me that he might be a right handed Hallahan, - all a matter of control.    I am not so sure that talking about his lack of control so much and the other emphasis we have put on it and the number of times and the number of people who have probably talked to him about it has made him subconscious of his lack of control, and everytime he winds up to throw a ball, he is thinking about method or means, - in any event his lack of control and that pressure which has been put upon him has not helped him and probably has retarded his naturalness in delivery and hindered his acquiring of better control. He is the type of boy who worries about his work, thinks about it, somehow or other. We have to get him out of that frame of mind. Whenever he gets control, he is a quicky.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 26, 1951    BERAN, Lee    Is a better prospect than my first report indicated. His fast ball is better than I thought, and he does have a curve.     Take out the word "fair" in my first report on this pitcher as it related to his fast ball.     I do not know enough about his ability to hold men on bases and I regard him as a pretty good runner.     I do not see any reason why he cannot become a good fielder.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 4, 1951    BERAN, Leon  One of nine children, - six older than he. About 5' 11", right hander and his father is a Kansas wheat farmer. He really lives on a farm. Fair fast ball, curve very medium speed, but it curves; has more the effect of a change of speed curve ball. Has about that velocity that makes it difficult to make it a faster or slower one. He worked on a change of speed off his fast ball with some success, - not much. He is a good boy and I mean good. If all our eighteen year old boys in America were like this chap, most certainly God would smile upon us as a nation. He cannot pitch, however, right now. Any slight criticism immediately dampens him. Failure in any respect would make him dejected. He would get discouraged easily in would seem to me. He can be pleasant, but his self-appraisement of failure would make him possibly even disagreeable. Right now he is a good boy in every way.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: REPORT OF BRANCH RICKEY ON NEW ORLEANS CLUB AS OBSERVED IN ONE GAME AT MEMPHIS ON MAY 29, 1951.    BEVAN    A twenty year old, 6' 1", I would say, fine build, fine action. He showed no power at the plate tonight, but I do not see any reason why this boy should not hit the ball hard. I would say that he can run, - above average. Showed no lead, and gave no evidence of gambling on a break. Played first base, and at least showed one fine skill,-on a throw from the catcher, he tags to his right, and seems to do the scissors with his right leg naturally. I have yet to see Kiner take a throw and tag to his right at anytime.    Bevan did not tag to the ground, but did tag six to eight inches high on several occasions. In this respect he has about two feet on Kiner. His foot shifting was beyond critcism in this game. He touches with both the left and right foot as the play may require. This also is a point entirely beyond Kiner who has never yet been known to touch the base with his left foot. Bevan might become a first baseman. I do not know. I would like to see him at some other infield position, - not because I do not think he can ultimately play first base, but simply because we have pro-  spective first basemen in the organization, - boys who ought to do the job. He looks and acts like a good athelete.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: June 25, 1951  New Orleans Club against Nashville in two games June 21st and June 22nd.    BEVAN - Second Base    Young, big, strong, runs good enough, and his arm is good enough. He could go major league. I doubt if he ever will, and because of only one reason, and that is because he has no adventure. Takes a six foot lead off first base and doesn't even dare the pitcher with that lead. As far as leads and breaks are concerned, he would do just as well as if he were the slowest runner in the world. It is just too bad that a fellow with his physical set-up should be without any dare whatever. This boy should become a good hitter. When Bevan gets on first base, he says to himself, - "I must not get caught off". He never says to himself, - "I challenge you." He never produces a thought in the pitcher's mind, or the catcher's mind, or anyone's mind that he is liable to run. He seldom will arrive at second base in time to take a man out on a possible double play.    I doubt if he is a second baseman.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 8, 1951    BRANCH, Leonard    This boy has a fast ball, not great, but the ball is as fast as some major league fast balls. He has no control of it whatever. He throws a curve ball and it is easily his best pitch. In fact, the ball curves. A windmill delivery on it from a 6' 4" fellow helps it out, BUT he has no control whatever of it either.     He is honest. Said his control at Modesto was "positively terrible." I asked about his control at Eugene, where he spent the latter part of the season. Branch said it was even worse than at Modesto. He has no ability to learn the change of pace on his fast ball. the ball almost never spins. It just rolls around. He is willing and it is just too bad. He needs a better teacher than I am. He is intelligent, that is to say, he knows what he needs and understands that some of his pitches are bad and some are good. He is understanding. Hate to give up on him. There isn't any point in changing the speed on his curve. His present curve is neither fast or slow, but is good, but is of that velocity that it will be difficult to get a change-up on it either faster or slower. It is the only curve ball he needs or should have.     Even if this boy has control of his present curve and fast ball, he must have an additional and distinctively different pitch and, it must be usable. There is a job ahead of him to become a major league pitcher, - a hard job, but he might do it. We really must work on him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 11, 1951    BRANCH, Leonard    I do not know what I said in my previous report about Branch's fast ball, but my judgment today is that he doesn't have one. He has a most deceptive curve, - very effective against righthanders. He must get another pitch.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 3, 1951    BROWN, John  He keeps the fingers visibly apart on his fast ball and tight together on his curve. His right thumb protrudes above the ball on his curve noticeably. In other words, the ball is back in the sock on the curve ball much more than on his fast ball. I do not believe the difference is enough to try to change him. I doubt if a coach or batsman will detect it, but it must have further attention.    His fast ball is good and his overhand curve is good. He also throws a sidearm curve and in the seven times he threw it, not one was over the plate. His change of speed on the fast ball is a "palm" ball. I do not like it. It is too fast for one thing. He must get a change-up on his fast ball. His change-up on his curve ball might be alright. I need to work on him again. I was rushed for time. I would say that he has to be improved in that respect also. He comes to a quick fielding position. I believe he has general athletic ability. He looks the part anyway. He is certainly worth a lot of attention in this camp.    October 5, 1951  This boy does not have control of his change of pace, and in fact he doesn't have a change-up on his curve ball. He says he threw one all summer, but he isn't throwing it now because of a sore elbow. Before he pitches in camp, I want the managers to have a conversation with him about this.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 3, 1951    BUNGE, Arthur    An eighteen year old left hander from San Diego. He is 6'3". This boy positively has the best control of a fast ball I have ever seen in any youngster. For about ten straight pitches, a tomato can would have caught nine of them, and he has fair speed. No curve, no change of pace on either his fast or curve balls, but his control, size, youth, and desire make him worthwhile of our attention. The decision to make a pitcher out of this boy is undoubtedly a good one. These boys will work together at the present time under Rex Bowen. If Rex gets anywhere with his job, these boys would then be turned over to Bill Burwell with the purpose of each one getting a better breaking regular curve ball.     Kaffel

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 4, 1951     BURKLE, John    Los Angeles boy about 6" 1" , 180 pounds, right hander. Good speed, fair change of pace curve. His regular curve has velocity, but almost no break. - perceptible, but that is all. He has no change of speed on his fast ball. He could well stand a better slow curve than he has, and he should have a better curve ball. He is working on his change on the fast ball. I believe he will get it. He should be assigned for regular work to Bill Burwell or Barrett or any coach who is full of suggestions. This boy is more of the Law type in the field of intelligence. Has the marks of culture about him, courtesy and manners, and all that. He can get out of the thrower class very fast and become a pitcher. He simply needs more material. He requires mechanical attention and help. I would call him a definite prospect, - that he will come as fast as his variables permit. I like him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 5, 1951    ANDERSON, Daniel  Ben Tincup has got something here. Barely 18, 180 pounds, probably 6' or 6'1", right hander. His father is an antique dealer up in Iowa. His mother calls him Danny, but he seems embarrassed when anybody else does. He can throw everything and I mean everything. He had no change up on his fast ball, but he has it on his first workout and in my judgement, all four of his pitches (and he has four) are usable. If this boy has any command of himself, has poise, competitive spirit, etc., etc., he will certainly amount to something. You do not have to fool around for four or five years with Anderson. His chrysalis stage is soon over. I see no reason why he cannot go to AAA next year. Everything depends upon stage fright, or possibly give-up-ness. These are things no one can tell about until the boy is under fire.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 5, 1951    BUTCHKO, Steve  This boy is a big right hander from the Pittsburgh District who mystifies me. His fast ball is not very fast and yet batters miss it, and catchers say it does something. I cannot figure it out. I do not know why anybody would miss it, but it does something, that's a cinch, and we will let it go at that. He says he has no curve and he hasn't. It is sort of a left hander's slider, a crazy pitch, but it is a cruve and it should not be taken away from him. He has a change-up on his fast ball, - not very good control of it, but he has it, and he should work on control of it and he will do that. He should be pitched again and eventually he should be given a change of pace curve ball. It would go good with the rest of his stuff as his present so-called curve ball has high velocity. Very honest, frank fellow. I like him personally very much, but I cannot understand how he can pitch with the stuff he's got. (He struck out six straight pretty good hitters in yesterday's ball game.)

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: June 25, 1951  New Orleans Club against Nashville in two games June 21st and June 22nd.    CARLSEN - Pitcher    The difference between a thrower and a pitcher is the difference   between a naked man and a man all dressed up. Carlsen was a pitcher in   the game on Thursday night, June 21st. He finished strong, and showed   no signs of a damaged arm. He was free and loose. Did not use any observable change of pace pitch off his fast ball, but did use what seemed   to be a slow curve. He used a so-called fast curve frequently. I was disadvantageously seated to describe his stuff, but it occurred to me   during the game that he could use, and in fact needed an additional pitch, -   a knuckle ball, or fade-away, or a take-off on his fast ball, or something.   The boy acts intelligent and looks it. He should be pitched regularly   and watched closely. Check on his disposition and background.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: September 12, 1951    CASALE, JERRY - Right Hand Pitcher    He will be 18 years of age within a few days. He will weigh about 210 pounds, - apparently overweight, but not unusual in boys of his type and age. Nothing to worry about at that point.    This chap can really throw the ball hard. He can throw the ball just about as hard as Bell can throw it. His curve ball is fairly good. Control of everything just about what you would expect from a boy of his pitching experience and particularly his strength. Any boy 18 years of age who can throw a ball as hard as Jerry can throw it will undoubtedly be wild. He comes to me with nothing but two pitches, and he will not acquire the new pitches too fast. He is a born power pitcher and without too much aptitude, but it well can be that he doesn't need too much of that stuff. He is a definite prospective major leaguer even if he never acquires any additional pitch at all. I certainly would like to have him.     P.S Branch, hearing my dictation on on Casale, stated that I may be wrong in reference to aptitude. Says Branch, "The boy perhaps has more aptitude than intelligence" and Branch may be right about it.     BR

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 11, 1951    CAYAVEC, Wm. J.    A right hand hitting infielder-outfielder. Very ordinary runner. Looks at the ground invariably on the first twenty feet from home plate as he starts to run. Has good arm, but has shown no power at all in the first half dozen games here. As a matter of fact, he has not hit the ball solidly at anytime. As a major league prospect as an infielder-outfielder, - I do not think so.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: REPORT OF BRANCH RICKEY ON NEW ORLEANS CLUB AS OBSERVED IN ONE GAME   AT MEMPHIS ON MAY 29, 1951.    CLARK  A little fellow who gives all the appearance of   wanting to do a good job. He impressed me as having a very   ordinary arm, fair runner, short stepper, no power at the plate.  I would rate him a fair Class B ball player.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 6, 1951    CLARK, Lou  This boy has had a history of a bad arm. He pitched last year at Greenville, - this year at Brunswick.  Hasn't pitcher [sic] very many innings either year. Had a bad arm most of the season. His arm is now sound. He has a pretty good fast ball, and he has learned an "inshoot". In other words, he really has two fast balls. He has no curve at all. It breaks just enough to see it, but no velocity on it. It is an amateur pitch. He must be turned over to Bill Burwell or Red Barrett, but I would say Red Barrett in this case, and next week must be assigned to Barrett, along with others, simply with the idea of improving his curve ball. Red should not hesitate to change him in anyway he pleases, keeping in mind that anyway he might tell him might be the wrong way, but it might suggest something that will help the fellow. You only have  something to win if you suggest a dozen different ways eventually getting one that might become effective.  I do not know whether he has any aptitude or not, and in/any event, he didn't show much to me.    Turn him over to Barrett.    By the way, he shows pretty good control of both his fast pitches.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 11, 1951    CLARK, Lou  Just a fast ball. Not a thing in the world but a fast ball. He should simply go in the same group under Bill Burwell. He must be given enough instruction to send him home on the 15th pleasantly. For the life of me, I cannot see why he should be sent above C or D next year. I think it would be a mistake to do so.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 6, 1951    COCHRANE, Donald    Fair fast ball, nice built, young righthander, last year witth Bartlesville. Will be eighteen right away. Slow curve ball overhand is the same as his regular curve ball, which, he says, he throws three-quarters. The latter is not much good. He really has only one curve ball, - usable in a small league. He is learning a change up on his fast ball and he will get it because he has ambition and will work hard. This boy should be assigned to a partner working on a change-up on his fast ball. Put him with any other pitcher needing this work.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 26, 1951    COCHRANE, Don    His curve ball is very good. it has the effect of a change of speed and it curbes, - a downer. Not a great break, but the adaptation of speed and rotation makes it a very unusually effective pitch. The control of his fast ball is not too good but is good enough. To be kept in the quicky prospect blass and by the word quicky, it is my guess that the boy could come to the major league as soon as he gets better control of his fast ball and is able to use he entire assortment.    This boy turns his shoulder too much toward first base when runners are on. He must from his hip up turn his body more toward the plate and then must look with indirect vision by turning the neck more toward the bag, or, indeed, he can get the correct body posture and substitute for his present one, a head movement. I notice no fault whatever in his looking at the runner when he starts his delivery but it must be watched and he may have this fault. I have not noticed it.    This is the boy who lives in Arkansas, but close to the Missouri line, - Salem, Arkansas.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: September 12, 1951    CONTILLO, Larry - Left Hand Pitcher    A left hander, weighs about 170 pounds, 5' 10". Well mannered, intelligent, inclined toward artistry in pitching, could  acquire anything on short notice. Has three of four different pitches of his own and took to both the change of pace on the curve and fast ball immediately, but really doesn't need either one. He has changes of his own. Very bad follow through on pitching. He stands on one leg like a crane, but his good sense and desire would probably overcome must [sic] of the faults in this direction.    It is my judgment that this boy's future depends upon the effectiveness of his speed. In other words, it is a question in  my mind whether or not he has enough speed to go all the way. If he were able to surround his present fast ball with the artistry of deflective pitches and changes of pace, he, of course, could become a Roe or a pitcher of that type, and he might do that very thing.    However, he is a gamble because very few boys develop into Roes. He is a pleasure to work with.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: James Joseph Anderson    A well built left hand pitcher weighing I would guess 175 pounds-180 pounds, only 5' 8" tall. He can throw the ball hard, - harder than Williams. Just fair curve ball.    He can get the change of speed on the fast ball, but it makes very little difference what he gets on the way of pitches, he cannot throw one ball out of twenty over the plate, and his record proves it, - if his showing with me needed proof.    This boy is what is known as a one-eyed pitcher. At the time of delivery, or at least immediately preceding delivery, he only has one eye on the plate and he pretty nearly cuts that one off. He is one boy in a thousand who would turn his head so far in the act of delivery that he cannot see the plate. I do not believe he will ever get control and I know he will not until he breaks the habit of turning his neck with his body.    Do the same thing with him as you do with Williams.    It seems to me that the only deal Olean could make with us is to leave the players right on their list subject to draft, and if they are drafted, they get the money and let it go at that, and if they are not drafted, then they become subject to our purchase at $1000 later if we want them.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: September 12, 1951    COVALESKI, JOHN - Infielder    An 18 year Eddie Stanky. He runs like him, aggressive, quick, strong arm on the short throws, likes to play, - the winning type. Batting form is o.k. Very ordinary power. A good runner, but not a great runner. Really might become a major leaguer, but probably several years to do it. I would not go too high on him and I doubt the advisability of going after him at all simply because of his present offers, or, at least, negotiations with other major league club. If the player would sign for say $6000 or something like that, I would be much interested.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 2, 1951     CURTISS, Joseph    I certainly would have to see him again to have a high estimate. An ordinary fast ball, no curve to speak of, a fair slow curve ball. Nothing impressive.   Not one of his different pitches has correct rotation, nor do they spin on any pitch. He should be sent to a Class D club next year surely.    He might be turned over to Bill Burwell or someone else for further work. It could be that I am wrong. Judging from his workout with me, I could not recommend any bonus whatever.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 11, 1951      DAVIS, Brandon    "They" say this boy cannot throw good enough. I think he can. He throws quick and he knows how to throw, and the ball hops well after it hits the ground. He can run. He knows how to run. He is alert and adventuresome. He will steal bases and take the extra base.    He hits fly balls and that is just too bad. He doesn't have power. If George Sisler can help this boy to level his drives, I am positive that this fellow can make the Pittsburgh Club.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: REPORT OF MR. BRANCH RICKEY ON NEW ORLEANS CLUB AS OBSERVED IN ONE GAME AT MEMPHIS ON MAY 29, 1951.    DORTON  A good receiver, a quick arm, and it is strong enough. Impresses me as a very highly intelligent chap. A sort of pest hitter. Does not hit at bad balls and will take a base on balls. He can run pretty good. A gentleman. I think I would like to have him on the PIttsburgh club in 1952. Meyer doesn't rate him at all nor does anyone else, so far as know.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: June 25, 1951  New Orleans Club against Nashville in two games June 21st and June 22nd.    DORTON - Catcher    Not a big boy. Not much power. Hustles every second. Albert, (might be a little more aggressive) very intelligent. Quick arm and accurate with it. Fine receiver, - body checks all low pitches. If he can hit a lick, Pittsburgh can use him. I believe this boy would consult pitchers during the game if he had a bit more experience, - knew the batsmen better. I believe a championship major league club could carry this boy.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 11, 1951    FACKLER, Earl    In the first half-dozen games here, he has not hit a single ball hard. Look likes he runs very good, his arm is not bad, but his helplessness at bat is apparent to everybody. I do not understand how the fellow with this fine build, - all the physical set-up, can be so utterly unproductive with a piece of wood in his hands. He would do just as well with a lead pencil.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: September 18, 1951    FISHER, Harry    Worked him out as pitcher this morning. He has enough   fast ball to pitch anywhere, fair curve ball and a fair change of   pace curve ball. He doesn't have any usable change of pace on his   fast ball. When he bears down to throw either of his curves, he has   no control. I would say that his record for the past three years   reflects his ability as a pitcher.     This boy has what I would call fine hitting form and a   lot of power. Right hand thrower, left hand hitter, and has all the   manner and appearance of a splendid gentleman. Doesn't seem to me to   be aggressive, or to have any sort of fighting spirit and perhaps no   leadership. This is bad because I have in mind making a catcher out of   him. He can learn how to throw and has plenty of arm for the job.     It is my very conclusive judgment that he can come quickly   to the major leagues as a catcher and it is a very final conclusion   with me that he can never go to the major leagues in any other position.     WOLFE, Edward    A big, tall right hander, 22 years of age, living in   California. His record at Bartlesville in 1950 was very good and his   record this year at Charleston was fairly good. He has a fast ball   and he has a high velocity curve, - a very good curve. His change of   speed on his fast ball is not good because, first, he doesn't control   it, and second, it would not be good if he had good control of it. For   one thing, it has too much velocity.     His change up on his curve ball is not good enough and his   control of that pitch is not good. He needs to learn a change up pitch   on both the fast and curve balls.     This fellow is a definite prospect. Needs a lot of attention   and must have it at the school in Florida this October.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 11, 1951    Flynn    A very young right hand hitting infielder from away up in Maine. Very aggressive. Loves to play. Will group up and have power. Doesn't know strike from a ball. Liable to hit at anything. Curve balls upset him terribly. He will get over that. He has a fine arm, and a quick arm, fair runner. Has a champion's heart with lots of adventure both offensively and defensively. Might become a very great player.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 1, 1951    FRIEND, Robert    He has every pitch he needs, - fast and curve ball, and change-up on each, and all four are effective. He needs no instruction on any of them.     He throws his fast ball with his two fingers far apart and he closes completely on the curve. Without any doubt he has the habit of winding up with his finger position set and there is no reason in this world why the opposing batsmen, to say nothing of the coaches, could know the fast ball from the curve ball and vice versa from the time he starts his windup. He must cover this pitch with his glove in the course of his windup, and in this connection, it would be better if he would start all pitches with his fingers apart, a fast ball indication, or he could start every one as a curve ball with his fingers together, but one or the other should become his continuous habit.     This boy cannot hold men on first base nor can he hold men on second base. He is undoubtedly nervous and this may account for his lack of fielding ability. Apparently he has no body control, - almost none whatever. He cannot field his position in any respect. He must be kept constantly on the pitchers fielding practice work, and have special instruction on holding men on bases.     Then, whatever time has he left should be devoted to batting in the cages.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 4, 1951    ANDERTON, Robert    Lives down in Alabama. About 6' 3", slim boy, - nice boy. Ordinary fast ball but it is the best pitch he has. Curve so so. Change of pace curve ball same thing. Cannot tell which is which. Change-up on fast ball no good. No aptitude whatever. He is a lovely kid, innocent. I would be surprised if he is not ignorant of vice, and if so, it is wonderful. He might be a pitcher someday, but it is surely a distant date. Has to pitch in D next year.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 1, 1951    ANTHONY, Lee    A big, strong right hand pitcher, 32 years of age, and a nice fellow. I think he knows how to pitch.    He has a very good fast ball, - not great. It is not good enough considering that he doesn't have much to go with it. His regular curve ball is very ordinary, - minor league. He has a slow curve ball which he says he can control. May be so.    His very best pitch is a screwball which he usually throws as an ordinary pitch. It doesn't rotate very fast and its direction is irregular. However, he can throw it with a fast spin and correct rotation and the ball is then a corker. He insists that he can control it.     He must have an additional pitch, - I would say a usable change of speed curve ball, and he must perfect and control the fade-away. He might then have a chance. He is working on this pitch and is turned over to Bill Burwell for further report.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 11, 1951    Babcock  Infielder. Looks intelligent, acts intelligent, very young. He can throw.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: BARBAO, Ken    A one finger curve bell pitcher. Throws a straight drop, medium speed, curve ball with his fore finger knuckled, and he controls it, and the ball breaks. It is a usable curve. Also has an effective change of speed pitch. His fast ball is good.    This chap has good body control. Should become, or perhaps is, a corking good fielder. He has learned the change of speed pitch on his fast ball. About one-half of the time it rotates correctly, and with acceptable velocity. The other half it doesn't. He must master consistency on the pitch. His fast ball is good enough, - very live. Could go to the majors. Sad to say, out of the thirty eight pitchers in this camp, this pitcher is one of the half dozen not over six feet.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 26, 1951    BARBAO, Ken    Plenty of speed, particularly when he presses, but when he presses, his control naturally slips away. Nevertheless, his speed is major league. Good curve ball and throws it from two angles, three-quarters, -perhaps a little more toward overhand, and also practically sidearm. Most of the time it is a good curve, -not always. Needs more regularity on this pitch and, of course, better control of the curve and fast ball. I think his change-up can be very effective. He needs to work on it further. His rotation on it is perfect. Nobody can tell how soon he will come, but the date relates to his being able to pin-point any one pitch. Very definitely a prospect, and might become usable at an early date.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 1, 1951    BELL, Bill    Big, right hand pitcher, not yet eighteen years of age. Comes from Goldsboro, North Carolina. He throws everything. A great fast ball, a great straight drop curve, a marvelous change of speed on his fast ball and he will have a great change of pace curve ball. He is a major leaguer if ever one was born.    Bell is a scarey-cat, -- knows nothing about pitching, and knows he knows nothing. Has no confidence in himself and is highly receptive to advice. He has big ears.    This boy should not be coached at anytime by more than one person. Doubtless has to be taught to hold men on base and to field his position, and should be given a lot of batting practice. He is worthy of a lot of attention.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 5, 1951    HAYSOM, Bert    A pretty good fast ball and a pretty good curve, and pretty good control of both. This boy is about 6'3" and comes from California. Very young. Has no change of pace on anything. Nice boy, willing worker, wants to learn, tries hard. Shows a little improvement on the fast ball change.    Branch, Jr. should take him along with Sam Narron on the curve change.    The boy is worth working with. He will get bigger and stronger, and he is intelligent.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 8, 1951    JACOBS, Will    Nineteen year old left hander from near Washington, D.C. Facile left arm, - good wrist. Good fast ball because of his delivery and, too, it has good speed on it. His curve ball is a downer-outer. Form good. Did not show me any control of it, but I think he would have control of it. Said he pitched a change of speed on his fast ball a good deal this summer. One was over the plate out of every five or six pitches, - besides it is too fast. He is a workman, - shows he has pitched. I set him on the job of acquiring a change of pace on his curve ball. He acquired all the techniques of the pitch within five minutes, and ten minutes later couldn't repeat the change to save his soul. He can get it - I think he will.    Set him up with Leonard Branch, one working on his change-up on the fast ball, and the other on his change-up on the curve ball, - 100 pitches a day. Within two days we should get a report, and their progress should be observed.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 26, 1951    JACOBS, William F    Do not let anybody disturb him with their coaching. Leave him alone. Curve ball is not bad and I see no reason why his control should not be satisfactory. He is not a wild pitcher. All of his stuff is around the plate but not at all pin-pointed.    This boy needs coaching on his move to first, unless indeed he has a move I have not seen. I would give a great deal to work with him and I hope next Spring I will have the opportunity to work with him on this move.    Classify him as a major league prospect. Needs a better move, better control. I want to know more about him. I want to have more work with him. It may be that he needs another pitch. I don't believe he does. If he gets control of the change on his fast ball, he will have enough.    This boy's rotation is not fast enough and it doesn't always come back toward him. He must work on that pitch until he gets regularity on the direction of rotation and hopefully will acquire more rapidity on it.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: September 18, 1951    JANSCE, John F.    Young, right hand pitcher. Lives up near Butler. Pitched for Deland, Florida this year and won 25 games. This boy was in our Deland camp and was released. The boys did not agree enough about signing him up. He has a fair fast ball, fair curve, and throws a slow curve. Nothing exceptional on any of these pitches and showed me nothing that would indicate that he could ever go major league. His control might enable him to do well in the smaller leagues. He might reach the A's. Surely this pitcher is better than he showed me, otherwise I cannot see how he could make the record at Deland that he did make.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: September 18, 1951    PETTIT, Paul  I have worked the famous Pettit twice. Occasionally he will show a fair fast ball but only when he presses, and when he presses his control is not too good. He has a fair curve, - a downer, not great, but usable. He has no change up on anything that he can throw.  He has had record for two years or more or less disability, - something always wrong with him. Has complained more or less constantly during that period of an ailing arm. He is green, unfinished, and it seems to me that he lacks any great desire to be accomplished in any direction. We have at least fifteen pitchers, none of whom is even as old as Pettit, who are better prospects. He is an embryonic neurotic, and if he cannot play in either position, then I would question his being a prospect even for the market.    JANSCE, John F.  Young, right hand pitcher. Lives up near Butler. Pitched for Deland, Florida this year and won 25 games. This boy was in our Deland camp and was released. The boys did not agree enough about signing him up. He has a fair fast ball, fair curve, and throws a slow curve. Nothing exceptional on any of these pitches and showed me nothing that would indicate that he could ever go major league. His control might enable him to do well in the smaller leagues. He might reach the A's. Surely this pitcher is better than he showed me, otherwise I cannot see how he could make the record at Deland that he did make.    GROAT, Richard  This boy will graduate from Duke this coming June. He is a fair runner, very good arm, and good batting form. The best thing about Groat is his disposition, - his desire to play and to win. He has unusually good coordination and could play shortstop on the Pittsburgh club much better than anyone we now have. It would not ever be necessary to send him to any minor league club.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 3, 1951    KAPPEL, William    An eighteen year old, 6'3" right hand pitcher. A crazy pitcher, and when I asked him how he threw his fast ball, he said "four different ways." "What do you mean four different ways"? He replied, "just what I said." Then he showed me the four different ways and all had to do with the handling of the seams, except that he changed the position of his thumb. One of these pitches gave him a so-called regular fast ball, another gave him a very decided sinker, - a fast fadeaway one might call it, and the third was a crazy pitch, a wiggle waggle pitch, - a slow slider without very fast rotation and fairly good speed. This chap was really hard for Sam Narron to catch.    Kappel has good control of his fast ball, and good control of his fast fadeaway or slider. He also has very good control of his sinker pitch. Three different fast balls and they are really different.    The boys want to change him to an outfielder. Well, he has the size, and the willingness, and a tremendously big hand. The decision to make an outfielder out of him ought to be taken with a grain of salt as I see it. May be he can hit, - we'll find out. May be he is a fast runner, we'll find that out too.    Bill Kappel had a fork ball. It has the effect of a change of speed. He can throw all of them into a nail keg if the nail keg is 5' high and 3' to the right of the plate. Therefore, he has good control. We simply have got to teach him to put the nail keg on the plate. If the fellow can learn a change of pace curve to go with everything else he has, I can see no reason what he cannot become a pitcher. We will try him in both positions.    I have turned him over to Rex Bowen, who with the other pitcher I tried out at this time, Art Bunge, first, to get control of the fork ball and the acquiring of a change of speed curve ball.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 2, 1951    KEENEY, Scott  A left hander about 160 pounds. An even 6'. Has a very good curve ball, not fast, not slow, pretty good control of it. Fair fast ball. Nice boy to work with. I do not believe he can get a faster curve ball than he has, nor do I believe that he can get a slower curve than he now has. Even if he gets both, there would not be enough difference between his present curve ball and either of the other pitches to be worthwhile. This chap has a knuckle ball I am told. I did not find it out. I must work with him again.    October 5, 1951    In his second workout, this boy impressed me very much more. He has a knuckle ball. It is not one that could be called a great knuckle ball, but he has control of it. He can throw most anything and learns very rapidly. He is an intelligent kid, and Sam Narron says he might become another Bracheen. I believe he has the most artistry of any boy I have worked at anytime.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 5, 1951    KLINE, Ronnie    Good fast ball and a corking curve, and he will have good control of it. He has never been worked with by anybody for change of speed on either his fast or curve balls. At heart he is a pitcher and not a thrower. He has aptitude, - plenty of it, and surely he will be a fine pitcher. He needs a pitching partner and to work possibly twice a day for a week on the 40' mark on his changes. Do not worry about his delivery. He will be the same on all pitches. He needs continuous attention, not because of his faults on points such as holding men on base or fielding his position but to obtain perfection on pitches and control. He might be perfect, and it is worth the effort of all of us to make him so. The same thing goes for Neccai and a dozen others, but certainly it goes for Kline.    This boy should team up with Bert Haysom. They both have identical needs, although Haysom is not yet in a class with Kline.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 11, 1951    KOVALESKI    To me he is a great disappointment. Fair runner, not much power, none at all. As a matter of fact, it is difficult to judge his power, for he hasn't connected with any pitch in the first week of school, or the first half dozen games. He is a quick fellow, aggressive, wants to beat you, but doesn't have the tools. A quick arm but limited to the proverbial second base arm. Might reach AA someday on the basis of his experience and aggressiveness.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 8, 1951    LAKEY, Jasper    Fast ball not great. Lakey will get all pitches, changes on both fast ball and curve ball. In fact, he has the pitches right now. In fact, he will get out of the thrower class and become a pitcher pretty quick. It is a question as to whether he has enough stuff. Needs only one thing, namely, control. Lakey must be pitched right away in a game. If he gets good control of all his pitches, the boy will go into the money and if he were to get an especially good pitch, I cannot tell. He must have perfect control to go anywhere.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 6, 1951    Gebbs, Donald  Gebbs is a prospect. A 6' 3" left hander with a lot of determination and poise. He doesn't need one thing to make a great pitcher out of him except experience. He should be pitched again so on Tuesday.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: REPORT ON VERNON LAW BY BRANCH RICKEY - SEPTEMBER 21, 1951    Vernon Law is a big right-hand pitcher who has been on the Pittsburgh Club for two years. Great things were expected of him for 1951. He roomed with Chambers; that was bad. He has been a constant complainer that his arm was "ailing" and has been of very little service or help to our club this year. He is the greatest single disappointment I have had. Law has the reputation of a great fast ball. I have not seen it and he is supposed to have a repertoire of pitches, adequate and effective. I have not seen the repertoire. He is about six feet four and can run very fast, and has considerable power at the plate. He is going to Florida both as a pitcher and a possible outfielder. He will either be an improved pitcher and what was expected of him or he will be an outfielder or he won't be worth very much, - one of the three, and the October school in Florida will tell the tale.    This player's salary was advanced from $5,000 to $10,000 in 1951 without good reason. In fact, the only reason was Senator Walker of Idaho through whom Pittsburgh first secured the player. His salary should be reduced back to $5,000 for'52, but it may be unadvisable because of Senator Walker and particularly Bing Crosby whose final effort secured the player. I gave the Senator all the reasons why this chap should not be advanced in salary to $10,000 and I believe if he had been signed as he should have been signed, we would have had a different player out of him.    I have great hope of doing something good for Law in Florida. He is the championship type, loves to play, fine general ability as an athlete and a genuine gentleman in every respect.    Branch Rickey  BR/emm

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 6, 1951    LAW, Vernon    A big right handed Pittsburgh pitcher. Good fast ball, good curve, good change of pace curve, and he has a change of pace on his fast ball which Bill Posedel gave him. It has a wiggle-waggle rotation, - a sort of half fadeway rotation, but it definitely is not a fadeway. The only effect I see in his change-up on the fast ball is in its velocity. It has no spin and no correct rotation according to my way of thinking. The velocity is reduced over his fast ball, but again, in my opinion, - not enough. He took the conventional change up on the fast ball quickly as to spin and as to direction of the spin. Had some trouble reducing velocity, but once out of every four or five pitches, he would get a beautiful change of pace, - and he knew it.    He can pitch on our Club alright and he can pitch his present change of speed, but I do not think anywhere near as effective as it should be. And I thoroughly believe that with some practice on the conventional changeup on the fast ball he will be much more effective. If he had the same fast ball change-up, for example, that Erskine has, Law would probably be a twenty game winner. He understands it, and if he returns to pitching, and he probably will, he can easily acquire proficiency in this new pitch before the opening of next season. He certainly is an intelligent gentleman, and a fine character.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 10, 1951    LIPSTAS, Robert    A poor boy, barely eighteen years of age. Father works hard and mother with two other children works in a road restaurant. A nice boy. Has no shoes, and almost no spikes on such shoes as he does have. He really is a poor boy. Has played the outfield and did not hit very much. Both Detore and O'Neill suggested the change to pitching. He can throw the ball hard. He has no curve at all. Never has tried to throw one, except a change of pace curve which he worked out all by himself says he. It is alright if he can control it. He must be turned over to somebody to work with him on acquiring a new pitch, otherwise he is a non-prospect as a pitcher. I suggest that Bill Burwell take him with another group of boys every morning who will work them on the curve ball, beginning say immediately.    A group, I suggest, of eight to ten boys who need curve ball attention should be turned over to Bill Burwell and Red Barrett for work all at the same time.    This boy did not properly belong in this camp and most assuredly should not have been sent here.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 8, 1951    MAY, Ronald    Sixteen years and three months old. 155 pounds, 5'11". Doesn't have a single solitary pitch of any kind. He has the wrong rotation on his curve ball, but it curves a little. His fast ball rotates slowly and out to the side. It may be effective too, but it certainly would be an exception. He throws a change-up on his fast ball and the pivot comes up directly facing the batter. Really, I have never seen the beat of it. If that pitch is worth a darn, then I do not know anything. More than that, it never will be worth anything. The kid attempts a change-up on his curve ball, but it is nothing. It has neither form nor substance. I am very anxious to see the report cards on this player. There simply has to be some reason for sending him all the way across the country. I have turned him over to Branch, Jr. and Branch will make a report on him in due course.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 11, 1951    MILLER, George    A big, tall, lefthander from California who came to this camp for the ride. He knew for three weeks that he was supposed to report to camp in shape to pitch. Did not throw a ball for over a month before he came here. Did not even have a ball in his hand for that time, although he had marvelous weather in Riverside, Cal. all that time. Says his arm is too stiff to throw when he came in and that it will take sometime to get it in shape. The thing to do is to send him right back and charge the transportation to the price of the experience. We should check on the condition of men before they come if we ever do this thing again. It is absolutely true that we have four or five men in this camp in the same condition.    He showed me no fast ball, no curve in the workout. However, in the game, he showed fair speed, a fair curve and a good deal of gimp. Acted as though he was not afraid.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 4, 1951    MURRAY, Arthur    Left hander. Must be 6'. Can throw smoothly. Only fair speed, with exceptional good control of his fast ball. Was nervous, - shook like a leaf driven in the wind. His curve ball is so so, but might become better. He is beginning to learn a change of speed on his curve and I believe he will get it. Change-up on his fast ball is very difficult for him. He doesn't have enough ability and experience to go beyond C or D League next year.    Because of the pressure on us in this camp, it might be well for Anderton, Murray and Beran to be sent back immediately. We just don't have the men or the time to give thorough work to our many pitchers.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 2, 1951    NECCIAI, Ronald    6'5", years of age, right hander with stuff. A great fast ball, both overhand and sidearm, a great curve ball from all angles. He can throw one out of every three or four balls a good change on his fast ball. He also can throw a slow curve ball and with fairly good control, but not good enough. This boy, also like Wolfe and others, is out of the major league because, first, he doesn't have usable pitches, i.e., he doesn't have control. Ronny has four distinct pitches and each of them from practically any angle of delivery. He is without a doubt a great prospect. No further away from helping the Pittsburgh Club than simply control. With no reservation whatever I say that this boy can become a unhittable pitcher.    I originally thought this boy was an ignoramus. It is not so. He is not only intelligent, but he is a very nice chap. He is full of ideas and might become someday a tricky, clever, shrewdly clever, artistic pitcher. He is going to require a lot of work and it is entirely possible that he should pitch one year no higher than Class B. Most certainly he has major league ability.    Work him out again in twenty days.    October 6, 1951    In workout today, this boy can throw his fast ball both overhand and side arm with fine control, - except when he presses, then the ball goes everywhere. It is my judgment that the boy presses anytime he pitches in a game. He would do the same thing in a workout if you did not tell him not to press and you have to tell him on practically every pitch. He has more speed on his fast ball when he throws it with ordinary delivery and no pressing than most major league pitchers throwing with their best speed.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 26, 1951    NECCIAI, Ronald    A big tall Pittsburgh boy who will become very  aggressive as time goes on. Has all four pitches. A big hand,  fine rhythm in delivery and there is no reason below his neck for   him not having control. His side arm fast ball is a great pitch,  but a dangerous pitch. If this boy has poise under fire, you cannot  tell how fast or how far he could go.    Yesterday, he pitched a couple of innings with out walking  a man and them, about his third innings or so, walking a man got two  balls on the next man and he did the "Brancas heave" four times, -  immediately followed by fast pitching.    Pitching attitude toward work is really wonderful.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: September 18, 1951    PETTIT, Paul    I have worked the famous Pettit twice. Occasionally he will show a fair fast ball but only when he presses, and when he presses his control is not too good. He has a fair curve, - a downer, not great but usable. He has no change up on anything that he can throw.     He has had record for two years or more or less disability - something always wrong with him. Has complained more or less constantly during that period of an ailing arm. He is green, unfinished, and it seems to me that he lacks any great desire to be accomplished in any direction. We have at least fifteen pitchers, non of who is even as old as Pettit, who are better prospects. He is an embryonic neurotic, and if he cannot play in either position, then I would question his being a prospect even for the market.     JANSCE, John F.     Young, right hand pitcher. Lives up near Butler. Pitched for Deland, Florida this year and won 25 games. This boy was in our Deland camp and was released. The boys did not agree enough about signing him up. He has a fair fast ball, fair curve, and throws a slow curve. Nothing exceptional on any of these pitches and shows me nothing that would indicate that he could ever go major league. His control might enable him to do well in the smaller leagues. He might reach the A's. Surely this pitcher is better than he showed me, otherwise I cannon see how he could make the record at Deland that he did make.     GROAT, Richard    This boy will graduate from Duke this coming June. He is a fair runner, very good arm, and good batting form. The best thing about Groat is his disposition, - his desire to play and to win. He has usually good coordination and could play shortstop on the Pittsburgh club much better than anyone we now have. It would not ever be necessary to send him to any minor league club.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: REPORT ON GEARGE WILLIAM PAUL PETTIT BY BRANCH RICKEY - SEPTEMBER 21, 1951    My original impression of this boy placed him in the "self sufficient" class. He showed slow reactions, both mentally and physically, I thought. Later and during the summer from conversations and reports, I believed him to be embryonic neurotic, due, I believed, to a satisfying financial status and a fear that he might hurt his arm if he threw hard. Managers and scouts and myself began to work on this boy, in an effort to have him understand that he had to go to work.    Following another dreary season, he reported to Pittsburgh at the close of the South Atlantic League season, and I have worked with him three times, the last two at his request. Everyone notes a change of attitude; he is seeking help. Yesterday when I worked him out, at the finish he said, "I thank you, Mr. Rickey, very much." That was a new day.    Undoubtedly, this boy originally had a fast ball. We have fifteen young pitchers with more speed than Pettit - I have counted them up - men I have personally worked with during this present year. He doesn't have a great curve; in fact, it is a very poor curve. His aptitude is just above average, but, as indicated, his willingness right now is great.    Pettit is a big boy, still very young and surely as physically sound as any youngster can be. It is my judgment that he is still subject to silly response, to trivial ailments or injuries. It may be that with him a bruise or abrasion is at once tragic. Most certainly, he is a better prospect now than he has been at any previous time. That is not saying very much. We still owe him $40,000 in eight annual payments of $5,000 each and he is working under an original contract, expiring at the close of 1952 at a salary of $6,000. The general charge against him is that he will not throw hard. He is saturated with fear a complex. That, I say, is the impression of everybody who has anything to do with him. It may have been a fully correct impression but I believe we are in front of a change, as I have stated above.    At the present time, he is not worth holding on our roster. We have Major League waivers on his contract. He could be placed at Hollywood, subject to draft at $10,000. Under all the circumstances, I think we have to hold him another year, although he presses our player limit, most unfortunately.    I have given him a new rotation on his fast ball and he has acquired, since coming to Pittsburgh this fall, a new change-up speed curve ball, and he has control of it. I see no reason for taking him to Florida to the fall school but he must have personal attention in spring training.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 6, 1951    GORDON, Robert    Canadian boy from around Hamilton. Very young, will be eighteen in about two weeks. He will weigh 200 pounds, about 6'1". Throws his regular fast ball about three-quarters, and it spins very slowly, is a heavy ball. he calls it the ball that does something. Can throw the fast ball overhand with good spin, - direct backward rotation, but he says it doesn't do anything. I asked him where he found that cut and he said that is what he thought about it. He has never pitched any professional ball at anytime, anywhere, except in a semi-pro game in the county, -up in Ontario. Throws curve ball semi-three quarters. Nor worth much. Also throws overhand curve ball pretty good, at least better than the other one. Can learn to throw change of speed off his fast ball and should be paired with someone working on the two changes. He is a Class D or C pitcher all over. Very green but very willing and I would say a genuinely fine boy. You cannot tell what he might become, but he is most certainly not a quicky. The boy might amount to quite a bit, depending upon his control. He will certainly learn pretty fast whether he has too much aptitude or not, simply because he will try so hard. He will work hours and he will follow instructions. There is hope for him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: September 18, 1951    PETTIT, Paul    I have worked the famous Pettit twice. Occasionally he will show a fair fast ball but only when he presses, and when he presses his control is not too good. He has a fair curve, - a downer, not great, but usable. He has no change up on anything that he can throw.    He has had record for two years or more or less disability, - something always wrong with him. Has complained more or less constantly during that period of an ailing arm. He is green, unfinished, and it seems to me that he lacks any great desire to be accomplished in any direction. We have a least fifteen pitchers, none of whom is even as old as Pettit, who are better prospects. He is an embryonic neurotic, and if he cannot play in either position, then I would question his being a prospect even for the market.    JANSCE, John F.    Young, right hand pitcher. Lives up near Butler. Pitched for Deland, Florida camp this year and won 25 games. This boy was in our Deland camp and was released. The boys did not agree enough about signing him up. He has a fair fast ball, fair curve, and throws a slow curve. Nothing exceptional on any of these pitches and showed me nothing that would indicate that he could ever go major league. His control might enable him to do well in the smaller leagues. He might reach the A's. Surely this pitcher is better than he showed me, otherwise I cannot see how he could make the record at Deland that he did make.    GROAT, Richard    This boy will graduate from Duke this coming June. He is a fair runner, very good arm, and good batting form. The best thing about Groat is his disposition, - his desire to play and to win. He has unusually good coordination and could play shortstop on the Pittsburgh club much better than anyone we now have. It would not ever be necessary to send him to any minor league club.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 10, 1951    SINNER, Wallace  139 pound right-hander, about 5'9". At Mayfield last year. Pretty good fast ball and pretty good curve and a very good change of pace curve. Both curves are thrown with the forefinger knuckled. He throws a change of speed on this fast ball, which he calls a "palm" ball, and it really is. The boy has assortment, - plenty of it and they are all good pitches, but he has usable control of nothing. His problem is one of control.    This boy doesn't have big hands and the fingers are the fingers of a small man. I do not mean to say that they are abnormally short,- they are not, but he bites this fingers nevertheless so vigorously that the fingers look short, and as I have stated above, the hand is not big at all. This could have something to do with his control, but I doubt it.    He has just completed [h]is first year in professional baseball. I do not have his record at hand, but I judge it is one of showing a very definite lack of control.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: September 8, 1951    SHEETS, Gene    University of Oklahoma player, which team won the National Intercollegiate Championship. He plays first base, third base, and outfield. About 6' tall, weighs 190 pounds, 20 years of age.    Has no pep at all. Apparently it doesn't make much difference to him whether school keeps or not. Quick in actions, and good body control. Batting form is good and should have plenty of power, but at that, nothing like Mel Heiser. An ordinary runner, arm good enough to play anywhere. Not great, but good enough. We must not be influenced by the "competitive urge" in any bidding race for his contract. A fine looking boy and no doubt a fine looking athlete. He could be better than he showed this morning.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: June 25, 1951  New Orleans Club against Nashville in two games June 21st and June 22nd.    SMITH - Left Field    He can run, and he can throw, and he knows how to throw. He keeps the ball down. Relay man can always handle it if he wants to. A right handed curve ball bothers this chap, but it ought not and possibly will not bother him for very long. He will learn to hit it. Smith is ambitious. I will be surprised if he is not in the major leagues. Needs experience, and in particular confidence at the plate against all kinds of pitches. He could show a little more life going out to his position and coming in from it, but he never loafs on plays either defensively or offensively. Sloping shoulders, well set-up, - should go to town.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: September 8, 1951    JACK SMITH - Catcher  A University of Oregon boy, 20 years of age, 185 pounds, 5'9".    This boy knows how to throw. His arm is good enough for a major league catcher. He has no wind-up. He has natural power at the plate, his stride is alright, and his batting form in general is good. I know of no reason why he should not become a good hitter. He can run, - at least he could outrun all the rest of the fellows on the field today, including Dick Groat, Gene Sheets, Mel Heiser and others. He looked overweight - 10 pounds or more, - admitted six. I would like to sign him. Indeed I would like to have him with the Florida camp group. He needs to learn to throw every ball with correct rotation, with rotation directly back toward him. He should have hours of it, and somebody constantly reminding him. He literally throws from all angles.    I understand he leaves us to go to Cleveland. I must talk to him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: REPORT OF MR. BRANCH RICKEY ON NEW ORLEANS CLUB AS OBSERVED IN ONE GAME AT MEMPHIS ON MAY 29, 1951.    THOMAS    This chap either cannot throw or does not know how, or both. He simply throws for distance and apparently does not have the arm for it, and in this game he showed aboriginal stupidity. His playing of the fly ball, also in his timing of getting to the ground ball, also in his playing and retrieving of a rebound from the fence.    Surely he can hit, - and with power. His batting form is superb. I do not believe any criticism can be made of his poise, or his stride, or his stance, or sweep of the bat. He should hit any kind of a pitch and for almost any distance. His running would not keep him out of the big leagues. His power will carry him a long ways. In fielding he times both fly balls and ground balls. Whether or not he can overcome the bad points in fielding, particularly his arm, I do not know. He should be talked to in detail about his weaknesses.    I met him outside my office door and talked to him this last winter for a minute or two. It is my judgment that he has very little of what is known as common sense.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: June 25, 1951    New Orleans Club against Nashville in two games June 21st and June 22nd.    THOMAS - Outfielder    He can DO EVERYTHING. Perfect form at the plate, and a lot of power. Should be able to hit any kind of pitching. Both Joe Brown and Rip Sewell tell me he is a good fellow on the club, - a team player, wants to win. Runs in and out from his position all the time, and his interest is just not put on. I think he really means it. I have never seen him throw the ball low enough to any base or the home plate. He is an "Andy Over" thrower, yet his arm is strong. If he would throw the ball down, he might then be accurate with it. Sewell says he is accurate, but he has never shown accuracy to me. He is a distance thrower. Can run good enough, and he never loafs. I like his potentialities.     He, too, is not daring. He assumes, for example, that the outfielder is going to get the ball, and he doesn't overrun the base as far as he should. There are a lot of things he doesn't know. He could stand a lot of correct coaching; illustration: When running off third base with a runner on first, - every time the pitcher threw to first, he started back to third. He should, with great daring, start for home. If a wild throw is made to first, or missed, he could easily score, but he is back on the bag. In other words, he moves exactly in the wrong direction on this play. He shifts very short distances on the different batters. This may be due first to lack of knowledge of hitters, or, second, it can be that the opposing team, in the few games that I have observed, all hit to the same spot.    "Whom the Lord loveth, he chasteneth.", and great players whom management would like to see in Pittsburgh are to be found fault with if they are not as good as they should be.     And, finally, one more possible criticism. With the score nothing to nothing, and a runner in scoring distance, he fails to take a chance. On a short fly ball that he could have caught, I am sure, if he had made a dive, he failed to do so. He, too, may not have championship adventure in his soul. I do not know about it.    If this team had a couple of ace pitchers, they could make a big stir in the Southern League race, and easily go into the play-offs, and that is my fault. I want everybody to do their best to help me find these pitchers.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 1, 1951    TRUITT, Billy    Tall, seventeen year old right hander from Salisbury, Maryland. He has a good fast ball and what I would call a strong curve. This boy has a big hand and he almost completely envelops his curve ball. He has never pitched professionally and he too is worthy of a lot of attention.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 26, 1951    TRUITT, Billy Benjamin    I sware I don't know what to think about that guy. I know that he has stuff, and he has size and everybody says he is a fine boy. The housekeeper at Deland told me that he was the finest boy in camp. I don't know what she said it, but she did. Ha s fine fast bal. Good enough. I am sorry that I do not know more about him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 1, 1951    WAUGH, James    He has a good fast ball and a good curve. Leave both alone. He is an iceberg. Unemotional, calculating well poised, and he has acquired a change of speed pitch on his fast ball. The rotation of it is bad, but the velocity is good. He throws the pitch with fine delivery, giving the impression that he is throwing a real great fast ball. He also is throwing a slow curve but he must work on this for control. It is not a bad pitch. His delivery on everything is the same and that is something.     This boy is a fine prospect, and if he acquires a better change-up on his fast ball, it might be that he could pitch for Pittsburgh at an early date.     He must be given considerable coaching in holding men on base and he also must be kept continuously on the pitchers fielding practice.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: September 18, 1951    PETTIT, Paul  I have worked the famous Pettit twice. Occasionally he  will show a fair fast ball but only when he presses, and when he  presses his control is not too good. He has a fair curve, - a  downer, not great, but usable. He has no change up on anything  that he can throw.    He has had a record for two years or more or less disability,   - something always wrong with him. Has complained more or less  constantly during that period of an ailing arm. He is green,  unfinished, and it seems to me that he lacks any great desire to be  accomplished in any direction. We have at least fifteen pitchers,   none of whom is even as old as Pettit, who are better prospects.  He is an embryonic neurotic, and if he cannot play either   position, then I would question his being a prospect even for the  market.    JANSCE, John F.  Young, right hand pitcher. Lives up near Butler. Pitched  or Deland, Florida this year and won 25 games. This boy was in our  Deland camp and was released. The boys did not agree enough about  signing him up. He has a fair fast ball, fair curve, and throws  a slow curve. Nothing exceptional on any of these pitches and showed  me nothing that would indicate that he could ever go major league.  His control might enable him to do well in the smaller leagues. He  might reach the A???????s. Surely this pitcher is better than he showed  me, otherwise I cannot see how he could make the record at Deland  that he did make.    GROAT, Richard  This boy will graduate from Duke this coming June. He is  a fair runner, very good arm, and good batting form. The best thing  about Groat is his disposition, - his desire to play and to win.   He has unusually good coordination and could play shortstop on the   Pittsburgh club much better than anyone we now have. It would not  ever be necessary to send him to any minor league club.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 26, 1951    WAUGH, Jim    Delivery great. Curve ball satisfactory, also slow curve ball. Change-up on his fast ball has just the right velocity. Rotation is not quire perfect. He understands that and will work on it. Rapidity of rotation on the change-up fast ball will, in my judgment, increase when he perfects the rotation, - when it spins directly back toward him. Control not good, but might be good enough to go to major leagues within a year. Holds men on very good. Should do more throwing to first base and holding runners on. Must be careful in turning his head to look at base runners and to come back with a full look at the batsman and pause before he pitches home.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: Report of Mr. Branch Rickey on New Orleans Club as observed in one Game at Memphis on May 29, 1951    WENTZEL  An older boy who is probably a good man in the Southern League, but not a prospect for higher classification.     No other players appeared in the game on this date.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: June 25, 1951    New Orleans Club against Nashville in two games June 21st and June 22nd.    WENTZEL - Outfielder    An older fellow, big, strong. This fellow also gives you his  very best. Not young. Sewell says he is a good man to have around, - a  good team man.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: September 8, 1951    RUDY WILLIAMS - Pitcher    He will be 20 years of age this coming December, but he has just finished high school. This boy is about 6'2" tall, weighs about 180 pounds, has as long a nose as you would see on any human. This boy can throw the ball hard enough. The angle of delivery varies. At somewhere around the three-quarter mark, he throws a live ball. It is not straight. His curve has good velocity, not much break. It might be a good pitch, and most certainly at the present time it should not be interefered with. He may not be smart enough in his books, but he is smart enough in baseball conversation. He has gimp. He wants to play. He wants to hit. He wants to shag. He wants to be busy. I like everything about him.    His change-up on the fast ball is a recent thing with him. He has no control of it, and the speed is not slow enough.    His change-up on the curve is not good, but I believe that he can learn fairly fast.    I gave him a thumb change of pace curve. He got perfect rotation immediately, and in my judgment he can become a very fine pitcher. If he can be signed, he should be signed at once. I would like to have him in Florida. I am sure I could save him one year in his minor league development.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; B-K
Transcription: October 8, 1951    WILLIS, Alan    Did not show me a particularly fast ball. Has a very ordinary curve. Boy has no change-up, but he will get a change-up on his fast ball. I want to discuss him in our meeting and I want to see him pitch one more time. Unimpressive. Jim Waugh and he should be paired. Both are working on the change-up on the fast ball.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: September 18, 1951    WOLFE, Edward    A big, tall right hander, 22 years of age, living in California. His record at Bartlesville in 1950 was very good and his record this year at Charleston was fairly good. He has a fast ball and he has a high velocity curve, - a very good curve. His change of speed on his fast ball is not good because, first, he doesn't control it, and second, it would not be good if he had good control of it. For one thing, it has too much velocity.    His change up on his curve ball is not good enough and his control of that pitch is not good. He needs to learn a change up pitch on both the fast and curve balls.    This fellow is a definite prospect. Needs a lot of attention and must have it at the school in Florida this October.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: REPORT ON EDWARD ANTHONY WOLFE BY BRANCH RICKEY - SEPTEMBER 21, 1951    Ed Wolfe is a big, tall right-hander with a finished Major League fast ball. It is a dandy.
