This boy is twenty-two years of age and it would seem that he cannot help being one of our great future pitchers.     He has two curve balls, a fast one and a slow one. He has absolutely no control of either of these two pitches. He needs very much the October school in Florida. He needs to acquire two additional pitches and he can get them, I am sure of that. He needs the complete course that will be offered in pitcher fielding practice and he needs to have thorough attention in bunting and batting.    REPORT ON HARRY FISHER BY BRANCH RICKEY - SEPTEMBER 21, 1951    He is a Canadian right hand pitcher who has absolutely perfect batting form and he has exceptional power with it. It is just too bad if his batting prowess cannot be made of great use to our Pittsburgh team.    As a pitcher, he has enough speed. He has two curve balls and can't get either one over the plate when he presses. That is to say that when his curve ball is good enough, when it breaks, he has no control over it. When he throws the curve without enough break and with lower velocity, he can get it over, but without velocity and break, it is no good. His slow curve is never over. In other words, the boy has no curve, either fast or slow that is usable and his change-up on the fast ball is worthless. He simply has one pitch, nothing else. It is going to be a job to make a pitcher out of him; it might be done but the same amount of attention and time would undoubtedly make an acceptable catcher out of him.    He has agreed to go to Florida for the thirty days in October and he will have a lot of attention. I stick my neck out to say in spite of his own protests and adverse opinions most everywhere, this boy will become a Major League catcher and will be able to be retained as a catcher on the Pittsburgh Club in 1952.    Branch Rickey    BR/emm

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: October 2, 1951    Wolfe, Ed    Darling fast ball. Curve is alright. He must have a change of speed on his fast ball and he is working on it very hard. He is a willing worker and he will get this change of speed. His distance from the major league is exactly the distance from control. He needs better control on every pitch. Whenever his pitches are usable, he will wear a Pittsburgh uniform.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: October 26, 1951    WOLFE, Ed    This boy has perhaps the most perfect change-up on a fast ball of anyone in the Pittsburgh organization. May be not the best control of it, but the most perfect mechanical effect. It spins with the right direction and its velocity is ideal. If he can control this pitch and doesn't have a curve at all, I think he could go quite a way.    He has other stuff. Definitely a man to be figured upon.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: REPORT ON EDWARD ANTHONY WOLFE BY BRANCH RICKEY - SEPTEMBER 21, 1951    Ed Wolfe is a big, tall right-hander with a finished Major League fast ball. It is a dandy. This boy is twenty-two years of age and it would seem that he cannot help being one of our great future pitchers.    He has two curve balls, a fast one and a slow one. He has absolutely no control of either of these two pitches. He needs very much the October school in Florida. He needs to acquire two additional pitches and he can get them, I am sure of that. He needs the complete course that will be offered in pitcher fielding practice and he needs to have thorough attention in bunting and batting.    REPORT OF HARRY FISHER BY BRANCH RICKEY - SEPTEMBER 21, 1951    He is a Canadian right hand pitcher who has absolutely perfect batting form and he has exceptional power with it. It is just too bad if his batting prowess cannot be made of great use to our Pittsburgh team.    As a pitcher, he has enough speed. He has two curve balls and can't get either one over the plate when he presses. That is to say that when his curve ball is good enough, when it breaks, he has no control over it. When he throws the curve without enough break and with lower velocity, he can get it over, but without velocity and break, it is no good. His slow curve is never over. In other words, the boy has no curve, either fast or slow that is usable and his change-up on the fast ball is worthless. He simply has one pitch, and nothing else. It is going to be a job to make a pitcher out of him; it might be done but the same amount of attention and time would undoubtedly make an acceptable catcher out of him.    He has agreed to go to Florida for the thirty days in October and he will have a lot of attention. I stick my neck out to say in spite of his own protests and adverse opinions most everywhere, this boy will become a Major League catcher and will be able to be retained as a catcher on the Pittsburgh Club in 1952.    Branch Rickey  BR/emm

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: October 11, 1951    HALL, BILL    About 5' 11", lefthand hitting catcher. I would guess him to be twenty-two or twenty-three years of age. The boy can throw, - he has a good arm.   If he can hit he might go to a pretty good classification next year. Knows more about blocking bad pitches than these other youngsters.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: Report of Mr. Branch Rickey on New Orleans Club as observed in one Game at Memphis on May 29, 1951    WOPINEK    He disappointed me very much tonight at the plate. His batting stance, in my opinion, is very bad, and he absolutely should not be changed until he proves very definitely to be a bad hitter, and further until he seeks help. Otherwise a fair ball player.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 25, 1951    New Orleans Club against Nashville in two games June 21st and June 22nd.  WOPINEK - Shortstop    His capacity and ability just about meet. He gives you all he's got in every way and all the time. Has surprising power at times, but in these two games it seemed to me that the right hander's curve ball bothered him very much. I like his interest and his effort. We will watch him. Fair runner.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: October 1, 1951    YOCHIM, Lenny    Young left-hander with three or four years of experience. He has a fast ball that rotates and goes in the direction of a fast curve. This probably is his very best pitch, and he should keep it and not be disturbed about it. His curve ball is so so, - good enough for occasional use. He learns pitches pretty rapidly. Throws a slow curve ball. He must have an additional pitch, preferably a change of pace curve ball. If he had an Erskine change-up on his fast ball, or one like young Bill Bell has, it would help him a lot. This boy is a pretty good athlete, and if he gets another usable pitch during this school period at Deland, he might help our club next year (1953).

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: October 10, 1951    Yochim, Lenny    In the workout, Yochim, right now, has almost perfect control of his change of pace curve ball. In both his appearances in the games in the past week, he has been nervous. If this boy would pitch in a game exactly as he pitches in his workout with me, his change up curve would be effective. He is ready for a good nine inning test against the best batters in this camp, and should be given a young catcher who will not help him too much. In other words, put him on his own.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: September 18, 1951    HALL, Dick    Swarthmore College boy to graduate in June 1951. 6'5" and a very fast runner and a very fine arm and with good power at the plate. More a line drive hitter than a fly ball hitter. Timid, lacks confidence, doesn't think well of himself at all. A very exaggerated modesty, and a neophyte would judge him to be a pussy cat, a mollycoddle, pin cushion, a softy. An ordinary observer would call him effeminate. He is a very fine student and a very sincere person. There is no hypocrisy or make believe about him. He has had very little baseball experience and could become a very great in the major leagues. Very largely, his experience is in the field of pitching, but I certainly do not recommend him as a pitcher. He might be an infielder, even a shortstop, certainly he could be a third baseman. He has a marvelous arm from the outfield, and if he could become a good fielder he could go all the way as an outfielder right now. Right hand hitter, - right hand thrower. A great prospect.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: October 4, 1951    HAMAKER, Wayne    6' 1", 185 pound right hander. Nice boy.   Positive fellow. Has a mind of his own. Could have a lot of pitching sense. Fast ball good enough. Throws both overhand and sidearm.    Curve ball just fair, but has good velocity. He claims to throw and does throw a curve ball two different ways. One in regular form, and the other with his thumb behind the ball, and, strange to say, the second pitch, the thumb curve, has even more velocity than the other one.    His fast ball and curve balls should be left alone. This fellow has a chance. He should be kept around awhile. Not like Anderton, or Beran, who for artistic and economic reasons should be permitted to return home immediately.    This chap needs a change of speed on his fast and curve balls, and should be assigned for regular work on these two pitches. He should not be pitched in games for sometime, and we must watch his progress closely.   He must have attention.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: October 11, 1951    HANSEN    A minor league ball player at best. Hitting, running, throwing, size, action, - everything, - simply minor league. This impression he gives me in the first half dozen games he has played here in camp.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: October 11, 1951    HAVERTY  Pretty good ball player, better ball player than he would lead you to believe when you first see him. Fair runner, a very good arm. Good sized boy, and he might drone himself into a pretty good job in baseball someday, - he might. I would vote him not higher than Class B next year.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: Inter-club Communication....  To: Mr. Branch Rickey At: Pittsburgh Date: Oct. 14, 1952.    From: Marty Purtell Written from: Cleveland O. Copies to:    (COVER ONLY ONE SUBJECT ON ONE MEMORANDUM)    Dear Mr. Rickey:   Am enclosing a copy of the letter I sent Mr. Frick also his answer. This is in regard to Del Bastock, although I did not mention any name in my letter.     Best regards,   Marty.   Marty Purtell.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: Baseball    Ford C. Frick  Commissioner  Charles M. Segar  Secretary-Treasurer    RCA Building, West  30 Rockefeller Plaza  New York 20, N.Y.  [handwriting: HSM?? 10/16]    June 16, 1952    Mr. Marty Purtell  3981 W. 162nd Street  Clevland 11, Ohio    Dear Mr. Purtell:    This will acknowledge your letter of June 13th to the Commissioner in which you asked information concerning a High School student.    The Commissioner's Office would hold that, under the circumstances you describe, that your club would be negotiating with the High School student and it would be a violation of the High School Rule.    Very truly yours,    [Signature]  Charles Segar      CS/ms

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: Copy   the Pirates  Pittsburgh Base Ball Club  Minor League System  Cleveland 11, Ohio.  June 13, 1952  Mr. Ford C. Frick  New York 20, N.Y.    Dear Mr. Frick:  Would it be against the High School Rules to get a High School student a job at our ball park in Pittsburgh? This boy has not graduated and it is to be understood the student is a ball player.  Yours respectfully,  Marty Purtell  Scout, Pittsburgh Pirates  3981 W. 162nd St. Cleveland 11, Ohio

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: March 31, 1952  DeLand, Fla.    BEANE, PETER    His mother calls him Pete, - his father calls him Pinky. He lives close to Charlotte, N.C. A right hander, 5'11" tall, and will weight about 175 lbs. Nice boy, pleasant chap, a pretty good fast ball and a fair curve, and I would say good aptitude. He has a slow curve which tips off badly. He is working on a change of speed off his fast ball. It has too much velocity and it will be a tough pitch for him to get. He needs a lot of work on it.    He requires a different pitch off his slow curve. There is no question about it.    His delivery is good. It repeats. He has a habit of pitching off the rubber, which, in the course of time, can be changed.    I would not give him $20,000 or anything like it. I am not interested at that figure, and I would not give him any substantial bonus until I see him further. He is scheduled to work with me again tomorrow.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 28, 1952    BECKER  Certainly cannot throw a lick. Very ordinary runner and did not look to me that he ever made a hit or ever would. You can give him his unconditional release at anytime.    B.R    Bristol-Pulaski  June 27, 1952

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: Beene, Charles: A 6'3", 18 year old right hand pitcher whom we signed up  during the camp in San Bernardino. Fred Haney told me that he might make the Hollywood  club this very year. We paid him a bonus of $12,000 payable over a period of three  years. He certainly belongs in the class with Waugh, Line, Necciai, Jack Brown,  Bill Bell, Ken Barbao.    Never has any of us, from the writer on down or up, taken a more active  or perhaps more effective interest in the production of so-called raw material than  each and every one of us has done during the past twelve months. I have not at all  covered all the prospects, however these with, perhaps, the addition of a half-dozen  others, represent the cream of the crop. If we knew that the Government were to stay  out of our picture, the Pittsburgh club would open the season with not less than ten  new men, every one of whom has had little or no previous professional experience.    Cordially yours,    Branch Rickey  Executive Vice President and  General Manager    BR;b    April 14, 1952  P.S. Since dictating the above, I have moved seven boys to the Pittsburgh club;  and, within the next day or so, first baseman Bertirome with doubtless be  moved from Charleston to Pittsburgh. These additions will give Pittsburgh  a roster of 35 players and this means that 10 players must be removed  from the active list of the Pittsburgh club on or before May 15, 1952.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: San Bernardino, Cal.  February 23, 1952  Beene  6'2", 170#, right hander, lives somewhere near San Bernardino. His first name, I believe, is Charlie. Past 18, -only fair fast ball, not a great fast ball, but his other stuff makes his fast ball seem live.    He has two curves, fast and slow, - both are good, - very good. He also reported to me with a change up on his fast ball, rotation was bad. He followed a suggestion or two and corrected the rotation, and he now has a very good spinner on his change-up fast ball. The boy is worth while. I would like to have him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: March 21, 1952    Don Beitter: A huge young man from Seton Hall. He has always player third base, but immediately we came to believe that his position is second base. Strong arm, left hand hitter with exceptional power, - not a great runner. It was my belief at the end of the first two weeks "work", that Beitter was the quickest man to come to Pittsburgh. Indeed, we figured on him for second base this very season. The boy has to return to Seton Hall for his school work otherwise he was subject to quick army selection. He will be available May 28th for the balance of the baseball season.  He might come directly to Pittsburgh, but it is more likely that he will now be assigned to either New Orleans or Charleston.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: July 1, 1952    BEITTER, Don  A big, good natured third baseman who has all the disposition of a champion. A very strong arm and the kind that would make him an ideal second baseman. He has great power with the bat but in the comparatively few times I have seen him, he shows no power strokes to right field. A left hand hitter, - he looks very weak against left hand pitching.   Any fault, however, of this sort he should and in my judgment he will overcome. Only fair runner, if anything below average, but he makes the most of it. I think he is a smart chap, and a very intelligent competitor. Only exceptional hitting ability will carry him to the big leagues. He may have it.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: March 21, 1952     Bill Bell: Very tall, 200 pounder. This pitcher is a mystery, can throw very hard, has plenty of assortment. Does not have control, but I believe he will get it before he is twenty, and that will be October 24, 1953. He is one of the great pitching "futures" on the Pittsburgh club.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 28, 1952    Allen, Bob    He has a knuckle curve, fair fast ball and that's Allen. George DeTore will work him in relief in losing games, hoping for improvement. If player limit becomes very difficult, then we can consider unconditional release for Allen.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: March 21, 1952    Lean Beran: A Kansas wheat farmer's son. One of several children. Not big, but big enough. Right hander with speed and agility. Played last year with Brunswick. Was sick with flu before reporting, and them got an arm ailment in camp. Nothing additional to report, but this player can be advanced to higher classification for 1952.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: March 29, 1952    BROCATO, DON  A 6'4" boy, 18 years old, from Gilbert, La., who doesn't graduate from high school until June of 1953.  Right hander, tremendous hand, free delivery, good speed, and when he throws a change of pace on his fast ball, it is just about as fast as his fats ball. Fairly good control. Curve ball not bad and he will learn a slow curve ball very rapidly. There are a lot of good things about this boy including his position on the mound, his stuff, and delivery. I would like to have his.  If someone would cultivate him and play up to him after the first of January it would be good. If the high school rule remains as it is now, then he should be signed on the first of January, 1953 and this should be done.     cc - Harold Roettger  George Sisler

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: July 1, 1952    BROOKEY  Brookey, at best, should be counted upon as the second string catcher at New Orleans. He cannot run. His arm is good enough, and his receiving is acceptable. Fair hitter, but terrible double play man.    Let him go to the draft at New Orleans.    B.R

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 28, 1952    BROWN    Left hand hitter, below average runner, fair arm, has power at the plate. Class A player, nothing more, - hardly that.    B.R    Cherleston-Columbus

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: March 21, 1952    Jack Brown: Perhaps as great a prospect as the Pittsburgh organization has anywhere. Not too big, - only 6', 180 pounds, but he has everything in the world to make a great pitcher. He is inexperienced and "nervous". Good fielding ab[ility] ability and holds men on bases beautifully, - has the making of a very great pitcher.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 16, 1952    BROWN, Otis    Not worth a nickel. Cannot throw, - should bound.  Two generations removed from the original chimpanzee. 175#.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: July 1, 1952    CARLSEN, Don  When I saw him a few days ago, he was on option to New Orleans from Pittsburgh. Branch, Jr. and Bill Meyer believe the player to have an ailing arm. Player insists otherwise. His performance supported Branch's views. He had nothing. I do not believe he can win at New Orleans or anywhere else right now. If player doesn't show great improvement before the end of the present season, then he should be placed on the New Orleans reserve list for the draft.    B.R

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 9, 1952    CARROLL, John    There is another fellow from Duke University name John Carroll. Right hand hitter, plays outfield. No power, no running speed, - not interested.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 16, 1952    CAYAVCE, Willard Thomas    Has a strong arm. Good enough to play anywhere. Shows agility. Believe he would come to have good body control. A very fine arm.    Looks like a good runner.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 28, 1952    CHRISLEY  Very average runner, - showed nothing at the plate whatever and I will certainly miss my if he will ever go into the money.    B.R    Bristol-Pulaski  June 27, 1952

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: Gair Allie: This is the well-built all around athlete from Wake Forrest. Right handed all the way. 6'1" tall, 185 pounds, 20 years of age, and lives in North Carolina. This boy is the sole support of his mother and three brothers and sisters and his mother believes that the Draft Board will defer him. Gair is a shortstop. He is a bit nervous, - perhaps stage fright, but he has sense, and his orientation is simply a matter of a season in the minors. He is bound to come.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 9, 1952    CLAPP, GORDON:    Right hand hitting outfielder from Duke University. Is only a sophomore. Very average runner, - if that. He knows how to throw from the outfield, - keeps the ball down, and throws without stepping. Of the eight boys I watched at the plate this morning, I would call him the best prospective hitter of the group, both for average and distance, unless, indeed, I were to make an exception of Monahan. The boy has execellent wrists and in the course of time he would be hard to fool on change-ups. On this point, however, I would give the edge to Stalker. This boy Clapp should [be] followed. He will surely prove to be a fine baseball player at Duke University in the next two years.    If I owned Duke University and also owned the Pittsburgh Baseball Club, I would undertake immediately to make a catche out of Clapp.    BRANCH RICKEY.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: July 7, 1952    Cochrane    18 year old right hander. Not subject to draft. Pretty good control of everything. Doesn't show you too much on the sidelines, but not easy to beat. We will follow him closely.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: March 21, 1952    Don Cochran: A 20-year old right hander last year with Bartlesville. Also one of the smaller boys. Weighs 180 pounds and is only 6???????. He was a very pleasant surprise to all of us in San Bernardino. He pitched effectively. His curve is better than it was at DeLand, and we believe his fast ball is good enough.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 16, 1952    CYPHER, Edward D.    Cannot catch, cannot throw. If he makes a high school team, they will never get into the championship - that's a cinch.  He would have to hit .400 to make any club, and it is an even bet he cannot hit .100.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 16, 1952    DAVIS, Bob     21 year old right hand pitcher from Duke University. Nice boy, well poised. Throws fast ball with ball in the sock, - not great speed, delivery regular and repeats. No reason for him not having control of his fast ball. Very ordinary velocity. Curve ball not great. Change-up on fast ball looks like it should be good and effective. Showed no control of change up on curve ball, and it was not distinctive from the fast curve. Position of ball in hand, generally speaking, entirely satisfactory. Throws fork ball. Best pitch he has if he can control it. Threw five of them, - none of them over, but might acquire this pitch. A very doubtful major league prospect.      BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: Aptil 14, 1952  Brandon Davis: A Duke University graduate, small, - only 6' tall, 165 pounds, but he has some age. He is 23. He is an outfielder and a great one. Hits and throws right handed and he beats the "turkey" in the races. That makes him exceptionally fast. This boy stole some 70 odd bases last year at Bartlesville. He knows how to get the lead and the break as a base runner. He has no confidence in himself. Thinks the other fellow is better than he is. We have got to do a job on him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: February 1952  DON DANGLEIS - A natural, 6' 2" tall, 160 pounds. Right hander. Good fast ball and good curve, and good control of it too. Has a natural slow curve, and he has already pitched it. He uses a three-finger knuckle ball for a change of speed off his fast ball, and he has suprising con-trol of the pitch. Doubtless, he would be a great high school pitcher and he could make good in a fairly good league immediately, unless, indeed, he is subject to stage fright in some form or the other. I would not hes-itate to send him to Waco or Burlington immediately. He is barely 18 and without a doubt has a fine future. He too is intelligent, calm, composed, deliberate, calculating. Worth a bonus. Indeed, worth signing at any-thing you could afford to pay.     ADDITIONAL FOR DANGLEIS - Tall slim fellow. Very young. Fine poise. I like him. No wild pitches. Everything around the plate. Has good stuff. And on the basis of my first look I would judge him a definite prospect. Threw a knuckle ball too, and it was over the plate. I would try to sign him before he gets any advertising.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: April 13, 1952    Bob Del Graco: This Pittsburgh right hander is very young. A well-built 5'10", 175 pounder who is surely a finished center fielder. He can throw, - quick, hard, and accurate, and he is a game guy. Neither the fences beyond him nor the low line drive in front of him gave him any trouble, and he has a poise at the plate. Against a pithcer like Bob Lemon with two strikes on him, he will jockey for you and get the base on balls. I think he is more or less a natural hitter and with enough power. Right now he has a center fielder's job cinched on the Pirate team for the coming season. But like all youngsters, he can go through the cycle of depression. There is no immediate certainty about him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 28, 1952    DEVEAU    Little fellow. Showed nothing in this game in any respect, but I cannot judge him because he did not having much to do. At the plate he looked very bad indeed.      B.R    Bristol-Pulaski  June 27, 1952

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: July 1, 1952    ALLIE, Gair    A very definite major league prospect in every respect. Corking arm, and will have good power. Lacks judgment at the plate, with consequent lack of confidence in himself. I see no reason for Allie not becoming a great hitter. Makes all the plays, - game and unafraid. He has a ready mastery of the shortstop skills, and I can see him some day as a technically perfect shortstop. A good competitor and a fine person. Not draftable at New Orleans for three more years, but should be with the Pittsburgh Club in Spring Training.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 9, 1952    ELLIOTT, Eugene     Colored boy from New Orleans, - shortstop, 20 years of age, about 5'11" tall. He can run. Not a great arm, in fact he throws like a girl at times. His arm has a glorified feminine effort. Quick as a cat, - a flustered quickness. Looks like he might become a very good hitter, but doesn't have any idea where the plate is. Hits at anything he can reach, and, indeed, every pitch he can reach it is his opinion it is a strike.      It will take quite a while for him to become a major league ball player.      He has a colored friend with him, - his teacher or something. They want $6000.00. I would give him $500 only and hope he proves worthy of it. I risk the opinion from only one look that he will never play shortstop on any major league club.      BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 9, 1952    Arnold, Buddy G.    Catcher. Nicely built, 20 year old boy, right hand hitter and a catcher. He has a good arm and is accurate with it. Not a great arm. but good enough. I would like to sign him up provided that no bonus is involved, or, at least, no big bonus. He is from Saltville, Virginia.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 9, 1952    BARKER, Roland    Right hand, 19 year old boy from somewhere in Kentucky. Sent in by one of Rex Bowen's bird-dog's. About 6' 2" tall, and weighs 160 pounds. No fast ball and no curve. Fairly good control. Throws a knuckle ball which doesn't do very much knuckling, but he has remarkable control of it such as it is. If he is a prospect for the major league, he will be one of Charlie Grimm's [hand-written correction: Graham's] examples, namely, a pitcher after he reaches thirty.      BRANCH RICKEY      P.S. He stutters terribly and I cannot get much out of him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: March 21, 1952    PITCHERS    Ken Barbao: Nineteen year old boy, weighting 180 lbs., right-hand six footer. Definite prospect for the Pittsburgh club. Inexperienced and wild. If this fellow has been on the Confederate Army on July 3, 1863, he would have led Pickett's charge up Cemetery Hill -- 40 yards in front of anybody, completely unarmed, but carrying the flag and he would not have heeded the general's order to retreat.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: March 21, 1952    Bartirome, Tony: Hardly big enough and not strong enough. He is greased lightening around the bag at first base. Very young, - left hand hitter and thrower. 5'10" tall and weighs 150 pounds. Lives in Pittsburgh. He is a very great fielder, - exceptional. Doesn't strike out, but purely a punch hitter. On a 154 game basis, he is a better man than Metkovich. It looks like we may lose Dick Hall to the army. If so, it is a question right now whether or not to give Bartirome the chance.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: October 15, 1952    MEMORANDUM    SUBJECT: Del Bastock    TO: Mr. George Sisler  Mr. Branch Rickey, Jr.  Mr Harold Roettger    Del Bastock is a big 6'5" left hand pitcher. He lives in Lorain, Ohio, - 25 miles from Cleveland. He is 18 years of age and graduates from high school this coming January 28th.    This boy has been working out with Cleveland all summer, or approximately all summer, going back and forth from Lorain, Ohio when Cleveland was playing at home. it is generally understood that he worked around the park - on the field, with the ground crew.    It is assumed that he did not pay his transportation to from Lorain and reported regularly for work without being paid some kind of compensation.    Our scout, Marty Purtell, wrote a letter to Commissioner Frick setting out a hypothetical case on all fours with Del Bestock-Cleveland case. Copy of this correspondence is attached.    This commissioner replied that he would regard this employment or identification as barring the club from signing the player. This player is highly desirable.    Yours,    BR/b  [E?]ncl:

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; A-B
Transcription: June 9, 1952    Frank Sononika brought in a pitcher named Powell and also an  outfielder named NORMAN J. KARLIK. Not a great runner and  certainly not a great arm, - in fact, he has an infielder's arm.  No carry to the ball whatever. The best thing he does hit,  and I will bet he hit plenty in high school, and he ought to hit  anywhere, but not with power. If you could sign him to a '53  contract and take him South next winter, I believe I would do it.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 28, 1952    KINNAMON    Let him go to draft at Charleston.    B.R.    Charleston-Columbus

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 28, 1952    LEFEVRE    Right hand hitter and thrower. Running, hitting, and throwing all shy of greatness, but he tries hard. Might become a very good hitter and with sufficient power. Should be left with Charleston for the draft.    B.R    Charleston-Columbus

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 9, 1952    LEWIS, Joe    Right hander from Duke University, 170 pounder, only fair fast ball, fair curve, fair change of pace on his curve. Just learning change-up on fast ball. Should get it. Nothing to rave about. Control not too good. This boy belongs in the class of possibilities, - only that.    BRANCH RICKEY    br/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: July 1, 1952    LONG, Dale    Nice boy, - good looking. Arm good enough, running average. Tremendous power. Has a definite blind spot much larger than most power hitters. Any good fast ball well above the knees and below his eyebrows, pitched inside, will strike him out with great regularity. I would say that the space is 20" high and 10" wide. He simply cannot hit the pitch. He swings through it whether the ball comes from a right hander or left hander, overhand or sidearm. If the pitch has speed and is within the space as above described, Long simply cannot put the bat on the ball.    A .250 to .275 hitter in the Southern League.  Let me go to the draft at New Orleans.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: March 21, 1952    Jacky Maddy: A right hander with a good fast ball and fairly good control. His change-up on both his fast ball and curve is not slow enough. He is working on it. He is a very intelligent young man. Pitched for Modesto in 1951, his first year. He is a college boy and shows it properly. He is now with Hollywood and may stay with that club. This chap happens to be the smallest pitcher in the camp with the exception of Pitcher Salgado. Maddy is only 5'11" and weighs 175 pounds. I think he will go major league.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 16, 1952    SOUCHOCK, Stanley    Has a quick arm, a good arm for a little fellow. Shows brash inexperience. This boy would have to run well, hit surprisingly, to be major league prospect.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 28, 1952    PASSINEAU    Sensible, intelligent boy, fast afoot, fair hitter and only fair arm. This chap has been in doubt about the advisability of continuing in professional baseball, and insofar as a major league career is concerned, he should give up playing the game. He will not make it. He is a good man for Charleston, might even go a bit higher.    B.R.    Charleston-Columbus

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 9, 1952    MALCOLM, Charles B.    6'1", 180 pounds. Will be 18 in January and comes from Huntington, West Virginia. His father is dead and his mother Alice is a secretary for some big company. His older sister is unmarried and works. Younger sister 16.    This boy has a pretty good fast ball. Has an easy rhythmical delivery. Curve ball so so, - not too much on it. He will learn a change up on his fast ball readily. If this boy would go out without a bonus, I would like to sign him and send him to a Class D immediately. He is a good kid and might become quite a pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 16, 1952    McMATH, Robert C    Ordinary runner, - 150# boy. No prospect.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 28, 1952    FILIATRAULT    Very tall youngster, arm looked good enough and he can run. I don't know what he may come to in the years to come as a hitter, but he certainly cannot hit anything now. He certainly looks terrible at the plate. Big enough to hit the ball over any fence, but has no power whatever, and I don't think he will ever have any power.     B.R.    Bristol-Pulaski  June 27, 1952

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 16, 1952    McQUIRE, Walter E.    Cannot imagine his "ever" being in the major leagues as a slugger.  However, he is a fair runner. He can throw like a son-of-a-gun from the outfield.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 9, 1952    MONAHAN, Jim    195#, 22 year old boy, just out of some college. Probably in the army. Scouted by several major league clubs. Probably in the high bonus class.     This boy can run, - well above average. He has power at the plate, - plenty of power, and his form is good. He should become quite a hitter. His arm is just normal, not at all great, and he doesn't know how to throw. He takes a double step and throws the ball high. Both of his faults are correctible.     Definite prospect. I would like to have him, and we should find out what it takes.    Jim is a right hand hitter and right hand thrower.     Branch Rickey     BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: July 1, 1952    Montemayor    A tall, 21 year old Mexican outfielder, - left handed   all the way. He can hit with power and run  exceptionally fast, and has a great arm, and probably from  a major league standpoint not worth a nickel. He knows how  to throw, and he knows how to run and he knows how to hit,   although he stands very far, - perhaps too far away, from the  plate.    He has no adventure in him and no competitive  spirit. I cannot imagine him shooting craps even with his  own loaded dice. He would not take a chance to win even   if every conceivable thing were in his favor. It is a  safe bet that he never made a dive for a low ball in his  entire life, either in front of him or sidewards. If the  game goes long enough, he will lose it for you. Chicken-hearted,  pussy cat, a softy. If you were to push your   finger in his belly the hole would not fill out for several  minutes. I don't think he has a gut anywhere. His very  unusual physical set-up and ability may enable him to play  acceptably in AAA, and somebody, sometime may give him  repeated trials in the majors. If so, I am sure he will  be on many teams. No one will keep him very long.    He is not draftable at New Orleans at all until  the end of another season. Therefore, leave him at New Orleans.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 28, 1952    Moore    Big man, left hand hitter, looked like he had power and looked like he had fair running speed. I do not know anything about him.    B.R.    Bristol-Pulaski  June 27, 1952

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: July 7, 1952    Morton    Tall, thin right hander from Rutgers. Inclined to be argumentative. Has the reputation of being intelligent. Has a fine record. I have never worked him out but from observation at a distance I judge that he is the most effective pitcher at this time on the New Orleans club. He will be considered for Pittsburgh sping training, - without assignment papers.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 16, 1952  NARDULLI , Frank J.    Doesn't look like he will hit.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: March 21, 1952    Ronald Necchiai: A smart kid, - may be too smart, knows everything, wants to run everything, and I wrote about this boy three or four days ago for the record as follows:  "About 6'5" tall, very slim, will not weigh more than 180 pounds. A nervous boy, inexperienced, very young, perhaps more speed than any other of the pitchers. Has a beautiful change of pace on his curve ball. Fairly good control of that pitch. Has a very great future and if we can get all of the "selling platers" off the club, this boy can very well be retained. He might "settle" by late mid-Summer. He will be unhittable."    He will be difficult for the manager in the years to come, but he can pitch. His sidearm fast ball has perhaps greater velocity than any other pitcher can produce. He is only 19, but he has some pitching skills.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 28, 1952    NOVOTNIAK    He has a good cut at the ball. Looks like he has power. He did not give me a chance to judge his speed. Played third base and on the two or three plays he had during the game the arm looked alright.    B.R.    Bristol-Pulaski  June 27, 1952

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: July 7, 1952    O'NEIL    32 years of age. Right hand hitting infielder. Smart chap, but never profound. Cannot hit, cannot run, and cannot throw, but he is tricky and very aggressive. Might manage and I am willing to have his name placed on the manager's list.    He is to be left on the New Orleans roster and placed on the unrestrictive draft list.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: July 1, 1952  PAEPKE    Not at all a great receiver, and not at all a great catcher in any respect. He has a strong arm and he runs very well. Has enough power in hitting but most of it is in the air. If he were a .350 hitter, he could go to the major league, but at .275, he belongs at New Orleans. Let him go to the draft at New Orleans.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 28, 1952    FILLIBEN    No power at the plate and I do note believe he will ever hit.    B.R.    Bristol-Pulaski  June 27, 1952

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 16, 1952    PELLEGRINI, Robert F    Doesn't show much body control. Seems quite awkward. Doesn't look to me that he can cover any ground. Doesn't look like a good runner, although I have never seen him run.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: March 31, 1952  DeLand, Fla.  PELLARIN, TONY  This fellow has more than most new pitcher, - a fair fast ball, - good enough, and he can get control of it. Seems intelligent. About 6' tall and weighs about 180 lbs. He has a fair curve ball and he has a slow curve ball, both useable, but he has a change up on his fast ball which is a "darb". It deflects somewhat like a curve, but it is identical with his fast ball delivery and it really does change-up, - and he has control of it.  Right now, he is a much quicker prospect, - indeed a much more finished pitcher than Beane. I would say that Tony should be signed up. I like him.  This boy should start low depending on his control. It is my judgment that he has enough stuff to start in "B". He is not going to be an easy babe to hit by any minor league ball player.  On the basis of the usual bonus paid to prospective pitchers at this time, this chap is worth some money. I hope the boys can sign him up.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 9, 1952  POWELL, Duane  Seventeen year old boy, about 6'1" or 6'2" tall, weighs 170 pounds, right hander. Good fast ball. His so-called fast curve breaks, - not too much, but does break. His slow curve is so so. Not too much between his fast curve and his slow curve. Never has thrown a change of pace on his fast ball. Learned it fairly quickly. Did not get it too good, but will get it. This kid could easily be a prospect. Should go to Class D under a manager with some patience. If this kid could be signed at no bonus, I wish you would do it.  BRANCH RICKEY  BR/b  P.S. He mumbles when he talks. He has to repeat everything to know what he said.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 16, 1952  RASCHIATORE, Felix A.  If this boy can hit, he should be given further consideration.  This fellow doesn't look like he can get the bat and ball together. Is a head swinger. He would do a lot of striking out, but he is a big, strong boy, and very young, and one cannot afford to dismiss simply because he doesn't hit at the present time.  A couple of years from now he might look very different at the plate. Not a bad runner. I think he should be followed up.  BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: July 1, 1952  RICE, Eugene James (Jim)  Runs above average, arm slightly below average, - a pest hitter. Gets a piece of the ball. Not great power but enough to enable him to become a .300 hitter. He should be watched, and observed thoroughly before the draft list is made up.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 16, 1952  ROARKE, Michael T.  He can throw, - very good, - strong arm. Has a fine build.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: March 21, 1952  Ramon Salgado: A Puerto Rican, 23 years of age, 5'9" tall, and weighs 165 pounds. A right hander whose contract was purchased from Texas City of the Gulf Coast League last Fall for $7,500. He will be with New Orleans. He cannot speak a word of English and cannot understand a word of English. As a matter of fact, he knows very few words in Spanish. He states to an interpreter that he has never had time to learn to read or write very well because of his interest in baseball. He said he did not have time to go to school because of the necessity of practising baseball.  His expense account from Puerto Rico to San Bernardino included a "woman." Upon further questioning and some investigation, Salgado agreed to "settle for half." Eventually I found out that the woman was probably his wife. Anyhow we paid him in full. He can pitch. He can strike men out, but he can walk them too. He is a cutie, - tricky, skillful, can field his position, and has a rather complete repertoire of pitches. Salgado is a showman, and takes over the crowd immediately. This chap is undoubtedly worth the purchase price and may make a major league job, but not this year.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: July 7, 1952  SALGADO  A Puerto Rican right hander with a convenient  Ferociously aggressive, - adds respectfully to the physical security of the batsman. Has a curve and a pretty good fast ball, and a dipsy-do for a change. Head strong, - very positive. He is an animal.  "[Cannot]Could not learn to speak or write Spanish because he had to play baseball". Therefore, he is illiterate.  Might be a major league pitcher. If he could really learn how to pitch this summer, he should be taken with the Pittsburgh club next Spring for training.  His judgment is not controlled by his brains.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 16, 1952  SHEPARD, JACK  KNOWS how to throw, but has only a fair arm, - not at all great. If he becomes accurate, the arm would be good enough.  I think he is a great prospective hitter, - with power. Form perfect. Reminds one of Joe DiMaggio very much.  BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 28, 1952  SMITH, Dick  His work with Charleston will determine whether or not Pittsburgh will dispose of him at the end of the season. The probability is that he will be placed either at New Orleans or Hollywood. for draft.  B.R.  Charleston-Columbus

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 28, 1952    FRANK GAETA   This fellow can throw the ball hard, but it goes everywhere. He has no curve ball of any kind. Might acquire a slow curve, but it would be a long time before hei would locate the plate with it. He has no change of pace.     In the course of time, - probably a long time, he might become a pitcher. He can really throw the ball hard.     Under our present circumstances he would get his unconditional release immediately rather than pay one cent of bonus. Wire Sam Davis to give him his unconditional release.      B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: March 21, 1952  Jack Smith: University of Oregon boy. Smart fellow, president of his fraternity -- holds a prominent campus office, elected by the student body. Height 5'11", 195 lbs. He can run and he has power and he throws very quickly and without double stepping. He graduates from Oregon in June and will be available for the balance of the season. He is signed with Waco (Class B). He will make good wherever we send him, -- Waco or above. His bonus was $10,000 payable as follows: $3,500 on contract approval, $3,500 on January 15, 1952 and $3,000 January 15, 1953. Salary $250 per month. Jack hits right handed, and he hits!

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: July 1, 1952  SMITH, Paul  Wear a 6-1/2 hat. Reminds me of an egg with a piece of chewing gum on the little end. No neck, - no size. Cannot throw very good. Has a firm habit of putting trajectory into every throw. Not one of the great runners but above average. Takes a good lead and constantly jockeys for the break. Can run bases intelligently, and does.  Hits to all fields, - left handers do not bother him. Treacherous, tricky hitter, - knows the strike zone. Likely to hit around .300 wherever he goes. His draftability should be investigated at once. Player will go to Spring Training camp with Pittsburgh.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: March 31, 1952  DeLand, Fla.  SMITH, TOM  He is a tall, slim, bespectacled left hander from Wilmington, N.C. I would say he is 6'2" tall. Tom started his work with me with a jerky motion, no freedom in his pitch at all. After sometime he became free with it. During the course of his workout someone told me that his arm had been ailing. This information explained everything. The boy has some pain in a bad spot when he bears down. I believe that he has a good fast ball in he is scheduled to work again with me tomorrow morning.  He should not be given very much throwing exercise while his arm is lame. He told me it is very much better. I will see him again tomorrow.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: March 29, 1952  New Orleans, La.  ST. AMANT, LARRY  He was ailing. He had pitched four innings last evening and he had a kink in his back and I did not work him very much. He weighs 168 lbs., and is 5'9", - good action, looked like he would have a good fast ball and good control of it. However, he has comparatively short fingers, stubby hand, holds every pitch, curve, fast and change of pace, - exactly the same. Intelligent talking boy. His curve ball repeats rotation regularly, and it is not bad, - in fact it is pretty good. He has a change up on his fast ball, also on the curve, and both are acceptable, and without coaching.  From my brief workout, I would say definitely he is worth-while and I would like to have him too. These two boys whom I worked out on the field just before the game at New Orleans on Saturday, March 29th, are well above the average of boys who appear before me for workouts.  BR/b  P.S. Larry lives in a town called Narco, La., which is a short distance from New Orleans, La.  cc- Harold Roettger  George Sisler

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 9, 1952  STALKER, Bob  Middlebury college boy, 21 years of age, left hand hitter, 190 pounder, 6', right field hitter and with good power, and he is a good runner, - not as fast as Monahan, but still a good runner. Arm [*at least*] average. His hitting form is good and I believe he will become a good hitter. I know of no reason why he should not. Looks intelligent, acts intelligent, and talks intelligent.  BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: July 1, 1952  THIES  Right hander, big enough, has enough speed, and a fair curve with fair control of both pitches. Did not use change-up either on fast ball or curve ball a single time during his game against Atlanta.  Shows desire to beat you. If he has enough desire and aptitude to learn the change-up, pitcher might go some place. At the present time, I would say let him go to the draft at New Orleans.  B.R.        [*Watermark: Neenah OLD COUNCIL TREE ONIONSKIN ???*]

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: July 1, 1952  THOMAS, Frank  A big, strong, active right handed outfielder, - 21 years of age. Ambitious  Home run hitter all the way from the left field foul line to dead center. Almost never gives the power stroke to right field. A cross fire right hand pitcher should never have any trouble with him, particularly if he throws a curve. Any sidearm curve if not pitched on the inside half of the plate fools him completely. It strikes him out. In fact, sidearm pitching of all description s from a right hander upsets him. Frank's youth, desire and practice may improve him.  His running speed is fair, - certainly not above average. I have never seen him in a race, and the so-called timing of runners so current in the Pittsburgh organization is not at all dependable due to the condition of weather and running rack, inexpert starters and timers and inaccuracy of distance. (I just returend from California where I saw a race between two boys, - one with a 7.3 record in our books and one with a 6.8. I was betting on the 7.3 boy simply from observation, and he did easily beat the 6.8 chap.) The boys may be right in classing him below average. He can throw, and knows how to throw. He is a good fielder and he doesn't loaf. Danny Murtaugh thinks he can help the Pittsburgh club in 1953, - very positive about it.  I have indicated his batting weakness, but this observation should be added. His right foot hugs the plate and his body is well over the plate. It seems to me he would have great difficulty handling the fast inside pitch, particularly the one on his hands. He will, of course, be given a thorough opportunity to make the Pittsburgh club next Spring.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: Feb 1952  HAROLD THOMAS - About 6'5", 220 pounds, right handed, and 20 years old. Has a lot of speed. Is wild, very wild. Should go to a little league where he could get by simply by use of his fast ball. He has a curve and it has good velocity, but he has no control of it. He has no changeups, either on fast or curve balls. He is a willing cuss and I think intelligent. Very small hands for so big a man. Quite unusual. If this fellow had control he would be a really good pitcher. Aptitude fairly nil but he tries hard. That is to say he keeps on trying. I would not give him a big bonus. In fact, he is somewhat in the class of Shinnick, insofar as the hazard of a bonus is concerned. It might pay off and it might be a very foolish expenditure. No good business man would give him a dime, but a damnfool baseball man might go crazy and give him anything. I don't know to which class I belong at the present moment but because I haven't got a nickel, I will be a businessman.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: July 1, 1952  THIES  Right hander, big enough, has enough speed, and a fair curve with fair control of both pitches. Did not use change-up either on fast ball or curve ball a single time during his game against Atlanta.  Shows desire to beat you. If he has enough desire and aptitude to learn the change-up, pitcher might go some place. At the present time, I would say let him go to the draft at New Orleans.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: March 21, 1952  "Dutch" Van Burkleo: Left hand hitter and thrower. A first baseman. Barely 18, 6'1" tall and growing. Weighs about 200 pounds. He has a very great arm and will have more sheer power at the plate than any player in the Pittsburgh organization, and I include Kiner. He cost a bonus of $35,000 and right now he is worth every cent of it. He must play this year in a small league, say Modesto. He lives, eats, and sleeps and thinks baseball constantly. He is an agile boy, and not at all a bad runner, - indeed very good. He could be a regular on the Pittsburgh club in 1953.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 28, 1952    HALL    A slightly built fellow, - very active and quick. As catchers go, he is a good runner, fair arm, good enough - a pretty good receiver, left hand hitter without much power. Strikes out very seldom.     This boy hustles all the time. Not a set-up at the plate. He was very unimpressive at DeLand in the Fall of 1951, but in this year, 1952, at Charleston, he pleases much more. If his hitting should improve, he could go higher, certainly AAA. He might be considered for placement with Hollywood this Fall.    B.R.     Charleston-Columbus

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: June 16, 1952  VIROSTEK, Conrad R.  Cannot throw a lick. He cannot do anything, and he cannot move. Again I say he cannot do anything.  BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: March 21, 1952  Jim Waugh: One of the most expensive bonus players Pittsburgh has signed in the past year, - a total of $30,000, payable over a three-year period. This boy was signed to a Class D club last mid-July, ended up with New Orleans. I believe he will be one of our pitchers in Pittsburgh this coming season. A right hander, 6'4"tall, 18 years of age. The work at DeLand helped him a lot.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; R-Z
Transcription: Feb. 1952  STAN WILLIS - Red head. Big right hander, 18, say 190 or thereavouts. About 6'2". Is a boy. Fast ball straight as a string, but he has good control of it and it isn't a bad fast ball. It has above average velocity. His curve ball is a 'darb' and he has good control of that. He has a slow curve, throws it readily. It curves straight down, and he has decent control of that, too.  He has no change up on his fast ball. He acquired it as to direction of spin and rapidity of spin, but did not acquire regularity in the velocity of it. About half the time it had the right speed. He will get it, however.  Quick mind. Affable. Nice boy. Not a dummy. If he didn't make good grades in high school it would be simply because he didn't give a darn. His father and mother and grandparents on both sides were smart enough. He is the sort of fellow who is looking for new worlds to conquer. "Show me some-thing else you want me to do", is his continuous slogan. I like him. He is worthwhile as a pitcher. He would need to be sent to a careful manager. He could become a ladies man or a good drinker. He could go a long way in the professional game. He is worth a bonus, I wish we could sign him decently.   This is a fellow that I think everybody would like personally. If he would run for political office, he would be a tough bird to beat. He would be elected by acclamation, and it could be true that he would be qualified for any job that he himself believed he could do.  ADDITIONAL FOR WILLIS Very good speed and his curve ball breaks. I see no reason why he should not have good control. He is really relaxed. Nothing tense about him out there and he is as loose as three gooses. I like him very much. If he had changes he might be a tough boy to beat. Shows no sign of excitement or pressure. I could easily see this boy in the Majors some day. I would try to sign him right now and I wish I had the chance to work him out. I would not be surprised if this fellow is good all-round athlete. I would like to find out about him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: July 1, 1952  WOLFE  Tall right hander on option from Pittsburgh to New Orleans. Contentious. Always mistreated. Inaccurate narrator and an insincere prognosticator. Has a lot of speed and enough stuff to be a good pitcher. If Pittsburgh gets waivers on this fellow after the season is over, I would favor at the present time to let him go to the draft at Hollywood. He is a dry kettle on a hot stove.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: March 21, 1952  Ed Wolfe: A great fast ball. A right hander about 6' 3" tall. Has had two years experience. Doesn't have the poise of Waugh or Kline, bu he has a chance to stay with the Pittsburgh club in the 1952 season. He acquired a change of speed pitch at DeLand and he has a lot of ability. Stage fright may get him. No doubt that CAN be said about all these young players, but I believe that Wolfe is more subject to it than some of the others.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: July 1, 1952  WOLFE  Tall right hander on option from Pittsburgh to New Orleans. Contentious. Always mistreated. Inaccurate narrator and an insincere prognosticator. Has a lot of speed and enough stuff to be a good pitcher. If Pittsburgh gets waivers on this fellow after the season is over, I would favor at the present time to let him go to the draft at Hollywood. He is a dry kettle on a hot stove.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: July 1, 1952  YOCHIM  Left hander. His fast ball is a curve, and his curve ball is a change of pace. If he had perfect control, it might be that he could win in the majors, but Yochim, more than any pitcher on the Pittsburgh list, simply has to have perfect control. I doubt if he should be retained by Pittsburgh next Spring. Likely best to let him go to the draft say at New Orleans. We will watch him.   B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: San Bernardino, Cal.  February 23, 1952    HENSON, DON.    A Chinaman named Don Henson. His father is Chinese and his mother a Phillipino. 6'2", and as green as a gourd, Throws a heavy fast ball, pretty good speed, slow rotation on it, has nothing else. A broad hand, but his fingers are not too long. Has no curve or anything that pretends to be a curve, and he will not easily learn anything else. No change-up on anything. It will take quite a while his ability to throw the ball hard leaves him in the possible, of course.    Right now, Pittsburgh need not bother with him.  The chap wants and expects a bonus and we can put our money somewhere else where it will bring us quicker results.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: June 16, 1952    HICKMAN, John R.     Not a great arm, but accurate and throws correctly and right now. Should be very accurate. Should be able to catch as far as catching is concerned. Big boy, about 6'1", 180#. Hitting form is not too bad, not good like Shepard and Roarke. Almost never gets the bat and ball together. Not a bad runner. I think we ought to follow up on him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: July 1, 1952    HOLLERAN    Tall, right hander. Pretty good fast ball, - not great. Pretty good curve ball, not great, and can and does throw change-ups. Shows spirit, - aggressiveness, - wants to beat you. I believe intelligent. Shows nervousness, anxiety, never completely relaxes. Seems tense all the times while working, all of which may account for the fact that his boy does not have dependable control. He would have to impress me very differently before I would remove his name from the New Orleans list for the draft.    B.R

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: March 21, 1952    Bill Jacobs: Our only left hander in this camp. Lives down in Virginia.  Fairly finished as a pitcher, but he has had two years experience. He is now 19 years of age, and left camp to take his physical examination at his home in Alexandria, Virginia. If he passes, he intends to enlist immediately at Fort Eustis, Va. If he doesn't, he will report back for baseball duty.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: REPORT ON THE LONGVIEW CLUB AS SEEN IN ONE GAME ON TUESDAY EVENING, SEPTEMBER 1, 1953 AT TYLER, TEXAS    BAAS    A nice boy, just good en ugh for this league. No chance to go higher. Why New Orleans held him as long as it did explains in part why New Orleans finished where it did.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM FOR TWO DAYS (JULY 31, 1953 AND AUGUST 1, 1953) AT DENVER, COLORADO, AGAINST THE DES MOINES CLUB.     RAFAEL RIVAS    Just disposed of to Brownsville in player trade. Not a prospect.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM FOR TWO DAYS (JULY 31, 1953 AND AUGUST 1, 1953) AT DENVER, COLORADO, AGAINST THE DES MOINES CLUB.    CURT ROBERTS    An artistic second baseman, - a 150 pound colored boy. Fast runner, fine arm and a very quick arm. Thoroughly finished as an infielder anywhere you put him. Defensively as good as anybody, - anywhere.    Batting form is good. Does not have great power, but the boy makes good use of his weight and strength. Must be moved out of the draft. Better man in every way than Cole, will outrun Pellagrini and outfield him and possibly outhit him. Roberts is 22 years of age, married and has two children. A nice boy.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM IN DOUBLE HEADER AGAINST SIOUX CITY AT SIOUX CITY ON MONDAY EVENING, AUGUST 31, 1953.    CURT ROBERTS    He is the class of the League at second base. He covers the ground, - all over the place, and he has a fine arm. He must be protected from the draft.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: REPORT ON THE LONGVIEW CLUB AS SEEN IN ONE GAME ON TUESDAY EVENING, SEPTEMBER 1, 1953 AT TYLER, TEXAS.    RODRIGUEZ, OSCAR    This player was purchased from Middlesboro, Kentucky on the recommendation of Bill Meyer. Should catch and not play the outfield. I don't believe he is a major league prospect.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    JOSE ROMAN   Visalia, California, June 24, 1953    Mexican. Chunky, stocky build. 27 years of age, right hander. Cockey. I would judge him to be temperamental and emotional. Wants to beat you. Fair fast ball, - only fair. Curve ball just the run of the mine. Throws a change-up with four fingers. Not too bad, but not too good. Change of pace curve ball no good. Has lately been throwing a knuckle ball down in Mexico, resulting in worn off nail on his forefinger. The ball knuckles plenty, but all over the place. If this fellow were to master the knuckle ball, he might become a pitcher, otherwise Class C and D all the rest of his life. Shows plenty of guts and determination, - but not much else.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: COMMENTS AND NOTES REGARDING VISALIA CLUB OF THE CALIFORNIA LEAGUE IN THREE GAMES AGAINST THE STOCKTON CLUB ON JUNE 23, 1953 AND JUNE 24, 1953:    ROUNDY (Outfielder)  Left hand hitter, can't throw, but he can run. He has pretty good power. He should be followed and if his record is good at the end of the season, he should be placed in a higher league, - just in case.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: THURSDAY, JUNE 25, 1953 (MEMORANDUM THIS DATE DICTATED AFTER SEEING THE  VISALIA CLUB IN THREE GAMES.    BARNES (Catcher)  Tall, right hand hitter, just 18 years of age. Loose  jointed. Somehow or other does not impress me too much with  build or body movement. However, Jerry Gardner says the boy can  hit with power, - if and when he hits at all. This boy can throw  and undoubtedly will become a fine receiver. Deflective pitches   are strangers to his inexperienced bat. The boy is worth while.   He needs work, - constant work.    COMMENTS ON VISALIA [CLUB] PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB  June 24, 1953    BARNES (Continued)  Can't understand why I missed his running speed. I am told that   the boy is a below average runner.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: LARRY BARONE July 11, 1953    A big, tall right hander, weighs about 185 pounds, has an unusual delivery in that he seems to fall way toward first base on every   pitch, - curve ball, fast ball, - everything. Fast ball seemed to be fairly good and his curve ball went down, and he had a change-up on his fast ball but nothing seemed to come over the plate. He was very wild indeed.    George Sisler told me that on his previous workout he had pretty good control. That could be. The boy should be followed.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: July 27, 1953    MIKE BELKIN    17 year old left hand pitcher from Cleveland, Ohio brought in by Marty Purtell. He is a tall, slim fellow, free motion, good speed, very green, no finish in any respect. Delivery, however is good, - follow through is good enough. He has a Newcomb curve, 4", good speed. Slow curve might be effective, although it changes his delivery. No other pitches. Believe he would learn a change-up on his fast ball.    Nationality: Jewish    Clean cut, good looking, nice person, good manners. He might become a very fine pitcher.    BRANCHRICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: March 23, 1953    CARLOS BERNIER    In a game like this, where the score was seven to   four in the sixth inning, with Bernier on first base and two   men out, the first two pitches were played by the batter.  If an exhibition game is not a place to let a man like   Bernier run, then I don't know what exhibition games are   for. We don't have power. It is not a power club. We   do have a lot of speed and we ought to use what we have,   and use it excessively, - rather than not enough. Our fast  men should be able to get leads and breaks and steal if  possible. We must run. It is the only asset we have. We   should establish a reputation as a team, - as a running   club, and we should EARN that reputation.    Bernier his a fly ball to right field in the sixth   inning. He loafed to first base very badly, - very badly   indeed. He didn't run at all. The right fielder muffed   the ball. Bernier could have been on second base. He had   to return to first. What a stinking play!    In the 8th inning with Fitzgerald on first base,   and nobody out, Bernier bunted the first pitch, cap button   high and well outside.    Bernier steals home in the ninth inning with a short   lead. The Dixie Walker, or Peewee Reese, or Robinson art of   changing the lead and bluff break would seem entirely strange   to Bernier. He could be taught that very easily.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: Saturday, May 23, 1953    TOMMY QUALTERS    A McKeesport boy, 6' - 185 pounds, right hander, with good speed and a fast breaking curve. Throws a screwball. Not too good, but gives the effect of a change of pace. Very good control of everything for an 18 year old boy. Fine appearance, good intelligence, should become a very fine pitcher. He has no mechanical pitching faults, - fairly finished in every detail. Our club could afford to take him on as a bonus player (if we get enough bonus players then some of them would simply have to be used).

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.  Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club    June 9, 1953    JOHN BRADY    Sent in by Ed McCarrick. He has worked out with the Brooklyn Club. He really has a fast ball. It rates with the best. No curve. Brooklyn called it a "nickel curve", so he said, and it just that. He will get a change-up on the fast ball, but it will take time. He can also get a change-up on his curve, but that will take more time. This fellow is crude, -- unfinished, but he is big and loose as a goose. A righthander and throws his foot clear above his head on every delivery. Tremendous hand. This boy might become really great and he will become great if he gets an acceptable curve ball. He is worth having around, but it would take a darn small league for him to pitch, unless indeed he would strike everyone out with his fast one.    6' ", 180 pounds. John can really throw the ball. I would try to sign him.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: September 7, 1953  ART BERTRAND   A tall, loose, agile, slim right hand pitcher from Baton Rouge, La. Just graduated from high school, about 6'3" tall, weighs about 180 pounds. Good pitching movement. No faults in delivery.    This fellow could be improved. What I mean is that he might become quite a pitcher. Fast ball fairly good, curve ball so-so, slow curve fairly good, change up on fast ball very good, and he shows learning ability.  I wish we could sign him up, but if he has bonus in his mind, that is another matter and we should give that consideration.  He was sent up here by Joe Brown after winning a newspaper conducted contest.  BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
