Transcription: THURSDAY, JUNE 25, 1953 (MEMORANDUM THIS DATE DICTATED AFTER SEEING THE VISALIA CLUB IN THREE GAMES.    BLOXAM (Pitcher)    Right hand pitcher, about 6', and weighs 170 pounds. Active, good runner, fair speed, curve seemed quite effective on most hitters. Ray Blade sitting back of him, (I was on third base side) told me that it was a very ordinary curve, but believed this fellow could be improved. He would be a good man on this club another year. Might go higher. Should be watched, - particularly if he gets an additional pitch.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: June 4, 1953    JOHN BRADEY    An 18 year old boy from Charlotte, North Carolina. Just graduated from High School, but was married almost a year ago and will have a baby in another two months. This boy is only 5'-8 1/2 or 9" tall, but weighs better than 180 pounds. He surely is solidly built.    Fast ball good enough, and he can throw it faster when he wants to, but his control varies with his pressing. His normal fast ball is just simply good, - not great. His curve ball is an ordinary curve ball, but his slow curve ball has the effect of a change of speed, but is well above average for a kid pitcher. I would say that he could use his slow curve ball in games. He throws a change of speed on his fast ball, but it is too fast, - but immediately he could slow it up upon instruction. This boy looks even younger than he is. He is a nice boy, - a good boy, and he might become quite a pitcher. And he might be able to go into baseball professionally in a small league right now, - the chief reason being that he has enough stuff and capacity for more, but particularly because he has unusual control. The boy tells me that he has never had any trouble with his control in High School and I believe it.    We could afford to sign him up. Have George see him and report to me.    His coach, Jack Martin, came with him from Charlotte, North Carolina.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: June 9, 1953        JOHN BRADY     Sent in by Ed McCarrick. He has worked out with the Brooklyn Club. He really as a fast ball. It rates with the best. No curve. Brooklyn called it a "nickel curve", so he said, and it just that. He will get a change-up on the fast ball, but it will take time. He can also get a change-up on his curve, but that will take more time. This fellow is crude, - unfinished, but he is big and is loose as a goose. A righthander and throws his foot clear above his head on every delivery. Tremendous hand. This boy might become really great and he will become great if he gets an acceptable curve ball. He is worth having around, but it would take a darn small league for him to pitch, unless indeed he would strike everyone out with his fast one.     6'"", 180 pounds John can really throw the ball. I would try to sign him.       BRANCH RICKEY      BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: July 11, 1953    JAMES BRETTELL      This boy from Mingo Junction, Ohio. He is 6' 1/2" tall, right   hander, weighs 150 pounds. A gentleman. He is kindly,  courtesous, straight-forward, clean in manner, and you would be proud  to have him for your grandson, - intelligent too. Remarkable  stuff for so slight a build. Pretty good fast ball, and he  has a good slow curve. He would acquire all pitches. With  experience he might go quite a way. If he could be signed to a   1954 contract, it ought to be done by all means. He might surprise  a lot of people in next year's spring training camp.    If there were competition for him, I might consider other terms  but I hope you can sign him for 1954.       BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: September 11, 1953      JOSEPH BURKE     From Rutledge, Pa., 6'3" tall, weighs about 180, right hander,  18 years of age. As green as a young gourd. Grips his fast ball  in the same manner a most pitchers throw a curve. No follow through  on any delivery but he could get that and when he steps full ahead  with the right foot, he at least looks like a pitcher.     No curve at all, and nothing else. Fast ball fairly good.  Completely inexperienced. I doubt if he is worth taking to spring  training at all, - even if he signs for nothing on a 1954 contract.  Really, it is doubtful.         BRANCH RICKEY        BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: September 11, 1953      JIM CARDOS     This boy would be worthwhile taking to spring training  on a 1954 contract. If he is looking for a bonus , I would pass him  up. I can put my time and attention to a better prospect who will come  quicker. Comes from Vandergrift, Pa. is a right hander, 6'3" tall,  and a nicely built boy. He would have a chance.      BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: June 18, 1953  New Orleans-Nashville Game    [?] you this afternoon about pitchers being worked  [?] rest may not apply to Carlsen. This fellow  [?] a bad back. I wouldn't give him an excuse  [?]. I would talk to him a day or two in advance  [?]nd to pitch him and have not only his consent,  [?] as well. In the first three innings of  [?]e showed plenty of stuff, - two curves, a  [?]m his fast ball, and his side arm fast ball was  [?] monkeys out of every hitter and Nashville had  [?]tters in the lineup, - all fairly good hitters.  [?] Carlsen should have more than three days rest,  [?] ho ld be consulted.    [?]t, Carlsen reminded me of a game I saw him  [?] Denver at Colorado Springs. He pitched  [?]ings and in the eighth inning because of a  [?]elding plays, he went completely to pieces.  [?] of pace, no nothing. He was a hight  [?]thout stuff.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: September 11, 1953    WILLIAM CAUSIN     He can run and his arm is good enough, but in my book great.  His batting form is good. I see no reason why he should not hit.  I would not say that he had great power, but he is no puny.  He says he is 21. He looks older to me. Comes from Fond du Lac  by purchase.      BRANCH RICKEY      BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: July 11, 1953      DICK CHADNER    6'9" tall, left hander, good speed both overhand and sidearm. Curve ball so so both overhand and sidearm, - better overhand. Very difficult to teach him a change-up on his fast ball, or indeed anything new. I believe he is a slow learner.    Barely 18. Doesn't shave, at least he is completely fuzzy. Tremendous hands, and all in all, a good delivery.    This boy surely has a lot to learn. He balks on every pitch with men on bases and takes him quite awhile to get the ball away. Certainly is a prospect, that is to say, he can throw hard, and he is big and young. This boy throws a slow curve ball by turning his hand over and gets an effective change of pace pitch. He calls this pitch a slider, but it is simply a change-up on his regular curve ball.    This boy is worthwhile.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: September 11, 1953    DICK CHADNER (See my previous report)       The boy has cone some work on the change of pace on the  fast ball. The direction and rotation on this ptich both good, -  velocity bad, i.e., entirely too fast. It will take a lot of work to  make this pitch effective. Curve ball still so so, and that will need  a lot of work. Fast ball not as impressive as it was on his first  appearance.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: September 25, 1953    STANLEY CHLEBEK    A hatchet-faced kid, - weighs 150 pounds, 5' 10 1/2" tall, right hander, 18 years of age. He doesn't have the fast ball the other kid had (Glen Grimes) and it is as "straight as a string." A good fast ball, - about the kind you would expect from a 150 pound good kid.    He throws a curve, - not great but it curves. He throws a slow curve, - not great, but it curves. Control of all three of these pitches so so. Under other circumstances, I think his fast ball would show good control.    This boy has a knuckle ball and it is as good as you will ever see. It goes every which way. He is very difficult to catch and if he had good control of this knuckle ball, he could go major league right now. He throws it with the two finger tips on the ball. This kid is worthwhile and you can afford to sign him if he is willing to go to our training camp next spring for further trial.    He has six brothers and two sisters, - and he is the oldest of the bunch. His father is a coal miner. He shows decision, initiative and from any baseball standpoint, considerable intelligence. When I walked out to work with what seemed to be a frail kid, I found a wiry, aggressive, and resourceful embryonic competitor. I wish he could make good and he has a chance.    His knuckle ball is indeed very unusual.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: REPORT ON THE CHARLESTON CLUB SEEN IN ONE GAME AGAINST COLUMBIA ON SEPTEMBER  2, 1953.    6'3" tall, right hander, with a good delivery and a fair  degree of speed, and a darn good curve ball. Showed me no  change of speed at anytime. If he had Bob Garber's change  of speed, it would be my judgment that he could go all the  way and help Pittsburgh very shortly. He got into trouble  in the fifth inning on a three and two pitch and a lovely  curve ball that split the middle of the plate fooled the  umpire and he called it a ball.    This boy Churn really has a beautiful side arm curve ball.  He has good control of it. He must get a change-up on his  fast ball that he can and will use. His fast ball should be  used [largely] for spot pitching or for effect. He should not  pitch his fast ball over the plate to a good hitter. He is a  much better prospect for Pittsburgh than Garber.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: COMMENTS AND NOTES REGARDING VISALIA CLUB OF THE CALIFORNIA LEAGUE IN THREE  GAMES AGAINST THE STOCKTON CLUB ON JUNE 23, 1953 AND JUNE 24, 1953:    ALFANO (Shortstop)  Sawed-off shortstop without any arm. Runs about average  for a 5'6" fellow. No power, and no nothing.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: COMMENTS AND NOTES ON LONGVIEW-WICHITA FALL DOUBLE HEADER AT WICHITA FALLS ON JUNE 20, 1953    COBOS  Colored catcher from Panama. Crude, - very crude. Doesn't know what any runner is doing. Never sees a man going to second or coming home. Doesn't know how to tag, - takes a full arm sweep in throwing, - arm good enough. He can run good enough. Form at the bat is good. Someday might become a pretty good ball player, but I doubt if he has any sense at all. We will watch him for another year.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM FOR TWO DAYS (JULY 31, 1953 AND AUGUST 1, 1953) AT DENVER, COLORADO, AGAINST THE DES MOINES CLUB.     PITCHERS  ROY CONTRERAS    Cuban right hander, fair stuff, some experience. About where he belongs. He would have to get something additional to go anywhere. He thinks he is a hitter. He isn't.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEKING THEM IN DOUBLE HEADER AGAINST SIOUX CITY AT SIOUX CITY ON MONDAY EVENING, AUGUST 31, 1953.    ROY CONTRERAS  A good Western League pitcher. I don't think he is much better than that.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: THURSDAY, JUNE 25, 1953 (MEMORANDUM DICTATED AFTER SEEING THE VISALIA CLUB IN THREE GAMES AGAINST STOCKTON.    CORELLA (Pitcher)    I saw him at 100 yards only.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: September 25, 1953    WALTER A. CRADDOCK    Sturdy built left hander, just finished his junior year in Syracuse University. Lives at Mt. Hope, West Virginia. About 6'1" tall, and weighs about 185. This chap has a fast ball and a darn good one, and it does something. It has a tendency to "shoot". Strong, fast, and repeating in delivery.     The curve ball ain't. Spin is wrong, rotation is comparatively slow. The ball curves very little and he showed no control of it. In other words, he has no curve. It is, of course, a different pitch from his fast ball and in that sense would have some value.     He throws a slow curve. It has a peculiar spin but the velocity is satisfactory. With control, this ball is useable. He has worked on the conventional change-up on his fast ball given to him by George Sisler on the occasion of his first visit to Pittsburgh sometime ago. It is useable but not at all what one would hope for. He told me he was 21 years of age. He really looks older.     I would not be surprised to find out later that he is opinionated. He is worth signing, and if he were to acquire better pitches to go with his fast ball, he would go major. If he would sign up with one of our B clubs, he would be worth $1,000, - safely enough.     BRANCH RICKEY  ADDITION BY MR. GEORGE SISLER    Helms, in my opinion, a rather erratic temperment. His pitches are inconsistent. He has a fine arm. He is a boy who will have to control himself in his pitching. A sojourn in the army may do him good. The first time he came into Pittsburgh his father wanted $75,000. I imagine he thinks he is worth a little bit more than $1,000, but on account of his going into the army, he might take it. He is certainly worth that.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.   OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    WICHITA FALL, TEXAS JUNE 20, 1953  WESLEY CURTIS    Tall boy, 6'4", right hander, 23 years old, side armer altogether. Showed absolutely no control whatever of his curve, and darn little of his fast ball. Has done practically no pitching all year. Tries to throw a change-up on his fast ball but it simply doesn't change-up, and the same goes for his slow curve ball. He has no artistry whatever. His fast ball is alive, and if the boy had control, - even a little, he might pitch effectively in a small league.     Hollywood should be notified immediately of Longview's desire to return the player, then if Hollywood cannot (1) place him at Visalia, he should be sent to a small club on option, or, (2) given his unconditional release.     If he were a free agent just coming out of high school or amateur baseball, I would not give him a penny bonus. He is simply a big, tall fellow, - a nice boy, who has some sort of a chance, and that's it.      BRANCH RICKEY      BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: REPORT ON THE LONGVIEW CLUB AS SEEN IN ONE GAME ON TUESDAY  EVENING, SEPTEMBER 1, 1953 AT TYLER, TEXAS    DANGLEIS, Don  Most certainly a major leaguer, and probably a great one.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: March 10, 1953  Havana, Cuba    Davis still has the fault of playing the ball at his  shoulder. He is better than he used to be on this pitch.  George Bisler is right about it, - he is better, but he still has  that fault. This boy should be against the pitching machine  constantly and really nowhere else. Yes, there is another  place he should be worked. He is not a good judge of a line drive  or the hard hit ball. He hesitates on the break, which gives one  the impression of misjudgment, and really it is just that.  A good strong fungo hitter who can hit line drives hard and right  at Davis should be employed for about an hour everyday. The  boy needs to know quicker where the line drive is. He hesitates  going back on it and he hesitates coming in on it. He needs a  lot of practice on that ball. I think that Davis has more chance  to help our club this year than DelGreco, - very much more, but  without improvement which he should be given full chance to make,  he cannot help us.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: COMMENTS AND NOTES REGARDING VISALIA CLUB OF THE CALIFORNIA LEAGUE IN THREE  GAMES AGAINST THE STOCKTON CLUB ON JUNE 23, 195[?] AND JUNE 24, 1953:    ANANIAS (Outfielder)    Spindle legged, 145 pound [ ]  at the moment suffering from a bad leg [ ]  run very fast if he had a good leg.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: March 23, 1953  In these games, for heaven's sake why not let  Davis run. Make him run. These games don't count a thing  and only tell us things about these players and to encourage  them to do what they can do.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: June 18, 1953  New Orleans - Nashville Game    Davis has lost his fire. Three different times he should have been running on the bases. Another time on a very high fly ball that fell 15 feet in fair territory along the left field line, he didn't try for the ball, - evidently thinking he had no chance for it. It went for two bases. I am ready to quit on him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: July 17, 1953    Frank Dechano  From up in New York. Very young, say 17, - weighs about 170 pounds. A right hander, good movement, fair speed only, no curve, throws what he calls a "let up". Pretty good. I just can't imagine this fellow pitching on a major league club, but he would give a lot of trouble in amateur circles without any doubt. It might be that he will be a great pitcher, but if he is one, then this is my 'off' morning.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: Comments on a game between Pittsburgh and the Havana Cubans at Gran Stadium, Havana, Cuba, on March 11, 1953.    Del Greco. Just what I have said previously. At the present time, I mean by that 1953, 25 Del Greco's on the Pittsburgh club will finish last. May be not in 1955.    March 24, 1953  Havana, Cuba  If Del Greco helps the Pittsburgh Club in 1953, I certainly will miss my guess. Watch him in the fielding practice. The boy plays half plays, -- as if he didn't care. He didn't back up the overthrow of Face's toss on the bunt in the third inning and the result was that Dick Hall went all the way to second. I have no doubt that if Paul Smith were in right field, "Turkey" couldn't have made it to second. If I ever saw a boy who needed another year in the minor leagues it is DelGreco, - and he might become a very great player.    I am beginning to understand why Fitzgerald has not been caught very much in these past three years. He is inaccurate and seems to belong to the class that will lose the game if it goes long enough. I am beginning to wonder about it

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: COMMENTS ON BASEBALL GAME, PITTSBURGH VERSUS CUBAN ALL-STARS, GRAN STADIUM,  HAVANA, CUBA, FRIDAY NIGHT, MARCH 20, 1953.    Then in the ninth inning, two men out, bases loaded, three runs behind, Del Greco makes it the fifth time in this game when someone hits with 3 and 1. It may be baseball, but it is different from what I learned.    March 24, 1953  Havana, Cuba    Another reason for Del Greco going to the minor leagues for another year. He takes the double step when he throws. He did it on Montemayor's hit in the eighth inning and lost Paul Smith at the plate.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: March 23, 1953  Havana, Cuba    Del Greco may come to be a great player someday. That may be well, but right now he belongs in Toronto. He would only help to keep us in last place. No fight, no confidence, and no sense. I think we have better potentials on this year's team until we find out all these potentials, Del Greco should be benched.    I don't think Del Greco can make this club this year and help us out of a lowly position. Most good curves will bother him very much, and sidearm pitching will put him on the bench.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: COMMENTS ON BASEBALL GAME, PITTSBURGH VERSUS CUBAN ALL-STARS, GRAN STADIUM, HAVANA, CUBA, FRIDAY NIGHT, MARCH 20, 1953.    I doubt if Allie should be allowed to hit very often  with the 2 and 0 or 3 and 1 count. In the first place, he  is a base on balls man. He got 122 at New Orleans last year.   In the second place, he is inclined to hit the bad ball when  told he can hit on the 2 and 0 or 3 and 1 pitch.    Four runs behind, on four different occasions our   players hit the 3 and 1 or 2 and 0 ball.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: September 7, 1953    Jerome Donnelly  From Steubenville, Ohio. His father was with him. 6' 2" tall, right hander, weighs about 185 pounds. Good hands, and I would say that he has good control. Fast ball is good enough. Curve ball so so. Change of speed on curve ball not good enough for use, but this pitch, - also his curve ball, normally throws him out of pitching position so far as fielding is concerned. Also, when he bears down on his fast ball, his body position is almost in reverse. Needs a lot of work on learning to field but no manager should insist on changing his delivery in order to increase his fielding ability. He must first pitch. Then he will require some work under the right kind of supervision. The boy is agile enough. A nice boy, undoubtedly good habits and undoubtedly comes from a good family.  The attended Notre Dame College, made the team, and pitched two or three games, won two and lost one. Would leave college to play summer ball but his draft situation depends upon his continuance in school. Should be followed.  He has learned the change-up on his fast ball very lately., and he does very well with it. He is 19.  I would say that the boy has a chance.   Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: June 9, 1953  Richard Donnelly  This boy is from Stetson University. Lives in Berwynn, Illinois. Right hander, 6'1" tall and weighs 170 pounds. Fair fast ball, - pretty good control of it. Fair curve ball, - pretty good control of that. Throws a change-up on his fast ball, - pretty good. Nothing great. 20 years old. Wears glasses. Has one more year at Stetson. Good boy, good habits, no doubt. Wants to play this summer. He belongs to that class that you cannot be too positive about. He might become a good pitcher, but he is not a Dizzy Dean in any respect, - not even a Qualters in any respect. He is worth a job, that's a cinch. Whether he is worth a $3000 job, I don't know.  Branch Rickey  BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: COMMENTS AND NOTES ON LONGVIEW-WICHITA FALLS DOUBLE HEADER AT WICHITA FALLS ON JUNE 20, 1953    DRILLING (After 4 innings)    Dick is a thrower. Fair speed, fair curve, -so it looked from the sidelines. No change-up at anytime, no control, constantly in the hole. Home run pitcher. Might have a lot of stuff and so far as I know may have a good change-up on his fast ball and curve. So what? He never used either.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: September 14, 1953  FALCIONE  Has a good arm, - very young, extremely anxious to play ball. He is just what George Sisler says he is, an arm hitter  BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: September 7, 1953  PETE FUHRMAN  From Portsmouth, Ohio. Went to school last year at Penn  State, - football candidate. Pitched on the freshman team a  few times. Boy attended Western Reserve Academy. Is going  to Miami University at Oxford, Ohio in 1953 and 1954. He is 5'10"  tall, weighs about 175 pounds. Very good fast ball, curve ball  so so. Learned change-up on slow curve very quickly. Throws  a change-up on his fast ball and it is a change-up. No control  of it, and tips it off badly on delivery. Needs a lot of work.  The boy is intellengent.  His mother was Fanny Davis, a neice of J. H. Finney.  He should be followed.  As a hitter, Pete is a "big man with a little poop."  BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    September 14, 1953    GUY GANNAWAY    180 pound, 5'9" tall boy, - a catcher from Baton Rouge, La. Right hander. Very ordinary arm. Has correct method of throwing, - looks like a good receiver, and his hitting form is o.k. Runs below average.    If the Pittsburgh club needed young catchers, this boy be given further consideration. However, we do not need catchers at all unless they are exceptional prospects and this boy is not in that class. Therefore, he would simply get a chance to go to our spring training camp next spring on a small classification contract and no bonus, indeed, unless a conditional bonus.    I know that this estimate is in complete disagreement with a number of our people, but I give it as I see the workout on this date.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b    COPY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; S-Z
Transcription: September 25, 1953    ROBERT GARBER    Belongs to New Orleans. Fine person, - a gentleman. Comes from a very poor family. He is the chief support. Father is a coal miner and in bad health, etc.    This boy is supposed to have a very fine fast ball. He didn't show it to me. It is what I would call a good fast ball without any deviation whatever, and I know of no reason why he should not have good control of this pitch. He has a good curve ball at times, - not all the time. He must become regular with a good curve.    He has a slow curve and identically the same thing can be said about it as I have said about the fast curve.    He has a change-up on the fast ball which does change-up, and the spin is rapid and fairly good direction, but it is too fast. He must take something off of it before it is to be made a perfect change-up. He should become a major league pitcher. I doubt if he is ready right now.    This boy has a grievous fault. In all windup pitches there is a slow movement of his pitching hand just after the right hand leaves the glove for 8" to 10" he goes very slow with his hands and runners can easily take advantage of it. Now this fault is really not a fault on his windup delivery but he holds the same movement with men on bases, and then the movement becomes most regrettable. This slow right hand movement is a habit and will be very difficult indeed for him to correct. He is sensible to the fault and he may be able with close attention to correct it. I doubt if the boy ever has greatness in front of him.    The reason I sent for him for this workout was to help me determine whether or not to bring him up to our club at this time and protect him from the draft. His recrod [record] in 1953 at New Orleans was nil because of a broken foot. This injury bothered him more or less during the first half of the season and probably had some effect mentally throughout the year. His work with the Longview club was so so and with Charleston the same. He had some very good games. He is the sort of chap that everyone who knows him would wish to be successful. He deserves our attention and help and he will get it. I think I will bring him up.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    September 7, 1953    DANNY GILBERT    Catcher, - 5'9" tall, weighs 165. Good action, good intelligence, knows how to throw and throws good enough. Not at all a power hitter. Does not look like a strike out man either. Runs, if anything, below average. I would like to see him in spring training. Everything he showed me, outside of running, was good.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: June 11, 1953    Harry Gilbert    Just out of the army. 6'1" tall, and weighs 185 pounds. Righthander from Winchester, Kentucky. His fast ball is alive. It takes off, - should be effective although it does not have tremendous velocity. His fast curve ball is so so. His slow curve ball is more effective and I think better than his fast curve. He throws a change-up on his fast ball, - and it is fair. He shows a great deal of finish. If this fellow would not get a bit of stage fright, you could send him out possibly to a B league. He might make it. Henry is married and has one child. Gilbert looks, acts and talks intelligent. He should go somewhere right away.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    September 7, 1953    JIM GILBERT    19 year old brother of Danny Gilbert. Weight is about 175-180 pounds, 5' 11" tall. Did not show me a very good fast  ball, - indeed very ordinary. Curve ball very ordinary. I didn't work him too throughly because his initial stuff did not appeal to me at all. He would have to become an artist to go anywhere as a pitcher, in my judgement.    Jim is a left hand hitter. Keeps hands apart. Jim looks like a hitter, and he might go south next spring as an outfield candidate.    BRANCH RICKEY    [*COPY]

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM FOR TWO DAYS (JULY  31, 1953 AND AUGUST 1, 1953) AT DENVER, COLORADO, AGAINST THE  DES MOINES CLUB.      ANDY ANDERSON    A lanky negro outfielder, past thirty, with a very great arm, highly  acceptable in both strength and accuracy. Runs a good average. Can  hit on occasion with real power. He just doesn't hit enough. If he  were younger, he would be worthy of attention. Right now, he is better  than the most of what we have in Pittsburgh. Left hand hitter, right hand  thrower. Weighs about 165 pounds and is 6' tall. Could help Hollywood  without any doubt.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: DARRELL DEAN GRIESER    Comes from up north of Dayton, Ohio, near Pickway, right hand, slim fellow, -  18 years old, three children, and he is the oldest. Father is 41, and   this boy is built like a 160 pound football halfback, but this chap is over  6 feet tall and can throw a ball with very good speed. His curve ball is  so so. Change up on the fast ball is so so. Change up on the curve ball  is so so. Everything but his fast ball is so so. He tips off his   different pitches but that is correctable. The boy is not at all ready  for professional ball right now. He would be a very good boy to bring  to spring training as a free agent. With attention, he might go some  place. He must have good coaching.    B.R>

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: September 25, 1953    GLEN ALFRED GRIMES    From down here in Pennsylvania, - some forty or fifty miles away. Has no father. Has a sister and three brothers, two of whom are married. The third one is just back from the Navy, - Medical Discharge, - bad eyes. Cannot get a job. This kid woks all he can to support his mother. Very poor.    Right hander, about 165 pounds, 5" 10" tall. Loose all over. Puts his full body into every pitch.    This is a case where a boy's ability has come to meet his capacity. He already has a variety of pitches and shows aptitude. His curve ball cures and his slow curve is a slow curve ball. He throws a change-up on his fast ball with three fingers. This particular pitch can be much improved. His fast ball is good, - surprisingly so. He can become a pitcher, and should be signed.    His delivery on the fast ball repeats identically. His right foot on all change-ups guess everywhere but with a full follow through. There is a chance that when this boy has two or three years of professional baseball under his belt, he might go major. It all depends on his techniques. He must become master of all the skills.    He has little eyes. They look exactly like the forty year old white slave in the Boise, Idaho jail, - the only criminal case I ever had (I was appointed by the court to defend him and he was a son-of-a-bitch). I am sure any such comparison ends at that point. I like the boy. Get him.     BRANCH RICKEY    P.S. His position and move with men on first is o.k.    ADDITION BY GEORGE SISLER    I also like the future possibilities of this boy and I would like to sign him. He has a good consistent on his curve ball and his fast ball is alive.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: July 11, 1953      WYNN HAWKINS       6'1", 175 pounds right hander. Will be 18 years of age  next February. When I asked him this question, I said, - "Well,  you are elegible for American Legion baseball." He said, "yes,  sir, I am on an American Legion team." I then dismissed him.     I told George to send him back home immediately.     In the few pitches I saw before dismissal, he had a  fair fast ball and a pretty good curve and he had good control of  it. He should be contacted just as soon as his American Legion  eligibility expires. This boy should not have b en brought in.         BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: July 17, 1953    "Ike" Holmes    Comes from over in New Jersey. 6', 190 pounds, colored boy, right hander. Throws a ball fairly hard, - not great speed, curve ball so so, nothing special, in fact below average. He throws a knuckle ball. It has good effect, but it is never a strike, yet surprisingly close to the strike zone all the time. The boy was nervous. He might become a knuckle ball pitcher. He really might.  He tells me he is not a great runner but plays the outfield. Has the reputation of being quite a hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR\b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: July 17, 1953    ORLANDO HOUGHTALING    About 6'1", 190 pounds, right hander, from Baldwinsville, New York. This boy has never played very much baseball or pitched very much evidently. He has a very ordinary fast ball and a very ordinary curve. Has never attempted to throw anything but these two pitches.  One unusual thing about this boy is the fact hat [ED note: it says 'hat,' not 'that.'] he doesn't change the position of the ball in his hand AT ALL on the curve and fast ball. That indeed is very unusual, but it is also unusual that a boy of his size would not have more stuff. He has played outfield but very little.   I have looked at four boys this morning but this may be my off day, but I see nothing but mediocrity.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: June 14, 1953    RICHARD IDZKOWSKI    Tal, 6'3", right hander from Michigan State University. Will weigh 190 pounds. Fairly good fast ball. Not great, but good. Curve ball very so so. Change up on the fast ball is too fast, in fact it is not any good, but he probably could get this pitch. He has no change up on the curve ball, but I believe he might get this pitch.  This boy has great determination. If he says he can do something, it is very likely he will do it. He will have great confidence sooner or later and he has plenty of courage. He would be a good competitor. He has a chance, but he is very unfinished.   He is not married. Just finished school. I would certainly give him a job. From what he showed me, I would not put him in the bonus class.    B.R.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: COMMENTS AND NOTES REGARDING VISALIA CLUB OF THE CALIFORNIA LEAGUE IN THREE GAMES AGAINST THE STOCKTON CLUB ON JUNE 23, 1954 AND JUNE 24, 1953:    JACKSON (Third Baseman)    A good looking boy. Girls will like him but not as well as they would like Spence. However, Jackson has good power, runs average. Shows me no arm at all. Now playing third base because he does not have the arm for the outfield. He might become a better hitter. Young boy playing his first year of professional ball. He should be left on this club for another season.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: A REPORT ON THE CHARLESTON CLUB SEEN IN ONE GAME AGAINST COLUMBIA ON SEPTEMBER 2, 1953.    JACKSON:    The second baseman. This boy might become a better ball player. I think he should be watched, in fact he might become a good ball player. I like what I saw in this one game.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: March 23, 1953    JANOWICZ [ED note: Could either be 'CZ' or possibly 'OZ.']    He can throw hard, but he throws a little less than hard with great accuracy and quickness. I don't believe anybody ought ever say anything to him about his throwing. Everything about him in this respect is at least on its way to becoming perfect.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE CHARLESON CLUB SEEN IN ONE GAME AGAINST COLUMBIA ON SEPTEMBER 2, 1953.      JOHNSTON    The first baseman. He doesn't look to me as if he had very much power at the plate.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM IN DOUBLE HEADER AGAINST SIOUX CITY AT SIOUX CITY ON MONDAY EVENING, AUGUST 31, 1953.    ANDY ANDERSON    A good Western League player, and might do just as well in Hollywood, for example, as he does in Denver.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: August 1, 1953    NELSON KING    A 6'6" right hander, 25 years of age. Belongs to New Orleans, pitching now for Denver. Side armer. Comparatively slow rotation on all pitches. Great control, fairly good speed. Curve ball not big, but also has good speed. Throws a change-up on his curve ball, but it is too fast. He can learn to slow up this pitch. The change-up on his fast ball is fairly good. It would be more useable if he slowed it up a bit. His delivery is the same on all pitches and his arm follow through is identical. His stepping foot hits the same spot on all pitches and I see no reason why he should not have great control of all pitches.    The finish of his delivery permits him to be a good fielder.    With a man on first, he comes down in a set position with the hands too far front. He should come back with the hands more in front of his right hip. He is very carelessly slow in starting his delivery from the set position. A man could run several feet while he is moving his hands the first four or five inches. He must become alert on this point, and it may be a hard job for him because a position of this sort, and particularly the movement, is a matter of habit and he must break it, and he should work on it until it does become habit.    The boy has a chance if he ever becomes master of his stuff to the point where he can, at his own discretion, throw the unexpected pitch. He could, most likely, go major league. Surely he should be a regular pitcher and a winner for New Orleans next year. It seems to me that he should have been able to pitch in New Orleans this present season.    Looks thin and pale. (Andy Cohen advised that he is just getting over a sickness recently contacted in Pueblo). He is engaged to a girl whom he intends to marry very shortly.     He is not a drinker, but has an occasional beer, etc. Marriage would probably help him.    His past two years at Fort Lee game him nothing in my judgment but added age.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: A REPORT ON THE CHARLESTON CLUB SEEN IN ONE GAME AGAINST COLUMBIA ON SEPTEMBER 2, 1953.    MACKLEY:    A big, tall fellow, about 6???????3????? tall, fair arm, - not impressive in any respect. Seemed he looked better to me with a bat in his hands than anything else.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: June 18, 1953  NewOrleans-Nashville Game    Manville followed and threw nothing but his side arm fast ball and a nickel curve and no control of either. When he did get the ball over, there was nothing on it. He simply had to let up to get any ball near the plate.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER BLUB AFTER SEEING THEM FOR TWO DAYS (JULY 31, 1953 AND AUGUST 1, 1953) AT DENVER, COLORADO, AGAINST THE DES MOINES CLUB.    DICK MANVILLE:    A big, tall right hander, - very intelligent, pretty good fast ball, also a knuckle ball. Throws from all angles, but mostly side arm. I don???????t know how good he is but I hate to give up on him. I didn???????t work him out. I should have worked him out this spring in Havana, but I was never invited to do so, and I felt very strongly that any effort on my part to help anybody would have been held in sheer contempt, - so I didn???????t have a chance to know too much about Manville. I would like to know a lot more.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM IN DOUBLE HEADER AGAINST SIOUX CITY AT SIOUX CITY ON MONDAY EVENING, AUGUST 31, 1953.    DICK MANVILLE    Showed no speed and no control. Threw one curve in two innings. He is apparently afraid to throw it. He allowed three runs on one hit, having filled the bases with two bases on balls and a hit batsman. Then with two out, two and three on the batter, he wound up and a short single to right center then scored three runs. That shows he doesn't have a whole lot of sense, but the dismal part of that particular play was the fact that Shepard let Manville do it. That made me sick.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: June 2, 1953    GARY "RED" MARHOOVER    About 5'10" tall, weights about 162 lbs, right hander. He is a good athlete and he is smart. Not a great curve, - not a great fast ball. Learns anything right now. He will become a pitcher. He is not a thrower even now. He is a likable fellow, - one would wish him well. He must not be discounted on account of size. He is as big as Sisler was, but he doesn't have either Sisler's speed or curve, but Sisler was Sisler, and Red is Red and he has a chance.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE CHARLESTON CLUB SEEN IN ONE GAME AGAINST COLUMBIA ON SEPTEMBER 2, 1953.    NATON    Naton is alert. Larry Shepard says he is not a good receiver. He looked like a corking receiver to me.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: August 1, 1953    ALBERT OSORIO    25 years of age this coming November. Slim fellow, weighing about 160 pounds. 6' tall, - a right hander. Lives in Panama.    Has all kinds of learning ability. Slim, narrow hand, but fingers are long enough. He could learn all kinds of pitches, but he has three. Good fast ball, fairly good fast curve, but a dandy slow curve. He throws it three-quarters, but it would be much more effective if he came overhand with it. I would recommend to him very strongly that he would throw his slow curve overhand a very great deal. His experience with it will enable him to choose which is the better ball.    His problem is to come to identically the same delivery on his fast curve as he has on his slow curve, and the same thing might be said about his delivery on the fast ball, because he throws his fast ball and his fast curve with an identical delivery. However, the slow curve is pitched with a different delivery. I have given him some suggestions that might be helpful in bringing his slow curve delivery to the same effort he employs in his other pitches.    This boy has a chance because of his aptitude and desire. In the course of time, I think an additional pitch could be added to him. He is certainly worth a lot of attention. One cannot now tell what he may be eventually.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: COMMENTS AND NOTES ON LONGVIEW-WICHITA FALLS DOUBLE HEADER AT WICHITA  FALLS ON JUNE 20, 1953:    BAAS    This boy is a nice boy, well built, should hit. Only  a very average runner if that, and he cannot throw a lick.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: September 25, 1953    PAUL PENSON    Sturdy right hand boy from Kansas CIty. Only child. In the army, - gets out in November.    Had a lot of speed, - well above average. Curve ball curves, - not a great curve, but it curves. His slow curve, so-called, is about as fast as his fast curve. Doesn't take much off. I believe he can learn it. In other words, I think he has considerable aptitude. He undertook a changeup on his fast ball. He had never tried it previously. The spin was rapid and direction good, velocity too much. He can get it if he really wants to and when he does get it, he might be a son-of-a-gun of a pitcher. Good action. His delivery at the finish leaves him in his fielding position. Doesn't need any coaching at that point.    Nice boy to talk to and work with. Intelligent face, good manners. He is worthwhile. I hope we can get him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: August 1, 1953    HARRY PRITTS    23 years of age, - started at Keokuk of the Three-I League. A left hander, weighing 170 pounds and 6' tall. Should have great control and I think he does have attractively acceptable control. Throws all four pitches. His change-up on his fast ball can be good. He knows how to do it, but out of sheer habit he pitches his change-up on his fast ball too fast. I mean the velocity is too great, but he can slow it up. How long it will take him to get the definite habit of taking something off the speed of this pitch, I don't know. He has a beautiful change-up on his curve ball. It is his best pitch. Speed is good enough.    He can pitch in the majors.    Married, - no children. Comes from up near Pittsburgh. This boy I like.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: Saturday, May 23, 1953    TOMMY QUALTERS    A McKeesport boy, 6' - 185 pounds, right hander, with good speed and a fast breaking curve. Throws a screwball. Not too good, but gives the effect of a change of pace. Very good control of everything for an 18 year old boy. Fine appearance, good intelligence, should become a very fine pitcher. He has no mechanical pitching faults, - fairly finished in every detail. Our club could afford to take him on as a bonus player (if we get enough bonus players then some of them would simply have to be used).    BR

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: June 2, 1953    LES REDMOND    Pig-eyed, pig-faced, 200 pound, right hander from Newport, Kentucky. A football player, - and if he started at me, I would run. He commanded a squad in Attila's invaders in Italy. Fair speed, - not much else. Impresses you as sort of a mug-wumper, an ignorant fellow, but I don't know about that. He has real aptitude. He can learn to throw different pitches. I don't know too much about the teaching of throwing a curve ball, but he can get a curve ball, and he can get a change on his fast ball. If I had a college team, I would give him a lot of time. I think he might make it. I don't believe the boy can make good in Class D right now, and I don't think he can make good in professional baseball right now. I would like to have him in our early training camp in the Spring of 1953, - under special attention. He might do it.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM FOR TWO DAYS (JULY 31, 1953 AND AUGUST 1, 1953) AT DENVER, COLORADO AGAINST THE DES MOINES CLUB    FRANK RICE    Left hand hitter, power good enough, arm good enough, speed good enough, might get better. Should be a satisfactory player for Hollywood.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM IN DOUBLE HEADER AGAINST SIOUX CITY AT SIOUX CITY ON MANDAY EVENING, AUGUST 31, 1953.    REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM IN DOUBLE HEADER AGAINST SIOUX CITY AT SIOUX CITY ON MANDAY EVENING, AUGUST 31, 1953.    FRANK RICE    My judgment is that he is just an average A ball player, - not much above it. He might improve in hitting and if he does, then he would be alright at Hollywood.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM FOR TWO DAYS (JULY 31, 1953 AND AUGUST 1, 1953) AT DENVER, COLORADO, AGAINST THE DES MOINES CLUB.    WHITEY RIES    A 26 year old right hand hitting third baseman. Can make the come in play as good as anybody in the world. Fine arm, quick hands. Fair hitter, poor runner. not a prospect but a good man at Denver. Would surely help New Orleans.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM IN DOUBLE HEADER AGAINST SIOUX CITY AT SIOUX CITY ON MONDAY EVENING, AUGUST 31, 1953.    WHITEY RIES    This boy can make the play on the slow hit ball as well as anybody in the world, - a really exceptional forearm, and his body control on the play is excellent. He might hit enough, but he cannot run. He really belongs in Denver.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.   OPERATING   PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB  SOLAN SHAW Visalia, California, June 24, 1953       Boy will be 19 in November. Right hander, a pitcher   type, not the thrower type. Fast ball only fair. Pretty  good control of it. Curve ball only fair. Pretty good C  control of that. Throws a change-up on his curve ball. It is  his own. Just fair and not worthy of a separate signal. He has O  a knuckle ball. It is pretty good. He throws it with three  fingers, all contacted on the smooth surface of the ball. The P   ball knuckles and you can't call it ahead of time. His delivery   on all pitches is the same and that's something. This boy worked Y   a few minutes on my slow curve ball. He can get it. The fact   is that he is the type that can get almost anything. He   comprehends.     He has a half-sister. He doesn't know how old she is, -   probably about 30. She has been married twice, - the first   one was killed in World War II, and the second one was no good.   Divorced, and she now lives all by herself in her own house.   He has an older brother. In Korea. His father is a policeman   down on the waterfront. They live in Compton, California.   This boy has a chance but he must go in the direction of   perfectionism. Caught intelligently he can win now in Class C,   and he might go the majors someday.     He is in front of the war.       BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: RONALD SHEETZ June 2, 1953    "Dead-Eye Dick" control. I have never seen anything to equal  it. In my entire live I have never seen anything to equal the  native, inherent control of this young pitcher. Out of a dozen  fast balls right off the start, only one missed the dead strike zone,  and the curve balls just about the same. Everything is over, -  constantly so.    This boy is 18 years of age, 5' 11" tall, and weighs 165.  Nice boy. Has two younger brothers and a father and mother. He  lives in Newmanstown, Pa., about 30 miles East of Harrisburg. His  father is a Bethlehem steel worker. He is a good clean boy, a   definite prospect, and unless he has emotional fracases that I cannot now  tell about, he can make good with a bang almost anywhere. I would   not be afraid of him in a B league, but he should go lower. He  is really much further along than the other boy I worked out from   Oklahoma City this morning, - Bob Shipman.    However, Shipman has more "potentials". Sheetz could become  a major league pitcher spiritually, very soon. And he will go to the  major leagues as fast as his stuff will let him. If I had him at  the University of Michigan, I would never lose a game.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM IN DOUBLE HEADER AGAINST SIOUX   CITY AT SIOUX CITY ON MONDAY EVENING, AUGUST 31, 1953.    JACK SHEPARD    His quick future depends upon his batting. He has lost  some of his confidence at the plate. He is no longer  cocky. He has power and eventually he will hit. How  soon is the question. He will go as far as his hitting  takes him.          REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM FOR TWO DAYS (JULY 31, 1953 AND  AUGUST 1, 1953) AT DENVER, COLORADO, AGAINST THE DES MOINES CLUB.    JACK SHEPARD    First year of professional baseball. Just out of Stanford University.  6'3" tall and weighs 190 pounds. Not a great arm but throws quickly  and correctly. Has a great desire. Has excellent batting form  and will hit with power. I see no reason why he cannot go to the  major league, and probably next year.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE CHARLESTON CLUB SEEN IN ONE GAME AGAINST COLUMBIA ON  SEPTEMBER 2, 1953.      LARRY SHEPARD ( MANAGER)     While coaching at third base, with nobody out, on a scratch  two base hit, he sent the man home in a tie game and the catcher had the ball  when the runner was barely half-way to home from third. In the same  inning, the pitcher bunted on what was apparently a squeeze play. The  base runner on third never moved. All this happened while Shepard was  coaching at third.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: June 2, 1953    ROBERT SHIPMAN     Just graduated from high school down in Oklahoma City, Okla.  6'3" tall, 185 lbs., right hander. Good speed, good fast curve.  Got another curve not as fast as the fast one and not as good  control of it. Throws a change-up on his fast ball. Not very good,  but he can learn it. He can learn a change-up curve ball.     This boy is intelligent, has good delivery, no faults. I  would say he is a major league prospect, but not too quick. He  pitches almost everything high. He needs perfection in techniques of his  pitches and definitely needs better control. His first engagement  should be in Class D. He might come very fast.     He has good eyes, good face, good manner and is worthwhile.  I would like to have him. His promotion might be faster than anyone  thinks.       BRANCH RICKEY      BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE CHARLESTON CLUB SEEN IN ONE GAME AGAINST COLUMBIA ON  SEPTEMBER 2, 1953.        JOHN SIMMONS    An outfielder. This is his league. He should hit .400 in this  league. That just about lets him out.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM FOR TWO DAYS  (JULY 31, 1953 AND AUGUST 1, 1953) AT DENVER, COLORADO,  AGAINST THE DES MOINES CLUB.        CHUCK SIPPLE    Didn't work him out. Didn't see him, but he should be disposed of  in a money market if we can find one. Should go to draft on a  B club. Would then probably quit. So what?

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: H8W  -----  5/26    George Sisler Pittsburgh May 25, 1953  Joe L. Brown New Orleans Branch Rickey  Branch Rickey, Jr.  Prospect- DON JOE BROCATO Harold Roeetger    Dear George:    Enclosed you will find a scout report card on player Don Joe Brocato, a 6'5"  195 lb. right-hand pitcher from Gilbert, Louisiana. I believe that you  already have a card on this young man, as he worked out for Mr. Rickey on March  28, 1952 and I forwarded a card on to you shortly after.    Brocato has already graduated from high school, and there are a number of major  league clubs interested in him. He has already promised the Detroit Club that  he will go to Detroit with his Mother and Aunt. I have written to Brocato three  times and have also talked with him on the telephone on two occasions, and he has  promised me that he will go on to Pittsburgh from Detroit and work out with you  in Forbes Field.    He is driving on the entire trip, and it will not be necessary for you to make  any transportation arrangements for him. I suggested, however, that he call you  collect and let you know when he is to arrive in order that you may make hotel  reservations for him and his mother and aunt. I also told the boy that you would  reimburse him for his transportation and living expenses and any other expenses  involved in making the trip from Detroit to Pittsburgh.    This young man worked with us last year and looked like a very fine prospect,  George, and I am quite anxious that you and Mr. Rickey have a good chance to see  him. I would appreciate receiving your opinion of his ability, as well as the  result of his visit to Pittsburgh.    With every good wish, I am,    Sincerely,  Joe L. Brown  Joe L. Brown    SPECIAL DELIVERY AIR MAIL

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: August 1, 1953    Roger Sawyer    An 18 year old left hander from Mt. Morris, - a town about 30 miles south of Rochester, N.Y. He is about 6' tall and weighs approximately 170 pounds. At the time I worked him out, he had won 18 games and lost only one for Hutchinson in the Western Association. He started pitching professional baseball in July of 1952. I worked him out at that time. I am now working him out again on August 1, 1953.    This boy has good speed, - not great, but it is good enough, and he has marvelous control of the fast ball. In fact, he has control of everything. His curve ball is not great either, but it is a curve and it is overhand and a "downer", - not a great "downer", I repeat, but it also has the effect of a change of speed. He throws a change-up on his fast ball and it does have less velocity, but it is too fast. He can get a slower ball on his fast change-up. If he will work on it, he will get control of it. Then, he will become quite a pitcher. He has a good pitching attitude and good pitching intelligence.    His father and mother drink some and he drinks and he has the apparent virility of a stud horse. He will be bigger and his big enough right now. Beyond any doubt he is quite a prospect. I shall not be surprised if he can pitch splendidly for New Orleans next year. I think so.    His hand is wide but he has short fingers. I will say with positiveness that I have never seen a pitcher with so short fingers who had so great control.    He has the reputation of being a little wild at night. No boy 18 years of age such as Roger is ever a bad boy. He can be salvaged completely, and Branch, Jr. is the fellow who can do it. He must be given very close attention off the field as well as on it. He can become a technically good pitcher and we must see to it that he becomes a technically fine gentleman.     I can easily see him in a World Series in Pittsburgh.    BRANCH RICKEY    I can easily see him in a World Series in Pittsburgh.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: COMMENTS ON BASEBALL GAME, PITTSBURGH VERSUS CUBAN ALL-STARS, GRAN STADIUM, HAVANA, CUBA, FRIDAY NIGHT, MARCH 20, 1953.    Dick Smith could take a job on our infield anywhere, - over most anybody, but he is surely a puny hitter.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: September 11, 1953  JIMMY SMITH    Jimmy is the son of old Jimmy Smith, - a tall, young fellow with a lot of pep and life and throws in all directions except the one he is looking at, completely erratic.       BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: THURSDAY, JUNE 25, 1953 (MEMORANDUM THIS DATE DICTATED AFTER SEEING THE VISALIA CLUB IN THREE GAMES.        SPENCE (Outfielder)       This boy is a better runner than I thought. He should be left right in Visalia. In my opinion, no harm could be one to turn him over as a hitter.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: RALPH TERRY October 31, 1953     Right hander, 6'3" tall, 184 pounds, will be 18 in January of  1954. Mother and guardian Mrs. Dawes. Has one older brother in the  army. Lives in Chelsea, Oklahoma. Good American Legion record, good  high school and semi-pro record.      In the graduating class of 1954, Ralph was number three/and/is  attending a branch of Oklahoma A. & M. at Miami, Oklahoma.      A good boy, good background, good habits, 12 letter man in high  school, interested in his school work and in his athletics to the  complete exclusion, I would say, of women. Intelligent face, fine manner,  understands my baseball conversation.      Aptitude fair to good. Will have trouble getting correct spinning  direction on all new pitches. Needs a lot of work but he knows how to  apply himself. He might acquire any new pitch because of his application.  For example, he would have considerable difficulty acquiring regular or  repeating direction to his spin on the so-called thumb slow curve ball.  He gets it on occasion, therefore, he can get it on all occasions. It is  doubtful if he needs this pitch for he has a slow curve ball distinctive  enough from his regular curve. He lacks useable control of the pitch,  however.      His fast ball is good enough, not great, but good, and his control  of it is indeed unusually good. He had difficulty also in spinning  direction on his change-up fast ball.      His regular curve breaks at times beautifully. However, lacks  consistency and when he presses on his pitch, he is wild with it.      The greatest reason for saying that this boy has a chance to go all  the way is, first, his size, body control, regularity in delivery, fast  ball control and above all his desire. If he were in the hands of  Kinnamon or Bragen, it is possible to show enough improvement in  one year to be generally rated as a prospect. In my book, he has a chance.      He needs attention on pitching skills, and lots of work. He should  not be placed anywhere that he would be benched; unless indeed he were  to be a bonus player, in which case he must close attention from a  special coach. His tendencies are in the way of a pitcher not a thrower.      I did not try him with men on bases. He might show similarly  bad form and inexperience in this department, but I think he would be  easily teachable.      He does not follow his pitch, evidently he has never been  coached on the point. There is a complete regularity and repeat in the  stepping position of his left foot, also the right one. I am very sure he would  acquire a follow-up movement of the left foot easily and quickly.      His fingering is good on all pitches. There is no variation in the  thumb position, nor in the split between the fingers nor the placement

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: September 25, 1953    James Scherkel    Tall, slim, bespectacled right hander from somewhere in Pennsylvania, - 100 miles out. Nice boy. Very ordinary fast ball, no curve, and absolutely nothing else. Delivery o.k. Good follow through. I would take this boy to Brunswick simply as an unsigned free agent. The boys might work with him and give him something else. He is the brother of the Minneapolis pitcher.    Not now worth a contract.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: in relation to the sock. His fine control of his fast ball is  therefore understandable.        BRANCH RICKEY        BR/b    P.S.      Following the above dictation, I had a talk with the boy and  his mother. He is in the field for $40,000 or some such sum. I am  not interested. I don't believe he will get $40,000 or any other  considerable bonus and if he doesn't get more than $4000, I think he is  inclined to come to Pittsburgh. Someone should keep in touch with him.      B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM FOR TWO DAYS (JULY  31, 1953 AND AUGUST 1, 1953) AT DENVER, COLORADO, AGAINST THE  DES MOINES CLUB.     JAKE THIES    Right hand pitcher, about 25 years of age, rugged underhand delivery,  comes over on occasion. This boy has never impressed me with great  stuff. He is probably right were he belongs. However, we will  watch him. He is making a great Western League record this year.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: COMMENTS AND NOTES ON LONGVIEW-WICHITA FALLS DOUBLE HEADER AT WICHITA  FALLS ON JUNE 20, 1953:    TURTURRO     He can play second base in the Big State League easy  enough. A glove artist. No hit. If he is smart enough, he  ought to go into something else. Probably limited to  Class B.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE LONGVIEW CLUB AS SEEN IN ONE GAME ON TUESDAY  EVENING, SEPTEMBER 1, 1953 AT TYLER, TEXAS      TORTURRO     He can play any infield position, anywhere, and that takes in  shortstop. He runs well enough and his arm is good enough. He  doesn't hit. I don't believe he will be drafted from Longview.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: September 14, 1953    RUDY TRBOVICH     A 17 year old right hander from East Liverpool, Ohio.  He has all the rhythm and movement of a finished pitcher. I would  follow him very closely. I didn't work him out, but observed him  closely from the stands. He impressed me very much.     BRANCH RICKEY     The above dictation was made thrity minutes ago. I have  now worked the boy out. He has a side arm fast ball which is very  much alive and he has a side arm curve ball which is very good. He  changed the method of throwing his cuve ball for me and showed great  improvement. There is no question in my mind that this boy could  become a major league pitcher and before long. I am for him all over.  He does not graduate until next June. I explained to him that we could  not spend one center on his expenses to come to Pittsburgh. He  said he understood that. He impressed me very much.     BR

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: September 9, 1953    TOM TROSSEN    6'4" right hander, weighs about 190, from Cleveland, Ohio. Has several  different pitches. Throws what we used to call in the country an  inshoot, also a regular fast ball. The so-called inshoot is alert,  active, a high rate of spin. I thought it was better than his regular  fast ball. He has a curve and it curves, - also a take-off on his  curve and he throws all the pitches with the same identical delivery.  His delivery is not bad, - nothing in it to keep from becoming a good  fielder.     He throws what he calls a slider, really a fast velocity, non-spinning  curve, having the effect of a sidearm curve ball. It does not curve  a great deal and it spins very slowly but it approaches his fast ball  in speed. It is a pitch that he probably could use to advantage  from time to time.     I would say his control on all pitches is not bad. In fact it is  much above the average of youngsters with try out.     From the so-called aptitude test to acquire a change-up curve, he  finally had to do it his own way, which involved a change in  fingering which enabled him to throw the change-up curve  on the same fingering and manner in which he throws his regular curve.  He got spin in the right direction and velocity was not bad, but  the ball rotated very slowly. He might acquire a useable pitch in  this direction.    He has just finished his freshman year at Notre dame. It is my  understanding that he is willing to go out next spring but would like  to have enough money to finish his first-half year (1953) of college  work. Most certainly if that is in the neighborhood of $500.00,  I would be quick to do it.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: July 17, 1953    JACK VALE     A very big left hander from Georgetown University. A  basketball player. Looks to be about 21 years of age, 200 pounds,  6'4". Only fair fast ball, but good movement. Curve ball  so so. Throws his curve ball with the tips of his two fingers, -  has a knuckle ball effect, really nothing else, and neither of  the two pitches he has is great. He may be a good hitter and a  good first baseman. We will look into that.    BRANCH RICKEY    br/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: COMMENTS AND NOTES ON LONGVIEW-WICHITA FALLS DOUBLE HEADER AT WICHITA FALLS ON JUNE 20, 1953    VANGELAS  Left hand hitter, right hand thrower, first baseman. Has  been in the army two years. Should have stayed there. Has  a better future as a soldier than as a ball player.    Batting form absolutely perfect. He should hit. Arm good  enough. He will never make any good play. He won't get a  man on a force play at second once in ten tries, - hesitates,  and holds the ball, plays every ball slow, doesn't know what  to do with it when he gets it. Very average runner, - indeed  below average. Not worth a dime. I don't know whether or not  to recommend him for the 1954 Waco team. If he hits enough  home runs, may be so.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: COMMENTS AND NOTES REGARDING VISALIA CLUB OF THE CALIFORNIA LEAGUE IN THREE GAMES AGAINST THE STOCKTON CLUB ON JUNE 23, 1954 AND JUNE 24, 1953:    Dick Schroyer (Pitcher)    A tall, 18 year old right handed pitcher with a fine fast ball, well above average. He just finished pitching seven innings, gave eleven hits, four bases on balls but only five runs.    There was not a strike thrown in the game with three exceptions except fast balls. In other words, he can't throw anything over the plate except his fast ball. You can't tell what the boy may become. I don't know, - but I do know that he should be in the hands of somebody who is technically capable of teaching this boy and something more than that, making him work on the things he needs.    I think Gardner is a smart fellow, knows all about his players, shrewd, likeable, unafraid when pushed, and with all a good manager. But he is tarred with the stick just the same as our Pittsburgh manager, - "finish out of last place." I would guess that an examination of the records would show that Schroyer has pitched enough innings in the three months period to average much less than nine innings every five days and Schroyer is the type of pitcher who should be pitched with two days rest and probably never with more than three days rest. So it goes.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE LONGVIEW CLUB AS SEEN IN ONE GAME ON TUESDAY  EVENING, SEPTEMBER 1, 1953, AT TYLER, TEXAS    VANGELIS   We should have a better man for the Waco club in 1954. Great  batting form, otherwise a complete bust.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM FOR TWO DAYS (JULY  31, 1953 AND AUGUST 1, 1953) AT DENVER, COLORADO, AGAINST THE  DES MOINES CLUB.    BOB WAKEFIELD  An outfielder with power. Pretty good arm, ordinary runner, not  going anywhere. Not too desirable. About 26 years of age.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM IN DOUBLE HEADER AGAINST SIOUX CITY AT SIOUX CITY ON MONDAY EVENING, AUGUST 31, 1953.    BOB WAKEFIELD  I think he is a good man to get rid of.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    HARRY WEAKLEY  Visalia, California, June 24, 1953     Right hand pitcher, - no follow through. 170 pounds,  6'1" tall, 23 years old. Has been in the army. No follow  through. Half the time hwen [when] he pitches the right food goes  back toward the mound in his delivery, - never passes the  left foot. Fair fastball, - only fair. No curve. Slow  curve better than his so-called fast curve, but no control of  it. Showed very good control of his fast ball although his  reputation on the Visalia club is bad on control. Change-up  on his fast ball is no good. Too fast, and no control of it.  I imagine this fellow in a game would look better. He would  have to show me something in a D League before I put  him higher.    BRANCH RICKEY    COPY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: September 11, 1953    AL WEDZIK    He can throw. He can throw hard, - harder than most anybody,  and he throws right now. I don't know whether he can run or hit, but we  should certainly find out.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: COMMENTS AND NOTES ON LONGVIEW-WICHITA FALLS DOUBLE HEADER AT WICHITA FALLS ON JUNE 20, 1953    WILCOX     Professional ball player simply because he is determined  to be one. He has improved very much over the Deland showing  of October, 1951, and he will doubtless continue to improve.  I can hardly imagine him playing above Class A and will not  make the money. Might be a good man for Waco in 1954.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM FOR TWO DAYS (JULY  31, 1953 AND AUGUST 1, 1953) AT DENVER, COLORADO, AGAINST THE   DES MOINES CLUB.      BARNEY SCHULTZ    A right hander with fair stuff, including a knuckle ball. He is worse  than Nelson King on holding men on. He moves his left leg   forward and then up and then out and then back and finally pitches.   He cannot go any higher and I would recommend that he be made subject   to unrestricted draft.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE LONGVIEW CLUB AS SEEN IN ONE GAME ON TUESDAY  EVENING, SEPTEMBER 1, 1953 AT TYLER, TEXAS    WILCOX     I don't want him at Waco next year. I don't like his  attitude although he is a real hustler. He cannot run a lick.  Put him to "C" League for draft and the same goes for Garcia,.....  and if we have a first baseman, I would have Vangelis go to draft from  a "C" League.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: June 11, 1953    DEWARD T. WILLIAMS    21 year old, 6' 2 1/2", righthander from Lincoln Memorial  College. Good speed, fair curve, - slow curve better and fairly  good. Change-up on his fast ball correctly thrown. This boy seemed  to be a bit nervous with me and didn't show the control his twin  brother Don had. Deward's delivery on his change-up fast fall is  very different from his delivery on his fast ball. His two curves  are at the same on delivery. This boy is no Dizzy Dean with his fast  ball but it is good enough. These William twins are country boys,  eleven children, live on a Virginia farm some twenty miles South of Roanoke.
