Very definitely they can be rated as prospects.    Deward pitched nine games for Lincoln Memorial and won  eight of them. He should.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: June 11, 1953    DON WILLIAMS     By three minutes, the older of the two, and they definitely  look exactly alike. Don has a better delivery than Deward on his  follow through. His stepping foot moves a seond time on almost all  deliveries. He has a good fast ball. Showed me a better fast  ball than Deward's. He has a very effective slow curve. His fast  curves is a "twister". His change-up on the fast ball is more developed   than Deward's and has good control of it. This boy pitched about ten  games for the University of Tennessee. Had a good record. He has a   fine strikeout record.     At the moment, I would say that Don is the more effective of  the two. I would like to have both boys.       BRANCH RICKEY        BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: COMMENTS ON GAME BETWEEN PITTSBURGH AND THE HAVANA CUBANS AT GRAN STADIUM, HAVANA, CUBA, ON MARCH 23, 1953.        Wolfe Never shook his head a single time, - eight straight  fast balls, - not very much on any of them.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: March 23, 1953      WOLFE INTERR-SQUAD GAME GRAN STADIUM, HAVANA, CUBA March 23, 1953.     Just before tonight's game, this man Wolfe ran around  the park and came up and told Kenneth that he just had to see  a doctor, - that he couldn't see. A few minutes later he  wanted Bob Rice to get a doctor for him. 15 minutes later,  he was working on the field, dancing around behind the pitcher.  Later, during the pitchers' batting practice, he hit a home   run over the fence and joyfully celebrated. He was full of  life and pep during the entire batting practice. Went into  the game in the sixth inning as the pitcher. Walked the  first man up on four pitched balls, then struck out a man.  The next man bunted and on the try to get the man at second  both men were safe. That put Wolfe up in the air and he  began walking everybody, ending up by Rossi hitting a ball  back at Wolfe, - struck him on the shoulder. Down went Wolfe  on his belly with the ball 10' away. You can have Wolfe.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: THURSDAY, JUNE 25, 1953 (MEMORANDUM DICTATED AFTER SEEING THE VISALIA CLUB IN THREEE GAMES AGAINST STOCKTON.    WORTLEY (Pitcher)  I didn't see.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: COMMENTS AND NOTES ON LONGVIEW-WICHITA FALLS DOUBLE HEADER AT WICHITA FALLS ON JUNE 20, 1953      WUESTHOFF     Big man, little poop. He ought to go into something  else, and if we have anybody for Longview right now, I would  recommend the assignment of his contract to Visalia.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: September 25, 1953    DAVID ZEBLEY     From over near Philadelphia. Looks to be about 18 years of  age, 6'3" tall, and weighing about 185 pounds. Right hander. Sent in   by Ray Welsh. Pretty good fast ball and very good control of it.  Curve ball nothing at all. In the first palce the ball isn't a curve   and in the second place it is never over. Throws a slow curve, - it   curves some and he has fairly good control of it. The boy worked on a  change-up on his fast ball. Showed promise.      Delivery is alright and he looks and acts intelligent. He   is certainly a deliberate cuss. I doubt if he has any undue excitement  in him anywhere.     He didn't impress me in his development as being worth a  bonus of any sort. He is worth signing to a contract without a bonus and  we would be hopeful to get somewhere with him next spring. Like all  young pitchers of his size, age, and strength, he mus be put in the class  of having a chance.     He is not at all a lemon.       BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE DENVER CLUB AFTER SEEING THEM IN DOUBLE HEADER AGAINST SIOUX  CITY AT SIOUX CITY ON MONDAY EVENING, AUGUST 31, 1953.        BARNEY SCHULTZ    The Western League is high enough for him and surely he is not an   ace in the Western League.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: September 14, 1953      RUDY SEECS     A catcher. He looks about 6'4" tall, - as   awkward as an overgrown 17 year old boy, but shows a lot of interest.  The general opinion is that the fellow cannot hit a lick. That may  be, but I would go with the crowd that would say he might become   a better hitter than he now is. If this slim gink can run at all,  I would see him next spring.     BRANCH RICKEY      BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: July 7, 1954    MIKE BELKIN    Tall, left hand pitcher from Cleveland, Ohio. Jewish boy. Bright and intelligent. Just completed Freshman year at Wisconsin. Passed all his work. Has remarkable record in semi-pro ball. Fast ball is alive and good enough. Change up on the fast ball is largely a matter of change of effort, but the ball definitely changes. Regular cure ball so so. His change-up curve ball is very good, and he seems to have very unusual control of it. This chap is all arms and legs. Many youngsters have arms like this boy and since pitching skill lies so much above the shoulders, it cannot be said at all that this boy doesn't have a chance to go to the major leagues. He certainly does have. Under no circumstances would I make him a bonus player on the Pittsburgh club.    B.R.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE HUTCHINSON CLUB IN ONE GAME ON JULY 23, 1954 AGAINST THE MUSKOGEE TEAM.    JOE BERAN    Right hand hitter. Well built boy, and undoubtedly possesses a corking personality. I think he has a good pair of legs (good average) and he has a lot of power at the plate. I would call him a head swinger. He strikes out in ungodly fashion. Popular with the public and popular with the players, and my information and observation both lead me to believe that he could be a good manager. He takes charge. He does not need to be protected from the draft.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Ga.    RONALD BLACKBURN  I like him. I think he has a chance to go places.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE WACO CLUB AS SEEN IN TWO GAMES, ONE ON JULY 24TH WITH THE CORPUS CHRISTI CLUB, AND THE OTHER WITH THE HARLINGEN CLUB ON JULY 26, 1954.    RONALD BOONE  Nice kid, intelligent boy, - good utility man. Leave him in Waco. He is valuable there.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: REPORT ON THE HUTCHINSON CLUB IN ONE GAME ON JULY 23, 1954 AGAINST THE  MUSKOGEE TEAM.    BOB BUNDY    Just Bundy.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: Hollywood, Cal.  June 16, 1954    Campbell, Dick    This boy is 22 years of age, 6' tall, 170 pounds, maybe more. Right hand side arm pitcher. Fair fast ball, not bad. No curve at all. No changes of any kind on any pitch. Dick has been in the Navy for four years and "pitched the first two years". What he did the last two years I don't know, but it was not spent in learning a curve ball or learning any kind of change on anything.    I was on the point of dismissing him entirely, when I asked him if he had anything else. "Yes", he said "a knuckle ball", and I told him to proceed to knuckle. He did. That is his best pitch, - in fact, all he has, - but he lets up so much in his effort and delivery that he has no deception whatever. However, the ball would not be easy to hit even if he wrote a letter to the fellow a day ahead of time, and he can throw his knuckle ball over the plate with fine regularity.    This chap is tremendously anxious to get a job in professional baseball. If he wants a dollar to sign up, I wouldn't give it to him, but he might make good on a small club and he could develop into something. I would not mind having him in camp next spring. That would be the best plan for him.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: February 22, 1954    Clarence N. Churn    Due to arm condition, Churn did not press at all. Did not throw a single curve, but did work easily on a change-up on his fast ball. Bill Meyer reminds me that the boy can become an ideal side arm pitcher and the pitch might become more effective if he concentrates on a ball having the tendency to sink rather than to go up.    Reschedule this fellow when his arm permits.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: CLARENCE CHURN March 8, 1954    This boy has more speed than I thought he had, and the ball 'bends'. It is not at all a home run pitch. He has a good regular sidearm curve, but even a more effective slow curve. It is so unfortunate, indeed, that he doesn't have useable control of this slow curve. He can easily acquire a better change on his fast ball, - the one he has had is too fast. He can slow up on it. He knows how.    He, too, must go to the spot pitching mound and work on control of his change-up curve. Good control of that pitch could bring him to the majors very quickly.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: February 22, 1954    DONALD DANGLEIS    I have told him to tell Rex to put him on the spot pitching target, allowing 30 minutes each day. Give him a dozen balls. He will work with Fred Green who will have the same practice at the same time. Dangleis is to work on the curve ball only for control, - simply center spot pitching with his curve ball, - either his regular curve or the slow curve, or both.    If this boy can get any kind of spot control with a curve, he might stay with the Pittsburgh club this year. He definitely can be a "quickey".    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: Hollywood, Cal.  June 15, 1954    GLEN DANGLEIS    6'2" tall, 156 pounds, 18 years of age, and a   brother of Don. Wears glasses, has quite a philosophic   approach to his work, what ever that means. This boy has   a good deal of general aptitude of his brother Don.   He is a natural in pitching. Surprising speed for a   boy of his weight. Not a great fast ball, but it is   very much alive. His curve ball is fairly good. He   throws everything on a high 3-4 delivery and also   everything on a sidearm delivery.    His change-up on his fast ball is a palm ball, -   has surprising effectiveness, but he shows it, and his   delivery of his pitch is not forceful, and his habit is   to show it in his windup, but the pitch is effective. He   worked on the thumb change-up curve ball and he can get   it immediately, - in fact he has it.    He is a pitching prospect and we should sign him.    BRANCH RICKEY    [Signed with Hollywood]

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; P-S
Transcription: Hollywood, Cal.  June 16, 1954    DIAL, BILL    6' tall, about 165 pounds, only 17 years of age. Will be 18 next September. Santa Ana boy. Only child, - nice boy, - intelligent kid, with fair speed, - good control of his fast ball. Stride repeats, fingering remains the same and is normal. Curve ball fair, - not good control of it, but probably due to pressure. He was on stage.    Has never had a change of speed on his fast ball and has never tried to get one. Does have a change up on his curve ball, but is simply a lack of effort. Everybody in the park knows it is coming, practically, when he starts. He can acquire the thumb change of pace curve, and he will do it. Getting a change-up on his fast ball will be difficult for him. He cannot reduce the velocity without change of effort.    Aptitude less than average. His chance depends upon his application of acquiring change of speeds and his increase of weight and strength. He is indeed very young, not only in age, but in body control.    At this moment, this boy is not in a class with any of the six boys I worked yesterday, June 15th.    It is my judgment he cannot help Billings, - not at all. He should pitch semi-professionally for a year or signed to a 1955 contract.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: LINO DINOSO February 23, 1954    A tall, slim, left handed, colored Cuban pitcher. Cannot speak English but is funny, darn funny. You have to like him. Reputation of careless deportment, - to say the least.    He has surprising speed for a 160 pound boy. He has a slow curve ball thatis good enough, - a change-up on his fast ball that is useable. His so-called fast curve is not at all impressive. Lino throws a knuckle ball. Not a great knuckle ball, but it breaks down every time, and he has control of it. This fellow might pitch anywhere. He deserves a good look and plenty of trial in this camp.     BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: REPORT ON THE HUTCHINSON CLUB IN ONE GAME ON JULY 23, 1954 AGAINST THE MUSKOGEE TEAM.    LARRY DORTON    He is on option at Hutchinson from Hollywood and will go back on the Hollywood list for the draft. He is a good looking boy and I believe he will become a good manager. Now managing at Hutchinson.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Georgia    DOUGLAS, CHARLES    I like him. He might pitch at Burlington but I am hopeful that the Burlington club will have better and more experienced pitchers.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Hollywood, Cal.  June 15, 1954    DON DRYSDALE    6' 4", 185 pounds, 18 years of age. A lot of   artistry about this boy. Way above average fast ball.  It is really good. Direction of the spin and the speed   of rotation the same on all fast ball pitches, -angle  of delivery the same, stride is wide, and his body is in   all pitches. Fine pitching hand, and placement on fast  and curve ball needs no coaching. Let him alone on all  his fingering. He is good. I don't know about his  agility or whether or not he has body control or can field   his position, but his work on the hill itself has an   unusual amount of perfection. Intelligent face and manner,   shows good breeding.    This boy's curve is fairly good, and he shows  control of it also. He has a change-up on his curve that  is usable. Change-up on the fast ball is too fast and he  lets up on his delivery. This will take considerable work  but I am very sure that this particular chap will acquire  an effective change on his fast ball.    It is my judgment that his aptitude would be far  above average. He is a definite prospect. With proper  handling, I could see this boy on the Pittsburgh club in two  years. He impresses me very much, - the same as Dangleis  did two years ago, - with one thing in his favor, namely,  more speed, but Dangleis was more finished with four pitches.    It is probably that this chap is worth whatever   it takes except that Pittsburgh is in on position to make  him a bonus player.    And here is a secret for you, Bob. Rather than  lose him, I would sign him to a Pittsburgh contract, for I   think he would come within the three years, but his first  contract must not be above $4,000, for he should go out  of course. If he were to stay with our club, however,  his salary would be the minimum in the major leagues, viz,   $6000.    This boy had a high scholastic record, - almost a straight A.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: July 2, 1954    JIMMY DUNLAP    Looks like he might be about 6'0" tall, 175 pounds, 18 years old, and he can throw and from all positions and angles - a really exceptional arm. Judging from the one time he ran to first base, he showed what I call average speed.    He might develop into a distance hitter, he might, I don't think so. He is a defensive batsman. He gets a piece of it all the time, but not often with applied power. With experience, he would not strike out very much, but I would be greatly surprised if his first year in professional baseball would show above 20% extra bases. His fielding and his age and his size and his body control make him worthwhile to sign.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Hollywood, Cal.  June 15, 1954    JIM DUNN    Right hander, 185 pounds, 6'2" tall, 18 years of age. Good good speed. Has a Newcombe curve, - doesn't break very far, but it should be effective.    [Signed with Yankees]

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Georgia    DWOJESKI, LEO    Quick arm, looks sort of bound up. Gets more on the   ball than his delivery would indicate. I suggest that he be  put at second base.      BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Georgia    ELLIOTT, EUGENE    I believe he has a stronger throwing arm than Sanchez.  One year ago he impressed me as a good runner. Broke his  leg last summer. Showed no speed today at all.    He should to to a very small league this year.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: REPORT ON THE WACO CLUB AS SEEN IN TWO GAMES, ONE ON JULY 24TH  WITH THE CORPUS CHRISTI CLUB, AND THE OTHER WITH THE HARLINGEN  CLUB ON JULY 26, 1954    [GOERGE MATILE]  Fine gentleman. A pretty good ball player. Doesn't show  signs of power or hitting percentage.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: FRED GREEN February 22, 1954    About 6' 3" tall, - an ideal left hander. He has  good speed and he has two curves and he has a change-up on  his fast ball. He has physical pitching aptitudes. He   understands you and he can do pretty nearly what he wants to   do with a ball. This boy can pitch for the Pittsburgh Ball   Club the very minute he acquires control. Then, too, it may  be that he needs dependable poise. It can be true that he  gets nervous and wild under pressure. Most youngsters do.  He is now 20 and he has sufficient intelligence to come  fast. He must devote himself to spot pitching as I have   explained in my comments to Don Dangleis.    Green has been assigned to go with Dangleis to the  spot pitching target and he has been told not to bear down  until his instructions are changed. He has been admonished  very strongly to come to a fielding position quickly. His  present habit, in my judgment, doesn't bring him to a quick  fielding position. That he must practice in this spot pitching   period.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: February 22, 1954    FRED GREEN    Has to work on spot control at the pitching target along with Dangleis for 30 minutes each day, and he is to spot pitch with both the fast ball and curve ball. They must be instructed to keep the same delivery, although they are not to bear down on this scheduled practice work, nor or they to try to make the curve ball spin faster or slower or to give it greater or less velocity.    In so far as those points are concerned, they are to pay no attention to it. They are simply to get in the strike zone, - pitching at the center spot, nothing else.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: ANDY HANSEN March 8, 1954     To me he is a mystery man. Why he would be in the majors for six years and be regarded as a minor leaguer in the majors is not easy understandable. He doesn't have a GREAT fast ball. However, it is good enough. He has a fast curve that curves, not great, but good enough. He has no change-up whatever on his fast ball. That COULD be one explanation. He has a slow curve. It is a/really very good slow curve, - useable and all that, - useable if indeed he had good control of it.     The reason he is waived out of the league is due to the fact that he doesn't have a high-class extra pitch. He can get it and he will get if if he applies himself. He should to to the spot pitching mound, and work on control of his slow curve and really master some kind of a change on his fast ball. He need not be pitched in any scheduled game for sometime, but before we break camp he should be worked in a regular game.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: [[preprinted]] PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB [[/preprinted]]    June 9, 1954    MICKEY HARRINGTON    6'4" tall, 20 years of age. Got one girl, - only one. Health always good. Outfielder. Arm fair, not great. Must throw the ball down and he is acquired the habit already of throwing it too high. He is worth a chance.    Right hand hitter with power. Inclined to hit the ball in the air but his stride is so short that he can adjust himself to bad pitches easily. Can hit to left or right field under instruction.    I would follow him, but I would advise him to finish his college course. Has one more year. Don't go $4,000.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Ga.    HARRISON, SHIRLEY "RED"    Left hander, tender girl's hand, small, nice boy,  about 5' 9" tall and weighs about 160. Fair speed, fair curve.  No change-up on his curve ball that amounts to anything, but he   does change-up on his fast ball. This boy could be a cutey.  He should easily make his ability to meet his capacity, and that is   not said in any uncomplimentary manner. His capacity is not bad  and might be increased, - if you know what I mean. I do. The  remark may need explanation to be at all intelligent.    I would give this boy a chance. He is very  young, - only 18, and he has been out of high school for one year.    BB/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Ga.    HAYES, TOM    A 20 year old boy from Brooklyn. Has been in the  army two years. Very aggressive, very confident. In fact, he  knows he knows. He is not finished, but he has more stuff generally  than most boys you will run into. His fast ball has good  average major league speed, and his curve ball is better than the   average major league curve ball. He can learn a change-up on  his fast ball.    If this fellow's disposition is manageable and if he can  keep himself from becoming the team manager, now or later, (and  more likely now than later) then he would be worth fooling with.  I would like to sign him.    I had no talk with him about contract, - no references  to salary. A real effort should be made to sign this boy.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: CAL HOGUE March 8, 1954       This boy weighs 202 pounds. Very likely too much for him to carry. He would probably be better at 190. He has a curve ball, - a corker, and his fast ball is good enough. He has a slow curve but it would be better if it were slowed up. I don't think too much of his change-up on his fast ball and this pitch should challenge him. If he hopes to be great and really help Pittsburgh into a pennant, he must get a useable third pitch. I am anxious to find out about his effort to get it.         BRANCH RICKEY      BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.   OPERATING   Pittsburgh Baseball Club     April 2, 1954    HUELFER     I don't know whether he has very much stuff or not. He was hit very hard. Didn't show me any speed. He didn't show any speed but he has a variety of stuff. From what I saw, I wouldn't bet a dime on him.        BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: REPORT OF THE ST. JOHN CLUB AGAINST THETFORD-MINES IN A DOUBLE HEADER ON TUESDAY, JULY 20, 1954    DAVE JACOBS    Right hand hitting first baseman. 1953 with Bristol. He can run very well, arm alright, and his batting form is good enough. I see no reason why he should not hit. He might eventually go anywhere, - depending upon his hitting ability.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Hollywood, Cal.   June 15, 1954    Babbitt, Lee    18 years old. Finishes at San Diego High School this coming Friday, June 18th. Tom Downey's pet. Little eyes, set close together, but I think he is aggressive and cocky. About 6'3" tall, 180 pounds, right hander, fast ball good enough. Curve ball is a downer and it curves. Nothing really great, but usable. He has a change-up on his curve that is really a change-up, but he showed no control of it. He has no change-up on his fast ball, but he could acquire it, I am sure of that. He is a prospect and worth signing, and if the club had plenty of money, you could give him the $4,000, but that policy goes for all big, young fellows who can throw the ball fairly hard and wants to do it.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: REPORT ON THE WACO CLUB AS SEEN IN TWO GAMES, ONE ON JULY 24TH WITH THE CORPUS CHRISTI CLUB, AND THE OTHER WITH THE HARLINGEN CLUB ON JULY 26TH, 1954      REX BABCOCK    A perfectionist in the field. Very good runner, very good arm, very tight at the plate. If he could hit, he could play most anywhere. A good size boy.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: REPORT ON THE ST. JOHN CLUB AGAINST THETFORD-MINES IN A DOUBLE HEADER ON TUESDAY, JULY 20, 1954    PEDRO BALLESTER  He is no good in any way and should have his unconditional release.    REIDER AND BALLESTER  The St. John's club is very distinctive by making very few double plays, - by far the least of any in the league. It is surprising if they make any at all.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: July 2, 1954    LOUIS BASILE    Left hand throwing, left hand hitting boy, - but merely a boy. Very high-schoolish at bat with now power. This chap might grow up and show more strength. He is agile and full of effort and his batting form is acceptable. Arm good enough.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.  Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club    April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Georgia    MOORE, LAMAR     A big country husky, rough in every way. I would put him out in a C league and let him go to draft next year not higher than B.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.  Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club    April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Georgia    MORRIS, H. MILTON    Infielder, played third base this morning. He is mature. In fact, he is 21. Nothing startling about him. We probably need infielders and it may be that he may be useable to us in our C or D Leagues. I doubt if he is highly desirable in a Class B league this year, therefore, I suggest that you stand pat on your present offer. I told him why it is embarrassing and difficult to raise the salary offered. Unless he is better than what I have seen, I don't think he is worth a bonus.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: April 2, 1954    <u> NISEWONGER, JAMES B. </u>    Slim fellow, looks to be about 6'2" tall, weighs about 175. Has a good fast ball, straight overhand, and his curve looked very good. It is a downer. This boy is a nice boy. He has a good eye. His father is a part-time minister. Not a wealthy family.    I asked him "where do you think you should pitch next year?". "Just don't know right now", he replied. The boy returned in about five minutes and said "Denver.". He is going to be married in about three weeks. Has an older sister married.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.  Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club    April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Georgia    <u> PAGE </u>    I would sign him and put him in a league not above C, unless, indeed, the player were to impress me more in future training camp games.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.  Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club    April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Georgia    <u> PANKO, EMIL </u>    Arm good enough.    Have a look, - he surely can play at Burlington.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Hollywood, Cal.  June 16, 1954    <u> PASTORNICKY, ERNIE </u>    Right hander, about 6' tall, weighs about 170 pounds, wears glasses. Lives in New Jersey. Went to Seattle University because of the O'Briens'. Pitched for that team successfully. A little above side arm in all deliveries. Good control and a fairly good fast ball.    His curve ball is a Newcombe curve without Newcombe. Has almost as much velocity as his fast ball and could be effective. He showed me no control of it but I believe he would have control under other conditions. He knew he was on parade. This boy is 22 years of age.    Has a good pitching hand . but was highly nervous, breathing heavily continuously. I would have to work him again and perhaps a third time before I would be able to see him at his best.     He has no change-up on his fast ball, - none whatever. Has no change-up on his curve ball, - none whatever. His stride repeats and his stepping foot goes in the same spot every time.    It may be my fault in the point of suggestion or instruction, but if he has ANY aptitude, I don't know how to find it.    On the showing today, he would be worth a trial in a C or D League without any bonus whatever.    This may be high blasphemy to those who recommended him, but I cannot help it. This is my report this date.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.  Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club    April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Georgia    <u> PEARCE, EARNEST </u>    Agile, quick arm, and may be strong enough. Ordinary runner.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.  Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club    June 9, 1954    LAUREN PEPPER     23 years old, 5'-11 1/2" tall, 190 pounder, - rugged type. Mississippi Southern at Hattiesburg, Miss. Has won ten straight games in college this year, - a junior. In love, - wedding set for June 17th, both families approve. Girl is 19 years of age. No bad habits, has spent two years in the army. Not out of this country. Never touched alcoholic liquor. Non-smoker. Good boy. Father's a farmer, - has three sisters and two brothers. He is next to the youngest. "C" average. Another year of competition. Generally regarded as an All-American football player. Must meet inducement from that angle.    Fast ball good enough. Has two fast balls, which he is able to determine in advance. One generally defined as a slider. The other has more velocity, - almost overhand, - direct back spin. Curve ball so so. Has speed, - somewhat like Newcombe's. Has change-up on fast ball. Has too much velocity. He knows how to reduce it, but he changes delivery when he does. Must be placed where he can afford to be pitched this fall, when indicated. That will take some work. It can be very effective. His hand is big, has broad, thick fingers, - longer than my own and he can take the fast ball hand position without increasing the chance of loss of control. Fingering is good on all pitches and his delivery repeats. The stepping foot markes [sic] the same identical spot if velocity is the same. Over-steps a bit on the curve, but too late to tip anything off to coachers or batsmen. Change-up on curve ball his best pitch, - but showed poorest control. However, he was under pressure. Hes not been in bed for 24 hours and I worked him rather rapidly. He was poohed at the end. He has good control of four different pitches. Much more finished than most boys you see. He is the strikeout type.    It is a frank gamble on making him a bonus player. The offer of $15,000, payable in three years, and salary of $6000 guaranteed for 2 years good enough. Try to get him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Hollywood, Cal.  June 15, 1954  LATMAN  <u>BARRY LITMAN</u>  About 6'3" tall, 200 pounds, will be 18 shortly. Pitched on the Fairfax High School team in Los Angeles. Right hander, and almost a cross fire delivery which is natural. His stepping foot goes two feet further to the right than the ordinary right hand pitcher.    Fast ball is pretty good and this boy will get better as he goes along and his control should not be bad. Fine hands. Just right. His curve ball has velocity, not a great curve, but he could go with it.    This chap has unusual fingering. The ball, on both the fast and curve ball, hugs the socket, and his fingers are close together on the fast ball, but slightly separated on the curve, but not enough to hurt him. Also, the ball is unbalanced on both the curve and the fast ball, - but more on the curve, but his thumb even on the fast ball is more to the left than I have seen on any pitcher in sometime. He shouldn't be changed. Let him alone for the present.    He had no change-up on his fast ball and trying to get it, he comes up with an unusual pitch. The rotation is screwy in direction and the ball actually has somewhat the effect of a change-up curve. It could become a very unusual pitch. I hope he gets it, and he should get control of it. He has no change-up on his curve which is at all usable but he took to the thumb change-up curve like a duck to water.    I like this boy. His father is a furniture auctioneer. He has a good face, - rugged, - a strong athletic type. I like him and you should try your level best to sign him. He will make good somewhere, someday, with a BANG.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: ROBERT PURKEY February 23, 1954    A well-built right hander. Not a kid. An unusual  type of pitcher. He is a one ball pitcher, it might be said.  He throws a fast ball, - very good. He then varies the speed  on the fast ball and the ball dips and slides accordingly  and he can control the direction or effect. That makes him  a pitcher. In other words, he has varying velocities simply  because of effort. If the ball has a great deal of   velocity, it has a tendency to 'slide'. If he takes something   off of the effort, thus reducing the velocity, the ball then  dips or sinks and does it with great regularity. He has found  these variations in speeds and deflection to be the result of  nothing more than effort. He retains the same fingering,  the same delivery, and practically throws no curves and no   so-called changes on either the fast ball or the curve.  A very unusual pitching procedure indeed.    Bob has no curve, - nothing to speak of. He should  be turned over to Bill Burwell along with Curtis Raydon and  let Bill work the two boys together, if he agrees to it. If   not, then give them separate times.    Bob Purkey should go to the spot pitching target  to work only on the one pitch, which he is now undertaking,  viz, the change-up on his fast ball.    If Bill Burwell does not get anywhere with this  fellow, then I want him in a week and I will undertake to   give him a change of pace curve, - the thumb curve, starting  him at say 20 feet. If I am not available then this   week, in event it comes to that, then turn him over to Sukey,  and show this dictation to Sukey before he starts on him.  We must follow up on Purkey.     He is a deliberate cuss. His mind rules his body.  He would be a thinking pitcher, - intelligent beyond the  ordinary, I would say. He is worth camp attention and   should be pitched between now and April 1st with REGULARITY.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: ROBERT PURKEY  March 1, 1954    He is a better pitcher than I thought. He varies the pitches on his fast ball continuously.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: July 3, 1954      PYLE, RONALD    6'4" tall right hand pitcher from Duquoin, , Illinois. Son of old left hand pitcher Ewall Pyle. This boy will be 18 years of age this coming October. Has no speed to speak of, -- well below average. His regular curve ball is a curve. Nothing great, however, in defelection or velocity, -- just a curve, but he has control of both his fast ball and his regular curve, -- exceptionally good control of both.    He has a change-up on his curve ball and good control of that. It could be that wise use of the change-up curve and his fast ball would let him get by in a low league with his fast ball. He has a change-up on his fast ball or rather it is simply an old fashion slow ball. He has control of it.    His delivery on his regular stuff is very different from his delivery on his change-ups. In other words, he tips off the changes. The movement becomes slow at the finish.     In the olden days, you would not give the boy anything but a chance in a small league. Today you may have to pay him $500 for the chance. If he can get more money somewhere else, I would encourage him to take it.    His age and size and very unusual control make him a possibility for the majors.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: REPORT ON THE HUTCHINSON CLUB IN ONE GAME ON JULY 23, 1954 AGAINST THE   MUSKOGEE TEAM    FRANK RAMSEY    Rookie kid. Leave him at Hutchinson. This kid is an infielder   of good size. Wears glasses. Surely only an average runner   if that. I would guess him to be over 6' tall. Observed him in   only one game.      (LATER) Same Date    This boy might become a very fine hitter. His stride is short   and his position at the plate is good. The big end of the bat is   out and back and the big end stays quiet all the time. When he   becomes accustomed to a curve ball, he should hit.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: REPORT ON THE HUTCHINSON CLUB IN ONE GAME ON JULY 23, 1954 AGAINST THE MUSKOGEE TEAM.    CHARLES RE    A first baseman on option from the Cincinnati organization. Left hand hitter, left hand thrower. About 5'9" tall. Arm is o.k. Form at bat is good. Short stepper, - looks fast but might not be very fast. Fair power only. I don't know his age or experience, and I saw him in only one game. We might follow him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: REPORT ON THE ST. JOHN CLUB AGAINST THETFORD-MINES IN A DOUBLE HEADER ON TUESDAY, JULY 20, 1954      DAVE REIDER     A mama's boy, - in size and ability. He is not going  anywhere. Puny hitter, puny in every way. He is a nice boy. It was   his father's (Jack Reider) opinion that Dave would be the regular second  baseman for Pittsburgh in 1954. He would probably be the captain on  the Lucasville High School team (Lucasville High School is not accredited).        REIDER AND BALLESTER     The St. John's club is very distinctive by making very  few double plays, - by far the least of any in the league. It is  surprising if they make any at all.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: February 22, 1954    CURTIS REYDON    Good fast ball. Has two distinct fast balls, one he calls a straight ball and the other he calls his breaking fast ball. The breaking fast ball is thrown with the two fingers far apart and the straight ball with his fingers closer together.    He has no curve at all except when he throws directly overhand with his body at the finish of his delivery considerably inclined to the left. It is the only curve ball he has, and it is not really good enough.    I have turned him over to Bill Burwell for about a week, -- then I want to work with him again on a change-up curve ball, and I will also investigate his improvement on his regular curve. The boy seems intelligent and anxious to learn. He is the most inexperienced pitcher in the camp having had only one year of professional work. He is a definite prospect. Might become great.    BRANCH RICKEY      BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: REPORT ON THE ST. JOHN CLUB AGAINST THE THETFORD-MINES IN A DOUBLE HEADER ON TUESDAY, JULY 20, 1954    RIVERA    Right hand pitcher. Puerto Rican. Good living boy. Has overhand curve ball. At times it is exceptionally good, - does not have control of it. Fair fast ball, good enough, - control of that very ordinary. This chap has a change up on his fast ball and his delivery on this pitch is exactly the same as his fast ball. It is very good indeed, but he seldom gets it over. It would be a highly usable pitch for Rivera if he could get the ball over the plate. This fellow has a chance to go on up. Everything would depend on his poise and control.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; K-L
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.  Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club    April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Georgia    <u> LACKATOSH, DENTON </u>    Catcher, - cannot catch anything below his knees. Catches high balls alright.    Don't quit on catcher Lackatosh.    If he has the mark on his forehead he is Denton. I know nothing about the other one, but this one threw very quickly and he is strong. He will learn to catch.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: REPORT ON THE WACO CLUB AS SEEN IN TWO GAMES, ONE ON JULY 24TH WITH THE CORPUS CHRISTI CLUB, AND THE OTHER WITH THE HARLINGEN CLUB ON JULY 26, 1954    OSCAR RODRIGUEZ    In my book, he would make a good utility man for Hollywood or New Orleans or any team short of the majors.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.   operating   Pittsburgh baseball club April 2, 1954   Brunswick, Ga.    ROSELLO, DOMINGO     If he gets control, he might pitch anywhere in the world. He has a peach of a change-up on his fast ball, - doesn't show control of the curve, but the curve is good. He can pitch.      BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: REPORT ON THE ST. JOHN'S CLUB AGAINST THETFORD-MINES IN A DOUBLE HEADER ON TUESDAY, JULY 20, 1954    CHICO ROSSELLO    Big, tall Puerto Rican pitcher, - right hander. Agile as the dickens. "They" say he can really run and he looks it. He stands up at the plate good. I think he is a good prospect as a pitcher, but he ought to be looked at next spring as an outfielder or a first baseman or something. He is a prospect for something, that's a cinch. He has a dark complexion, - must surely have Ethiopian ancestry somewhere. Next spring I want this boy played in the outfield and to get a lot of machine hitting and also in the games, and further he must be taught a change-up on his fast ball and he must be made to use it. Still further, he must be pitched a lot in spring exhibition games.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Ga.    ROSELLO, DOMINGO     If he gets control, he might pitch anywhere in the world. He has a peach of a change-up on his fast ball, - doesn't show control of the curve, but the curve is good. He can pitch.      BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: REPORT ON THE ST. JOHN'S CLUB AGAINST THETFORD-MINES IN A DOUBLE HEADER ON TUESDAY, JULY 20, 1954    BOB RYAN    About 6' tall. Very fine arm. Left hand hitter with power. Shows no particular ambition to run bases. He would never steal a base. Might become sort of a Frank Thomas. He might, repeating, he might.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Georgia    <u> RYAN, ROBERT</u>    Fine arm, runs with the ball. Left hand hitter, and his form looks good. He might have power. He cannot run a lick, unless indeed he has a bad leg.    Has a great arm and looks alright up at the plate, but in this game today he certainly looked like anything but a good runner.        Br/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: May 11, 1954    <u> LEE, REGGIE </u>    6'2" tall, left hand pitcher. 22 years of age. Just out of the Marines. Fast ball good enough, - not great. Curve ball good enough, - not great. Has a change-up curve. Pretty good control of it. Has change-up on his fast ball and will get good control of it and it will become an effective pitch. Nice boy.    Delivery can repeat on all pitches, but on his change-ups, he almost has the habit of letting up on his delivery. He can give it some force when he thinks about it. With men on bases, he has a tendency to look at the base runner when he starts his delivery. That is bad and it will take some time to correct it.    Doesn't drink and appears to be a boy of good physical condition and of good health.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Georgia    <u>SANCHEZ, ROBERTO</u>    Quick, alert, active, good body control, and arm good enough considering his quickness.            BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: REPORT ON THE WACO CLUB AS SEEN IN TWO GAMES, ONE ON JULY 24TH WITH  THE CORPUS CHRISTI CLUB, AND THE OTHER WITH THE HARLINGEN CLUB ON JULY, 26, 1954    ROBERTO SANCHEZ  A little fellow, not over 150 pounds. Can run pretty good,  wonderful arm, great fielder, and plenty of guts. Stands up  to the plate well, in fact, hugs the plate. Might become a  very good hitter, and with surprising power. I have no doubt  that he would make corking shortstop for New Orleans in 1955.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: ROGER SAWYER July 26, 1954    CHANGE-UPS THROWN    1 For strike - not hit at  2 " " " " "  3 [*"*] " " " "  4 Popped to second base  5 For strike - not hit at  6 Strike and not struck at  7 Popped to third base  8 Strike and not struck at  9 Called a ball  10 Strike - struck at and missed  11 Ball - high, wide, and outside  *12 High - called a ball  13 High - called a ball  14 Strike - not hit at  15 High - a ball - a bad pitch  *16 Ball - outside  *17 Ball - inside  18 Low pitch, but hit for long foul   1[*9*] Right through the middle, - easy  grounder to the 3rd baseman.  20 High - a ball  *21 Low - a ball  *22 Inside, - a close pitch, - ball.  23 Through the middle, a strike, - not hit at.  24 High - ball.    *12 - Wont pitch with two strikes.  *16 - Looks like he is afraid to throw the change.  *17 - Looks like he is afraid to get it over.  *21 - Working on the first pitch all the time.  *22 - Thrown with one ball and no strikes    SAWYER MUST THROW HIS CHANGE-UP ON HIS FAST BALL

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: REPORT ON THE WACO CLUB AS SEEN IN TWO GAMES, ONE ON JULY 24TH WITH THE CORPUS CHRISTI CLUB, AND THE OTHER WITH THE HARLINGEN CLUB ON JULY 26, 1954.    ROGER SAWYER  Plenty of stuff, left hander.  (1) He must keep his curve ball lower to right handers,   overhanded, but he must throw it lower. He pitches   his curve generally above the waist line. All  wrong.    (2) He is a thrower. Unless he pitches change-ups, they  will knock his block off, - one after another. He  will not throw his change-up on his fast ball. He  must use it. Paepke doesn't use his change-up at  all. He is pitched diametrically wrong.    (3) In this game against Harlingen, after they had scored  four runs, he threw his first three change-ups on   his fast ball and all three were over the plate and  not struck at.    Change-up with two strikes a good pitch very frequently.  Jack Paepke will never call it. Sawyer never holds anyone  on first. Either has no move or pays no attention.  Usually Paepke asks for the change-up on the first pitch.  He needs to learn the value of the change-up pitch on his fast  ball. If Jack Paepke would catch a game where Sawyer would  throw every single pitch a change-up on the fast ball, it would  be valuable to Paepke.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: SAWYER, ROGER (ON NEW ORLEANS ROSTER AT PRESENT)  Home: 8 Eagle Street  Mt. Morris, N.Y.    Date of Birth: October 31, 1934    Position: Pitcher  Height: 6'  Weight: 172  Bats: Left  Throws: Left    YEAR CLUB LEAGUE CLASS G W L IP H R BB SO SHO ERA  1954 Waco Big State B 24 14 6 181 137 79 60 135  1954 Williamsport Eastern A 9 1 6 60 57 [??] 28 [??] 24 35

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: SCHULTZ, DONALD M (NOW ON NEW ORLEANS ROSTER)  Home: Burlington, N.C.  Born: Rockford, Illinois  Date of Birth: July 22, 1930    Position Pitcher  Height: 6'3''  Weight: 180  Bats: Left  Throws: Right    YEAR CLUB CLASS G W L IP H R BB SO ERA  1954 Burlington Carolina State B 32 17 11 235 205 88 76 178*    *League Record for 1954      Married Burlington, N.C. girl whom he met last season  and now resides there.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Ga.    <u> MALCOLM, CHARLES B. </u>    This fellow can become a very fine pitcher. He should be in a very small league. With control, he can pitch anywhere. About 6'2" tall, and weighs about 195. It will be a mistake if they send him too high.    I had a talk with this boy and paved the way for him to go to a small league and that is really where he belongs, - not above Class C. He might be promoted next year.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: ROBERT DUFFY SCHULTZ February 23, 1954      Left hander, 29 years old, got a lot of stuff.  Good fast ball and a good curve, inclined to press.    I would say that this boy's troubles for some  years past in the major league is pressing, - that is to say,  he realizes, for example, that he is in the major league;  that he simply has to make good, so he tries to make every  pitch his very best; it must be great. He has in mind  that the batter must not hit any of his pitches. Whether  he knows it or not, he evidently has in mind striking him  out. He doesn't want them to touch the ball.    I don't believe it has ever occured to him that  a pitcher can be in the majors simply because he offers a  problem to the batsmen in the field of timing. In other  words, he is what is commonly called a 'stuff' pitcher.  He is major league, if at all, simply because he is tough  to hit in the vertical plane. The idea of getting men off  stride is not an objective to him. Undoubtedly in his  pitching experience he has occasionally thrown the slow  curve ball. However, I have a doubt that he has ever used  that pitch very much.    He is not an artist pitcher, - a finished  technician, in any sense of the word. He is a 'throw it  by 'em' pitcher and inclined to pitch too fast and really  to 'press' all the time. He would be great against teams  of ordinary hitters and would be out of this world against  inexperienced batsmen. I can imagine him being the strike  out king of the baseball world, for example, in a class C or  D league, but it is understandable to me with his pitching  disposition, - temperment, - or whatever you want to call  it that he walks so many men in the majors. He has no  major league orientation whatever. He is a complete stranger  when placed in unusual circumstances.    He has a reputation of careless habits but I believe  the boy is now very serious, would give a great deal to make  good. I don't know if it means anything to anyone else  that I wish he had some sort of philosopher attitude  toward his work. By that, I mean, he has none of it. He  might become a pithcer in the majors. He might, but he has  to come to a quiet, deliberate thinking performance.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: ROBERT DUFFY SCHULTZ (Continued) February 23, 1954    If after he gets a signal from the catcher he were to say to himself, "a thousand and one" or some such sort of foolishness or may be good sense, would help.    Send him to the spot pitching target along with Urquhart and give the two boys 30 minutes, and Bob is to use his part of that time in acquiring an effective change of speed pitch off his fast ball.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: ROBERT DUFFY SCHULTZ February 23, 1954    Left hander, 29 years old, got a lot of stuff. Good fast ball and a good curve, inclined to press.    I would say that this boy's troubles for some years past in the major league is pressing, - that is to say, he realizes, for example, that he is in the major league; that he simply has to make good, so he tries to make every pitch his very best; it must be great. He has in mind that the batter must not hit any of his pitches. Whether he knows it or not, he evidently has in mind striking him out. He doesn't want them to touch the ball.    I don't believe it has ever occurred to him that a pitcher can be in the majors simply because he offers a problem to the batsmen in the field of timing, In other words, he is what is commonly called a 'stuff' pitcher. He is major league, if at all, simply because he is tough to hit in the vertical plane. The idea of getting men off stride is not an objective to him. Undoubtedly in his pitching experience he has occasionally thrown the slow curve ball. However, I have a doubt that he has ever used that pitch very much.    He is not an artistic pitcher, - a finished technician, in any sense of the word. He is a 'throw it by 'em' pitcher and inclined to pitch too fast and really to 'press' all the time. He would be great against teams of ordinary hitters and would be out of this world against inexperienced batsmen. I can imagine him being the strike out king of the baseball world, for example, in a Class C or D league, but it is understandable to me with his pitching disposition, - temperament, - or whatever you want to call it that he walks so many men in the majors. He has no major league orientation whatsoever. He is a complete stranger when placed in unusual circumstances.    He has a reputation of careless habits but I believe the boy is now very serious, would give a great deal to make good. I don't know if it means anything to anyone else that I wish he had some sort of philosopher attitude toward his work. By that, I mean, he has none of it. He might become a pitcher in the majors. He might, but he has to come to a quiet, deliberate thinking performance.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: ROBERT DUFFY SCHULTZ (Continued) February 23, 1954    If after he gets a signal from the catcher he were to say to  himself, "a thousand and one" or some such sort of foolishness,  or may be good sense, would help.    Send him to the spot pitching target along with  Urquhart and give the two boys 30 minutes, and Bob is  to use his part of that time in acquiring an effective change of speed pitch off his fast ball.      BRANCH RICKEY              BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: RONNIE SHEETS March 8, 1954      This boy has poise and I am sure, intelligent.  His control is good, curve ball is alright. He has  a dandy slow curve but lacks control of it. Ronnie's  change up on his fast ball has too much speed. He  must reduce it and not only that he must control it.  He really doesn't have any useable change-up on his fast  ball. He should go to the spot pitching mound and work  on both changes. Keep him here in this camp until I  work him again, - four or five days hence.    BRANCH RICKEY  BR/b          BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: REPORT ON THE ST. JOHN'S CLUB AGAINST THETFORD-MINES IN A DOUBLE HEADER  ON TUESDAY, JULY 20, 1954    RAY SMALLWOOD  Well built boy. Looks like he can run and throw good  enough. This boy comes from Buffalo. Right hand hitter, - stands up  at the plate alright. He is very young, girlish, and an effeminate  negro. He will get married if and when the girl proposes.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: SMITH, JACK LESLIE (NOW ON WACO ROSTER)  Home: Eugene, Oregon  Date of Birth: September 22, 1930  Position: Center  Height: 5'11''  Weight: 195  Bats: R  Throws: R    YEAR LEAGUE CLUB CLASS G AB R H BB SO RBI AVE  1952 Big State Waco B 86 315 20 81 31 53 29 .257  Break Down on Total Bases of 99  2B 3B HR  10 1 2    First year boy - University of Oregon graduate  WAS IN ARMED SERVICES IN 1953 AND 1954

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: REPORT ON THE ST. JOHN'S CLUB AGAINST THE THETFORD-MINES IN A DOUBLE HEADER ON TUESDAY, JULY 20, 1954    MIKE SOLOMKO  Not a big boy, but well built. Stands up to the plate in a good fashion,   Doesn't pull at all. Right hand hitter, fair runner, arm looks adequate. He will bear watching.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: Hollywood, Cal.  June 15, 1954  WAYNE SPERRY    6'7" tall. This is June 15th and this boy will  be 18 years of age this coming August 27th. This boy has  the best fast ball I have seen in a long time, and his  control is good. His fingering on all pitches is perfect.  His curve ball curves, and he has control of that too.  He has no change-up on the fast ball or the curve. He has  never tried it, but he will get both. He is a definite  prospect and highly desirable. He is worth whatever it  takes, - he really is and he has the best talking manner  of any boy I have ever been a bout in a long time. If he  were 47 years of age, he couldn't be more sincere about  himself, and a bout his work, and a bout everything.  I would call it a red letter day for all of us if you should  sign him up. He is not as finished as Drysdale, not at  all, but he is more in the direction of power pitching than  Drysdale is. Drysdale has more artistry and more technical  perfection. This boy is in the rough.    He is worth a full year's work of any scout to get  him.    BRANCH RICKEY    [*Signed with White Sox.*]

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Ga.     STAIR, HAROLD  He could get by with his arm if everything else is good.   He should go to a small league this year.   BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.  Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club    June 9, 1954    <u> BILL MAZEROSKI </u>    The kid has a good arm. Looks to be 6'0" tall, 175 pounds, and is 17 years of age. He can throw sidearm, underhand, and overhand. Has good body control. From a fielding standpoint, he is definitely a prospect.    Hardly strides at all. Wonderful. Good power, not great, but good. Changes of speed should not bother him very much and eventually it will never bother him. What he will do with the curve ball with deflections, I don't know. He hits at bad balls as all kids do, but he plays the ball well whenever pitched.    I would definitely consider him a prospect.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: DONALD URGUHART February 23, 1954      A big, powerful right hander, red headed fellow about 6'3" tall and weighs about 185. He can throw hard. His curve is not great but pretty good. Throws a change-up on his fast ball, - o.k. Throws a change-up on his curve but has no control of it. The boy is intelligent, - knows what it is all about. I can see him in the major leagues. He is good type, - physically and mentally.    Rex will give him work on spot pitching on the slow curve ball, and he must divide his weight on delivery. He hangs his right foot in air. He must bring it down. That is the biggest job this boy has in front of him. He must work on it.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.  Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club    April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Georgia    MEEKINS, DENIS    He hit, but did not look like a hitter.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: REPORT ON THE HUTCHINSON CLUB IN ONE GAME ON JULY 23, 1954 AGAINST THE MUSKOGEE TEAM.    TOM WATSON    A second baseman, - formerly a first base. Fast runner, fair arm. I believe this boy is a good hitter, - not a fly ball hitter and therefore not a home run hitter. He doen???????t have fence power. He should be protected from the draft.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: July 2, 1954    [underline] MIKE WELTMAN [end underline]  [L.H. HITTER] R.H. HITTER    Jewish boy from Brooklyn, age 19, about 5'11" tall, and weighs about 170. Good arm, - knows how to throw from the outfield. Runs well. Good running form, - easily average, if not above average runner. I like this chap at the plate. He swings as though he meant to hit a ball a "fur piece". He [ha]s what I call a wrist finish. I think he would have an extra base hitting record in baseball.    Don't know anything about his background, habits, or disposition, but for one look on the field, I would call him a definite prospect and this is of interest to our club because the outfield is the department in which we have very inadequate prospective strength. Weltman might be a "quick[y]IE.    The most impressive this about Weltman is his batting form, - stance, stride, swing, arm position, - indeed his form is fairly perfect.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Ga.    WOODS, HAROLD G.    Right hander. I see no reason why Woods should not have control. He has good speed. Woods has a change-up on his fast ball and I think it is a good one.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: April 2, 1954  Brunswick, Georgia    ZASKI, REGIS    Second baseman. Small, slight, cubbish, but shows signs. Looks tuburcular.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: July 2, 1954    REGIS ZASKI    Already signed up. An infielder. Not too big, but is aggressive type. Arm looks to be good enough and he slashes into the ball with a sharp finish. Left hander. Form is good.    If this boy is a good runner, he might be worthwhile.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: Dublin-Vidalia Game  Vidalia, Georgia  July 19, 1955    ARENT   First baseman. In the field he looks awkward,-cubbish. I would say that he is weak on ground balls.     (LATER)   He simply cannot field.      This boy is making a record of batting power. If Arent is draftable, then he should be moved at least to Class B. His disposition will be discussed later.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: JALAPA VS AZTECAS AT SECURITY STADIUM, MEXICO CITY, ON  NOVEMBER 17TH AND NOVEMBER 19TH, 1955.    ARRIETA    Right fielder on the Jalapa club. Left hand hitter and  can really hit. Looks like a fine batsman. He looked to  be 35 years of age. Habits not good.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: MEXICO CITY REDS VS. PUEBLO AT SECURITY STADIUM, MEXICO  CITY, NOVEMBER 26TH, 1955.    Auaiz    First baseman. Old timer. No good.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: MAZATLAN VS CULIACAN AT CULIACAN, MEXICO,  DECEMBER 8, 1955.    AZAMAR    Culiacan pitcher.    A little left hander. Very ordinary speed, a twister curve, good control. I wouldn't give him a dime to sign even if he were a free agent.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: SALINAS-CHANNEL CITIES' GAMES OF MAY 17TH and MAY 18TH, 1955 AT SALINAS, CALIFORNIA    BABBITT, LEE    In the two innings he worked, this tall right hander showed no speed at all, a fair curve and no control of anything. If this is Babbitt, then you can lose nothing by giving him his unconditional release immediately. But surely this is not the Babbitt I worked out a year ago.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: April 28, 1955    LINCOLN-WICHITA GAME AT LINCOLN, NEBRASKA    BABCOCK, REX    The boy is a play maker, - a good journeyman ball player, who in all probability has reached his limit in Class A.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1951; A-F
Transcription: LINCOLN-COLORADO SPRINGS GAME OF MAY 16, 1955 AT COLORADO SPRINGS    BABCOCK, REX    Second baseman. Nice boy. Looks like a corking  good fielder. If he can hit, I am still a pretty good hitter  at 73.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 18, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA BETWEEN CIENFUEGOS AND HAVANA    LOREN BABE appeared in the last two or three innings for Cienfuegos at second base. He came to bat twice and looked terrible both times. Most certainly he is not aggressive in any respect. He does not run out his hits, and if he can play second base anywhere, then I can play it successfully everywhere. I would call him a very average runner, if that. The best thing he can do is when he has a bat in his hands. That may not be good English, but it is a good statement of fact. He won't help Hollywood unless he is played in the outfield, -- possibly at third base, -- I don't know about that. Hollywood bought him conditionally from Toronto for $1500.00 down and $13,500.00 if the player is retained. He would be returned right now if the rule permitted the return. If it were to do over again, I would not give the $1500.00 for him on an outright assignment.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: LINCOLN-COLORADO SPRINGS GAME OF MAY 16, 1955 AT COLORADO SPRINGS    Adkins, Ted    The Western League is probably his top limit. He   might go into the money if he would hit .300 in any league other   than the Western League. Four home runs were hit in this   Colorado Springs park tonight by ordinary power hitters and all   these in the first six innings, - and three of the four were   over the centerfield fence, 10' high and 400 feet distant.   Hall hit one and Bell the other and a Colorado Springs puny hitter   the third one. This, together with the Pueblo and Sioux City   parks, make the Western League averages fairly meaningless.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: BARBAO, KENNETH M. (ON NEW ORLEANS ROSTER AT PRESENT TIME)  Home: Orchard Place Plan   Donora, Pa.   Date of Birth: January 14, 1932  Position: PITCHER  Height: 6'  Weight: 180  Bats Right  Throws Right    YEAR CLUB LEAGUE G W L IP H R BB SO SHO ERA  1952 Charleston Sally 29 9 10 181 176 78 91 118 1 2.69  1953 ) IN ARMED SERVICES  1954 )     1951 - Pitched at Salisbury of the N. C. State League  1952 - " " Waco of the Big State League

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: February 18, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    KEN BARBAO    This boy is now 21. His fast ball is good, - not one of the great  fast balls, but good enough, and his curve ball impresses me as  it did in 1951 and 1952. Good enough when it breaks, but it  does not break all the time. He still needs regularity in this  pitch. His change up on his fast ball is perfect and his  delivery is good. He throws a change up curve ball and it is  good, and he throws another change of speed on his curve ball by  placing the forefinger point on the ball. I doubt if he needs  the pitch, but I would go with this boy on his judgement in his  selection of pitches.    He is mentally sound pitcher-wise, - knows what he is doing and  is, in my judgement, just as good a prospect as I believed he was  in 1951, better, because he is two years older.    I discussed with him the possibility of his needing an additional  distinctive pitch, for example, a knuckle ball. He told me  he was throwing it some and he thought he had fair control of it.  He then demonstrated the pitch to me and he does have control of  it. It is not a velocity pitch at all, but with greater delivery  effort the ball might have greater speed, and in any event might  have amore effective result. I believe he has nothing whatever  to lose by perfecting the knuckle ball and adding it to his  repertoire. This chap certainly has a chance to go all the way.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: JALAPA VS AZTECAS AT SECURITY STADIUM, MEXICO CITY, ON  NOVEMBER 17TH AND NOVEMBER 19TH, 1955.    BARBON    Colored first baseman-outfielder.    Cuban.    Home run hitter. About 27 years of age. Don't believe he  is ever going anywhere.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES    The left fielder is    BARO One of Bob Maduro's boys. He can field, can throw pretty good, not old, and might come to be a pretty good hitter. If he develops, Cincinnati will get him.    MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 20, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND HAVANA    BARO, the left fielder, is fast, - well above average in running speed.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: WILLIAMSPORT-BINGHAMTON GAME AT WILLIAMSPORT, PA. ON JULY  9, 1955    BARONE, DICK    Impresses me as above average runner. He has short legs and  they move fast. His running speed could easily be over-  estimated. I would want to see him in some races.    He can really throw, and he is quick, well reflexed, and   aggressive. The boy looks like quite a hitter except for  one thing. He very definitely over-strides, - more than  any other hitter on the Williamsport club. Indeed, it is a   pronounced over-stride. It could possibly be a fault  sufficient to remove him from any serious consideration. I  don't know about that. I must see more of him. This  observation compares with such a statement as saying a boy  has the build to be a great hitter, but he is stone blind.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: July 11, 1955  Burlington, N.C.    Bartirome, Tony    Tony is having an unfortunate year. Charley horse in  his right leg, pulled tendon in his left one, sprained  ankle, etc., etc.    If he finishes the season hitting .350 or better at  Burlington, he probably could help a AA club next  year and should have draft protection accordingly.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: Burlington-Greensboro Game   Burlington, N.C.   July 20, 1955      BARTIROME, TONY     A puny hitter. He never will go major. He should go to the draft in A league, - possibly AA.       B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: Poza Rica vs Pueblo at Pueblo, Mexico, on November 17th and 18th, 1955 and Poza Rica vs Mexico City Reds at Poza Rica on December 1st and 2nd.      JIM BAUMER    So so ball player in every aspect. Not a great runner, not a great arm, not a great hitter, - not a great anything. Apparently a nice boy with a lovely wife. At his very best he might play utility at Hollywood. Everything counted, it would be a toss up between Baumer and Lohrke. If I had to be pushed off the boat to make a choice right now, I would take Lohrke.          B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: April 23, 1955      HOLLYWOOD-SAN FRANCISCO DOUBLE HEADER AT SAN FRANCISCO, CAL.      BEARDEN, a pitcher on the San Francisco club, has good control. I believe the only way to beat him, - at least the best direction to go toward beating him, is to hit his two and none and three and one pitches. He has no speed on his so-called fast ball and he throws change-ups almost all the time. I was not sitting behind him and it looked like a knuckle ball. When Bearden is in the hole, he spits on the ball, - also into his hand. It may be through nervousness that he does this, but it may be something else. In any event, after each spitting fracas he throws what looks to be, from a side position, a knuckle ball. It could be something else.    Four times in the seven inning game in San Francisco, Hollywood batsmen had the call three and two, - I mean four times when the next pitch was very bad (in each case a very low pitch) and on each occasion the batter either struck out (three times) or fouled out, - thus trading off a base on balls. Three of these four times there was a runner on first base. It could have meant quite a little if the base on balls had been accepted.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA,  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES    The first baseman is a left hand hitting youngster by the name of    BECQUER He can run and he can field and he has enough power.  It is my guess, at the present time, that he is not a high average  hitter. He looks very youthful. I would like to own his contract.  He blongs to Washington.    MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 20, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND HAVANA.    BECQUER has plenty of power.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: Burlington-Greensboro Club  Burlington, N.C.  July 20, 1955    ADUBATO, ROBERT (Greensboro Pitcher)    About 6'6" tall, 215 pounds, wears glasses, but he can really throw the ball hard. Didn't show much of a curve and no control out of what he did have. He became terribly wild in the second inning and threw the ball everywhere. I believe this fellow would come to have control.    B.R.
