Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: March 7, 1955   Fort Myers, Fla.    BILL BELL     Bill has great speed and a fine curve and a change up on his fast ball, and a fair, only fair, change up on his curve ball. He has two problems, - one, his control, of course, and the other his pitching knowledge. What to throw and when to throw it and where to throw it. My judgement is that he doesn't know his letters on the general subject. He is, at the present time, a thrower and not a pitcher and under stress or pressure, he would have no pitching sense at all. Physically and technically so far as his stuff is concerned, he is a major leaguer right now. But he is not ready to help the Pirates. He needs target work.      The boy, by nature and habit, comes set fast and quick. He should vary this movement by coming slow after he passes his letters and pitch on the continuous motion. He understands it and can get it if he will practice.     His delivery finishes him out of position to field and he can straighten up but he can't think to do it unless he is told on each individual pitch in advance. This is going to be one of his toughest jobs, - to straighten up after delivery. He is agile enough, and has good body control, but he is far from being as good a fielder as he might be.       BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: LINCOLN - COLORADO SPRINGS GAME OF MAY 16, 1955 AT COLORADO SPRINGS, COLO.    BELL, BILL    Pitcher in tonight's game. He is certainly a prospect but he COULD be as far away as Friend. He has wonderful stuff, - great speed, a great curve, and change-ups. He has everything, but he lacks control of everything, and when he senses his lack of control, HE LETS UP. That is Bill Bell's greatest fault. When he bears down, he is unhittable, but wild. I have admonished him repeatedly not to let up, but he does that very thing invariably. Whenever this fellow gets control of his stuff, he is a real major leaguer. That arrival may be some years away. On this May 16, 1955, I would risk the decision to place him this fall on the Hollywood club where he will be subject to draft. Let 'em draft him at $15,000. This early decision is subject to change. We will watch him during the year.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: WILLIAMSPORT-BINGHAMTON GAME AT WILLIAMSPORT, PA. ON JULY 9, 1955    BELLA (Binghamton)    Right hand hitting outfielder. Looks to be better than 6' tall and will weigh around 190 pounds. Age unknown. He has power and he can run pretty good. Arm probably average, maybe better. I did not see it good enough.    Highly nervous. Has a complete and original set of manual mannerisms. I believe that good change-ups would upset him. He might be followed.         B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN, PUERTO RICO, ON JANUARY 25, 1955.    BILKO, the first baseman, who was with the Cardinals and Cubs. Good hitter and with great power. That's all.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: June 25, 1955  BINDER, FRED   6'1" tall, will be 19 in September. Right hander.   Graduated from high school last year and goes to Duquesne University. This boy has a good fast ball, very live. He throws a sidearm pitch which is especially good. His curve ball is no good. He throws a change of pace with a three finger kunckle position and he has remarkable control of it, - that is to say, much better control than most boys have of a kunckle ball. He must learn a change up on his curve, or rather he must learn a curve. I believe he can do it. He is worth attention and if he can be signed for 1956, that would be great.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: WILLIAMSPORT-BINGHAMPTON GAME AT WILLIAMSPORT, PA. ON JULY 9, 1955    BLANCHARD, JOHN (Binghamton)    Very tall, left hand hitting catcher. Has power at the plate. Can hit fast pitching. Breaking stuff seems to bother him very much and I believe changes would tie him up. however, his form is good, and an additional look could easily change my opinion about this fellow. He is worth following.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 18, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA BETWEEN CIANFUEGOS AND HAVANA    At shortstop was a boy who can run, - run like all-get-out. His name is    BLASINGAME He also belongs to the St. Louis Cardinals. He can throw and quickly. Looks to have good hands. is all over the place all the time. Stands up to the plate well, hits no bad balls, and I imagine that he has occasionally some power. he is no set up at the plate. A left hand hitter, and in all probability a major leaguer. I liked him very much.    MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 20, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA BETWEEN MARIANAO AND HAVANA.    I was more impressed than ever with the fielding skills tonight of BLASINGAME AND BOYER.    BLASINGAME is a pest at the plate. He should become a good base on balls man, and his power is simple. He is no puny in any respect, and he makes the most of his speed and when you say that you are saying something, because he has a lot of it, and he certainly knows how to use it.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: July 11, 1955  Burlington, N. C.    BOHUNY, BRUCE    Tall left hander, - a gentleman by instinct.    He has a great fast ball. it not only has velocity, but it has 'shoot'. That is all he has got, and not good control of that.     He might get a change up on his fast ball. he needs to work on it at 45 feet and it will be a semi-palm ball when he gets it. He has darn little aptitude.    He should go tot he knuckle ball or indeed any third pitch which he might come to have control of. He should work constantly with Stricklin on the knuckle ball. Stricklin is absolute master of the knuckle ball, - in control and lack of rotation. In fact, if anything, he doesn't have enough circular movement on this knuckle ball. It should even rotate more to be more effective. Stricklin, I am talking about. Stricklin might teach the knuckle ball to Bohuny.    Bohuny can go major. He could go on his fast ball alone. We perhaps do not have any one in Pittsburgh organization who can throw the ball as hard as Bohuny, unless indeed it is Paul Martin. That is something to start with but it is too bad he doesn't have anything to go with it. That's too bad.    In this league (Cardina) right now, he should just throw the fast ball through the middle. If he has good control of it nobody will hurt him much. he ought to win.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    BONE, WILLIAM (Albany Shortstop)  No power whatever at the plate. Strong arm.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 18, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA BETWEEN CIENFUEGOS AND HAVANA    At third base, I saw the best ball player on first impression that I have seen in many a day.    BOYER by name. He can run with very deceptive speed and he does run. Never loafs. He has big hands, and he knows what to do with them. He has a quick arm, - a very fine arm from his elbow on down. Every body muscle is under control. He could play shortstop and certainly would be a corking second baseman. Indeed, I think Boyer could play anywhere and I mean ANYWHERE. His position at the plate is not exactly orthodox, but the movement of his left leg (he is a right hand hitter) enables him to time the pitch. It is not an exaggerated hoisting of the leg like Ott, but there is enough pause in the lift to enable him to adjust himself to the change of speed pitching. He may have some weakness at the plate, but he should not have any and eventually he will not any. He drives the ball with great power, and he is not a fly ball hitter. He is a line drive hitter deluxe. The newspapermen down here are raving about the outfielder Virdon, saying, in effect, unanimously, that Virdon is the greatest player ever to be in Cuba, etc. etc. I will take Boyer. he must be 6' tall and weigh 185 pounds. I was not close enough to him to risk positive accuracy on his vital statistics, but every inch of him and every pound of him is a professional player of great promise.    In RAND, BLASINGAME, VIRDON, AND BOYER, the Cardinals have splendid prospective additional strength. It is my opinion that if the Cardinals had a pitching staff like the Giants or the Braves or the Dodgers or the Phillies, that club would run away with the pennant in 1955, - certainly in 1956. If I were the owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, this is the time where I would again offer $400,000 for a great pitcher as I did at a certain time when I had the Brooklyn club. If the Cardinals get pitching, the National League can look out for a St. Louis pennant winning club, - may be not this coming season, but certainly the following year.    MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 20, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA BETWEEN MARIANAO AND HAVANA.    I was more impressed than ever with the fielding skills tonight of BLASINGAME AND BOYER.    BOYER might not hit for too high an average for the Cardinals in 1955, but eventually he will hit in the major leagues and with fine power. He is made to order for Forbes Field. He is definitely a line drive hitter, and with plenty of power.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: Burlington-Greensboro Game  Burlington, N.C.  July 20, 1955    Albanese (Greensboro Pitcher)  Tremendously big right hand pitcher with lot of 'swift', and he   looks to have a pretty good curve. He should strike out a lot of   Class B hitters. He showed nervousness.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: St. Louis-New York Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis, Mo.    BOYER (St. Louis Infielder)    This boy is not orientated. There is nothing  he cannot do, but he is not hitting. The right hander's  curve ball and the change-ups have apparently got  him down. Just now, he looks a little like Clemente on  a right hander's side arm curve ball, but good change-ups  confuse Boyer very much.    [*He will [feel pla?t?].*]  B.R.  [*Eventually -*]    [*BR*]

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 18, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA BETWEEN CIENFUEGOS AND HAVANA.  In right field is a negro named  BOYD A left hand hitter. this boy can run and he looks to be a good hitter. I am sure he is a good hitter. He cannot throw. [very good.] In fact, he has a weak arm. Why he would be playing in the outfield, I don't know. Sure the only place this boy could play acceptably in AAA or higher, or even lower, is at first base. I would like to have him at Hollywood or on any AAA club. At the present time, I believe he could beat anything we have at first base in Pittsburgh. However, I would not claim him on waivers, considering the prospective strength we may have at first base.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: [1955]    ELVIN BOYD - Came from Fullerton. Right hander. 6' 1", may be about 180 pounds. His fast ball is under the average velocity of the other boys I have worked out here. Pretty good control of it. His curve ball is so-so, but not as good control of it by any means as he has of his fast ball. Quite a mistrustful chap, serious minded and leaves the changeup on the fast ball on the very first pitch and I mean he had it. Also acquires the changeup on his curve ball immediately. He will have control of that too. The chap could be a pitcher fairly quickly, and a good one if he had more speed. This last sentence probably requires explination. I simply mean that the boy can ac-quire four distinctly different pitches right off the bat. I do not think his force, strength, stuff stands out enough to put him in the positively great class. I wish some of these other bohunks could learn different pitches like Elvin can. I would not put a bonus into him and probably he can not be gotten without it. I would follow him up. This chap could fool you or me or anybody. He is not at all unimpressive and he does have a chance. His aptitudes save him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA,  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES    BRAGAN is very unpopular here. He has been put out of the games by the umpires very often. The umpire called a questionable strike on Hatten tonight. Bragan never moved a single step from his coaching position at third base, but must have said something or other, and the umpire put him out of the game again.    Dr. Sanguily and Mochy and Bob Maduro all tell me that this is not an unusual treatment of Bragan by the umpires. I will find out what Bragan said.    Dr. Sanguily believes that Bragan is the greatest manager in the world, but agrees fully with me about the boy's self-sufficiency. Bragan has never communicated directly or indirectly this year with President Sanguily, nor with anyone else. I told Dr. Sanguily in 12 years relationship with Bragan, having made him manager at Fort Worth and then at Hollywood, that never one single time has he ever written me a letter on any subject whatever or voluntarily offered information about his own players or players on other clubs or free agents. Dr. Sanguily told me that he thought Bragan was disappointed because he had not been given heretofore the Pittsburgh job; that Bragan had expressed himself as determined to quit if he stayed in the minors more than another year. Doubtless Bobby has heard rumors about being considered by Roy Hamey and these rumors may have been highly exaggerated.    He is certainly an entirely different person off the field than on it. His clowning, buffoonery, and physical indulgence in ridicule cause much comment hereabouts. None of this shows up at all except when he is in uniform. He is full of decision, deliberate and instant in action., and every detail of his work is important. He handles men, is solicitous about their welfare and health, associates socially and closely too with the players and their families, and yet maintains a strict discipline and holds the respect of every player. As a tactician, he is sound, with enough daring to make his management unpredictable. He is no respector of persons, - Hornsbyesque in no respect for persons. They are all on the same level with Bragan, and that's something. He has management ability of baseball players and of the game itself that very few major league managers have. Fred Haney, a grand character, - the best, - is the first reader compared with this post graduate in the field of command and procedure. In spite of all his faults, I really believe that we will go faster and further toward a winning team in Pittsburgh with Bragan than anyone else I have in mind at this time.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: July 11, 1955  Burlington, N. C.  BRENNAN  Second baseman. Saw him only in infield workout. Didn't impress me at all as a major leaguer.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: February 25, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    CHARLES BROCKELL    A well built right hand hitting infielder from Brunswick who is not being tried as a catcher. His arm is alright. He can hit the ball pretty hard. He is a slow runner and a very crude catcher. He doesn't know what it is to shift on any pitch and he catches low balls like a shortstop. Doesn't know what it means to body check. However, he has never done any catching and at this stage of his experience we must not turn thumbs down. I would say that he should return to Brunswick as a catcher in 1955.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    BROCKELL, DICK  Tall, right hand hitting catcher, with a fine arm, and a fairly quick throw, and absolutely accurate. A crude catcher. He should be caught everyday somewhere. He has power enough and if he would hit, I would have to change my mind about this boy. Frank Oceak may be right about Brockell being a major league prospect.    He can't run.    B.R.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: May 10, 1955  MEMORANDUM OF TELEPHONE CONVERSATION WITH JACK BERGER OF THE BRUNSWICK CLUB ON THIS DATE  "One thing I particularly want to tell you, - and Frank (Oceak) and I have talked it all over, and he feels and I agree with him, that I ought to tell you that we believe CANUSO is a major league catcher and should catch every day.  We also feel that BROCKELL can go to the major leagues as a catcher and he too should be caught every day.  Therefore, it is our opinion that one or the other, preferably BROCKELL, should be assigned elsewhere and send us another man who would not have to be caught every day. This is said not because we cannot use BROCKELL, - we surely can. He can play shortstop or second base or almost anywhere. He is a good ball player and he can go to the majors as a catcher. Therefore, he should be given the chance."  JACK BERGER      BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b  cc - Branch Rickey, Jr.  cc - Harold G. Roettger

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: April 27, 1955    HOLLYWOOD-LOS ANGELES GAME, LOS ANGELES, CAL.    BROSNAN    A tall, flaxen haired right hand pitcher. Belongs to Chicago, now with Los Angeles. A thrower, - not a pitcher, at the present time, - a heaver, an objector. Looks to have good speed and a good curve. His first inning showed no control whatever.    (Later)    He has a corking good curve ball, good velocity, and good break. Has a change up on his fast ball and it looks to be a good pitch. I would say a major leaguer if and when he has good control. He needs to learn to let the umpire do the umpiring.    I would take Brosnan in a deal with Chicago.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: BROWN, CLINT July 7, 1955    CLINT BROWN    17 year old Junior Legion boy from Meadvile, Pa. Smart little kid. Weighs about 165, 5' 10" tall. He will grow up.    This fellow has a knuckle ball, - a real knuckle ball and apparently pretty good control of it. He should go a long way with nothing else. His fast ball is fair, - nothing great at all, but good enough considering the knuckle ball pitch. This boy has no curve, almost none. He needs a lot of work on getting a third pitch of some kind. But he has this remarkable one pitch, namely the knuckle ball and he should be followed closely and encouraged to stay in baseball. When he becomes eligible on September 10th of this year, he should be seen again.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: Memorandum of January 20, 1955 Following Game in Havana, Cuba Between Marianao and Havana    Almenares played left field for Havana. He was an outfielder with Elmira last year. He is now on the St. Paul list, and that park is made for him. He is a tall right hand hitter, and he made a couple of great catches in the outfield in this game. He runs good average and has power, but it will be some time before he is regarded as a great hitter.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: June 4, 1955    BROWN, FRED    Third baseman from Avon, New York. His father is with him. Right hand hitter, - pretty good arm but inaccurate. Runs average. Batting form good. I will se him again after game tonight. At this moment, I would not give him a cent to sign a contract but I would give him a Class D chance. That's all.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: February 18, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.  JACK BROWN  Just as good a prospect as he has ever been but with the same identical fault. He needs to be put on the target for continuous work. His fast ball is great and his curve ball is also great and his change up on his curve ball is hardly a change up, but is discernibly slower than his regular curve. He can get a fairly decent change up on his fast ball. It doesn't spin as I would like to have it, but the velocity is occasionally very good, but he has no control of this pitch. In fact, he has below average control of each and every pitch. His delivery on all pitches is remarkably good. In the first place he follows through on every pitch and is therefore a great fielder of his position. His body follows his pitch. In the second place, every delivery regardless of the call of the pitch repeats. He is completely finished in deliveries.  He must be placed on the target. I don't think he needs another pitch. He simply needs control of what he has and he would be able to pitch in the majors with great ease.  This boy has been recently married. He comes from a large family. His wife is now four months pregnant and finances are worrisome. He is also afflicted with rectal warts. All his problems will be given immediate attention.  BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: POZA RICA VS PUEBLO, MEXICO, ON NOVEMBER 17TH AND 18TH, 1955 AND POZA RICA VS MEXICO CITY REDS AT POZA RICA ON DECEMBER 1ST AND 2ND, 1955.    JACKIE BROWN    Brown was born prematurely, and has never caught up. I don't think he ever has a thought. He has never related an incident in his has life, never told a story in his life, never had a belly laugh in his life. He would be incapable of comprehension to so deep a point. He is as near animal instinct and as far away from human intelligence as a man can be and retain human form.    He has all the pitches. I would be less surprised to hear him suddenly bark like a bog at nothing than I would to see him pitch a thoughtful inning. He has two arms and two legs, - two eyes, and, in fact, all body organs seem to function. How could mother nature cheaT him so sadly upstairs.    He might shut the Brooklyn club any old day but more likely will walk the first half dozen men to face him if he ever pitches against Brooklyn.    Jack has plenty of things besides baseball to worry about. He has a wife and a baby living with about 15 other poor folk in a four room house.    He is a 20 game winner, - major league stuff.    Just too bad he was brought up. Chiefly I am to blame for it.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: Dublin-Vidalia Game  Vidalia, Ga.  July 19, 1955    BUELL  Left hand hitter, left hand thrower. Great arm and a great pair of legs, and he seems to know what to do with both his arm and legs. However, up at the plate he acts like he does not want to swing. He gives the impression very definitely of expecting to take every pitch. He makes no signs in movements that he expects to hit, that he is up at the plate in order to hit. I really don't believe he wants very much to hit.  We definitely should not give up on this boy.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: April 23, 1955  CLARENCE BUHELLER  A nice boy, - apparently scared to death. Right now he doesn't belong here in Hollywood. He is not ready to do anything. Why he is playing, I don't know. Walls is on the bench, - played three or four innings in the previous game but I am told that Walls got hit on the head by a pitched ball four or five days ago.  Buheller should be placed out somewhere and in my judgment not above Class B, - just as soon as it can properly be done. In this connection, it must be kept in mind that he was assigned outright to Hollywood by New Orleans at a time when the player was claimed on waivers on the New Orleans request for waivers in the Southern Association.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: Burlington-Greensboro Game  Burlington, N.C.  July 20, 1955    BUHELLER, CLARENCE    He is on option at Burlington from New Orleans, and he can very safely go to the draft at New Orleans whether or not he is draftable.    In my judgement he is a very unfinished outfielder. In fact, he does not know where the ball is.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: July 11, 1955  Burlington, N.C.  BUHELLER, CHARLES  This boy has been with this club only a few days. Baseball people tell me that he is the only possible prospect on the Burlington club. Not by any means a finished outfielder. Pretty good arm, pretty good runner, and a pretty good hitter. Can't tell.  He is on the roster of the New Orleans club and should go to the draft there.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: February 17, 1955  Fort Meyers, Fla.    CHARLES BULLOCK    Left hander, about 6'2" tall, 170pounds, good action, shows a lot of finish. Fair fast ball, fair curve, good aptitude. I would guess this boy to be unusually intelligent. he would be the student type of pitcher. Would master change-ups.    This fellow is shopping around. He tells me that he has to go to the Cardinal, White Sox, and Yankee camps before signing. I am sorry about that. I would like to have the boy. I would keep him with my club for awhile.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    July 7, 1955    ALOYSIUS DRAPCHO    He is a Junior American Legion boy, 6'2" tall, 178 pounds. Lives up near Penn State College. Right hander, small boy, pretty good speed and a fair curve, nothing else. He should be followed. I would not be surprised if the boy could become a good pitcher.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: BINGHAMTON-WILLIAMSPORT GAME AT WILLIAMSPORT ON JULY 9, 1955    BURBAGE    Saw very little of this fellow, but I don't believe he is much of a runner or a hitter or a thrower. He surely can go to the draft at Williamsport, and I hope he is drafted.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MAZATLAN VS CULIACAN AT CULIACAN, MEXICO,  DECEMBER 8, 1955.      ALVAREZ    Culiacan shortstop.    About 5'8" tall, right hand hitter. Apparently no power, but his hitting form is good. 22 or 23 years of age. A pretty good looking fielder.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MAZATLAN VS CULIACAN AT CULIACAN, MEXICO,   DECEMBER 8, 1955    AMARO  Shortstop on the Mazatlan Club. Looks young, acts young, colored boy, probably about 21 years old. Belongs to the Cardinal organization. Has been moved to Houston, presumably to avoid the draft. He can throw. He has a very good hands. Showed some power in batting practice.    I rather like Amaro, although it looks like he is a fly ball hitter.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 20, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA BETWEEN MARIANAO AND HAVANA.    Pascuale was relieved by a tall, slim right hander by the name of AMOR, who was drafted by the Chicago Cubs from Oklahoma City last December. Bragan calls him a "dart thrower", - not a bad description. AMOR must be a better pitcher than he showed tonight. He had neither stuff nor control.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN,   PUERTO RICO ON JANUARY 25, 1955.    SANTURCE CLUB    The catcher was    CHITI 6'2" tall, weighs 240, - or so he looked to me. Had   no life, looked slow in his physical actions, and I could not   help thinking that he was somewhat indifferent about his work.   I think he has a strong arm. It is my belief that he cannot   hit a curve ball at all. He didn't try to run at anytime and   I don't know whether he can run with any speed whatever. Wid   Matthews had built me up considerably on this fellow Chiti and   I experienced a very great disappointment.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN,   PUERTO RICO ON JANUARY 25, 1955    CLARKSON played third base, and I know Clarkson is past forty.    A tall, slim Puerto Rican negro played the last three innings at  third base for Santurce. This boy's name is THOMAS. This boy  is a catcher and I am told that he belongs to the Pittsburgh   organization. He lives hereabouts and played last summer in   San Domingo. This boy can really throw. He pulls the trigger  and a rifle bullet results. Looked to be accurate too. I   think we should try to get him to to report.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN, PUERTO RICO, ON JANUARY 25, 1955    CLEMENTE played centerfield for Santurce.    I would guess him to be at least 6' tall, weight about 175 pounds, right hand hitter, very young. I have been told very often from many sources about his running speed. I was sorely disappointed with it. His running form is bad, definitely bad, and based upon what I saw tonight, he has only a bit above average major league running speed. He has a beautiful throwing arm. He throws the ball down and it really goes places. However, he runs with the ball every time he makes a throw and that's bad.    He has no adventure whatever on the bases, takes a comparatively small lead, and doesn't have in mind, apparently, getting a break. I can imagine that he has never stolen a base in his life with his skill or cleverness. I can that it if was done it was because he was pushed off.    His form at the plate is perfect. The bat is out and back and in good position to give him power. There is not the slightest hitch of movement in his hands or arms and the big end of the bat is completely quiet when the ball leaves the pitcher???????s hand. His sweep is level - very level. His stride is short and his stance is good to start with and he finishes good with his body. I know of no reason why he should not become a very fine hitter. I would not class him, however, as even a prospective home run hitter.    I do not believe he can possibly do a major league club any good in 1955. It is just too bad that he could not have had his first year in a Class B or C league and then this year he might have profited greatly with a second year as a regular say in Class A. In 1956 he can be sent out on option by Pittsburgh only by first securing waivers, and waivers likely cannot be secured. So, we are stuck with him, - stuck indeed, until such time as he can really help a major league club.    The most disappointing feature about CLEMENTE is his lack of adventure, - of chance taking. He had at least two chances tonight to make a good play. He simply waited for the bounce. I hope he looks better to me tomorrow night when Santurce plays San Juan, - the final game of the regular season and the city championship of San Juan is at stake. Perhaps this boy will put out in that game.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: OBSERVATIONS (CONTINUED) IN THE GAME BETWEEN CHICAGO WHITE SOX AND THE PIRATES ON MARCH, 23, 1955 AT FORT MYERS, FLORIDA    I will not be surprised if Mr. Clemente gets to the place where he will be permitted only to play against left hand pitchers. When the pitchers in the National League know his terrific weakness on sidearm pitching, he will not get anything else to hit.    in the 9th inning with Shepard on second and the tying run, - don't we have any fast runners on the bench?

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: WILLIAMSPORT-BINGHAMTON GAME AT WILLIAMSPORT, PA. ON   JULY 9, 1955    COATES, JIM (Binghamton)    Right hand pitcher. Must be 6'3" or 6'4" tall, strong, agile, well built fellow with a lot of speed. His temperment is temper. He has a very strong tendency to umpire his game as well as his pitch. This tendency will be an emotional hindrance for a long time to come, - however, he may be able to cover it up.    The fellow has a curve ball, not very good control of it, but there is not any reason to suppose that he will not get control of the curve. With a third usable pitch, this fellow Coates might really be great. He can throw his fast ball right by an ordinary hitter. He apes the manner of placid poise. It could be real. I would rather own Coates' contract than any other player I have seen in Johnstown, Binghamton, and Williamsport clubs, these past few games.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: Memorandum of January 18, 1955 Following Game in Havana, Cuba Between Cienfuegos and Havana.    At first base, there was an old negro player by the name of Cabrerra not worth a nickel. Can't run and can't field. A stationary first baseman. He would be taken continuously by surprise on any unusual or unexpected play. I image he might hit for distance if and when he hits at all.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: April 28, 1955    LINCOLN-WICHITA GAME AT LINCOLN, NEBRASKA    COBOS    AN ignoramus from Mexico or Cuba or somewhere. Good arm, fair   runner, ordinary hitter. He has no sense.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: 1955    COMMENTS AND OBSERVATIONS ON PITTSBURGH PIRATES AND HAVANA CUBAN ALL-STARS GAME OF SATURDAY EVENING, MARCH 14TH, GRAN STADIUM, HAVANA, CUBA.    Cole Cole is supposed to be a smart player. With  Castiglione caught off second in the fourth inning, he only  went half way to second, and then went back to first. He could  have easily gone to second.    Sandlock Lindell was wild and difficult, but if I ever saw  a catcher handcuffed, this was it. His one throw to second  base had nothing on the ball. The runner simply outran  it. He must be superb defensively every minute in order to   stay with this club, for he will not hit a lick.     The sooner Fred comes to know that Castiglione,   Cole, and Metkovich are impossible as starters, the sooner the   Pittsburgh Club will be started in the right direction.   Everyone of these boys are simply last place players.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN, PUERTO  RICO ON JANUARY 25, 1955.      COLE, the tall right hand pitcher, now belongs to the Cubs.  Pitched very effectively after the fifth hitter in the first  inning, allowing only three hits in the last eight innings, two of  which were home runs. I did not sit behind Cole, but no one at  anytime did anything with his curve ball, and his fast ball was  pretty good. His control could have been better. He might be a   pretty good pitcher. He looked better at the plate as a hitter  than most of the other players on his club.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: COMMENTS AND OBSERVATIONS ON PITTSBURGH PIRATES AND HAVANA CUBAN ALL-STARS GAME OF SATURDAY EVENING, MARCH 14TH, GRAN STADIUM, HAVANA, CUBA    Cole. Cole is supposed to be a smart player. With Castiglions caught off second in the fourth inning, he only went half way to second, and then went back to first. He could have easily gone to second.    Sandlock. Lindell was wild and difficult, but if I ever saw a catcher handcuffed, this was it. His one throw to second base and nothing on the ball. The runner simply outran it. He must be superb defensively every minute in order to stay with this club, for he will not hit a lick.    The sooner Fred comes to know Castiglions, Cole, and Metkovich are impossible as starters, the sooner the Pittsburgh Club will be started in the right direction. Everyone of these boys are simply last place players.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JAN, PURETO [sic] RICO, ON JANUARY 25, 1955.    CONDE was the second basemen. Played a good defensive game. Was unimpressive at the plate, but I was disturbed by dignitaries so much during the game that I did not do the job of scouting that I know Andy High did. Andy came down to Puerto Rica with me and he sat alone up in the stands. This boy Conde is to go with Dallas this coming season.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: (Marianao Club) -3- January 19, 1955    He was followed by the old pitcher    CONTERAS, whom we had in 1953 at Denver, and noticeable only as a  stick-in-the-mud.     This club is owned by one man, who assembles his club out of the  record book and Sporting News. His manager is N. Reyes,  whome I have known for some years.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: WILLIAMSPORT-BINGHAMTON GAME AT WILLIAMSPORT, PA. ON JULY 9, 1955    COOGAN, DALE    He is probably right where he belongs. Hitting right around .300 - lots of life, fielding very good, in fact, hustling all the time. To me, he was a new Coogan. If he could do as well at Hollywood, he would be very helpful there. He is still a very young man.    On account of previous reports and records and figures and facts, I would be willing to see him go to the draft at Williamsport.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: May 18, 1955  Salinas, Cal.    CORELLA    6'3" tall, 180 pounds, left hander, just 21 years of age. Fair speed. Pretty good control of it. Fair curve, - pretty good control of that. Change up on his fast ball could be better but is fairly good right now. The change up on his curve is not distinctively slow, but it is slower than his fast curve. The fellow might become a pretty good pitcher if he can become a "cutie". He does not have burning speed and I don't believe he ever will have. He might go into the money. If he gets a distinctive pitch, he might become anything, - and by distinctive pitch, I mean, for example, a knuckle ball. There is nothing wrong with his delivery and he could become pretty clever in holding men on.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: Memorandum of Game Between Santurce and Ponce at San Juan, Puerto Rice on January 25, 1955    A tall, aged, negro left hand hitter named Crowe, played first base. He can hit. A poor fielder and cannot run.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN,  PUERTO RICO ON JANUARY 25, 1955.    LOPEZ was followed by an underhand right hander named    CABRERA He pitched against Brooklyn five years ago here  in Puerto Rica and at that time I regarded him as forty years old

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: WILLIAMSPORT-JOHNSTOWN GAME AT JOHNSTOWN, PA. ON JULY  7, 1955    DANGLEIS, DONALD    DANGLEIS has the best change of pace pitches of almost  anyone I know, particularly effective is his change up on  the fast ball. For seven innings the opposition pounded  his fast ball for eight runs and nine hits. Dangleis  threw his change-up on his fast ball altogether three times.  One was called a strike, one was a called ball that should  have been called a strike, and the third was a pop-up to  the right fielder. Dangleis had Burbage as his catcher.  He never shook off a sign. In other words, Dangleis says  to the baseball world, "I have an arm, the catcher has my  brains". So, he leaves 50% of his pitching ability on the  bench, - and if the catcher has enough experience and  brains, Dangleis is a pretty good pitcher. Otherwise, he  is a thrower. When he gets into trouble, the only thing  he thinks about is to throw the ball harder.    For aboy [sic] of his potential, he is a great disappointment.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: April 28, 1955    LINCOLN-WICHITA GAME AT LINCOLN    DANIELS    A fine built colored right hand pitcher. Good fast ball, - only a fair curve. Showed a very excellent change up on his fast ball, but won't use it. Showed me only throwing ability. Was very tight, tense, nervous, - never relaxed. Has some mannerisms of deliberateness, but simply throws everything his best. No change-ups whatever. Not at all a pitcher. Doesn't have any control which may have been due to the fact that he was pitching at my request, etc., etc. All in all, he is destinctively a thrower. If he would use a third pitch frequently, he might become a fine pitcher.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; L-R
Transcription: New York-St. Louis Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis    DARK (Shortstop N.Y.)    I would not let any outfielder shift very much for Dark.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: MEXICO CITY REDS VS PUEBLO AT SECURITY STADIUM, MEXICO CITY, ON NOVEMBER 26, 1955.    DARNELL (Mexico City Reds Pitcher)    Didn't look anything like he did two years ago. Nice boy. Fair speed, pretty good curve, showed no control. Belongs to Brooklyn.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: WILLIAMSPORT-BINGHAMTON GAME AT WILLIAMSPORT, PA. ON JULY 9, 1955    DAVIS, RANDY    The Duke University,right hand hitting, speedy outfielder. Born short. Not the boy's fault he will not go anywhere. Correctly chargeable to his ancestry, immediate or remote. Take your pick. Probably both.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    DAVIS, WAYNE (Albany Outfielder)    He is as bad as Powers against left hand pitchers. Dead right field hitter, and in my judgment not a prospect. Probably has a lot of power.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: April 23, 1955    SAN FRANCISCO-HOLLYWOOD GAME AT SAN FRANCISCO    DEL GRECO, ROBERT    He is not a third baseman. He is a "catch and throw" infielder.   He looks better at the plate,- simply because he is swinging.   It is indeed gratifying to observe that he is not continuously   taking strikes. Doesn't know how to tag a runner and I believe   he is afraid if he does know how.    I can't understand Del Greco on the bases He is absolutely dead.   Takes a stationary short lead and just stands there. Gets no   break at all, - doesn't jockey for one and particularly when running   off second he is an Abrams or a Bell. It is sickening to watch him   now as a base runner. I had not seen him in a game for two years   and it was my recollection that he was somewhat adventurous and that   he would become a good base runner. He doesn't look like it now, -   not at all.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA,  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES    The big, colored right hand hitting third baseman, DELIS, may not  be a third baseman, but he has a lot of ability. He can run very  fast and he has power at the plate. We should have a pretty good  look at him when he is with the Washington Club at Orlando, Fla.    MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 20, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND HAVANA    The third baseman is    DELIS A colored Cuban boy, a right hand hitter, runs fairly  well, shows some power, has a good arm, and not old. I would guess  him to be 22. He belongs to Washington.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: JALAPA VS AZTECAS AT SECURITY STADIUM, MEXICO CITY, ON NOVEMBER 17TH AND NOVEMBER 19TH, 1955    CANDELARIO (DIAZ)    Third baseman Jalapa club.    Some major league club has made considerable inquiry about this player. He is a heavy built fellow. Very average runner, fine arm, young, perhaps 22 years old, but not an impressive hitter.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 18, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN CIENFUEGOS AND HAVANA    Second base a boy named    de SOUZA A small package of mediocrity belonging in not above a  Class B league.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: SALINAS-CHANNEL CITIES' GAMES OF MAY 17TH AND MAY 18TH, 1955 AT SALINAS, CALIFORNIA.    DIAL  Fair fast ball, not great at all, and a very fine breaking curve ball, and he shows remarkable control of his curve. He threw one change in the first three innings and it was a good change up off his fast ball. If this boy is intelligent and would acquire an extra pitch, he might go places. I don't believe he will ever go into the money limited to what he has now.    B.R.    (LATER)  He must pitch his curve ball. It is the only thing he has. If he could get his change-up a little bit slower, he might use that too. Hold him.    DIAL  Fair fast ball, not great at all and a very fine breaking curve ball, and he shows remarkable control of his curve. He threw one change in the first three innings and it was a good change up off his fast ball. If this boy is intelligent and would acquire an extra pitch, he might go places. I don't believe he will ever go into the money limited to what he has now.    BR    (Later)  He must pitch his curve ball, It is the only thing he has. If he could get his change-up a little bit slower, he might use that too. Hold him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 20, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND HAVANA.    DIAZ was the catcher tonight for Marinao. This is the boy whose  contract I purchased for Brooklyn eight years ago only to find  that the seller, Joe Cambria, did not have title to the player's  services. The purchase was cancelled. He is no good, - perhaps  a nice boy, but he cannot catch or do anything else.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: MEMORANDOM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING THE GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA,  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES    DONOSO will likely pitch Saturday night. I will report on him  further. I had a talk with him tonight.     MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 22, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME BETWEN ALMENDARES  AND CIENFUEGOS AT HAVANA, CUBA.    DONOSO    Should pitch the knuckle ball, - at least enough to put it into  the minds of the batsmen and keep it there. In the first  three innings of the game tonight, he never threw a single  knuckle ball. The first one he threw was to the second   hitter in the third inning. The hitter struck at it and  missed.     Another reason and a sufficient reason in itself for Donoso  throwing the knuckle ball is because he will have a tendency  to tire. He throws his best all the time, - curve and  fast ball, and I thoroughly believe that the occasional,   if not frequent, use of the knuckle ball would extend his  strength.     LATER    Donoso is trickly a minor leaguer without the knuckle ball.   Futhermore, Donoso can pitch in the major leagues only if he   throws his fast ball occasionally, only occasionally.   He was pitch the curve, the knuckle ball, and the change-ups.   His fast ball is not bad, but he over pitches it very much.     The first six hits made off Donoso were off his fast ball.     There are a good many left hand hitters who are weak on left  hand side arm pitching. Donoso can throw both his curve  and fast ball side arm, and he should have sense enough to do  it on occasion. He will throw the side arm pitch in warming  up before the game, but when the game starts, quite evidently   he never thinks of it.     A 2 and 2 pitch to Gonzales in the 8th inning was the second time  he threw the knuckle ball in this game.     [Handwritten] Donoso advised Monchy this pitch was not  a knuckle ball but a curve.   He only threw one the entire game.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: March 1, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    CHARLES "WHAMMY" DOUGLAS    He really has a fine curve ball and throws it  both overhand and sidearm and his fast ball is good, and  I see no reason why his control of both the curve and fast  ball should not be good.    This fellow cannot hold men on, - that is to   say, the runner can get a long break. It may be that  Douglas can throw quickly to first base and perhaps catch  men on occasion and all that, but when he pitches to the  plate, some movement of the shoulder or arm, I am not sure   which it is, gives the runner plenty of change for a running  start. This must be given attention in a special workout  and Rex must schedule the boy with me at an early date.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: CHARLES "WHAMMY" DOUGLAS  March 10, 1955  OBSERVATIONS IN A GAME WITH THE KANSAS CITY ATHLETICS AT FORT  MYERS, FLA.    It was the 6th pitch in the second inning before the boy threw  a change-up on the fast ball. It was high and outside.    Of course he has a beautiful curve and a good fast ball, but  Fricano, the opposing pitcher, not having a good fast ball,  pitched five of his first eleven pitches as change of paces and  all were effective. Not one time in the first inning did  Fricano throw a fast ball as a strike.    If Douglas is not going to pitch any changes, then most assuredly  he must go to his curve ball as his dominate pitch.    Changes of speed offer just as great a problem to the batsman in  the horizontal field that deflections offer to the batsman in   the vertical field. A man only good in one field and not in  the other can make good in the majors. Those who are good in  both fields are Mathesons and Deans.    Douglas must have control ofhis curve to pitch in the majors   and he could pitch in the majors provided further that he would  pitch it.    Apparently Douglas has no control of his change up on his fast   ball/    Wilson, in the first inning, showed he could hit fast stuff with  power. Did he get a single change-up the second time at bat?  Douglas proceeded to show his great speed on his fast ball,  the idea being to throw the ball by the batsman. He would  show him said he and cut loose he did. It never occurred to  him to fool anybody. He was simply determined to overpower   the batter.    Let me have Douglas for another special workout on his move  on holding men on. Not once did he practice the move of  coming through without stopping. Not one time.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: July 7, 1955    ALOYSIUS DRAPCHO    He is a Junior American Legion boy, 6'2" tall, 178 pounds.   Lives up near Penn State College. Right hander, small boy, pretty   good speed and a fair curve,nothing else. He should be followed.   I would not be surprised if the boy could become a good pitcher.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: LINCOLN-COLORADO SPRINGS GAME OF MAY 16, 1955 AT COLORADO SPRINGS    DRILLING, DICK    My former written opinion on Drilling may have under-estimated him. He certainly gives you all he has. The difference between him and Bill Bell is that Bell has infinitely more stuff but conceals it splendidly. This fellow shows you all he has.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: May 10, 1955    MEMORANDUM OF TELEPHONE CONVERSATION WITH JACK BERGER OF THE BRUNSWICK CLUB ON THIS DATE    "One thing I particularly want to tell you, - and Frank (Oceak) and I have talked it all over, and he feels and I agree with him, that I ought to tell you that we believe CANUSO is a major league catcher and should catch every day.    We also feel that BROCKELL can go to the major leagues as a catcher and he too should be caught every day.    Therefore, it is our opinion that one or the other, preferably BROCKELL, should be assigned elsewhere and send us another man who would not have to be caught every day. This is said not because we cannot use BROCKWELL, - we surely can. He can play shortstop or second base or almost anywhere. He is a good ball player and he can go the majors as a catcher. Therefore, he should be given the chance."    JACK BERGER    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b    cc - Branch Rickey, Jr,  cc - Harold G. Roettger

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: July 13, 1955  Brunswick, Georgia    DROTAR, JOSEPH    18 years old, will be 19 in October. Right hander, slim boy, 6' tall, from Munhall, Pa. He is three-quarters delivery or perhaps below that. The ball is 'live' and his speed is good enough. His curve ball is hardly a curve. It rotates differently, of course, than the fast ball, and deflects some, but no one would call it a good curve and the boy himself says that he doesn't have a curve. He wishes he did. He has had a change-up on his fast ball, but it was too fast. He slowed it up beautifully by making a semi-palm ball out of it. He really has a good change-up now, and he has good control of it.    This boy took to the curve ball change-up beautifully. He will get it. He has to do a lot of work on it simply for control. I like this chap, - he might go all the way.    Hands are adequate and his fingers are long and slim.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: July 13, 1955  Brunswick, Georgia    DUFFALO, JIM    21 years of age in November. He is from Dubois, Pa.  Married, right hander, about 6'1" tall, 170 pounds.  This boy has a fair fast ball, - not great at all, -  not in the class with Foss and Perry and fellows like  that. He has very fine control of his fast ball, -  an easy delivery. Curve ball so-so. Not particularly  attractive in any respect but he has fair control of it.   He has a change-up on his fast ball, but it is no good  and he has no control of it. He throws a slow curve  by simply letting up on his pressures and he has pr[e]ty  good control of that. This fellow should win in a  Class D league and should win in somewhat higher than  D simply because of his control. He undoubtedly gets  his stuff over the plate. He doesn't have the stuff  or power that most of these other good prospects have.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: LINCOLN-COLORADO SPRINGS GAME OF MAY 16, 1955 AT COLORADO SPRINGS, COLO.    DUNLOP, HARRY (Catcher)     Tall, Slim right hand hitter. Young enough, big enough.  He stands too far back of the plate in his catching position.  Looks like a very good receiver and I think he throws good enough  considering a catcher doesn't have to throw. I don't believe this  fellow can hit a lick, - in any league, - certainly not with power  in a little league. I have seen him only in two games, - once  three years ago and tonight. It is indeed a very brief  observation to risk a positive opinion, but I repeat again, I don't  think he can hit a lock [i handwritten over o]. He didn't get any chance to run, so I  can't pass on his running speed.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 18, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN CIENFUEGOS AND HAVANA    In center field was a negro kid named    CARDENAL This boy was drafted by St. Louis from the Cincinnati   organization, I believe it was. I don't believe he has great   power at the plate. His arm seemed good enough, and his speed is   good enough. He showed me nothing tonight to get excited about.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: JALAPA VS AZTECAS AT SECURITY STADIUM, MEXICO CITY, ON   NOVEMBER 17TH AN NOVEMBER 19TH, 1955.    CARMONA    Third baseman on Aztecas club.    Tall looking boy, very young. He might come to be a pretty   good ball player. Fair runner, fair arm, pretty good power.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: MAZATLAN VS CULIACAN AT CULIACAN, MEXICO,   DECEMBER 8, 1955.      CASTRO    First baseman on the Mazatlan Club. Left   hand hitter. A perfectly natural stroke   and a perfectly correct one, with power.   He might have been, 15 years ago, a major   league pinch hitter. He does not have quite   the power of John Powers, but Castro hits   the ball invariably fair. Par excellence   at the plate. He can't run. I had he and   his wife to dinner. He seems to know a lot   about players, - all over Mexico. I would   guess Castro to be around 40 years of age.     With a man on first, and one out, the ball was   hit on the ground to Castro. Castro   leisurely retired the batsman at first when the   play, of course, should have been made on the   force at second. A single followed, - and a run.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: June 4, 1955    CHIARAMONTE, MICHAEL E.    Right hand hittter, 21 years of age, just graduated from   Duquesne University in Pittsburgh. He is about 5'8" tall, - weighs   about 170. Short-stepper, below average runner, good arm and   good batting form. Not a power hitter, but he should hit. I   don't know what he would do against curve balls or change of speed   pitches, because I saw him only against Sam Narron, and judgment   of batters against Sam Narron pitching is untrustworthy. But   the boy's form is good in every respect. I would be willing to   send him immediately to Burlington, but he should be signed to a   Class D contract so that in case he should not make good in Burlington,   his contract could be taken over as a free agent by a Class D club.   If he should become a .300 hitter in good company, he could have a   baseball future.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: Dublin-Vidalia Game  Vidalia, Georgia  July 19, 1955    GONGOLA (Vidalia Catcher)    He either can't throw or he has a sore arm. He is not much of a hitter. The biggest trouble about him is that he can't catch.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: Havana, Cuba  January 20, 1955    GONZALOS NARANJO    20 years of age, 6' tall, 165 pounds, right hander, small fingers, but long, hand big enough, Cuban, white boy, nice manners, speaks pretty good English, not married, good habits, intelligent.    This chap has a pretty good fast ball and a corking curve, - that is to say that he has it most of the time. Then it won't curve. When the time comes that his curve curves all the time like it does some of the time, he will be a very fine curve ball pitcher.    He has aptitude. He has been with Bragan all year and has been under good managers and coaches for two years previous to this winter, and he is ambitious and inquisitive and wants to learn, yet no one has given him any attention to changes of speed. He throws a slow curve and it is good, except that his delivery on this pitch is known to everyone in the park before he lets go of the ball. Therefore, his change-up is not worth a nickel. He can learn a change-up on his fast ball, and did, and he is the sort of boy who will work on it.    I want him to report to our Fort Myers camp, February 15th. Please tell Bob Rice.    I also worked with Naranjo on what I call the thumb back change of pace curve. He will learn that, in fact he is the kind of chap who will do what he is told. I have great hopes for this boy.    He has fully recovered, so he says, from any and all arm ailments he has had in the past year. He attributes his recovery to his tonsillectomy.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: April 28, 1955    WICHITA-LINCOLN GAME AT LINCOLN, NEBRASKA    MANUEL GONZALES (Wichita Pitcher)    Manuel Gonzales looks like a very young chap. Right hand pitcher. Has a good fast ball and a good curve, - lacks control. No change-ups of any kind. Worth following.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: SALINAS-CHANNEL CITIES' GAMES OF MAY 17TH AND MAY 18TH, 1955 AT SALINAS, CALIFORNIA    GOSS, HOWARD    Hits at bad pitches, but has improved. Can throw and can run and has a lot of power. Poor fellow! It is a shame for a man with all the tools to fail utterly, and he surely won't. He has more natural ability than any man in the Pittsburgh organization.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: April 28, 1955    LINCOLN-WICHITA GAME AT LINCOLN    GOODRICH    If this boy had some power at the plate, he might be a pretty good ball player. His form at the plate is good and the curve ball doesn't seem to worry him over much. I am hardly able to pass judgment on the strength of his arm.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: LINCOLN-COLORADO SPRINGS GAME OF MAY 16, 1955 AT COLORADO SPRINGS.    GOODRICH, WARREN    Stanford University infielder, now playing shortstop. Right hand hitter, and his form at the plate is good. I don't see any reason, and I cannot think of any, why he should not hit. This may not be good English, but makes good sense to me.    Goodrich does not have a strong arm. It is a sound arm, ordinarily pass as a good arm, but not by any means adequate for shortstop. He might play third or indeed he might play second. In the field, he looks like a shifty, quick moving boy and his running speed is good. This chap might go into the money and if he hits, he might possibly go anywhere.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: New York-St. Louis Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis, Mo.      Grammas (St. Louis Infielder)    This boy is not a fast runner at all, but he has great body control and a fine arm, good hands, and can make all the plays.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: February 21, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    FRED GREEN    Intelligent, has stuff, a left hander with everything it takes but short of the usual left hander criticisms. He has one tremendous fault. His fast ball and curve are thrown on the same delivery. Very good. His change ups on both his fast ball and curve have a distinctly different delivery from his fast pitches and this is his problem. He needs competitive experience to the point where he will not become tense or perhaps frustrated under pressure. That will possibly take time. How much I don't know. The job is up to Fred.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: March 7, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    FRED GREEN    Fred Haney says that it is a matter of control of this fellow's curve ball that spells his immediate chance for the majors. In my judgment, it is a matter of control of all pitches.    He has a beautiful fast ball, - one of the best, and he has a change up on his fast ball that has good delivery and good velocity. The ball in itself is alright, but it simply goes in the direction of the plate, but he has about as good control of it as he has of his fast ball at that. He simply lacks control.    His fast curve ball is good, - good enough. It breaks and it has speed. His change up on the curve ball is useable, - that is to say, it also has a definite change of speed and it does not curve. I believe his control of this pitch is better than the control of his fast curve.    This fellow is a great prospect. How soon, perhaps God only knows. He is a willing fellow and a fine person, probably a "gentle man" in every respect.    It would not surprise me if he failed to be a great pitcher in New Orleans in 1955. He is possibly two or three years away from major league stardom. That's too bad, but I just don't know what to do about it.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: June 28, 1955    GROVER, DARWIN (BUCK)    6'4", 215#, right hander, just finished Brownsville High School. Has a very good fast ball, and it is good enough to carry him all the way. He has a curve , - a so-called regular curve ball, - not much of a curve and really no control of it. He throws a slow curve ball which is much better and he has better control of that pitch. It is my judgment that at the present time this boy should "can" his so-called regular curve.    He can throw a four finger knuckle ball and he would probably come to pretty good control of it and he should probably be encouraged to work on it.    He took the change up on the fast ball quickly, and this would be a very effective pitch.    I would say this boy is a prospect, - a green, crude prospect, somewhat clumsy now but in a couple of years this boy could give anybody a satisfactory surprise.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: March 9, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    FACE, ELROY    Worked him only to observe his so-called new pitch, - a fork ball. He has it. It is not at all in effect a knuckler. It simply doesn't knuckle, but it is a very effective change of speed pitch. It spins exactly in direction and rapidity the same one after another, but he has fine control of it. He can use it as a change of pace. It has indeed marked his improvement. We will see about it.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.   OPERATING   PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    St Louis -- New York Game, May 13, 1955 at St . Louis    HADDIX (Pitcher St. Louis)     This boy, in my judgement, is still a thrower and when he doesn't have control, -- he beats himself. Has a good fast ball and a good curve, -- above average in both respects. In fact, Haddix, with control, is a hard man to beat, whether he has any pitching sense or not. He seldom throws changes. Never showed me one in the whole game that he has a change-up on his fast ball. He did throw a couple of slow curves, but this fellow doesn't particularly need three pitches when he has control.     Don't hold Haddix cheap at the plate. This fellow I would call a darn good hitter for a pitcher.       B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: Fort Myers, Fla.  March 1, 1955    RICHARD HALL    Right hand Swarthmore outfielder who has been very disappointing in his hitting improvement, now being tried out as a pitcher. He has a good fast ball and he has control of it. That is about the only thing he has to start with. His curve 'ain't'. but his curve 'can be'. He has no change up on the fast ball but he will get that, but best of all, he can get a change on his curve ball or rather he will get a slow curve from a modified 'thumb position'. This chap really has all the aptitude that any one man can have. He can throw anything just by telling him about it. I don't think I've worked with a human being who could come quicker to a new idea, rather to the implementation of a new idea. I know that if I had him on a college team, he would be a great pitcher, - at least he would come that quick.    He will work with Sukey or Larry Dorton daily or under other direction, or indeed he may simply pitch to the target.     Under no circumstances is he to pitch the slow curve at a distance above 30 feet for at least the next ten days.    BRANCH RICKEY      March 7, 1955    He is showing fine improvement and he must be put on the target at 40 feet on his change up on his curve and knuckle ball. He should not be pitched in any regular exhibition games.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: April 28, 1955    LINCOLN-WICHITA GAME AT LINCOLN, NEBRASKA    HALL, DICK    We certainly made the right decision when we made a pitcher out of him. He cannot handle an inside fast ball at all up at the plate, and the curve still makes a monkey out him. He is so tight up at the plate that you would think a number of bones would break in his body somehow or other before the pitch gets up there. If this boy could only relax and seem not to care whether he hit or not, he surely would be better. I suggest that Bill Burwell alternate him and Daniels against left and right hand pitching. That might be followed with advantage to the club.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: LINCOLN-COLORADO SPRINGS GAME AT MAY 16, 1955 AT COLORADO SPRINGS    HALL, DICK    Dick Hall played left field tonight. He is good defensively, and he still doesn't know a strike from a wild pitch. Dick is a pitcher.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18. 1955    HARTBARGER, JIM    A little, right hand hitting second baseman. A puny at the plate, a tiny pair of hands. I don't think he can catch a thrown or a fly ball. Can't run, can't hit, and he can't throw.    This boy certainly had a bad night. He was helpless, horrible, and hurtful.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    HAYDEN, JIM    Left hand pitcher. He has plenty of stuff. The Albany club from top to bottom cannot hit breaking stuff. However, Hayden has enough speed to pitch in Class D even if he were not to throw anything other than his fast ball.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; A-E
Transcription: July 13, 1955  Brunswick, Georgia    HAYDEN, JIM    "How old are you, Jim", I said, when I met him on the mound this morning at the start of my workout.    "Well", he said, "I am 20".    "When will you be 21?"    He said "in July."    "What day in July"?    "Let's see", said he, "the 11th of July".    I said, "this is the 13th".    He said, ""of July"?    I said, "yes, July".    "Not July"?    "Yes, this is July, and this is the 13th of July".    "Well", he said, "I must have had a birthday the day before yesterday".    Tall, slim, left hander, naive as the dickens. "Are you married, Jim"?    "No, I ain't".    "Are you about to be?"    "No, but I am in sort of a mess though".    "Oh, is that so, - what about".    "About this damn curve ball."    "What's that got to do with your girl, if any"?    "Girl, - who said anything about a girl. What I'm talking about , said he, "is the mess with this curve ball. That's the only thing that worries me!"

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: HAYDEN, JIM (Cont.)    He has a roundhouse curve and a square-off curve according to his terminology, and he was 'messed up' because he couldn't get the ball over the plate.    His fast ball is very good and his change-up on the fast ball can be made very good too.    He should become a pretty good pitcher.    He is about 6' 2" tall. He is a prospect. Might become most anything.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc  Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club    New York - St Louis Game, May 13, 1955 at St Louis, MO    Hemus (St Louis Infielder)    Hemus is not as a fast a runner as he used to be, but he is a tricky runner and makes the most out of his speed. He can't throw. As a general statement of how to pitch to Hemus on the part of most pitchers, I would say not to experiment with him at all. Pitch immediately to the center of the plate. He is "tough potatoes" when he has the pitcher in the hole. Make him hit early. Under no circumstances do I believe a pitcher ought to try to pitch inside to him. This does not mean that he is a dangerous hitter on the inside pitch. He is simply dangerous to pitch there because he has a great faculty for getting hit by the pitched ball and the knows the strike zone on the inside. He won't hit at a bad inside pitch, - moreover he can hit the inside pitch if it is over. Pitch immediately to the middle of the plate on this boy.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Dublin-Vidalia Game  Vidalia, Ga.  July 19, 1955    HOENES    Catcher. Must be very young. He acts it all over. Energetic, aggressive. Arm seemed alright. Left hand hitter and certainly not what I call a power hitter. Tall, very slim, and not a bad runner.    We should not quit on this boy.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    FACKLER, EARL    Tall, lank, left hand hitting first baseman. If Fackler can run, he should be protected from the draft.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.   OPERATING   PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    New York -- St. Louis Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis    HOFFMAN (N.Y. 1st Baseman)     He has power at the plate. He acts up at the plate like a guess hitter to me. He must never get what would normally be called the expected pitch. Change up on him constantly, -- slow curves and change-ups on the fast ball. I would say to make the fast pitch high and tight, and I would not pitch that ball right into the fellow. I don't regard him as a good hitter, but he has power, -- if he knows what's coming particularly.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    HURST, LEON    Right hand pitcher, has just come 18 years of  age. Has a good curve ball. Has good change-up on  both his fast and curve balls. His fast ball is so-so,  - not great. He should spot pitch his fast ball.   Every base hit off Hurst tonight in seven innings was   made off his fast ball. The curve ball was never   even met fairly by anybody. He threw two change ups   on the fast ball and both were very effective. He never   shook the catcher off a single time.    He made two errors and two wild pitches. The  first two runs scored by Albany were made after the third   batsman was clearly struck out on a curve ball. The  next run was made with two outs, nobody on, and the  batsman was struck out again on the curve ball, but was   walked, - according to the umpire. Then followed two   errors and another run.    The fourth run was also unearned. However, Hurst  was wild, - wilder than he would ordinarily be.    He is a prospect but he must become a pitcher  instead of a thrower. He must use his own head and not  trust completely to the catcher.    Three times when batsmen had two strikes and no  balls, he threw the fast ball fairly through the middle,  and two of these batsmen looked very bad on his curve.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: February 21, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    JACK ISENHART    20 years of age, weighs about 180, 5' 11" tall, right hander. He is a natural pitcher. Not in any sense of the word a thrower. If he has a good curve, then indeed he has plenty of stuff. He has a corking change up on his curve ball and he undoubtedly has a great fast ball. We didn't let him throw it on account of the history of a sore shoulder and this worries me very much. We must not allow him to go in any exhibition games, - intra-squad or anything else. Bill Burwell will work him daily but always short of any pain. He might go anywhere and fairly quickly if his arm is sound.
