There cannot be any question about his pitching future if he is a healthy boy.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: St. Louis-New York Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis, Mo.    JACKSON (St. Louis Pitcher)    A thrower, but a vigorous, aggressive thrower. He has a good fast ball and a strong curve. No changes, but wild in streaks. He might become a very great pitcher. No batter should do any guessing when Jackson is pitching. He can and will come with his fast curve ball anytime with two strikes on the batter. Take advantage of his periods of wildness. When he gets wild, he lets up.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: July 11, 1955  Burlington, N. C.    JACOBS, DAVE    A jack of all trades, and a Class B player at best.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Burlington-Greensboro Game  Burlington, N. C.  July 20, 1955    JACOBS, DAVE    He can go to the draft right where he is.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: SALINAS-CHANNEL CITIES' GAME OF MAY 17TH AND MAY 18TH, 1955 AT SALINAS, CALIFORNIA    JACOBSEN, (First Baseman)    A doubtful prospect.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: WILLIAMSPORT-BINGHAMTON GAME AT WILLIAMSPORT, PA. ON JULY 9, 1955      JACUIK, JOHN (Binghamton)    Tall, left hand hitting first baseman for Binghamton. Very unimpressive against pitcher Sheets. He acted like a very young boy. Looked very inexperienced, indeed amateurish at the plate.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: August 26, 1955    DON JACQUIN    Big boy, 190 pounds, 6'1" tall, 19 years old, very good arm,  right hand hitter with power. Average runner. I don't know  what he wants to sign. His father is here with him. In the  olden days, I would sign this boy to a C or D contract right  now and if he would go to our camp next spring as a free agent,  that would be ideal.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: August 25, 1955    DICK JAMISON    Right hand hitting catcher from Peoria, Illinois. His father came  with him. He caught on the same team on which Leon Hurst played.  His hands are bigger than anybody's, and his arm is strong and  he knows how to throw. His is no puny up at the plate. I think  he would come to have a good power. He is about 6' tall, weigh  about 180 and he will not come to be 18 until November. He is a   prospect. The father wants the boy to go to college for at least  one year, and then he may be available. He is going to the   University of Iowa. We should follow him up pretty carefully.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: LINCOLN-COLORADO SPRINGS GAME OF MAY 16, 1955 AT COLORADO SPRINGS    FALLS, JACK    Left hand, fine form hitter, with enough power to count. Take a bat out of his hands and you have a very ordinary minor league player. His only chance to go anywhere is in catching. I understand he does not want to catch, - if so, forget him.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: JALAPA VS AZTECAS AT SECURITY STADIUM, MEXICO CITY, ON  NOVEMBER 17TH AND NOVEMBER 19TH, 1955.    JENKINS    JALAPA catcher. He belongs to the Giant organization.  Played last year with Sioux city, now on Minneapolis list.  He will have to look very much better than he did in the few  games I observed him if he ever makes the majors.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Havana, Cuba  January 20, 1955    DAVID JIMINEZ    I worked out this big, tall, right hand  throwing negro pitcher in March of 1952 here in Havana.  He had three big front teeth out at that time.    He can throw the ball harder than anybody I  have seen in a long time. He is really dangerous and   he has pretty good control of it too. His curve ball  is so so, - not good enough. He can pitch from all  angles. He throws a change-up according to Hoyle.  Some pitcher showed him, - I forgot who it was, but it  was one of the boys who had been taught correctly.  However, his change-up on the fast ball is too fast. He  must be given a definite program immediately upon reporting  to our camp at Fort Myers on February 15th. He can  throw a knuckle ball with fine control. It doesn't  knuckle very much, but does have the effect of a change  of speed pitch. This fellow is a real prospect.  I want him turned over to Bill Burwell immediately upon  reporting. David needs a better curve.    Those who know him tell me that he is a good  boy, poor as a snake, ambitious, and anxious to be a great  pitcher. He is a fine prospect.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA, BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES.    The starting pitcher for Marianao was a tall, 6'4" negro right hander by the name of    CONNIE JOHNSON He broke in with Colorado Springs in 1952, was with the Chicago White Sox in 1953 and last year in Toronto. He has stuff, -- a lot of stuff. Above average major league fast ball and a good downer curve, and a fade-away that has the effect of a change of speed. I would like very much to own his contract for Pittsburgh. He is deliberate under fire and stress, but he simply does not have control, and I believe without a doubt that he will come to have control with a little more experience. You will claim him on any waiver request by the Chicago American League club. He gets behind the hitters but I do not believe he is inclined to let up. I think he prefers to walk the batsmen, -- and he does. Johnson has a chance to help the White Sox in 1955.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: SALINA-CHANNEL CITIES' GAMES OF MAY 17TH AND MAY 18TH, 1955 AT  SALINAS, CALIFORNIA    JOHNSON, DICK    Small, but not puny, 20 year old right hand hitter,  married, has a boy four months old. This kid is a good competitor.  Quick reflexes. Not a great runner, but good enough. Defensively  he is fairly finished. Knows how to make all plays, and makes them.  I am very strong in believing that his position is second base.    I like him at the plate, - not great power at all, but  he puts everything he has into the stroke. AND he is unafraid.    He played 60 odd games at Boise, Idaho in 1954 and hit  only .143. Unless I am terribly wrong, Richie Johnson will hit  .250 this year or better.    He is draft able at the end of the 1955 season. We  will watch him closely.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: July 12, 1955  Dublin, Ga.    JOHNSON, ERNIE    6'3" tall, 180 pounds, right hander. Good fast ball,  good curve ball, both pitched practically overhand.  Has a change-up on his fast ball. It is very good,  but he doesn't have great control of it as yet.  It goes high all the time. He has two curves, both  definite downers. This boy showed me enough to be  of real interest. I would hate to see him given an  unconditional release.    He is 23 years of age. Was in Korea for two or three  years and his wife is going to have their first baby  this week.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.  Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club  New York-St. Louis Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis    KATT (N.Y. Catcher)    I don't believe this boy can hit the fast pitched  ball right at his hands. He swings through them time and  again and he does it in the batting practice. I don't think  he can hit the pitch any better than the old first baseman  Kelly could hit the pitch on his hands, and this goes whether  it is a left hand pitcher or a right hand pitcher.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: February 17, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    DONALD KILDOO    He was 20 years of age in November. 6' tall, 180 pounds, and he has a good fast ball and he looks to have good control of it. His curve ball is good and he has a change up on his curve ball which is also good. In fact, it is really a good pitch. His change-up on the fast ball is not good. The spin is faulty and the velocity is too high. He could well afford to 'can' that pitch altogether unless he gets it better. I thinks he is a good boy and a darn good prospect, but he must use his curves a great deal.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: April 23, 1955    SAN FRANCISCO-HOLLYWOOD GAME AT SAN FRANCISCO    KIRRENE    A corking good hitter on fast balls, -- has power. Looks terribly weak on all kinds of breaking stuff, but particularly on change-up pitching. Make the fast ball bad, -- high and inside, and then make him hit change of speed pitching.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: March 9, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    KLINE, RONNIE    Doesn't need any additional pitch. Has only three. Has change up on his curve. As a matter of fact, his curve ball is a slow curve, but it bends, -- plenty. His fast ball is fast and his change up on his fast fall is good enough. All three pitches are useable. With control, this fellow can help our team this year and I know of no reason why he won't have control. This boy, under no circumstances, must let up to get the ball over.    He must come to the place in his own mind where he is willing and able to pitch his breaking stuff, that is to say, his curve or his change up on his fast ball, -- when he is in the hole. That the thing he must do.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Dublin-Vidalia Game  Vidalia, Georgia  July 19, 1955    KOLASA    Shortstop. This boy is the best looking player on the Dublin club. Good arm. Best looking batsman at the plate, and not a puny in power either. I don't know his age. He looks to be 5'9" tall and weigh 170 pounds. Kolasa is a good runner and has a good arm.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Burlington-Greensboro Game  Burlington, N. C.   July 20, 1955    FIGARD, GORDON    Figard is certainly erratic. The boy does not belong in Burlington. He is a Class D ball player and next year should be placed in D. Then if he wants to quit, let him quit. He does not need protection from the draft in his contract should be assigned to a/Class C or D club for the coming draft. This must be done.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: June 30, 1955    KOMISAR, TONY    18 year old boy from Beacon, N.Y. Left hander, 6' tall, 175 pounds, was accompanied into Pittsburgh by his coach and Elmer Dobberstein. He has a very ordinary fast ball, and he throws overhand, 3/4 and almost sidearm curve balls. Nothing especially great or quick about the curves, but they all curve.    He throws a change of pace curve, which is simply slower than some of the others and the ball is largely produced by a change in effort. He has no change-up on the fast ball, but he throws what he calls a 'different' fast ball. It occasionally has sort of a screw ball effect.    He throws a knuckle ball, -- four fingers. It goes almost anywhere. He has used it very little. The boy could be a cutie and of course that old saying that you never know about the future of a pitcher applies in his case, but most certainly he is not the kind of prospect to go wild about at this stage of the game.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: July 13, 1955   Brunswick, Georgia  Koski, Bill  This boy has a good fast ball and looks like he may have recovered his old time fast ball. He is 6'4 1/2" tall. He used to weigh about 195 pounds four years ago. Now he won't weigh over 175 pounds. Looks very thin and has had a history of pneumonia, - I believe two attacks.     His curve ball is so-so, - never was very good, but his slow curve is pretty good and he is fully free throwing it. He follows through on it.     He has a fork ball which is something like a knuckler and he has pretty good control of his slow curve and his fork ball, I believe he could return as a prospect.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: August 20, 1955  Robert "Bob" Koski  Left hander about 190 pounds, 6'1" tall, 19 years old. He can throw a ball as far as he can see. One cannot afford to stand behind the catcher when Bob is throwing the fast ball. This fellow is really fast. He has almost as good control as Pepper, - not quite. This fellow got one over the plate in 14 pitches. Pepper successfully misses the plate 16 out of 17. One would think that he would get wild at times and carelessly let one get over the plate. This fellow is not that bad but he is bad. Curve ball is so so. It has speed. Ben Tincup taught him the change up on the fast ball and he taught him correctly and the fellow has got this pitch pretty good. Has never tried to throw anything else.   This boy joined the Yankees at the beginning of June of 1954 at Owensboro, Kentucky (Yankee system). Walked everybody but they kept him. He was attending the University of Michigan and stupidly quit and Christmas time. Insists he was doing good work in his studies when he dropped out. The Yankees returned him to Owensboro and he rode the bench until mid-summer and pitched almost not at all. He wants a job and he should have a job. I don't think he should pitch anywhere professionally because he can't get the ball over the plate, but there is nobody going to hit him, that's a cinch. If he wants a job, I would give it to him. We don't know what he might become in a year or two. I would like to have him. No bonus whatever, - just salary.   Marty Purtell says he can hit. We will see him up there right now.   (LATER)   This boy has power at the plate, - ran out one hit. I would call him a very average runner if that, but this opinion is not trustworthy. I will have to see him further, both as a runner and as a hitter, but he does have a lot of power.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: June 22, 1955   Kosko, Jim  17 year old, 6'1" tall, right hander. Graduated from Duquesne High School. Good fast ball, strong arm, no curve at all, fair hands but a short thumb, very short. Has change-up on the fast ball which is a dandy. Just learned it, - but there is a change in his delivery on this pitch. This boy needs work and help on his curve. He might become something. He is very young and very crude of course.     He belongs to the American Legion and cannot be negotiated with even if he were desirable until after the American Legion program for 1955 is finished. He should be followed up.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: June 28, 1955  Kowalski, Charles  A left hander from Chicago, Illinois. A little over 6' tall, and weighing about 185 pounds. Good fast ball and good control of it. He can go all the way so far as his fast ball is concerned. His regular curve ball breaks part of the time and sometimes breaks good. He throws a slow curve and it doesn't curve much but it has a splendid effect as a change and he has better control of it than his regular curve. Charles tells me that he uses this slow curve more than he uses the regular curve.     He throws a change-up on his fast ball but it is not a change. He took to the conventional change up and shows quickly that he will get it. They boy is in the class of a prospect. I would like to have him. He is not all a bonus candidate.     This boy is a good athlete, - has agility and build and manner. I believe he is intelligent.     He father is with him. He is a scrawny sort of cock-eyed father, who, it seems to me, has been in an automobile accident at sometime. Seems to be a very nice gentleman. We should follow him up.     Howie Haak makes the statement that he (Haak) knows the boy has ten $4,,000 offers. That means that some scout or other has talked to him along these lines and he probably doesn't have one single offer either in writing on indeed genuine. This he is worthy of consideration.   B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.   Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club     Burlington-Greensboro Game  Burlington, N.C.  July 20, 1955    Knox (Shortstop on the Greensboro Club)  Good arm, pretty good runner, over-strider at the plate.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Fort Myers, Fla.   March 1, 1955    Danny Kravitz  He may not double step all the time, but the few times I have seen him when they are running or pretending to run, he does double step before he throws. This is bad. His arm is plenty strong enough for him to throw on the catch and without moving his pivot foot the second time.   Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.   Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club  New York-St. Louis Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis    Liddle (N.Y. Pitcher)  Left hand pitcher. Not a great fast ball, but a good curve and a dandy change up on his fast ball, -but in this particular game against St. Louis, he didn't have control of anything and he only pitched about two or three innings and was taken out. Liddle also threw slow curves. Very definitely he has four useable pitches. On days when he has good control and is properly pitched, he would be pretty tough to beat.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: March 15, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.     Dick Littlefield  A left hander. This fellow has good stuff, all four pitches. Is sensible, intelligent, -he can go world series. He needs perfection in his move with men on bases. If he will only learn to practice the slow movement before he comes set, it will help him. He should learn that he can pitch without stopping and then he must be clever enough on occasion and frequently to come absolutely set and hold it for a time, say while he counts one thousand three - three times. Then he must know that he can pitch off the slow movement without any pause in it. He understands it. It is a matter of practice. Really it is a matter of him really wanting to do it. He follows his pitch good enough. He should field his position. When he bears down his left foot comes up even with the right one and his weight is somewhat divided, not very much, but enough to enable him to go right or left or to field the ball right back at him. He has undoubtedly the making of a fine pitcher.   Branch Rickey  BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company, Inc.   Operating   Pittsburgh Baseball Club    July 8, 1955    Llewllyn, Ed  5'11" tall, weighs around 185, right hand pitcher. Lives in Williamsport, Pa. He was accompanied by his father. Both work in the same manufacturing company in Williamsport. This boy is fat. He has taken off about 10 pounds in the past week. He needs to take off another 10 pounds.   Intelligent, 21 years of age and has sense accordingly.   His fast ball is alert, -not great velocity, but good enough. His curve ball is not good and showed me no control of it. He throws a slow curve ball. It is usable, but his delivery has distinctively a change of pace delivery, therefore the pitch is no good. He took to the change up on the fast ball like a duck to water. He can learn that pitch easily. He needs work on the change up on the curve ball. I didn't have the time to even approach that pitch. I did work him on a knuckle ball. He will get it and very good and he should be encouraged in that direction.     He should to to our spring training camp next year and he should work hard on his knuckle ball. If he gets control of his change up on the fast ball and keeps the fast ball delivery with it, then this boy has a chance. He might become a good pitcher, I don't believe he should go into professional ball this summer, but I do believe if he was under expert attention for two or three weeks next spring, he could make good in professional baseball.     This boy has a real handicap. His thumb is a full 3/4" shorter than mine, and his fingers are likewise short. He has to hold the ball full back in the sock both on his fast and curve ball. It is the tightest position of any boy I have worked out in a long time.   B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.   OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    Burlington-Greensboro Game  Burlington, N.C.  July 20, 1955    FLYNN, BOBBY  A hustler, tries hard, - in fact too hard. A right hand hitter with some power and a fine arm. Cubbish. I doubt it he knows very much about baseball and particularly about catching. His eagerness would cause him to be erratic. He stands perhaps 6" too far behind the hitter and he "jukes" his head everytime the batsman swings. Both of these faults could be corrected.     Undoubtedly Flynn can be allowed to go to the draft at Burlington.    Flynn singled into left field with a runner on second, and the left fielder threw it 'over the haystack', - almost over the catcher's head. Flynn ran to first and stopped. I am very much afraid this boy is plain dumb.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Salinas-Channel Cities' Games of May 17th and May 18th, 1955 at Salinas, California    Lopeman  I would call him a good average runner and a very average hitter. If he is a power hitter, then he might possibly go some place, but he is not a power hitter. What can he do? He cannot start a double play and he most certainly cannot finish one. Let him return to catching. I don't believe he will ever go major league.   B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: June 30, 1955    LUDWIG, KEN T.    Right hander from Effingham, Illinois. Just graduated from the State Teachers College at Charleston, Illinois. He finished high school in 1951. He is 21 years of age and goes into the army this coming September.    Has fair fast ball. Throws it without any effort and has really fine control of it. He throws curve balls from all angles and the ball curves and he has decent control of the curves. He throws a slow curve ball and he would get the change up on the fast ball. Never has tried to throw it. This boy is about 6' tall and will weigh around 175 and I believe if he wanted a job in a Class D league, I would give it to him and send him out immediately.    I would rather have him than the left hander (Komisar) I worked out today.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: August 26, 1955    GEORGE LUKART    Right hand hitting catcher. Undoubtedly a nice boy, and his mother and father are nice folks. He ought not be encouraged too much to play professional baseball.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: February 18, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    Gangelhoff    6' tall right hander from Clearwater, Florida. Graduated from High School sometime last June. Pitched with some semi-professional bunch in Minnesota last summer. Played second base when he was not pitching. Fairly good fast ball, - nothing to rave about, but the speed of his fast ball would not handicap him too much if he had other things to go with it.    This boy has no curve to speak of. It is what I call an outfielders curve. He has no change-ups of any kind and he is wild with every pitch. It may be that he had some stage-fright.    In the workout, he insisted that his best pitch was his knuckle ball. I was delighted to hear this. He proceeded to throw the knuckle ball generally in the direction of the South Pole as his catcher Larry Dorton was standing in a generally southern direction. The knuckleball went everywhere. Sukey said it was no good anyhow. After the workout the boy told me that he had not shown his true knuckle ball; that it was much better than he had shown, etc., etc., etc.    I believe that George might offer this boy a contract at $200.00 per month and no bonus whatever and send him to Brunswick where we can see him under fire as a pitcher. I doubt his future. However, a big, strong boy with a fairly good fast ball might fool us. We will take a chance on him at Brunswick on something like the above terms. Otherwise, I would suggest that we let him go to the Philadelphia club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: April 23, 1955    HOLLYWOOD-SAN FRANCISCO GAME AT SAN FRANCISCO    BOB GARBER      At this time, if Bob Garber is a major league pitcher, I am not only a Swiss watchmaker, but I am the best Swissman ever put out. In the first place, he does not have adequate control of any pitch, and in the second place, I don't know what you would call his "third pitch."    He cannot hold men on, or rather the base runner can steal any base on his break. It takes Bob so long to throw the ball that I don't know how a catcher could throw any base runner out at either second or third. This could be corrected and should be corrected and beyond any doubt the boy has been told to balance his weight by putting his front foot out further, but evidently that advice doesn't mean one thing to Bob.    Bob comes set on every pitch, - comes down fast and firm and abides strictly by the balk rule as written. The fact that there isn't any balk rule likewise doesn't mean a thing to Bob. The idea of not coming set has been presented to him by both word and action and in detail. The movement of pitching off the slow motion just before comes set is completely ignored.    I hope he wins every game he pitches and if we get a market on Garber, for heaven's sake make the most of it.      (SECOND PAGE IS DUPLICATED)

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    GILBERT, JIM    Left hand hitting outfielder. Very average arm, very average runner. He might become a good hitter and with some power.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: MAZATLAN VS CULIACAN AT CULIACAN, MEXICO  December 8, 1955.    MACKO    Culiacan first baseman.    6'2" tall, right hand hitter. Looks to be 24 or 25 years of age. Good batting form.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: April 27, 1955    HOLLYWOOD - LOS ANGELES GAME AT LOS ANGELES    MAZEROSKI    If this boy had any confidence at the plate, - any at all, he might be a very fine player in the Pacific Coast League this very year. He fields splendidly and has a lot of second base skills.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, Inc.  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    New York-St. Louis Game, May 13, 1955, at St. Louis.    MC CALL, "Windy" (Pitcher N.Y.)    In the seven innings that McCall worked against  the Cardinals, he must have thrown surely not less than   15 change ups on his fast ball, and they were one and all  effective pitches, and he used an equal number of slow  curves.    This fellow impresses me as a wily, clever pitcher.  He showed me good control of four pitches. I don't think  he has a great fast ball but he used what he has effectively.  I would call him a pretty smart pitcher. He is jolly well   worth the waiver price. I'd like to have him.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC.  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    Burlington-Greensboro Game  Burlington, N.C.  July 20, 1955    MCCARTHY (Greensboro - Center Fielder)    Left hand hitting outfielder. Can run like all get out, and he is alert on the bases.    B.R.    (Down side in large red letters COPY)

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: June 4, 1955  MCMAHON, JIM    Comes from the University of Connecticut, left hand hitter, about  6'3" tall, weighting about 190 pounds. He runs average and his  power is adequate. His batting form is good. I saw him against  Sam Marron only. I will see him after tonight's game.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: June 22, 1955    MEDIATE, TONY    Right hand youngster, about 18, and just about my height.   Will weigh around 160 pounds. Side-armer, -regularly, - few inches   above side-arm, and all curves, changes and fast balls are thrown from   that angle. Very good.    A good fast ball, - very surprising for a boy of his size.   Has a curve ball that breaks every now and then and when it breaks   "now" it is good, but "then" exceeds "now" by about three to one. He   throws a change-up on his fast ball, and he would get a very good one.   He says he throws a slow curve and [that] he takes it with a two finger   knuckle position, then he attempts to wrist curve it. No control of   it. He took the ball in the same knuckle position and then threw it   repeatedly as a fast ball and he got a drop spin curve out of it and   very good control. It would be at once a usable pitch as a deflecting   change of pace. In other words, the boy can quickly come up with four   different pitches.    This chap has an unusual mental pitching problem. His   control is very good indeed to a spot two feet to the right of the plate.   That is to say, every pitch, -curves, fast balls, -everything, would   hit a right hand batsman in the very back tip of his rump. When catcher   Levy would s tand [sic] two feet to the left, the boy would throw mostly   strikes. This leads me to say that his problem is mental. If he   wanted to throw the ball over the plate, he would be able to do it.   He has minor faults, one of which is the habit of pitching with one   or more of the spike points in contact with the rubber.    He is worth a job. Nothing more, - and indeed nothing   less. Should go to a D club and he might give a good account of   himself after his first two or three times out.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Dublin-Vidalia Game  Vidalia, Georgia  July 19, 1955    MEEKINS    Third baseman. Does not impress me as a prospect, even for the market. However, he is young and he should probably be given another season somewhere.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    MESSINA, DINO    Right hand hitter. Fair arm, doubtful power, - certainly not above average runner. Just from this one game, I have a very real doubt that this boy will ever reach the market.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: New York - St. Louis Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis    MAYS, WILLIE (N.Y. Outfielder)    I would pitch a lot of slow stuff to Mays, particularly when he is anxious to hit. The slow curve ball he 'slobbers' all over the place. You might occasionally get the fast ball by him but I would worry about it a bit and I would try to make him hit the breaking stuff and particularly the changes, and this does not mean at all that he will never hit the changes. The fellow is simply a good hitter.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: SALINAS-CHANNEL CITIES' GAMES OF MAY 17TH AND MAY 18TH, 1955 AT SALINAS, CALIFORNIA.    MYERS, JOHN    I am told that the boy is a bad receiver. It could be, but there is no reason for John not being a good receiver. Whatever faults he may have in this respect could easily be corrected. He can receive and he can throw. He cannot run and after two years of playing, I don't believe he is very much improved as a hitter. When he does connect, the ball goes foul. Nothing probably would be lost if he were given his unconditional release.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: Dublin-Vidalia Game  Vidalia, Ga.  July 19, 1955    MINJOK    Tall, right hander. In the two innings I saw him pitch, he showed inexperience, nervousness, and was very self-conscious, - extremely so.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB  St. Louis-New York Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis, Mo.    MOFORD (Pitcher - St. Louis)    A tall, good looking right hander. I don't know his age, but he has a beautiful curve ball and good speed. I never saw him before and I may never see him again, but on the two or three innings which I saw him, I would like to have him. I want to know about his past record and he must be followed closely. I don't know how Stanky or the Cardinal club regard him.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, INC  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    St. Louis-New York Game, May 13, 1955, at St. Louis, Mo.    MOON (St. Louis Outfielder)    He can't throw, or didn't - maybe ailing arm. - not good. I think the runners   should regularly go to third on balls hit to Moon in right   field. The left handers are bothering him.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; T-Z
Transcription: June 22, 1955    MOORE, GAYLE    Well built boy, 18 years of age, weighing 165 pounds, and 5'9" tall. He is a shortstop, left hand hitter, and he runs good, - I would say good average in the major league. His arm is so so, - not great, - fairly quick and accurate. This boy has good body control.    He is not what you would call a power hitter from any major league standpoint. He is not a puny.    Gayle does not have a great arm. He does not have great running speed and he does not have great power. From a major league standpoint, he is not great in any department.    For example, compare Gayle with the boy from the University of George, Reggie Andrews. Andrews will out-run him, and will out-throw him, and I would say the hitting prospects would rate about the same. If Gayle can get a job at $4000, in justice to himself and to his folks and to everybody, I would say that he should take it. I would like to have him simply on a job basis. His hitting eventually might carry him quite a ways. However, I don't care to gamble $4000 on that chance, - not now, with Pittsburgh finances as they are.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: April 23, 1955    SAN FRANCISCO-HOLLYWOOD GAME AT SAN FRANCISCO    MORAN (San Francisco Second Baseman)    Walks, swings, and acts like he can't hit and doesn't expect to hit,  and in the three games I saw him, he was very true to his actions.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY  OPERATING   PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    New York St. Louis Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis.    MONTE IRVIN (Left Fielder N.Y.)    I think that Irvin always looks for a fast ball.   He will play the curve ball, but he strokes it much more   gently than he does the fast pitches. I regard him as the   most outstanding guess hitter in the league today, and   further I do not regard him as a good curve ball hitter.   All outfielders must play him deep, and in Forbes Field the   right fielder should play him toward center.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: PITTSBURGH ATHLETIC COMPANY, Inc.  OPERATING  PITTSBURGH BASEBALL CLUB    St. Louis-New York Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis, Mo.    MUSIAL, STAN    Hits anything and everything anywhere it is pitched  and can hit in all directions. He is still a good runner  but not a base stealer, - never was.    The Philadelphia Club, particularly Robin Roberts,  pitched him fast balls outside, but with men on the bases  and two and none, Roberts came with the curve ball and  followed it with three more curve balls and each of these  curves looked simply like Roberts' regular curve ball.  I believe Musial hits all low pitched balls to right   field. Pitched balls well over the plate and below  Musial's waistline will be pulled to right field  regularly. Show this statement to Fred and ask him if  I am right about it.    In Sportsmen's Park in a close ball game, Musial  is allowed to hit the three and none with a man on base  anywhere when two are out. In fact, if the game were a  tie game, it should be kept in mind that Musial is permitted  to hit the three and none pitch with anybody on base and  two out. This is important because this is the usual   tactics on the part of Stanky and Musial under the above  circumstances.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: April 23, 1955    SAN FRANCISCO-HOLLYWOOD GAME AT SAN FRANCISCO    NAGY (San Francisco Pitcher)    Has no stuff and has no control of no stuff. If this is a double  negative, make the most of it.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: Havana, Cuba  January 20, 1955    GONZALOS NARANJO    20 years of age, 6' tall, 165 pounds, right hander,   small fingers, but long, hand big enough, Cuban, white  boy, nice manners, speaks pretty good English, not  married, good habits, intelligent.    This chap has a pretty good fast ball and a   corking curve, - that is to say that he has it most of  the time. Then it won't curve. When the time comes  that his curve curves all the time like it does some of the  time, he will be a very fine curve ball pitcher.    He has aptitude. He has been with Bragan all  year and has been under good managers and coaches for  two years previous to this winter, and he is ambitious  and inquisitive and wants to learn, yet no one has given  him any attention to changes of speed. He throws a slow  curve and it is good, except that his delivery on this  pitch is known to everyone in the park before he lets go   of the ball. Therefore, his change-up is not worth a  nickel. He can learn a change-up on his fast ball, and  did, and he is the sort of boy who will work on it.    I want him to report to our Fort Myers camp,  February 15th. Please tell Bob Rice.    I also worked Naranjo on what I call the thumb back  change of pace curve. He will learn that, in fact he is  the kind of chap who will do what he is told. I have  great hopes for this boy.    He has fully recovered, so he says, from any and  all arm ailments he has had in the past year. He  attributes his recovery to his tonsillectomy.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: February 25, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    WILLIAM MAZEROSKI    Not a great runner. A really remarkable forearm.  He is barely 18 years of age even now, and he played last  season at Williamsport. His batting form is excellent. I  think he might become a corking hitter.    His fielding indicates a second baseman of high order.  Don't know anything about his habits or temperament, but no  boy is a bad boy at his age, and not very many indeed before  they reach 25. This boy is a very sure prospect for  Pittsburgh.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: NARANJO, GONZALOS (PRESENTLY ON HOLLYWOOD ROSTER)    20 year old right hander from Havana, Cuba. Last year with Charlotte, - but was plagued with a sore arm. Has had his tonsils removed and player claims his arm has recovered to normalcy. Pittsburgh organization drafted this player at the last draft meeting. Pitched this Winter for the Almendares Club in the Cuba Winter League and was so impressive that Mr. Rickey wanted a look at him in our early camp. He has been held over.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: JALAPA VS. AZTECAS AT SECURITY STADIUM, MEXICO CITY, OH  NOVEMBER 17TH AND NOVEMBER 19TH, 1955.    NAVARRETE    Shortstop on the Aztecas. Young kid. Good batting form,  might come to be a pretty good hitter. Not big, only a   fair arm. Runs pretty good. We might follow up on  him.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: April 23, 1955  SAN FRANCISCO-HOLLYWOOD GAME AT SAN FRANCISCO    NECCIAI    Poor boy, he is really an object of pity. He cannot throw hard and he has no control at all. He is hardly a shadow of his former self. The only time he looks like a pitcher is when he throws underhand. This pitch has more velocity than any other, but it gives him about 1/2 of what he used to have. I was almost in tears for his sake to watch him pitch 3-1/2 innings against San Francisco. He gave up only one hit, walked four and hit two men. If the San Francisco batters had gone to the plate without a bat they would have beat him to death.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: January 21, 1955  Havana, Cuba    RON NEGRAY    If this chap is ever to become a real major leaguer,  he must get an additional pitch and probably better  control. Even if he had perfect control of what he's  got, he would still have trouble in the majors.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA,  BETWEEN MARIANO AND ALMENDARES    The first baseman was  NELSON, a sort of a fixture down here. We all know Nelson.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: MAZATLAN VS CULIACAN AT CULICAN, MEXICO,  DECEMBER 8, 1955.    NIXON    Culiacan catcher.    Left hand hitter. About 5'11" or may be 6'  tall, 175 pounds. Fair arm, but very   inaccurate in the fielding practice, and I  don't believe the boy has any power at the  plate. Believe he belongs to the Cleveland  organization.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 18, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN CIENFUEGOS AND HAVANA    His catcher is    NOBLE NOBLE can throw and he works hard enough. I would not   call him a good receiver at all. He can hit the ball hard, - if  he hits it. He can be pitched to and even if he were ten years  younger, he would not, in my book, be a major league prospect. He  might do a good job in the International League as a catcher for Bob  Maduro if the rest of the club were high class. I would never trade   for him as desirable for any of our minor league clubs.     MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 22, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME BETWEEN ALMENDARES  AND CIENFUEGOS, AT HAVANA, CUBA .    NOBLE belies his looks. He is a good sort, a gentleman.  Considered by people who are in a position to know as   high class.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: SAM NUNN - Not yet 18. Comes from Long Beach. 6'4", 190 pounds,  right hander. Only child. Father works in a tool machine shop. Fast  ball is good enough to go all the way. His delivery is good on all  pitches. He takes the change on the fast ball immediately, and it  would be effective within the next two or three days. He learned a  new change on teh curve ball, and it was not the thumb pitch. It is  a dandy.     The fast curve is not good, but the boy can learn almost  anything quicker than almost any boy I have had in my hands in a long  time. He just does it.     He has tremendous hands and talks sense. I would put him  in the class with our very best prospects in the entire Pittsburgh organization.     I talked with him about bonus and advised him first to  consider going with an organization that is administratively set up for  a championship future, and second to go with an organization where his  advancement would be quickest and most permanent, and that he should then  consider in third place the amount of bonus. I think I made hay with him.    I like the chap very much and I defy all you boys in the   Hollywood camp to show me a better one.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: July 11, 1955  Burlington, N.C.    Pitchers MALCOLM, OLSEN, AND SCHULTZ should have been able to help the Burlington club. Their records are not good in any respect. It is the consensus of opinion on the part of the press and the radio, citizens, ownership, baseball scouts, and what-nots that the present Burlington club is the very worst that has ever represented the city.  Dorton says that, in his opinion, there is nothing on the club worth my time in seeing the team in a game. I don't believe that in fifty years that I have ever had a team in Class B with so many uniformly bad reports.  Fowler will take another big financial loss this season. He doesn't complain, makes no accusations against anybody. He takes any player we send him on whatever terms anyone makes. I feel very sorry for him. His savings of approximately $50,000 will probably be wiped out by the end of the present season.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: February 17, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    ANDY OLSEN    Left hander, 6' tall, 190 pounds. Got a good fast ball, better than average, and he has a good curve, - in fact he has two curves. Throws a change up on his fast ball. In other words, he has plenty of stuff. Acts nervous, could be some sort of a hypochondriac. Could be.    Ordinarily on all pitches, he has a tendency to step back with his left foot. He has no follow through with his body. The force of his pitch throws him backwards. He has stuff and he might pitch anywhere. He belongs to Hollywood and we will judge from his games here whether or not to send him on to Hollywood for further training.    Eyes set close together    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: April 23, 1955    SAN FRANCISCO-HOLLYWOOD GAME AT SAN FRANCISCO    OLSEN, ANDY    This boy never comes set with a man on first. He is exact opposite of Gerber. If Olsen would throw to first occasionally on his movement, he might be alright. The umpire never calls a balk on him, although every pitch is a balk. Showed me no fast ball at all, but showed a variety of pitches. He should go back to B.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: July 11, 1955  Burlington, N. C.     Pitchers MALCOLM, OLSEN, AND SCHULTZ should have been   able to help the Burlington club. Their records   are not good in any respect. It is the consensus of   opinion on the part of the press and the radio,   citizens, ownership, baseball scouts, and what-nots   that the present Burlington club is the very worst   that has ever represented the city.    Dorton says that, in his opinion, there is nothing   on the club worth my time in seeing the team in a   game. I don't believe that in fifty years that I   have ever had a team in Class B with so many   uniformly bad reports.    Fowler will take another big financial loss this   season. He doesn't complain, makes no accusations   against anybody. He takes any player we send him on   whatever terms anyone makes. I feel very sorry   for him. His savings of approximately $50,000 will   probably be wiped out by the end of the present season.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: February 21, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    JIM O'NEIL    A big, tall 6'5", 211 pounder, - too much weight. He has wonderful control of everything. Pretty good fast ball, but he needs target work. His delivery on everything is good. He must go to the target under Bill Burwell.    This fellow throws a knuckle ball and his delivery on it is perfect. Same identically as the fast ball. Good control of it. It is not a good knuckle ball, but it is useable because it has the effect of a change of speed. He should include it in his repertoire constantly. At the end of the workout, I taught him a change up on his fast ball. He must get some pitch because his curve ball is not good enough. He must work daily on this change up, thirty minutes per day at the 35 foot mark.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: LINCOLN-COLORADO SPRINGS GAME OF MAY 16, 1955 AT COLORADO SPRINGS    PADGETT, DON    Well built youngster, right hand hitter, played third tonight. My first look. With the bases full and one man out, a ball was hit to Padgett. He played it very slowly and instead of stepping on third base six feet away, he threw to second. He should have stepped on third and thrown to first base for an early double play. One run scored. Two more runs followed.    Padgett's form at the plate is good. I liked his appearance very much. I am not too sure about his running speed, but I believe it is at least average.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: June 22, 1955    PANEK, BOB    Just out of high school, and his high school did not have a baseball team. Tall, lanky, fellow. No fast ball. His delivery would keep him from fielding his position.    He has a pretty good curve ball and good control of it. It would be a fine change of speed pitch. He throws a change up on his fast ball. Just learning it. It is too fast.    He throws a knuckle ball and this pitch he should keep on throwing. It might make him into a fair pitcher. It breaks the same way and sooner or later he would have good control of it. He is not worth a professional contract at this time. He needs to pitch semi-professional ball and one cannot tell what he might ultimately do. I don't count him completely out because he might come to have as many as three usable pitches other than his fast ball and cleverness with those three pitches might make him into something or other.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: August 20, 1955    JAMES PASSILLA    Tall boy from Meadville, Pa. Right hand hitter. Shortstop. Wears glasses. He can throw and he looked to me like he could handle a ground ball. On account of other work, I was simply unable to give the boy proper attention. I saw him hit only once. I cannot pass on his hitting. I saw him run out one hit at a distance. He impressed me as not certainly above an average runner.     Because of our lack of decision, I think the effort should be made go get him to go to spring training.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: July 13, 1955  Brunswick, Georgia    PATCHELL, STANLEY    Right hander, third year out. First year at Billings, next year with St. Johns and Brunswick, and this year with Phoenix and Brunswick.    "Why in your third year do you find yourself still in D?"    "I don't know the answer to that", he said, "I am wondering too."    "Well, there is some good reason for you being in D".    "Well, I suppose there is, but I don't know what it is. I would like to find out, because I know I can pitch anywhere."    Then I said, "even in the majors?"    "Yes, in the majors!"    This boy is a well built, 185 pound, 6'1' tall athlete with a lot of action and a lot of speed. Curve ball is good. I would say that his control also should be good. There is no reason for his being wild. His hand is big enough and his delivery is normal. Everything about him is good. He looks to be a good fielder.    He could be a positive, opinionated person with ideas about everything, perhaps talkative - I don't know. But, he has pretty good stuff, that's a cinch.    It's a bit of a mystery to me why he is not able to make good in higher company.    It is probably safe to protect him from the draft, - no higher than A.    Here is the common criticism to be made of the handling of pitchers in modern baseball. For example, Duffalo in his workout with me showed great control and I said to him, "when did you pitch last?", thinking that recent and regular pitching accounted for his fine control. My

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: PATCHELL, STANLEY (Cont.)    setback came when he told me that he had not pitched for   seven days. "I get to pitch about every eighth or   ninth day, counting in the bad weather." Now there   was a boy who should be worked with three days rest.   Patchell has only pitched 31 innings. Duffalo has  pitched 91 innings and has been down here in this   league since mid-April. In fact, he has pitched   the most innings of anybody. It isn't fair to the   player, or to his future, or to the Pittsburgh   organization for these youngsters to be pitched once   every ten days, and yet here in Pittsburgh if you   talk about pitchers working with three days of rest, such   a person is considered crazy. It is no wonder that the   pitchers who come up to Pittsburgh have in mind seven   days rest as that is all they experienced in the minor   leagues. I feel like assigning our Class C and D   clubs only four pitchers. We would get further and   faster and have better results and better boys pitching   on the Pittsburgh club.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: June 4, 1955    PEELER, TOM    Left hand pitcher from Buffalo, 22 years of age, married, (three years), no children. In 1950 he was with the Yankees and pitched for Newark, Ohio, winning 14 and losing 1. In 1951, the Yankees offered him $200 per month salary and he quit, and didn't play that entire season. In 1952 he joined the Quincy club and I believe finished that year with Palm Beach. His record was fairly good in both places and while at Palm Beach he was drafted into the army. He returned to the Yankee organization this past spring of '55 from the army and was sent to Winston-Salem. He was in good shape. For the first three weeks of the season he was not given a single starting assignment. The Yankees said he was washed up and assigned his contract outright to Grand Forks. The player was very unhappy with his alleged treatment and quit the Grand Forks club and stated he had an ailing arm. Various things happened and at the end of three weeks in Grand Forks he was given his unconditional release. Immediately his arm was fully recovered and he told Dick Fischer that he was in great shape and ready to go to town and wanted a bonus for signing. Dick Fischer evidently believes in this fellow and sent him to Pittsburgh for me to look over. I did. The player has an ordinary fast ball but good control of it. He throws what he calls a spinner, which is another name for the modern new-fangled pitch generally called a slider. It slides. I don't believe in the pitch at all.     Tom's curve ball is just so so. Fair speed on it and it does break, - not a great deal, but it breaks. He has good control of the curve. He throws a change-up on his fast ball but he tips it off plenty. He throws it with a complete give-away motion. If this pitcher were able to acquire a knuckle ball, a usable knuckle ball, he might go places. He seems to have composure and I would say a very acceptable pitching disposition. He wants $1000 bonus to sign.    I told him I would give him a job at Burlington with a Class B salary and no bonus. He was quite disappointed and felt that if he could not get $1000 to sign a contract, then he would go into something else. This I advised him to do.    Tom Peeler has had three years in the Buffalo State Teachers College. He is not a bust but he is not great.     Sukey worked with me on Tom. I should like to get his advice.    (LATER) Talked with Sukey and he agree with me.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN, PUERTO RICO, ON JANUARY 25, 1955.    MALZONE, a third baseman, not very big, but runs well, and throws well, and stands up to the plate well. He looks to me like a pretty good ball player.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: Fort Myers, Fla.  March 4, 1955    LAURIN PEPPER    6' tall, weighs bout 200 pounds. Can run like the dickens and can throw hard. The fact is that he has a very good fast ball. it really has plenty of velocity. He showed me no curve ball. Sukey called it a 'slider' and told me that it was an 'intentional slider'. He through a change-up curve ball which was good enough and his change up on the fast ball may be good if he can get it somewhere near the plate.    This fellow, at sometime or other in his early life, or perhaps when he was in grade school, hit some kid somewhere or other and hurt him, - and all through his adolescence and through his college course and up to now he has had the idea and undoubtedly still has it that the plate is an imaginary floating jumping jack located somewhere away from the batter. In 19 straight fast ball pitches, only one was a strike, the other eighteen were outside and away from the batter, - whether the batter was a left hander or a right hander, it made no difference. He shows signs of being definitely afraid to pitch inside to any batsman. How long it will take to get out of his head the fact that plate is located very close to the batter and that some of the batters are even as close to the plate as 6", I don't know. But I do know that he has to come to the facts of life.    It would be very surprising thing to me if this boy could win right now in Class B. However, he couldn't win there if the batters would simply take pitches and not swing on the bad ones. He would be a very much better pitcher in our league at the present time if he never threw a single fast ball, - not one. It serves only to put him in the hole.    He comes definitely set on all pitches with men on bases. He could very easily vary this position. He conforms strictly to the balk rule and that is good and proper. However, the balk rule is not enforced anywhere, and this boy must come to pitch with some regularity without coming to the stop. The last three or found inches of his movement before he comes "to set" are made very slowly and he could pitch off this slow movement and tie up every runner.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: March 4, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    LAURIN PEPPER (CONTINUED)    He needs a lot of work and talking to. He has ideas, - ideas of his own. He is not a featherhead at all, but he needs to get new ideas and practice on them until he comes habituated to definite ideas.    This chap is a fine athlete. He has body control. He can run and I think he will be able someday to pitch and perhaps be a very intelligent pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY    P.S. Later in conversation with this boy I found out that he had hit a kid when he was in high school and hurt him badly.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: Dublin-Vidalia Game  Vidalia, Ga.  July 19, 1955    PERRY    Plenty of stuff, but wild. He simply needs to grow up. When he knows something, he will do something, and when he comes to know that he knows, he might be a champion.    (LATER)    Perry is a good example of the average young pitcher. He is not only 2 and 0 very frequently, but he is pretty much confirmed as a 3 and 0 pitcher. And he is also an example of most inexperienced or dumb pitchers in that he either does not have change-ups or he refuses to use them. He is simply a two pitch pitcher.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: SALINAS-CHANNEL CITIES' GAMES OF MAY 17TH and MAY 18TH, 1955 AT SALINAS, CALIFORNIA    PITTS  A left hander about 22 years of age. Not big, but strong. He has good stuff. More speed, I think, than May. He walked 8 men in six innings but he was consistently close to the stroke zone all the time. He didn't show nervousness, - not really wildness at all.    This pitcher has two real faults:    FIRST FAULT  His third pitch, a change up on his fast ball is always outside and above the waistline. Nearly always it is thrown side arm or rather it has a side arm pitch effect. To a right hander, it should be, and I think is, an effective screw ball. This change up in itself is quite a pitch. Apparently he is afraid to pitch it over the plate. And also, apparently, he thinks the pitch should be above the waistline rather than below it. If Pitts would get his change up on the fat ball into the strike zone and then pitch it oftener, he can go places.    I like Pitts. I think he has a good chance. His fast ball is good enough and his curve ball is good.    SECOND FAULT  Whenever Pitts gets behind the hitter or in trouble for any reasons, HE presses, - more obviously than any young pitcher I can now think of. He throws his fast ball with extra effort and then he really is wild, i.e., wild for Pitts. Instead of him becoming a thinker, and clever, and resourceful, and trying to mentally out-maneuver the batsman, he resorts to force. he thinks, "now I have got to over-power him." He goes in the direction of an animal. Whatever human intelligence he may have, at that moment goes out the window.    When in trouble, Pritts becomes a "pressing pitcher."    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: SALINAS-CHANNEL CITIES' GAMES OF MAY 17TH AND MAY 18TH, 1955 AT  SALINAS, CLIFORNIA.      PIVER, VERN    Fine arm, stands up to the plate vey good, good runner.  Gets no lead off first base but acts energetic. Gets no lead off  second either, but he gives you the impression of intending to run.  Shows a lot of life and fight. If he hits, he might go into the  money. I like this boy.        B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: Dublin-Vidalia Game  Vidalia, Georgia  July 19, 1955      PROBITSKY    Left hand hitter. He is leading this  league in batting percentage, but if I ever saw anybody  without power at the plate, he is that person. He  is one sweet fielder. He starts before you can see  him start. He knows where the ball is and he does  not time the catch. He can come in and he can go  back and he can go anywhere defensively.    Runs average, throws average. I can hardly  imagine a boy of his lack of power ever reaching the   money market. This boy can be protected from the  draft very easily if that move seems desirable.      B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA,  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES.    The second baseman was    QUINTANA This boy played shortstop for San Antonio in 1954 and  is now on the Baltimore list. He is generally regarded as a  shortstop and he has shifted to second because Dick Smith is the  Marianao shortstop. This boy is about 5' 11" tall, very slim,  young, - not over 25, and he runs very well. His hitting form  is acceptable in all respects. He is not impressive for power at  bat and probably a very ordinary hitter in the record book. He makes  the plays and one a one game look, I would class him as a chance   for the major leagues. Baltimore's other shortstop candidate is  Miranda. With my limited knowledge of the two players, I would  take Quintana.    MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 20, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND HAVANA.    QUINTATA has more power than he showed me in the previous game. I   doubt if he is a great fielder. His arm, however, is good enough  and he is well above average in running speed.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 18, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN CIENFUEGOS AND HAVANA    RAND. Bragan says he is the best catcher in Cuba and a great  major leaguer. I doubt it. He stands on top of the plate and  he is having another good year in Cuba, - hitting pretty good,  catching pretty good. He has a strong arm, but didn't throw  directly overhand at anytime, either in the fielding practice or  in the game. He is probably a better catcher than he showed  tonight and might be desirable. He has good size and fairly good  action, and he is youthful. We will watch him.    MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 20, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND HAVANA    RAND is a good receiver, - excellent. He throws almost three-quarters,  but he has a strong arm. A right hand hitter, his right toe is not  two inches away from the plate. He is hitting .265 in this league  but I don't believe he can hit anything like that against major  league pitching. He will have to change his position surely.  However, the necessary fundementals are not lacking in this fellow  when he goes to bat.    If the Cardinals get pitching, look out for them in 1956.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA, BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES  [*arrow pointing to ALMENDARES*]    In left field was    EARL RAPP Quite evidently he has quit on himself, - helpless at the plate. LYONS, the Pacific Coast League right handed hitter, hit for him in the 8th inning against Kent Peterson.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: POZA RICA VS PUEBLO AT PUEBLO, MEXICO, ON NOVEMBER 17TH AND 18TH, 1955 AND POZA RICA VS MEXICO CITY AT POZA RICA ON DECEMBER 1ST AND 2ND.    RAYLES  Mexican relief pitcher with courage and apparently great confidence. No prospect.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: April 23, 1955  SAN FRANCISCO-HOLLYWOOD GAME AT SAN FRANCISCO   MANGAN  Bragan says that Mangan is a smart catcher, - knows how to handle  pitchers, - knows what pitch to ball etc. I cannot agree at all.   I think he will put any young pitcher to a lower classification   as fast as he can possibly go there.   I believe an examination of my previous report on Mangan will show the same criticism.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: August 26, 1955    BOB REAGAN    A diminutive, 20 year old right hand hitting shortstop, average runner, very average arm, quick as a cat, and considering his size and strength, this boy is a darn good hitter He knows the strike zone and would be a pest up at the plate. Got a good piece of each pitch. He would be of interest in a spring training camp too. He has more natural ability as a batsman than you see in most kids.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: April 23, 1955    SAN FRANCISCO-HOLLYWOOD GAME AT SAN FRANCISCO    REGHETTI (Shortstop at San Francisco)    If this fellow could hit consistently, he might be a pretty good ball player.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: MAZATLAN VS CULIACAN AT CULIACAN, MEXICO, ON DECEMBER 8TH  AND 9TH, 1955.      REJON  Third baseman on Culiacan club.  He can't run and he can't throw. Certainly does not have power.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: St. Louis-New York Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis, Mo.    REPULSKI (St. Louis Outfielder)    Change up curve, from either a left hand or a right hander, - he does not like. he looks to me like a good all-around ball player.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: POZA RICA VIS PUEBLO AT PUEBLO, MEXICO, ON NOVEMBER 17TH  AND 18TH, 1955.  PUEBLO VS MEXICO CITY REDS AT MEXICO CITY ON NOVEMBER 26, 1955.    RESENDIZ    First baseman, Pueblo club. Fat tub. Cannot do anything.      B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: February 19, 1955  Fort Myers, Fa.    CURTIS REYDON    I think this boy has good aptitude. He has no change of speeds on either the fast ball or curve and he should have one or the other of them good, indeed very good if he is to become a great pitcher and it would be a fine accomplishment if he had useable control of both changes, and in my judgment he might get both. he is a simon pure rookie when it comes to learning a change of speed pitch either on the fast ball or the curve ball. Curt is a willing worker and wants to be great.    This boy is scheduled to practice for the next four days, 50 pitches each day at 30' at the target on his change-up on the curve ball. He can get it.    BRANCH RICKEY    His delivery on all pitches is perfect and I mean by that you cannot tell the difference between his curve or fast balls or his attempts to throw changes. He follows through and finishes well. There is no tip off on his changes.    It is my judgment that this fellow will come to have good control. I base this statement on the fact that he has fine control of his fast ball.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: POZA RICA VS PUEBLO AT PUEBLO, MEXICO, ON NOVEMBER 17TH  AND 18TH, 1955.        R. REYNA    Poza Rica pitcher. I did not see him.      B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: LINCOLN-COLORADO SPRINGS GAME OF MAY 16, 1955 AT COLORADO SPRINGS      RICE, FRANK    Rice played centerfield tonight. A right hand  hitter. This is his league.      B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: April 23, 1955      SAN FRANCISCO-HOLLYWOOD GAME AT SAN FRANCISCO      RICHEY (Catcher on San Francisco Club)    He can't throw and he is not accurate with any of his trajectories.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: Brusnwick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    RIKARD, BOB (Albany Catcher)    Big, right hand hitting catcher. Undoubtedly has power at the plate.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: POZA RICA VS PUEBLO AT PUEBLO, MEXICO, ON NOVEMBER 17TH  AND 18TH AND PUEBLO VS MEXICO CITY REDS AT MEXICO CITY  ON NOVEMBER 26TH, 1955.    MARTELL    Unimpressive in every respect in the three games I saw.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: WILLIAMSPORT-BINGHAMTON GAME AT WILLIAMSPORT, PA. ON  JULY 9, 1955      RIVERA, CHICO (Binghamton)    Shortstop. Not big, very aggressive, well below  average hitter, quick, active, fair runner. Not  especially impressive in any respect. Compared to   Barone's arm, Rivera hasn't any.        B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    ROBERTSON, TERRY  Well built boy, fine arm, stands up to the plate very well. So far as I can seem there isn't anything to keep this boy from coming to be a pretty good hitter.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA,  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES    At third base was    HECTOR RODRIGUEZ, last year somewhere in the International League.  He is a good runner, a good AAA ball player. If he could hit  enough, he could be a major leaguer.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN, PUERTO  RICO, ON JANUARY 25, 1955.      There are three boys named Rodriguez on this club, -   JULIO RODRIGUEZ, an outfielder, - not a prospect, and the second  one is a third baseman, - also not a prospect, and the third one  is our own boy, who is known hereabouts as JUNIOR RODRIGUEZ.  He was at Waco last year. Plays most anywhere, and possibly as  good a player as either of the other kids of the same name.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: April 27, 1955    LOS ANGELES-HOLLYWOOD GAME AT LOS ANGELES    RODREIGUEZ, Leonardo  A sturdy boy, about 5'7", 170 pounds or thereabouts, - maybe less, with a quick, accurate arm. He played shortstop in the two games I saw him. He is a quick starter, exceedingly fast in his reflexes. Only a fair runner, and not a great arm. I would say his position is not shortstop, probably only a third baseman. His future depends entirely upon his hitting ability. Might be a corking utility man in this league.    Del Greco is going great at third, and so long as Del Greco hits as he is now, he cannot be benched. I think that Sanchez is a better shortstop than Rodriguez, and will probably hit the ball with more power.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; C-D
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 18, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN CIENFUEGOS AND HAVANA    The pitcher for Havana tonight was    ROEBUCK A tall rugged right hander, who impresses me as a good   athlete. He runs well and in the batting practice he showed a  lot of power with the club, and he showed it in the game. It would  be my guess that he is able to help himself in every game he pitches.  He showed a very good fast ball and a good curve, both overhand and  sidearm. Changed up very little. He was master of the situation  all through the game, - allowed only three or four hits, struck  out three or four men, and gave only one or two bases on balls.  He didn't need to be smart to beat Cienfuegos, - in fact, he shut  them out. I can easily think of him as a future major leaguer.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: SALINAS-CHANNEL CITIES' GAME OF MAY 17TH AND MAY 18TH, 1955 AT   SALINAS, CALIFORNIA    MAY, RONNIE    Has enough stuff to win here and might go into the  money. One cannot tell how far the kid might go. All of this  is said having in mind that he must get control of his three  pitches.    (LATER)    This left handed, 21 year old has the appearance of guts  and intelligence, but I cannot understand his pitching policy, which  never varies. With two strikes and no balls, - first he will  throw the fast ball every time and second he will throw it high and  two feet away from the batsman, - whether the batsman is left or  right handed. It makes no difference. He has marvelous control  of this pitch. It will go almost exactly hair high and within a  gallon bucket two feet outside of the plate. I doubt very much  if Ronnie May has ever thrown a ball in his life high and tight to  a batsman. I really doubt it. AND this pitch could make him.    Generally speaking, May's fast ball should be either  spot pitched or pocketed. Of course there are times when he should  throw the fast ball down through the middle, e.g., on sure "takes".  Otherwise, the ball should be generally pitched for effect. He has  two curves and he has a dandy change-up on his fast ball, but he  throws this latter change-up invariably high, and again away from  the hitter. The only ball that May throws close to any batter is  his curve and that, I take it, not by intent.
