This boy  needs a new bath of courage on pitching close to batsmen, or  perhaps I should say a new deal on knowledge of pitching.    I like May. I think he might go places. If he were  to become a smart pitcher, I do not find it at all incredible for him  to be regarded as a major league prospect.    Therefore, this long dissertation.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: June 30, 1955    JOSEPH ROSANIA    Well built boy, 175#, and a pretty good arm, - not great. Pretty good power, - not great, - has quick wrists. i would not be surprised if the boy became a pretty good hitter. Don't know how he runs. I don't think he would ever hit a ball over our fence, but he might become a good hitter in Forbes Field. Not easy to fool.    B.R.    Running speeds  6.6 6/29/55  6.9 6/30/95

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: February 16, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    DOMINGO ROSELLO    This fellow has a good curve ball and a good fast ball, a change up on the curve, and a change up on the fast ball. His delivery tips off both pitchers, - not bad, but it does tip off. He has a beautiful delivery from the standpoint of fielding his position. He has a Newcombe hop when he bears down. He is undoubtedly a prospect.    His regular curve breaks, I would say, about one half the time, - just about that, and when it doesn't break, it is just too bad. The encouraging thing about this weakness is that Domingo knows it, and he knows it instantly when he lets loose of the ball. Now that should be some reason for hope that he will improve his curve even without instruction.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: SALINAS-CHANNEL CITIES' GAMES OF MAY 17TH AND MAY 18TH, 1955 AT  SALINAS, CALIFORNIA      ROSSELLO    Tall right hand Cuban pitcher, about 20 years of age.   He can run and if the right hand pitcher's side arm curve ball  was never thrown, or if indeed right hand pitchers did not have  curves, this fellow might become a major league outfielder.  BUT, ------------ it so happens that right hand pitchers do have  curves. He can hit the inside ball and indeed he can hit his  pitch with extraordinary power.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: SALINAS-CHANNEL CITIES'S GAME OF MAY 17TH AND MAY 18TH, 1955 AT SALINAS, CALIFORNIA    RUCKER, JOHN    It is my opinion that we threw away some railway fare when we sent this boy out here. He put on a fine exhibition of hitting in Pittsburgh at Forbes Field against Sam Narron. He is very nervous at the plate, and sags, buckles, and water-buckets all together and at once on practically every pitch. In fact, he does everything at the plate but hit. If he would get his pitch he would have power. Give him his unconditional release immediately. He can run and his arm is O.K. I doubt if this club should keep him thirty minutes.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: MAZATLAN VS CAULIACAN AT CULIACAN, MEXICO, DECEMBER 8, 1955.    MARTINEZ    Pitcher on Mazatlan Club.    He showed me the sum total of nothing. He has a roundhouse curve, no speed, - a typical batting practice pitcher.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA,  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES.    In center field was  SAFFELL He looks helpless. Not doing any good down here. Can run and does, and intelligently too. And Saffell can field. Arm good enough. His habits are questionable. I have had some conversation with him and I intend to talk further with him. He reports to our club in Fort Myers on March 1st.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN, PUERTO  RICO, ON JANUARY 25, 1955.    SANFORD, an infielder belonging to the Giants, played second base.  Does not impress me at all with his running speed. Played well  in the fielding practice at second base and was also good in the  game. He is a right hand hitter and showed some power. Hit  a ball four miles into the left-centerfield stands, but it is my  guess that that hit was an exceptional stroke for him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: July 7, 1955    SANFORD, JACK    6' right hander from Springfield College. All his actions  remind me of Murray Dickson. A pretty good fast ball and pretty good  control of it. Curve ball fair. Fine person, good intelligence,   and might go into the money, and if he gets a really usable third  pitch, - of course he might go anywhere. He needs work with me or  somebody who will try to help him get this third pitch.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: St. Louis-New York Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis, Mo.    SARNI (Catcher - St. Louis   Not a great arm. He is a faster runner than  most catchers and he hits the right hander's curve ball  pretty well. The change up curve ball bothers him, -  in fact any change up ball bothers him. He is a better  hitter than he is rated in the average baseball mind.  Hits mostly to left field, I would say, but you cannot play  for him. Do not underrate him as a hitter.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: February 18, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    ROGER SAWYER    I am just as strong on this boy being a major leaguer as I have   ever been, but his progress is disappointing. He has not   perfected his change ups to the point where he is willing to use  them and his lack of control of these change ups may be sufficient  reason for his unwillingness to use them in a game. I chance to   think that he has not applied himself assiduously on acquiring  control of these pitches.    He still pitches his regular curve ball high, - too high, and if  he can throw the ball consistently high, then if he really wants  to do it, he could throw the same pitch consistently low, and that's  all there is to it.    He needs to go to the target and work on his changes every day.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: Fort Myers, Fla.  February 25, 1955    ROGER SAWYER    I am as strong for this fellow as heretofore.  He can have remarkable control and he knows what it means when  he is told to do something. He not only tries to do it,  but he does do it. For example, originally as a pitcher, he  held his glove sidewise in covering up. That habit is  completely gone and the full back of the glove faces the  batter on every delivery. He has good control of his side  arm, I call it, fast ball. Throws it a little above side  arm. The pitch is usually low but in the strike zone. He  has a curve ball that talks. Doesn't break all the time,  but much better regularity on it than Brown, and a great deal  better than Rosello. These boys have great curve balls, - - -  when it curves. Sawyer's curve will break much better than  one-half the time. He has a dandy change up on his fast  ball, but he doesn't have control of it. If he could get  control of this pitch, I think he could go anywhere, - right  now. He is working on it. He is also working on his change  up on his [fast] curve ball, but his change up on the fast ball  is a darn good pitch, and I believe he will get useable control  of it very soon. He could pitch for me at New Orleans beyond  any question.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: July 11, 1955   Burlington, N.C.    SCARTH, JIM    Tall, slender, 21 year old boy, weighing around 175  pounds and about 6'1" tall. Infielder-pitcher.  He told me he wanted to pitch.    Got a fine fast ball and it does something. Curve  ball so-so. No change-up on his fast ball at all,  but can throw a slow curve which could become  effective. It is simply a sort of let up on his  regular curve.    This chap is a long ways off. You cannot tell what  he might become if he were to go to a small league for  a year. He might come on his fast ball, but he would  have to spend a year in Class D.    He is going to have another baby in September. He  already has two children.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: Burlington-Greensboro Game  Burlington, N.C.  July 20, 1955    SCARTH    He is hardly a good high school player. He should be given his unconditional release.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: July 12, 1955  Dublin, Ga.  SCHAMMEL, GEORGE  Left hand pitcher from around Baltimore. Got out  of school on June 4th and joined the club on June  6th. Good size boy, fair speed, less than any of the  other boys I have worked out in Dublin. Curve ball  is so-so, and no control of it. Schammel has nothing  else. A change-up on his fast ball could be acquired  and he might get control of it in time, - probably the  long time. This boy should pitch semi-professional  ball for a year or two. He has enough strength.  He might amount to something but it won't be right  away. He could have his release without fear of  quick disaster to anybody.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: June 22, 1955    SCHMIDT, BILL    225 pound football tackle from the University of Pittsburgh, with another year to go. I don't believe he has a good arm, but I bet he can hit with power. There might be a doubt about the "hit" but none whatever about the "power". The boys tell me that he now has a sore arm. This could make a lot of difference in my opinion. We will follow him.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: SALINAS-CHANNEL CITIES' GAMES OF MAY 17TH AND MAY 18TH, 1955 AT  SALINAS, CALIFORNIA    SCHNEIDER   Saw him in just one game. Not tall, but stocky.  Has good power. Bad throwing method. Makes complete circle.     This boy has a doubtful reputation as a receiver.  I see no faults in this respect, - nothing certainly that experience  will not correct. He stands up at the plate in good style and  his form is good. Has no palpable faults. In other words, he should  hit. Comments on his power as a batsman are conflicting. I am  inclined to go with those who have seen his power.    I have been told that he has an exaggerated idea of his  ability. If so, time will correct that.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: St. Louis - New York Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis, Mo.    SCHOENDIENST, RED    This player is, [practically through] not what he used to be. I don't believe   his arm is as strong as it formerly was and most   certainly his legs are [decidedly] slowed up. He is   dangerous at the plate and I believe he has more power   right handed than left handed. If I had a club in the   race, I would take him, but for the Pittsburgh club I   doubt if he is worth [the] much more than waiver price. Schoendienst   is still able to get a good lead and gets a good break.   He must be held on the bases by the pitcher, and yet he   is the kind of runner that I would like to see try to   steal if I were the catcher or the pitcher against him.    This is one player who, in my judgment, responds   at the plate to the score and the men on bases, particularly   if it seems up to him (Schoendienst) to win the game. He   will hit at bad balls. He is extremely anxious to hit   and with two strikes on him, it has always been true that   he will hit bad pitches. In all such cases the pitcher   should bear down and put a lot of stuff on the ball,   whatever he throws and know that the ball doesn't have to be   in the middle. He will pretty nearly swing at anything with   two strikes on him when men are on base. It has been his   biggest fault all these years.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: July 13, 1955  Brunswick, Georgia    SERAFINI, IRVIN (Ed)    About 6' tall, 165 pound boy, comes from Dubois, Pa.   His father is dead, and his mother is now in Italy and   will return in October. He is the youngest of four   children. Married, one baby two days old. I would   judge him to be a very modest, - almost shy boy. Good   appearance, seems to have good aptitude.    This boy has no fast ball to speak of. It is not good   enough to carry him to the majors. He would have to   spot pitch his fast ball, keep it away from good hitters   and never pitch when he, himself, is in the hole.   It is the weakest pitch he has. The fact is that his   whole picture depends upon his variety of stuff and the   usability of the variety.    His curve ball is very good, and his change up on his   [fast] curve ball is very good also. Let him alone with both   of these pitches. He can get and will get a change up   on his fast ball. The one he has been throwing is too   fast, but he gets a semi-palm pressure change-up on his   fast ball that is plenty slow enough and he will, of course,   in time get control of it.    This boy, in my judgment, must master the knuckle ball to   go anywhere. I would say he needs the pitch to go   into the high minors. He has a good knuckle ball. If   he had good usable control of it, he might go all the   way. He does not need a great deal of work on the   perfection of the pitch itself. He simply has to come   to have strike zone control of it.    It will be interesting to watch what he does within the   next season.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: MAZATLAN VS CULIACAN at CULIACAN, MEXICO, ON DECEMBER 8TH AND 9TH, 1955.    SERRELL    Culiacan second baseman.    Tall, slim, colored second baseman. Right hand hitter. Runs pretty good, hits pretty good, fields pretty good, but really no good. He is a show boat player. He is not a prospect for anything, but apparently a very popular player in Mexico.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: February 17, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    DONALD SCHULTZ    About 6'3" tall, 180 pounds, fine boy, very honest. Took a full   semester's work at Elon College this year. He has a good fast ball   and splendid control of it. He has two curves, both are good, and   he should be able to pitch either one a great deal. However, he   tells me he didn't have confidence in either curve, - not enough   at least to pitch it when he is in the hole. He thinks he would be   a much better pitcher if he were able to throw his curve ball when he   is 3 and 1, as he put it. He is most certainly right about that.   We discussed the difference between a pitcher and a thrower.   This fellow, depending upon whether or not his fast ball is the   remarkably good fast ball [.] has a chance to stay with the Pittsburgh   club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: July 11, 1955  Burlington, N. C.    Pitchers MALCOLM, OLSEN, and SCHULTZ should have been   able to help the Burlington club. Their records   are not good in any respect. It is the consensus of   opinion on the part of the press and the radio,   citizens, ownership, baseball scouts, and what-nots   that the present Burlington club is the very worst   that has ever represented the city.    Dorton says that, in his opinion, there is nothing   on the club worth my time in seeing the team in a   game. I don't believe that in fifty years that I   have ever had a team in Class B with so many   uniformly bad reports.    Fowler will take another big financial loss this   season. He doesn't complain, makes no accusations   against anybody. He takes any player we send him   on whatever terms anyone makes. I feel very sorry   for him. His savings of approximately $50,000 will   probably be wiped out by the end of the present   season.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: Burlington-Greensboro Game  Burlington, N. C.  July 20, 1955    SCHULTZ, DON    Right hand pitcher. I like him, but it must certainly be that he  doesn't think I know very much about baseball. Down in Fort Myers  in spring training I talked to pitchers, all of them, and Don  Schultz in particular, about the non-enforcement of the balk rule,  and I explained in detail, both in language and in physical  demonstration about "coming set" and the "slow movement", etc.  I explained that a pitcher did not have to come set; that he could  pitch when he started into the slow movement or at anytime during  the slow movement, or that he could continue the slow movement  until he did come set; that when he did come set, he should  frequently throw to catch the runner from the set position.    Tonight Don came set on every pitch. In the first inning, with  McCarthy the Greensboro center fielder on first base, with one man  out, Don came set and held it. McCarthy had such a lead and break  that catcher Flynn could not have shot him out with a high powered  rifle. Moreover, his arm movement from this set position gives  the base runner a lot of time for his break.    Schultz must be saying to himself, "Well, the old man is a lot of  hot air. He doesn't know what he is talking about. I don't intend  to learn any kind of a move such as he has suggested. I am going  to be the old conventional type pitcher that lets the base runner  get all the lead and break he can."    Then Don proceeded to give them the first run on a ball that was hit at  him, and which bounced off his arm and rolled back toward the catcher.  The catcher ran up to retrieve the ball and could have retired the  man at first, but he fumbled, and then the runner on second turns  third and goes for home. Catcher Flynn turns to toss the ball to  somebody or other, - the runner being half-way between third and home.  Flynn was 30' away and he has the ball. He got up, made a couple  of fake tosses, but nobody covered the home plate. Schultz was  standing a half a foot back of catcher Flynn. If he had covered  home plate, the man would have been out by 20'.    The umpire missed some of his best pitches, that is true, but when he  got into trouble he came with the fast ball, acting like a young,  18 year old, thinking evidently about throwing the ball by the  batsman instead of trying to think how to outsmart him. The result  was that they knocked Don around very badly.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: DON SCHULTZ (Continued)    This boy could become a pitcher -- there is no question about it. He has a variety of stuff and it is all usable. He must spot pitch his fast ball, and it may be necessary for him to have a distinctive additional pitch in order to reach the majors. The distinctive additional pitch could be the knuckle ball, and probably it is just that.     Schultz must have a lot of confidence in Flynn's brains. I never saw the catcher change a single signal.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: February 25, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    RONNIE SHEETZ    This boy has a good fast ball, a good curve, a   good change up on his fast ball and will have a change up   on his curve, but he doesn't have control of this last   pitch. His pitching movements are perfect. He holds   men on. I think he is a pitcher from the neck up. He   has one fault and that is that he doesn't straighten up   after his pitch. He can do it. He knows how. It is   a habit that must be broken and a new one formed.    I have told him to go to the target on this change   up curve ball and he should work a lot on it. He has   three pitches he can use and could go very good probably   on any minor league club, but he might come to Pittsburgh   with a 'bang' if he has the fourth pitch.    I don't believe he is inclined to stage fright.   I wan to see more of him.    BRANCH RICKEY    Fred Haney's comment:  "This boy has more poise than any boy in camp."

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: Ronnie Sheetz  March 10, 1955    Observations in a game with the Kansas City Athletics at Fort Myers, Fla.    Sheetz must pitch his change up or use his curve. He DOES NOT ("Does not" is underlined) have the fast ball to pitch against major league batters.    Sheetz should never pitch his fast ball to a good hitter. he simply doesn't have a fast ball. If he doesn't learn that he can't pitch his fast ball to good batters, he will be in the minors all his life.    Sheetz without change-ups is a Class B pitcher, - not even Class A.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: WILLIAMSPORT-BINGHAMTON GAME AT WILLIAMSPORT, PA ON   July 9, 1955    SHEETS, RONNIE    A good fast ball and a good curve and pretty good control.   Judging from the last two games I saw this boy pitch, he   was a two pitch pitcher, - just the fast and curve balls.   Indeed, that is all he or anyone needs if the two pitches   are good enough. In the case of Sheets, he will never go   major with these two pitches.    This boy has a change-up on his fast ball that is   exceptionally good, and he could easily get to control it   perfectly. He seldom uses the pitch. Probably thinks  he doesn't need it, - therefore doesn't use it, and therefore   has faulty control of it. Without a third pitch, he   'ain't', and the fact that he doesn't have a usable third   pitch could be strong evidence of mental opaqueness, whatever   that is. I choose to think, however, that his lack of   pitching efficiency is more the fault of managerial   inattention than it is the fault of the boy.    If his work keeps up the balance of the season in line with   his present record he should go to the draft at Williamsport.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: June 14, 1955    Shelestak, Michael    Just graduated from high school. Left hand   pitcher, 160 pounds, 5'9" tall, 19 years of age. Fairly good   fast ball, nothing great. No curve at all. No change up   on his fast ball. No change up on his curve ball. Has never   tried either.    His best pitch is a knuckle ball and it really   'knuckles', but he has no control whatever of this pitch. It   goes everywhere. Very seldom over the plate. He is a long   ways off. Not worth trying to sign at the present time.    This boy has exceedingly small hands.    The fast ball, also the curve, - both of them   indeed, are full tight in the sock. I don't believe he is   worth fooling with.    B.R.    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: WILLIAMSPORT-BINGHAMTON GAME AT WILLIAMSPORT ON JULY 9,   1955    SHEPARD, LARRY    Shepard has no control of the 'take one strike' situation.   It probably has never occurred to him. If he wanted to   make a player take one strike, he would have to pull him   out of the batter's box and hold a conference. Shepard   probably does not feel that he has any right to control   the 'take one strike' tactic, and of course the importance   of it has possibly never occurred to him. He is on all   fours with Haney in this respect.    The boy is industrious, loyal, and I believe he would have   the courage to control the 'take one strike' situation,   for example if indeed he thought 'control' was advisable.    In the above respect, Shepard is not at all out of line with   most managers. Only the exceptional managerial mind does   this job correctly and they are the winners.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: POZA RICA VS PUEBLO AT PUEBLO, MEXICO, ON NOVEMBER 17TH AND 18TH, 1955 AND PUEBLO VS MEXICO CITY REDS AT MEXICO CITY  ON NOVEMBER 26TH, 1955.    SIEBERN    Tall, left hand hitter. This fellow looks like he can hit and with power and he can run. Just out of two years service in the army. Belongs to the Yankee organization. He showed me no throwing arm at all. Atley Donald told me later that the boy had a very bad shoulder and was instructed not to try to throw. May be so. Anyhow, he didn't throw. This fellow is impressive. He should be followed, - just in case.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 18, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA BETWEEN CIENFUEGOS AND HAVANA    At first base was a Class B ball player by the name of    SIERRA I say Class B because I know the boy from away back. He is   probably a better ball player today than he has ever been, but I   have a very great doubt if he ever is a AAA player of any real   value. SIERRA must be 28 years of age.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    SISOLAK, FREDDIE  He might be a fair ball player in a Class D   league. That's the way he looked to me in this one   game.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1995 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA, BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES    Marianao's shortstop is  DICK SMITH We know all about him. He simply lacks real major   league class, but particularly he lacks something at the plate.  He really has no power stroke. I think that we should carry him   as a utility man on our club this coming year if the choice should   result between him and Curtis Roberts. He can outrun Roberts, and   he can get more bases on balls, and he has a stronger arm than   Roberts. However, Roberts will occasionally hit the ball harder   than Dick. He and his wife are to see me tomorrow afternoon   at 3:30 P.M.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: June 14, 1955    DONALD REGIS SMITH    18 years old. Dressed terribly. Looks like a   circus tumbler. Everything is tight except his shoes. They   are at least four sizes too big, and his shirt sleeve drops   clear down over his hand on every pitch, - far over. He was   pitching out of the mud. That made no difference to him.   He acted as if he never pitched but out of the mud. No apologies   or excuses for anything. Definite sidearm pitcher.   About 5' 9" tall and weighs 180 pounds, - he says. If he would   take his tights off he would still probably weigh 190 pounds.    He has a pretty good fast ball and he has "Dead-Eye   Dick" control, - right out of the mud. He has a curve, - just   so so, but he controls it. Throws a slow curve, he calls it.   Not much of a curve, but he gets it over too.    This boy throws a knuckle ball. It is a change of   pace pitch. Rotates the same all the time, - sort of a downer.   He could use it.    This kid shows a lot of sense. He has a mother and   father living. His father does something for Otis & Company.   He has an older brother, married, who lives hereabouts; also an   older sister, also married who also lives hereabouts. He   has a younger sister who goes to school. This kid is worthwhile.   I would have him.    B.R.    BR/b    If he had another point, he would have graduated  with honors. Out of a class of 143, he was 37th. I don???????t know  how he looks in ??????civies???????, but he would have made that point if he  ever got rid of those tights. I like this boy.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    SMITH, FREDDIE (Outfielder-Albany)    No power at all at the plate, - none whatever.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: April 28, 1955    LINCOLN-WICHITA GAME AT LINCOLN, NEBRASKA    GEORGE SMITH (Wichita Pitcher)    A big, tall right hand pitcher, - threw a 1-1/2" curve, - another  thrower on the Wichita club. Fair speed, but I don't think he   is the prospect that Gonzales is.    With a man on second, he pitches to the plate looking at second.    He is a long way from becoming a major league pitcher.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: February 25, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    JACK SMITH    Graduate of University of Oregon, just out of the   army, about 5' 11" tall, and weighs something over 210   pounds. Weight is his biggest problem. If he could come   down to 190, he might go all the way. He can throw good   enough, and he will come to catch good enough. He is   intelligent, and he is game and he wants to do it, - and the   surprising thing is that he is not a truck horse.  He handles his avoirdupois pretty good.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: July 11, 1955  Burlington, N. C.    SOLOMKO    A second year, 5'8" tall, well built, little fellow.   According to the books he has power. He can run  very good. When we go back through Burlington,  Kenneth will take him to the hat store. This boy  beat Buheller in the 60 yard race by a foot and a   half. Solomko does not have a great arm, or   what could be termed as a strong arm. He must  throw the ball low and he has the habit of not doing   it. I doubt if he needs protection from a B draft.      B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: Burlington-Greensboro Game  Burlington, N. C.  July 20, 1955    SOLOMKO    In two practices and one game, - Solomko looked good to   me. His arm is not bad at all. It is not a great  arm, but it is a whale of a lot better than Mejias'  arm. I see nothing wrong at all with his batting  form and he has some power, and he is a good runner.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: SALINAS-CHANNEL CITIES' GAMES OF MAY 17TH AND MAY 18TH, 1955 AT   SALINAS, CALIFORNIA    SPENCE, JACK    Right hand hitting outfielder, about 20 years old. Can  run good enough, and has power enough, but has impressed me always  as a strike out batsman. Arm not at all great, but I don't think  that the arm would keep the boy from going into the money. He  is satisfactory at Salinas and should be watched for advancement  next year.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: June 25, 1955      STENHOUSE, DAVE    6'1" tall, 190 pounds, right hander, from Rhode Island   University. He has finished his eligibility. On May 18th, this boy   got a pulled tendon below his elbow that came on a curve ball pitch.   He is unable to pitch the curve ball since that time without pain, and if   he bears down on his fast ball , he gets the same thing. In other words,   he is, at this time, unable to throw hard. He looks to me like a boy   with excellent control and he is intelligent. He has aptitude. He can   get a usable change up on his fast ball right away.    He throws a change of speed pitch by knuckling. The ball   deviates regularly and I would say that he has good control of it, -   indeed exceptional control of it. Beyond any doubt, this fellow, when   sound, is a corking prospect, and probably a quicky. I didn't see   his curve of course because he is afraid to throw it.    The probability is that the boy will, sooner or later,   fully recover from his present injury. However, the hazard of that   recovery is the gamble in his case.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: July 11, 1955   Burlington, N. C.    STERNS, ROLAND    The hot dog right hander from Milwaukee. He has a fast   ball, - a good fast ball, - velocity is good enough,   but the ball bends. His curve ball is so-so. This   boy is so utterly ignorant from a baseball standpoint   that it is hard to classify him. He insists on keeping   his whole foot in the middle of the pitching rubber.   The fast and curve ball signals of one finger and two   fingers respectively are not simple enough for him.   I did not know until the workout this morning how   really ignorant this fellow is. He ought to be   pitching in Class D and immediately.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: April 23, 1955    SAN FRANCISCO- HOLLYWOOD GAME AT SAN FRANCISCO    R.C. STEVENS    Fine fielder. Still overweight. Average runner. Everything he   does or says indicates lack of orientation.    I don't believe he is anymore at home on the Hollywood club right   now that if he were sitting in the chair of the President of the   United States.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: April 27, 1955    HOLLYWOOD-LOS ANGELES GAME AT LOS ANGELES    R.C. STEVENS    This boy is not at home at all. He is really a colored boy in a   strange country. He strikes out, highly nervous, so anxious to   hit that he is inclined to hit at anything, particularly the high   inside fast ball. He has played perhaps a dozen games with   Hollywood and he still shows high nervousness at the plate.   If and when he settles, and takes off a little more weight, he   should be a good man here and eventually might become quite a   hitter. If he doesn't get orientated pretty soon, he won't help   this club.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: JALAPA VS AZTECAS AT SECURITY STADIUM, MEXICO CITY, ON  NOVEMBER 17TH AND NOVEMBER 19TH, 1955.    R. C. Stevens    21 Years old, 6'2" tall, right hand hitting, left hand throwing,   first baseman. If this boy ever gets over being scared to   death of white folks, he would be a good ball player.   He has played great ball so far in the winter league, - hitting   hard and often. He should go, say, to Lincoln for 1956,   and that decision should probably hold regardless of how he   looks in spring training.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: July 11, 1955  Burlington, N.C.    STRICKLIN, TOM    Comes from Mississippi. Right hander. Slim boy, little over 6' tall. Got all the aptitude in the   world. Can learn anything. Not much of a curve, but he will get some sort of a usable curve because   he is intelligent and will want to do it. Has a change-up on his fast ball which is OK. He should   use it. His fast ball is good, - not great.    He has a knuckle ball. Never has had one. The very first on he threw knuckled. Everyone of them   knuckles and he has remarkable control of it. As a matter of fact it does not rotate enough. It is a   positive non-rotating pitch. He might be a knuckle ball pitcher deluxe. His change-up on the fast ball   and his knuckler should equip him for rapid promotion. His curve ball is an added starter and might become usable. I hope it does.    I tried this boy later on a change-up on his curve ball. He can get it. He really can. I doubt if he   will need it. This fellow is a prospect.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: February 25, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    RICHARD STUART    A boy who could be and probably is misunderstood.   He sincerely wants to do good and be good. His   inexpressible contempt for anything disagreeable to himself   is reflected only in his facial expression. To me he is a   natural comic without intending to be or without knowing it.   His arm is good enough, and he runs medium, - perhaps a bit   above it, and he has power at the plate. It is my judgement   that we should give up on him as a third baseman or as a   first baseman. Surely he belongs in the outfield, nowhere   else.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: August 20, 1955    ARTHUR "RED" SWANSON    About 6'2" tall, 180 pounds, right hander. He can throw from 19   different angles of delivery, and with good control on everyone of   them.    His fast ball is good, go enough to go anywhere, and his curve ball   is good. He doesn't have the control our of his curve as he does out   of the fast one, but the curve ball is very usable. He has a change   up on his fast ball. It is too fast but he will slow it up. This   chap is intelligent, has big hands, long fingers and enough sense   to go with his physical set up to make him undoubtedly a fine pitcher.   His slow curve is not acceptable, but he showed me remarkable aptitude   in learning the thumb change up curve. This chap at 19 years of age   this past March could be a major leaguer easy enough at 21.    I am a bit mystified because no one has signed him up. Where has he   been all this time?    I would like to have him.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA,  BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES.    SANCHEZ He belongs to Bob Maduro, and Cincinnati will get the   first crack. Sanchez has speed, plenty of it, and that's all  I know about him from the one inning he pitched. Almendares won   the game 8 to 3, and Sanchez was complete master in his one inning.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: POZA RICA VS PUEBLO AT PUEBLO, MEXICO, ON NOVEMBER 17TH  AND 18TH, 1955.  PUEBLO VS MEXICO CITY REDS AT MEXICO CITY ON NOVEMBER, 26TH 1955  SANDERS  Tall, right hand hitting shortstop on the Pueblo Club.  Young, runs fairly good and has a good arm. Looks like  he might hit. Belongs to the Yankee organization and  just came out of two years service in the army. Not yet  reinstated.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: [*[1955]*]    COMMENTS AND OBSERVATIONS ON PITTSBURGH PIRATES AND HAVANA CUBAN ALL-STARS GAME OF SATURDAY EVENING, MARCH 14TH, GRAN STADIUM, HAVANA, CUBA.    Cole Cole is supposed to be a smart player. With Castiglione caught off second in the fourth inning, he only went half way to second, and then went back to first. He could have easily gone to second.    Sandlock Lindell was wild and difficult, but if I ever saw a catcher handcuffed, this was it. His one throw to second base had nothing on the ball. The runner simply outran it. He must be supurb defensively every minute in order to stay with this club, for he will not hit a lick.      The sooner Fred comes to know that Castiglione, Cole, and Metkovich are impossible as starters, the sooner the Pittsburgh Club will be started in the right direction. Everyone of these boys are simply last place players.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: POZA RICA VS PUEBLO AT PUEBLO, MEXICO, ON NOVEMBER 17TH AND 18TH, 1955 AND POZA RICA VS MEXICO CITY REDS AT POZA RICA ON DECEMBER 1ST AND 2ND, 1955.    SANDOVAL    Poza Rica catcher.    A big young fellow, right hand hitter, doesn't get much chance to work. He has a good arm and I saw him hit a couple of balls in batting practice for good distance. He is doubtless satisfactory as a second string catcher at Poza Rica, but I didn't see enough of him to have an opinion about his prospective ability.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: Mazatlan vs. Culiacan At Culiacan, Mexico,   December 8, 1955.    Torres    Right fielder on the Mazatlan club. Looks like a colored fellow to me. Left hand hitting outfielder. I don't believe he is a good hitter at all and even if he got the bat and the ball together it wouldn't go very far.     This boy is no kid. He is certainly old enough to quite, - anyhow, forget him.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA, BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES.    The catcher was  TRIANDOS A well built young man, right hand hitter with a strong arm, and a power stroke at bat. I see no reason why he could not become a formidable hitter. He is not a good runner but his receiving was good and he looks intelligent. I would guess him to be about 25 years of age. He belongs to Baltimore.    MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 22, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME BETWEEN ALMENDARES AND CIENFUEGOS AT HAVANA, CUBA.    TRIANDOS (Almendares)  Should be and probably is a good hitter.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: POZA RICA VS PUEBLO AT PUEBLO, MEXICO, ON NOVEMBER 17TH AND 18TH, 1955 AND PUEBLO VS MEXICO CITY REDS AT MEXICO CITY ON NOVEMBER 26TH.    TUCKER    Catcher on the Pueblo club. A big fellow. Crude behind the plate, on the bases, and at bat, but he is not in shape, according to his manager. Just reported. Unimpressive.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: Dublin-Vidalia Game  Vidalia, Georgia  July 19, 1955    URBANSKI    Left hand hitting infielder. He is right where he belongs, - Dublin.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA,  BETWEEN MARIANO AND ALMENDARES    The shortstop was a 19 year old kid, a Cuban named    VALDIVIELSO, about 6' tall, very slim, fast in action in every respect and a good runner, and a good arm, and a good form at the plate. He has benched Miranda for Valdivielso, and rightfully so as I see it. This boy belongs to Washington, a product of Joe Cambria. From just tonight's fielding practice and the game, I like this boy very much. If I had no previous information on Fernandez and was judging all the youngsters I have seen down here just from these two games, I would prefer this kid over Fernandez. Undoubtedly this is a very erroneous judgment, but this boy is certainly a very real major league prospect. I think he will hit, and I think he will eventually have considerable power. If I knew how to go about it to buy his contract, I certainly would do it without delay. This boy has real class. If the Pittsburgh club had had the right representative scouting for us in Cuba instead of Monchy, and if we had an organization manager in charge of the Almendares club, there isn't any question in the world about our having the contract of Valdivielso. It is just too bad that Pittsburgh would lose a player of this sort to Joe Cambria when Monchy and Bragan and everyone else knew about the youngster.    [MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 22, 1955 - GAME BETWEEN ALMENDARES AND CIENFUEGOS, HAVANA, CUBA.]    VALDIVIELSO (Almendares)  He is a boy up at the plate. He can???????t reach the fence with his power. He may grow up to be a big hitter, however, he might. He can do everything else.    4

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN, PUERTO RICO,   ON JANUARY 25, 1955    VALENTINE, in left field, made a great catch, as did the   right fielder, Julio Rodriguez. Both these boys looked good  defensively.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: JALAPA VS AZTECAS AT SECURITY STADIUM, MEXICO CITY, ON  NOVEMBER 17TH AND NOVEMBER 19TH, 1955    VINICIO    Second baseman on Azteca club.    No prospect.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: Memorandum of January 18, 1955 following Game in Havana, Cuba between Cienfuegos and Havana.     In center field is a fellow named     VIRDON He wears glasses. He is a left hand hitter also. He is a good runner, - good enough. He didn't show a great arm in the fielding practice but he may not have been throwing his best. He had no chance to show his arm during the game. His form at the plate is good, - good in every respect. His stance is acceptable, his stride is short, the bat is held well back, the big end is very quiet. He has no hitch of any kind, and his sweep is level. I would not call him a power hitter but his power is good enough. He is not a fly ball hitter. I will bet on that. I would like to have him.     Memorandum of January 20, 1955 following game in Havana, Cuba between Marianao and Havana    VIRDON can really run and he can throw, and he can hit right handers. I don't know what he will do against left handers.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: St. Louis-New York Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis, Mo.    VIRDON (St. Louis Outfielder)    Almost a finished player, both at bat and in the field. He doesn't hit many bad pitches. I would work on him much as I would work on Hemus. This boy will get a lot of bases on balls and it is a very bad policy to 'cripple' any pitch when a pitcher is in the hole. The fellow can lift the ball out of the park. He is a good runner and has a fine arm.    It seems to me that he plays a very deep outfield on everybody.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: St. Louis-New York Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis, Mo.    TIEFANAUER (Pitcher - St. Louis)    This boy came in in relief, but did not last out the inning. Altogether he threw seven pitches and every one a knuckle ball. The control of these seven pitches was not good, and with a right hand batter coming up, he was taken out. That's all I know about him.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: WADE, BEN    Fort Myers, Fla.  March 9, 1955    About 32 years of age and has been hanging around the major leagues for years. A tall right hander who can't hear. His fast ball is not great, but possibly fair. His curve ball is fairly good and only ordinary control of that. He has a new pitch he calls a screwball and this is exactly what it is. It screws, - it fades, and his delivery is not bad on it. This fellow's success, such as he has had, is due, in my judgment, to a pitch which he calls a slider, and that too is exactly what he says it is, - a threeor four inch slide, - a typical Newcombe pitch, but it very likely has been his most effective pitch for years. If he can use this new pitch, - the change of pace, he might help us.    He is exceedingly anxious to do just that.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: February 25, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    BOB WADE  I am right about his change up on his fastball. He has it. I am right about his regular curve. It doesn't break all the time, and he doesn't have as good control on it as he should. His change up on the fast ball has proper velocity, sometimes a bit too fast its spin is correct most of the time.    This boy needs target practice and plenty of it. Without throwing too hard and without throwing any fast balls, he should be on the target just as much as his arm can take it. Give him two dozen balls. Let him recover his own. Practice control on his curve ball and his change up fast ball - these two pitches primarily. I should say that he should have at least thirty minutes per day or anytime he wants. I will follow him.    I want to hold him over next week for that purpose.    Of course, Bob must keep constantly in mind the retention of the pitch.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: February 25, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    BOB WADE  Very young right hand pitcher from California. 6' tall, weighs about 185 pounds. This boy is rugged. He has a fair curve ball and a corking change of pace curve ball. I am not sure about his fast ball. His delivery sometimes makes him look like a shotputter. Then again he will come through with a forceful delivery with pretty good speed. All in all, I think the boys did a good job in signing him. He might become a very fine pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANIARY 19, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA, BETWEEN MARIANAO AND ALMENDARES    In right field is    WALLS He can run, and he can throw, and he can field, and he is a much more agressive and confident batsman, - very much more so than when he was with us a year or so ago. He is no pushover at the plate, but he is still a doubtful batsman for us in Pittsburgh. I would call him a .290 gitter in AAA, and he may possibly go to pieces again for us this coming spring. The only thing I have in mind about Walls is hope, - nothing more than that.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: July 11, 1955   Burlington, N. C.     Weltman    Did not see him. Family illness in New York accounted for his absence. From the barber shop up to Manager Doton, the opinion is that he will never go into the money. He exalteth himself unseemly.      B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: Burlington-Greensboro Game   Burlington, N. C.    July 20, 1955    Weltman    Should have been playing in a lower league this year.   I am not prepared to quit on this boy, but I am very  much disappointed. He should be left for the draft  right where he is (Class B). However, it is possible  that he should play in Class C in 1956.      B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: Burlington-Greensboro Game   Burlington, N. C.    July 20, 1955    Wickersham, Dave    This boy had been told, too, about the slow movement  in holding men on. Nevertheless, he is old  "Bill Hasmer" also and comes to the coventional  set position on every pitch, but he throws quicker  than Don Schultz. the base runner cannot get the   break on him that Schultz permits     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: June 25, 1955    WICKERSHAM, DAVE    19 years old, 6'3" tall, 180 pounds, right hander, from East Springfield, Pennsylvania, 20 miles west of Erie. Just finished his second year at Ohio University at Athens. His speed is good, - not great, but good enough. He has a curve ball and it is a very good curve ball. His delivery is O.K., - in fact his whole pitching technique is good.    His change up on the fast ball is not good, but this boy is intelligent and has aptitude. He understands quickly what it is he wants to get and I believe he is intelligent enough to know how to get it. The velocity on his change up fast ball is too great, and needs slowing up. He throws a change up on the curve ball but it has simply a bit less speed than his regular curve. It is not at all slow enough. He undertook to get the thumb change up curve and he will get it and very quickly.    This boy has good control of everything and my strong belief is that has pitching temperment. He will be a natural.    This chap has had some sort of serious jaw operation on his upper jaw, - the roof of his mount indeed and he is in front of a further operation. His father is a farmer, - I would say a fairly prosperous farmer. He raises 10,000 bushels of apples per year. David pays his own way through school. He waits on tables. He has the only baseball scholarship at Athens. He neither drinks nor smokes and he has never had a girl. And I mean by that, he has never "dated". That might lead some reader of this memorandum to think that David goes in the direction of eunuchry. I don't think that at all. He is simply a country boy who doesn't find his school work too easy, having made "C" plus in his first two years at Ohio University and his mind is on a career in professional baseball. The boy wants to make everything subordinate to a baseball career.    He could make good right now in a B League, - provided he doesn't go through the not unusual course of frustration. I would be willing to send him to Burlington, and I would give him some money to get his contract.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; S-Z
Transcription: Pittsburgh Athletic Company. Inc.  Operating  Pittsburgh Baseball Club  New York-St. Louis Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis    THOMPSON, HANK (Infielder N.Y.)    Third baseman, - left hand hitter. First of all, left handers can strike him out, and second, I don't think he likes changes either. I believe right handers' curve balls low and inside bother him a whole lot.    B. R.     [*COPY*]

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: New York-St. Louis Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis    Williams, Dave (N.Y. 2nd Baseman)    "Brigetty", - cockey kid, can run pretty good, and can make the plays, but I am inclined to believe that all outfielders in the National League generally play this boy too deep. He might get a long ball occasionally, but the long ball is by no means this kid's long suit, and outfielders should play him accordingly.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Dublin-Vidalia Game  Vidalia, Georgia  July 19, 1955    WILLIAMS, FRANKLIN DELANO  A right hand hitting colored outfielder. Fair arm, good running speed. Might hit someday,?????? I don???????t know.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    WILLIAMS, GALEN (Albany Second Baseman)     He can run and he stands up to the plate well. Has a good cut. Showed power in the batting practice.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Brunswick-Albany Game  Brunswick, Ga.  July 18, 1955    WILSON, JACK    Left hand hitting center fielder. He is a hustler. His form is good at the plate. I don't know anything about his power. He showed me nothing. His arms is good. He might go some place, and if draftable, should be protected.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Dublin-Vidalia Game  Vidalia, Georgia  July 19, 1955    WILSON (Vidalia Third Baseman)    Colored third baseman. Great arm and can run. Gets a good lead on bases and acts like he wants to run. I don't know about his batting power or ability but his form at the plate is good.    How old is he?    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: April 27, 1955    HOLLYWOOD-LOS ANGELES GAME AT LOS ANGELES    WITT  At the beginning of tonight's game, he was very nervous. The papers carried the story very fully that I was staying over in Los Angeles in order to see Witt pitch. He took something off trying to get it over. He surely cannot be as wild as he showed. Threw two curve balls in his first 12 pitches which may have been proper pitching under the circumstances, -- I don't know, -- because I don't know the pitcher. He looks to be 6'3" tall and will weight 205 pounds, and he showed good speed.    LATER  Throws a change up on his fast ball and it is a good pitch in itself but has doubtful control of it.    When Witt is in the hole, two and none, or three and one, Bragan called for the fast ball invariably, or in any event the fast ball was pitched. The boy comes fully set on every pitch. In other words, he doesn't know anything at all about taking advantage of the "no balk" situation, and his delivery from this set potion is not quick. I don't think he can hold runners on at all. A base runner on first could easily take a 15' lead and take all kinds of a gambling break. In the second inning of the game, Witt acted like a boy who had never pitched before in his life.    Witt has no control of his change up on his fast ball. This pitch would really be very effective if he could get it over. His delivery is good for it and it is a marvelous change from his exceptional fast ball. With control this boy is a great major league pitcher right now, but he needs above everything else a Bragan catching him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: MAZATLAN VS CULIACAN AT CULIACAN ON DECEMBER 9, 1955    GEORGE WITT    This fellow has enough sheer stuff to pitch all the way, -- and right now. His fast ball is good enough and his curve ball is good enough and his change-up on his fast ball is excellent. In the first inning he struck out the side and in the second inning when he came out he kept working on his arm, going through all kind of gyrations continuously. Surely the game should have been stopped and a conference held about his physical condition. He evidently was in great pain, and he put nothing on the ball. He loafed through the inning and every batter that faced him simply had a 'hope so' attitude.    He struck six men out in the first three innings, with only one hit, -- a little pop fly ball in back of the shortstop. Both in conversation with me and with his actions on the field, he impresses me as a mental problem, a neurasthenic, a psychopath, or something. I would lay a bet that he was more or less a problem child to his parents, domestically eccentric as a husband, and probably a pitching enigma to any manager.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 18, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN CIENFUEGOS AND HAVANA    A tall, well-built, right hander by the name of     WOODRIGE started for Cienfuegos. WOODRIGE belongs to St. Louis. He  has a bad right leg, - wears a protection on his leg (broken leg   last year). He has pretty good speed and a pretty good curve.   Fair stuff all the way along the line. He didn't pitch intelligently   and his support was bad. He might be a very much better pitcher   than his game record shows. I would not dismiss him as a major   league possibility on this showing, - not at all. I would want to   see more of him.    He pitched about three innings and was followed by a left hander by the name of

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: JAKE THIES Fort Myers, Fla.   March 22, 1955  Underhand, right hand pitcher. Heavy fast ball, slow rotation - a penetrating pitch, - knocks your glove off. Curve ball is a twister underhand. Not a great curve, but it deflects. It is different and probably effective. He occasionally throws overhand with everything, particularly to right hand hitters.  This boy has an overhand change-up, - he calls it, on his fast ball, but the effect of it is a change-up curve, I would call it, and he has control of it. He can pitch that ball.  But Thies is not an overhand pitcher and he has no change-up of any kind on his underhand delivery. He needs a change-up of some sort on the underhand pitches. He should be worked at 40' and not more than that in an effort to get that kind of pitch. I gave him some ideas about it. It is an experimental job in front of him and if the boy works on it, he might get it. Clyde Sukeforth has been assigned to see that this work is undertaken.  His change-up on the curve ball is a good ball in itself, but he doesn't have good control of it. He should work to the target on that pitch.  The boy must come to the habit of not coming stopped in his delivery with men on base.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: September 7, 1955    YURMAN, FRANK    Little over 6' tall, weighs about 180, right hander, will be 18 years  of age this coming January. He has a 'live' fast ball. It is  exceptionally good, and he has a curve ball and sometimes it really  curves, but not all the time, but surely the day will come when his  curve ball will do a lot of talking.    This boy has a knuckle ball. I believe he calls it a 'downer' on   his fast ball, but he throws it in the conventional two finger  knuckle position, and he has remarkable control of this pitch.  This kid has a baby face, looks young, acts young, and talks lik  a gentleman and is a very find prospect. He can't miss. I would   like very much to have him.    His change up on the fast ball does not have the correct spin and   his change up on the curve ball is both too fast and besides he tips  it off. He showed ability to learn the change up curve and   undoubtedly will get it. With control of the four pitches he now  has or can easily get [], this boy could star right now in the major  leagues.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF JANUARY 18, 1955 FOLLOWING GAME IN HAVANA, CUBA  BETWEEN CIENFUEGOS AND HAVANA    ZABALA    He looked like a tricky boy, - fair stuff, but I would not care to pass  on him on what I saw. He might be a pretty good pitcher. With the  score about 8 to 0 against Cienfuegos, ZABALA was relieved by

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN, PUERTO RICO,  ON JANUARY 25, 1935    ZAVALA was the catcher for Ponce and was just so so.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Burlington-Greensboro Game  Burlington, N.C.  July 20, 1955    ZIMMERMAN (Catcher - Greensboro Club)    Looked like a good catcher, - good arm and I liked him up at the plate.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: MAZATLAN VS. CULIACAN AT CULIACAN, MEXICO,  DECEMBER 8, 1955    ZONTA    Mazatlan center fielder.    Right hand hitting outfielder with some power.  Not a young fellow. Can't run. He has not   come from any place and he is not going anywhere.  A doubtful professional player.    He is a fly ball hitter if ever I saw one. Surely  "Chile" Gomez can find Mexican players who will   help Mazatlan more than Zonta.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN, PUERTO RICO ON JANUARY 25, 1955    A chap named    THURMAN played left field. He is a tall negro and I would guess him well past thirty years of age. He surprised me with his running speed, and he looks like a good left handed hitter. Cincinnati recently signed him up, and I shall not be surprised if he helps Cincinnati in substitute work.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN, PUERTO RICO ON JANUARY 25, 1955    A chap named    THURMAN played left field. He is a tall negro and I would guess him well past thirty years of age. He surprised me with his running speed, and he looks like a good left handed hitter. Cincinnati recently signed him up, and I shall not be surprised if he helps Cincinnati in substitute work.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: New York-St. Louis Game, May 13, 1955 at St. Louis    THOMPSON, HANK (Infielder N.Y.)    Third baseman, - left hand hitter. First of all, left handers can strike him out, and second, I don't think he likes changes either. I believe right handers' curve balls low and inside bother him a whole lot.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: February 25, 1955  Fort Myers, Fla.    KENNETH TOOTHMAN    A kid, one year's experience, aggressive, clean cut, fair arm, fair running speed, pest hitter without much power. Wants to beat you, might be several pounds over weight. Left hand hitter who doesn't seem to be bothered very much with left hand pitching. We must take him seriously at the present time. I think his place this year is probably not higher than A and probably he would do his best work and come faster if sent to B.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: MEMORANDUM OF GAME BETWEEN SANTURCE AND PONCE AT SAN JUAN, PUERTO  RICO ON JANUARY 25, 1955.    TORRES was the shortstop. He looked good defensively.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood-Seattle June 24, 1956    Bob Balcena. Chunky, 5' 6" tall, right hand hitting   outfielder. I don't know his age, but he runs pretty good and has   a pretty good arm. Stands up at the plate well. Fair power, just   fair, but this chap is a fine outfielder, - exceptional defensive   ability. I should like to own his contract [???] Hollywood.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: April 2, 1956    BARONE, RICHARD  Barone has been sent to New Orleans, but entirely too soon.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: June 24, 1956  Hollywood, Cal.    Baumer as a utility man can play anywhere, and just about   as good one place as another. He is a 'selling plater'. If   he were representing a college in an inter-collegiate meet on the   track team, he would be last in the dashes, in the hurdles, in the   shotput and particularly last in the decathlon. I think he   has a very lovely wife. His best chance for possible distinction   lies in his posterity.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    BELL, RON (Outfielder)    Left hand hitting outfielder. Can't throw a lick   and I don't believe he can hit a lick. He must be able to   run or he wouldn't be here. Good average runner.    OUT.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    BELTROM, BOB (Infielder-First Baseman)    He is a big boy, plenty big, but I doubt if he is   a power hitter.    BRANCh RICKey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    Heran, Mickey (Catcher)    He runs very well, above average. Showed now power at the plate at all. In fact, he looked bad against Bob Fontiane.    BRANCH RICKEY    HR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: June 24, 1956  Hollywood, Cal.    Right now, this club is a very bad club in the Pacific   Coast League. The loss of third baseman Gair Allie hurts very   much, not because Allie was so great, but chiefly because his   substitution is so bad. Bernier is the most inept third   baseman I have ever seen in professional baseball. He belongs   in the outfield and most surely should never be seen anywhere   else. Also, Bernier is as close to the dictionary definition   of a 'fool' as I have ever seen on a baseball field. He needs   discipline, and almost nothing else. He can be a winning player   in the Pacific Coast League as an outfielder, provided he is   constrained to be a normal human being.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Observation One Day - Los Angeles Club June 17, 1956    Steve Bilko (First baseman) A great hero in the Pacific Coast League. Home run reputation carries him. I wouldn't want him on any major league club, even in an emergency.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    BISCOTTI, TOM (Infielder)    Not worth anything. Out.    BRANCH RICKEY      BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: June 26, 1956  Phoenix, Arizona    One Day Observation    Blash (Phoenix Catcher)    Big, overweight, right hand throwing, left hand hitting catcher, with power at the bat. Arm ordinary, running speed below average, and I doubt if he can catch.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: April 2, 1956  ALLIE, GAIR  I do not believe that Gair Allie should have been sent to Hollywood, but it is not a matter of great importance because he will find his way, undoubtedly, to New Orleans in due course. But it does take away from his prestige in New Orleans and takes away from his importance from a public relations standpoint that the player should come back from Hollywood to New Orleans rather than coming to New Orleans from Pittsburgh. I think that is thoughtless transaction.  B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: One Day Observation Los Angeles Club June 17, 1956    Bolger (Outfielder) Can't throw. Both Coates and Wade in the outfield simply throw "Andy Over". All in all, it didn't look like either man was throwing.    Looked to me like there wasn't a major league arm anywhere on the Los Angeles club.    Bolger (Later) Should become a fine hitter. I think he is a good hitter right now.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: March 20, 1956    MEMORANDUM    In complete opposition to every plan, program, or understanding or anything else connected with player Ward, - who incidentally is a fine gentleman, (this player was not only on the list for disposal, but was not to be brought to our training camp) he has been used and quite obviously with the idea of making an outfielder of him on our club for the season of 1956. He has played in several games.    Now Bragan is not a hard-head, - is not obstinate. Indeed he is not anything of that kind. He is a wonderful person and wants to do a great job. Now, who is responsible for the Ward situation? God knows, - I don't know, but somebody is. A lot of things need immediate attention and the most pressing one at the moment is the waiver situation on various players on our club.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    BRANDT, LEROY (1st Baseman)  Can throw underhand and not overhand. Gets good stuff on the ball underhand. His arm is alright throwing in any form. He simply wasn't warmed up when he started the game.    June 19, 1956  Looked immature but he can throw. What he can do otherwise, I don't know.    Tall, thinnish, right hand hitting first baseman. Mostly right field hitter, sharp but no power. He might become something at the plate, but surely not ready for professional ball up at the plate at this time.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: April 2, 1956    JACKIE BROWN    See previous reports on this player. I see no reason to change any of the observations in those reports.    Jackie should be sent to one of our minor league clubs and it doesn't make too much difference where he is sent. If there is a question between a high or a low league, then the choice should be made by sending him to the low league. It doesn't make too much difference whether an option is used up on this player's contract or not. Let him go outright, but if outright, then probably to a high classification league.    Investigation should be made as to whether or not this player's assignment status permits him to be moved from a minor league club to a higher minor league club in case his contract should be assigned outright by Pittsburgh.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Luther Carr  June 24, 1956    I have just wired Babe Barberis as follows:  "If you can arrange to have Bob Fontaine see the negro outfielder in action, that would be good, and I suggest that you and Bob try once more to sign the fellow at four thousand before July first. If signing with Hollywood is absolutely necessary to get the player, I would personally say do it. However, I will talk with Clements and he will advise you on this score.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: June 24, 1956    Report on Player Luther Carr    This is a 6' 2", 195 pound negro living in Seattle, Washington. He plays all positions, probably an outfielder. Right hand hitter with great power. He is supposed to outrun anybody and everybody, and has a much talked about arm, - very exceptional indeed.    About a year ago, upon his graduation from HighSchool in Seattle, he was recommended by our Seattle scout, Babe Barberis, (illegible) Bob Fontaine, and Bob Clements. Upon the combined recommendation, Pittsburgh offered $4,000. The University of Washington outbid us and the player has just completed his Freshman year at the University of Washington.    I had the boy for an extended visit and it is possible that he may change his mind. Hollywood will renew the offer.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    CASELLA, GARY (Catcher)    I wouldn't be interested in him unless he is a great runner and a great hitter.    June 19, 1956    Right hand hitting infielder-catcher. I don't think he is a hitter at all. Not at all a major league prospect in my book.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    CASTLEMAN, ROBERT    It seemed to me that the boy had good speed, but very poor control of it. It also seemed to me that his curve ball was good but most certainly he threw it everywhere, - a good number of wild pitches. He very definitely has a change of speed pitch. I see no reason why this fellow cannot pitch, all dependent upon his control. I can see why he got a release from Magic Valley. He simply walked everybody and wild pitched them home. The ideal thing for this chap would be to pitch semi-professionally this year and sign him to a contract after July 1st for the 1957 season. I don't think he can make good in any little league with the kind of control he showed today.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR?B

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, Calfornia [sic]  June 20, 1956    CASTLEMAN, ROBERT    Past 20, out of high school, right hand pitcher, 175 pounds, about 5' 11" tall. Fine fast ball and a good curve. Good velocity on his curve. Nothing else and no control of either his fast ball or curve ball. If this boy would go to spring training and had some personal attention, he might make good and he might have a great future as a pitcher. He should be signed after July 1, 1956.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Phoenix, Arizona  June 26, 1956    One Day Observation  Campbell (Douglas Third Baseman)    Is a well built boy, a youngster, right hand hitter. Did   nothing in either game to attract attention either in the field or   at bat, Has a fine arm.     Branch Rickey    (Later) Size o.k. - good action - good runner. I would put him   above men like Toothman and McDevitt. This boy might become a good   hitter.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: June 24, 1956  Hollywood, Cal.  I was not at all sure that Allie would prove to be of value to the Hollywood club when he was sent there by the Pittsburgh club. In the early days, Mr. Cobb and others felt that he was a failure. However, in the last few weeks, he has impressed everyone, including major league clubs. I take it that upon his return from the army he should be given a further trial by Pittsburgh.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 20, 1956  Carlson, Phil  Left hander, 175 pounds, 18 years of age. This boy not eligible for high school ball this spring because he pitched for a semi-professional team. Fair speed, - not bad, curve ball is a sweeper, but it is a curve and has some velocity.
