He simply cannot get a change up on his fast ball and doesn't have anything to substitute for it. Looks like he can get a change up curve. He would be alright for a 1957 contract, signed after July 1st. I would like to see him get some attention in spring training.   Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956  Chiponis, Richard (Infielder)    Little boy in the white swim suit. If he can run and hit a lick, you will simply have to give him attention. I like him.  Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    Christiansen, Bruce (Outfielder)    Has a good arm but too much trajectory, but   a fine arm. He has power enough and his form is not   bad, but he is a head swinger. Good runner. Misses lots   of strikes. Might do a lot of striking out. I would give   this fellow a whale of a look.     Branch Rickey    br/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Phoenix, Arizona  June 26, 1956    One Day Observation  Cigar (Outfielder with Douglas)    A very tall, right hand hitting Negro. He can run   like the dickens, has a good arm, but he could not hit a curve ball   once in a 100 times.    Branch Rickey    BR/b    (Later) At the present time, this chap is the all-american strike  out. I am told that he struck out 15 times in succession. If he  can come to hit a lick, he can be a great major leaguer.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: April 2, 1956    COLE, DICK    There is a deal on Dick Cole. Two or three clubs would like   to have him, and if we knew enough about our kids, - if they   had been kept in the game more often, or rather if they had   been kept longer on our team, and exposed to competitive play,   it is entirely possible that Cole could have been dealt with   advantageously to one of our other clubs. It is possible,   or rather likely, that the best market on Cole is in   Philadelphia on the basis of money. Cincinnati really   wants him more than any other club. I talked to Joe about   this recently and I told him that we ought to deal Cole   for not less than a $50,000 cash basis, but that I did not   feel that we ought to deal Cole at this time or until such   time as we knew more about the strength of the club and   his place as a utility player on the team.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: April 2, 1956    Cole, Dick     There is a deal on Dick Cole. Two or three clubs would like to have him, and if we knew enough about our kids, - if they had been kept longer on our team, and exposed to competitive play, it is entirely possible that Cole could have been dealt with advantageously to one of our other clubs. It is possible, or rather likely, that the best market on Cole is in Philadelphia on the basis of money. Cincinnati really wants him more than any other club. I talked to Joe about this recently and I told him that we ought to deal Cole for not less than a $50,000 cash basis, but that I did not feel that we ought to deal Cole at this time or until such time as we knew more about the strength of the club and his place as a utility player on the team.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 20, 1956    Curry    I saw this fellow working out in the bullpen at a distance of approximately 75' and saw him throw about 25 pitches. I do not believe he is a pitcher.     Branch Rickey     BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    CUTLER, MIKE (Outfielder)    Quick arm and a sound arm. Definitely knows how to   throw. Not a Furillo arm.     Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: April 2, 1956    Lino Donoso    This boy should be kept on the club until cut-down time.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: June 24, 1956  Hollywood, Cal.    Lino Donoso. I am through with him. He won't get a usable third pitch.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Hollywood, California  July 20, 1956    ANDERSON, RON    This boy is 6'4" tall, 190 pounds, right hander. Fair speed, not great at all, and a pretty good curve ball. He will acquire a change up on his fast ball. A willing fellow and not dumb. His father is a cement contractor in Torrance, - a suburb of Los Angeles. This boy should not be sent into professional ball this summer, but he should be signed to a 1957 contract to report to spring training somewhere. He would be worth some attention next spring.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: Phoenix, Arizona  June 26, 1956    One Day Observation    Drain (Douglas Catcher)    Looks like a mechanically good catcher. A lively   fellow, runs fairly well. Arm is o.k. I see no reason why   he should not be a good man in this league and perhaps go higher.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: June 17, 1956   Observation One Day - Los Angles Club    Dick Drott (Pitcher) This boy, Dick Drott, with the Los Angeles club, has plenty of speed and appears to have a corking good curve. He is good size, a good arm indeed, and he is what I call a wrist pitcher. He is really a major leaguer.  Another word about this fellow Drott. I have now seen him pitch 1-1/3 innings. He is the best looking pitching prospect I have seen in many a day. He comes set all the time and holds his position a long time. Could be taken out of that and when he gets older it is likely he will get out of it himself.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: June 24, 1956  Hollywood, Cal.    Joe Duhem. a 5' 7" tall, well built right hand hitter. Impresses me as a "dummy." I don't know exactly why, but he does. Joe can run and he can throw and if he gets his pitch he can hit the ball with authority. He was originally a pitcher and has had only two years, about, in the outfield. Some pitches bother this boy very much, but his improvement has been fairly rapid. We should not quit on him now.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1952; F-Y
Transcription: April 2, 1956    ELROY FACE    He should be retained for the year.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 16,1956    FREESE, EUGENE    This boy has all kinds of possibilities for the majors. His greatest fault outside of his tendency to real or insignificant injury is his refusal or inability to body check hard hit ground balls. He wont do it.     Long has the same fault at first base, but hot as consistently as Gene Freese.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: April 2, 1956    FRIEND, ROBERT    Friend has finally become a sort of pitcher rather than an thrower. He has great future value.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: April 2, 1956    GARBER, BOB    Bob has had a sore arm all spring, and there is   no additional evidence of pitching ability that warrants   his being retained by a major league club. If he has   another option, and I think he has, then he should be   optioned back to Hollywood for the season.     B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 27, 1956    HALL, BILL    This boy makes capacity and ability meet. He does not  carry the power nor the potential of either Lynch or  Kravitz. He is far more finished than either and very  comfortably be our third catcher.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 27, 1956    HALL, DICK    I see no reason for changing my former memorandum on this player. I think he needs a knuckle ball and must use it in order to be a winning pitcher in the major leagues. On this date, he does not show his customary fast ball.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Albuquerque, N. M.   June 27, 1956    One Day Observation    Bill Jackson (Lincoln First Baseman)    Now playing first base. He has good power at the plate.  Is agile around first and shows a good deal of finish defensively.  I don't believe he is as good as average in running. Arm o.k. I  would let him go to draft in 1956 at Lincoln.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    ARANDA, JAY (Outfielder)    Right hand hitting outfielder. He gets the bat and the ball together regularly. I think he has good power. He has an average to good arm. It is a very quick arm. He gets the ball away. I would be interested in this boy.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood-Seattle June 24, 1956    I saw some other pitchers on Seattle, including Larry Jansen  and Don Fracchia. Not impressed.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 20, 1956    JONES, JIM    From Seattle. Has an older brother 22 years of age and a  younger sister of sixteen. Father living and works for the Boeing  Aircraft Co. This boy is a fine boy, - a gentleman. 6'2" tall, 195  pounds, Left hander. Corking fast ball. It is a dandy. Just about  no curve at all, but he can get the change up curve ball, - the thumb  curve I call it. He can get that. Otherwise, he shows the least  aptitude I have had anything to do with for a long time, but his fast ball  might carry him a long ways. He is going to pitch two innings this  afternoon and I will have more to say about this boy this afternoon.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 27, 1956    KRAVITZ, DANNY    This boy must learn to throw the ball back to the pitcher accurately. His history in this respect should be investigated. Does he have a mental hazard at this point and if so how long has he had it? This could be a very serious thing.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: April 2, 1956    KRAVITZ, DANIEL    Once more let me say, that this boy should be caught  consistently and constantly, - and he should warm up  pitchers with the sole idea of practicing his footwork on  returning the ball to the pitcher, and I mean in this remark  that he should return the ball to the pitcher quickly. He  must be taught to catch the pitch with his left foot off the  ground if possible and to so adjust his body movement that the  left foot will be off the ground when the ball actually hits his  glove. Elsewhere and in other memorandum, I talked about  his throwing the ball accurately back to the pitcher. That  had to do with the possible hazard the fellow has had in the   past about throwing the ball back to the pitcher. That is  an entirely different point, and this memorandum has to do  with getting the ball away from him, - not accuracy.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 27, 1956    KING, NELSON    Just simply cannot hold any runner on base. The slowest  man in the league can steal on him. For him to be a  winning pitcher on a World Series club he must have an  additional pitch, of if, indeed, he has the additional  pitch then he must most certainly use it. And when I   speak of an 'additional pitch' in connection with  King, I mean a distinctive pitch that is effective and  usable and one that he can afford to use with more or   less regularity. It can be a screw ball or it can be  an effective change of pace or it can be a knuckle ball,  but it must be something.    Somebody or other should convince King of this need and  if he agrees, then he has enough intelligence and desire  to do something about it. But if by his own judgment  he does not need this so-called 'additional pitch', then   we ought to let him go.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: April 2, 1956    KLINE, RONALD    A sort of in and outer, but a boy who has a chance to be an ace for the Pittsburgh club. The proper employment of his new pitch, a knuckle ball, should place him in the front ranks. He has plenty of stuff.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: April 2, 1956    LAW, VERNON    Law should be retained, of course. He has a chance to be a very unusually fine pitcher.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 27, 1956    LITTLEFIELD, DICK    My opinion has not changed on this fellow since late last   summer. There was, I felt, from manager on down  the feeling at the close of the 1955 season that Littlefield  should be traded to some other club. I so stated to  everybody. Joe did not agree on the trading of Littlefield  and of course nothing has been done about it. I still  favor his disposal but not at the waiver price. I think  he has a good fast ball and pretty good stuff and he will   pitch some fine games, but as I have said many times, he  is a 50-50 pitcher on a pennant winning team.    In any event, what could it hurt to expose Littlefield  to the market or indeed to find what club or clubs need  a left hand hitter, having in mind a player deal,  although as far as I am concerned, he could go for cash.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 20, 1956    LYNCH, JERRY    I have had several conversations with Lynch. He has told me and very recently that he wants to catch, that he feels that he can come to be a good catcher and that he knows that he will like to do the job. If he is telling the truth, and I believe he is, then he should be given all the possible chance in this world to catch. It is the only position in which Lynch can become a World Series major leaguer. No consideration should b given to Lynch as a regular outfielder, although his retention on our club would provide an additional emergency outfielder at anytime, - and emergency only, which means an accident requires him to play in the outfield.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 16, 1956    MARTIN, PAUL    His poise is a lot better and he shows better control, - much better. His change of pace is a very effective pitch, but he keeps it high, - much too high. Curve ball is no good. It is a twister and should be used, but I wish it were better. He has a knuckle ball. It is my opinion that this knuckle ball should be used more often, perhaps substituted almost completely for his curve ball.    I believe Bobby should examine the position of the ball in Paul's hand on the fast ball pitch. I shall not be surprised if this ball is set back too far in the hand, - ball could be further extended toward the finger tips.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Phoenix, Arizona  June 26, 1956    One Day Observation  Arent, George (Douglas 1st Baseman)    A big boy, young, strong. Has power on his pitch. Can hit a home run. A .200 hitter against any kind of good pitching. He can't run and can't field. Can and should become a veteran in about Class C. He is a permanent fixture here, - should go with the franchise.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Observation One Day - Los Angeles Club    June 17, 1956    Gene Mauch. For utility purposes would be desirable and a good club could carry him as a regular. If we could make a deal for him on a trade basis, using players not necessary for Pittsburgh, - then that should be done.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 23, 1956    MAZEROSKI, BILL    This player should remain with this club until at least   April 10th, which is the opening of the Pacific Coast   League season. This boy could be a quicky, and it is   easily conceivable to me that he could take our second   base job before the year is over.    We know what O'Brien and Roberts can do at second base   and we know that neither of these boys is subject to   stage fright. They are already oriented. If we   knew the same thing about Mazeroski, then we could make   a final decision on him with some certainty. But we   do not know about his possible stage fright in the major   league. I think we ought to find it out in these   exhibition games.    Mazerowski can run as fast as either Roberts or O'Brien   and his arm is possibly better, as a second baseman, than   either of them. He has more power at the plate.    On April 10th, consideration should be given to his purchase   by Pittsburgh, even though it might be felt at that time   that he was not ready to open the season for us. in that   event, the player should be send to Hollywood on a one day   option recall agreement, with the understanding that   either O'Brien or Roberts or some satisfactory second   baseman would be sent to Hollywood in the place of   Mazeroski if and when that player might be recalled.    This gives the kind of protection to Pittsburgh that should   be given having in the mind the possibility that Pittsburgh   would prove to be a favorable surprise in the mid-season   campaign.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: April 2, 1956  MEMORANDUM -- WILLIAM MAZEROSKI    I learned about the sending of Mazeroski to Hollywood at a   luncheon at the Country Club attended by Mr. Galbreath and   Mr. Fairless and others. Joe stated at the luncheon that   Mazeroski had already been sent to Hollywood. I was so   upset by it that I impulsively gave vent to my feelings and   I said that I thought it was a 'terrific mistake', etc., etc.   Later, I said to Joe that I had spoken out at the luncheon   very impulsively and that was not good, but I felt so strongly   about it that I apparently did not seem to able to control   my words. As a result of my further conversation with Joe   about Mazeroski, I came to feel that he was likely to make   an effort to change the agreement on Mazeroski to a purchase   assignment by Pittsburgh from Hollywood and then subsequently   option the player to Hollywood on a one day option agreement,   as was outlined in my previous memorandum. The only thing   lost by this late move is simply that Mazeroski is not   exposed to a chance to make the Pittsburgh club. It would   be bad to bring him back from Hollywood to Pittsburgh again   during spring training only to find, probably,   himself on his way back to Hollywood again.    The whole Mazeroski procedure, as outlined by me in a previous   memorandum, was based upon the assumption that the player had a   chance to make the Pittsburgh club. Ordinarily that sort of   thing does not happen. That was stated very explicitly.   But it does happen in the history of baseball on occasion, and   Mazeroski positively had that chance.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: WILLIAM MAZEROSKI  June 24, 1956  William Mazeroski is a heavy-hipped, 5'11" tall, 185   pound infielder, - a right hand hitter with some power. His   running speed fools you. He wins in the races. Not impressive   as a base runner, but his great ground coverage explains not only his   speed afoot, but proves his shiftiness. This chap has the most   effective forearm in the game today. No arm anywhere equals   Mazeroski's in the combination of quickness, strength, and accuracy.    He has fine hands. At bat he has a slow preliminary wiggle of his   hands, - not enough, I believe, to affect adversely his timing.   The fault is noticeable but I do not believe it should be mentioned to him.   Let him alone. He as a level sweep, a short stride, and can on   occasion reach the fences. On the field he looks veternized.   Close up, he is a mere boy, - will be 20 years of age this coming   September.     If he can play with the same poise and composure in   Pittsburgh as he now shows with Hollywood, the boy can make good with   a bang. I have respect for the abilities of the O'Briens', Roberts,   Freese, Jacobs, et al, but they are all pretty much "boys" in   comparison with Mazeroski who is a "man".

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 16, 1956    McMAHAN, JACK    This left hander knows what it is all about. I would  call him a pitcher, not a thrower. Showed me no  special stuff, either curve or fast ball. Used no  change of pace. In character and in manner he might  be great. Everything is wrong with his health, -  his eyes, his tonsils, hernia, all of which should have  compulsory attention and immediately.    I would need to see him more to risk an opinion as to  whether he can help us in the pitching department.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: April 2, 1956    McMAHAN, JACK    I have not agreed with anybody, I suppose, on the   handling of McMahan. If he was worth the draft price,   he was worth having his hernia attended to, and his tonsils,   and his teeth, etc. He gives every impression, at least   to me of being a pitcher rather than a thrower. He takes   charge.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: April 2, 1956    MUNGER, GEORGE    If George does not use his knuckle ball, or if for any reason he cannot use it, he should be marketed. He can't do us any good unless he has the knuckle ball. He is a different pitcher with it. Without it, he is the same pitcher he used to be and not worth very much.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 16, 1956    MURRAY, ARTHUR    Has stuff, - fast ball and curve. Throws no other pitch. Was wild.    He is inclined to pitch everything outside to hitters. Keeps the ball away from every batsman, and when he presses he really is wild.    He is an eccentric and that's a kindness in language.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: June 24, 1956   Hollywood, Cal.     Cholly Naranjo. Cholly Naranjo is the best major league  pitcher I have seen in the minors in a long time. If properly  pitched, he could win anywhere. He has a three-quarter, sweeping,   fairly fast velocity curve ball, and it is very effective. He uses  it very seldom. He does throw and so-called regular curve and one  that is a slow curve and both are good but there come times when  his fast curve, not really a great breaking ball, should be used.   His change up on the fast ball is invariably effective. Cholly   does not have a great fast ball, not great, but it is not a softy.   Because of good curves and his frequent use of them, the batter   is set up constantly to expect curves. His fast ball is usable.   Naranjo is intelligent, is a good competitor, and not a silly set   up at the plate like Raydon.     Within one year, Naranjo could become a regular starter   in the major leagues. Bragan got rid of him a year ago, thought   he was no good. In my judgment, he was the best pitcher on his   staff at that very time.     Arroyo, in my book, is just a so so pitcher. I may be   wrong about it, but Bragan and the coaches could set me right about   it. If I am right [about it], and further if waivers can be secured   on Arroyo, then he should be sent to Hollywood in the Naranjo deal.     If I am right about Naranjo, it would be a great thing   if he was with us the balance of the season. The future greatness   of the Pittsburgh pitching staff depends very much, it seems to me,   upon Dick Hall. The addition of Dick Hall and Naranjo could   conceivably make us next year, - to say nothing of the possible help   that might be given us by Trimble and Pepper.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: June 24, 1956  Hollywood, Cal.     Pete Naton. Clay Hopper does not like Naton. However,  he will not say that the boy does not have a chance to go major  league. However, he won't catch him. That is bad. Naton  should be moved, - moved to Lincoln or someplace where, by previous  agreement, he will be caught regularly, - and that move should be  made immediately.      Hollywood has no catching that can do its full part in  putting the team in the race. If Kravitz could be moved to Hollywood,  that would be great.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 20, 1956    Atwell, Toby    This player should have been marketed last fall just as  I proposed to do and outlined the procedure at that time.  It may be that no move was made on Atwell because Joe  felt that the player should be retained. It was in  very late January that I was given a surprise call on the  telephone and it was suggested that I might see the  Philadelphia people since I was going to Philadelphia  on other matters.    I was to talk on a possible deal on Surkont and/or Ward.  I said at that time that I was also going to New York and  would it be alright to see the New York people.    It was naturally downright humiliating whether it should  have been so or not that I should have to ask somebody  whether or not I could talk to the New York club about  a player who was, I thought, by general agreement  scheduled to be traded. Oh yes, I was to see New York.  In the course of my conference with the New York people  I took the liberty of talking Atwell.    I find that during this training period when practically  all clubs are tremendously optimistic about their immediate  future it is difficult, if not impossible, to arouse very  much interest in second rate players and Atwell belongs  in that class. We should have realized, in my judgement,  not less than $25,000 for Atwell, plus a player. It is  my belief that the player will not bring us more than the  waiver price.    It would be better for the Pittsburgh organization if Atwell  were waived out and could be sent outright to Hollywood  where at the end of the coming season he might reach the  money market. This is said upon the assumption that the  waiver price is the top figure that could be secured in the  money market for Atwell.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Albuquerque, N. M.  June 27, 1956    One Day Observation    Nordberg, Bill    Western League is as high as Nordberg will go, unless indeed he were to get an effective additional pitch.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 16, 1956      O'BRIEN, EDDIE      May not be ready, at all, for our club this year and it  is possible that he should go out when his bonus  period expires in June. Right now, however, he should  be played at shortstop every inning every day and he   should also be told and practised on running 90' from  home to first base instead of 110'. This telling  and this practice both applies to several other  players on our club.         B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 27, 1956      O'BRIEN, JOHNNY    I believe that Johnny O'Brien will eventually be a regular   in the major leagues. Since Mazeroski has left, it seems   to me to hold both Roberts and the O'Briens on our club, -   also Cole at least untill cutdown date.    If Johnny O'Brien can hit .260, I would prefer him to   Roberts. He has a much stronger arm than Roberts and he   can outrun him.    If, however, Johnny does not hit, then Roberts should be   played.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 16, 1956    PEPPER, LAURIN    Pepper should be sent out on June 18th on option and   no particular attention should be given to him until   after that date. With the number of pitchers who   ought to be seen in this spring training camp period,   Pepper should not be permitted to appear again.   Then a good pitcher should be placed out on a one day   optional recall with the understanding that the pitcher   is to be recalled on June 18th and Pepper substituted.    There seems to be some fear in some quarters that   Pepper will quit baseball and go into professional   football. So what? The answer to this is that the   player has told me personally and very positively that   he wants to go out when his bonus period terminates   and go to some minor league club where he can pitch with   great regularity. He further stated that he did not   want to go into professional football and wanted very   definitely to make good in baseball. I am very sure   that a proper conversation with Laurin will confirm   this understanding.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March, 23, 1956      POWERS, JOHN    Powers has the bad habit of hitting his power drives, -  all foul. I say that it is a habit and it is a habit, -  a bad habit. Keeping this habit, Powers is not  worth a nickel. He must change. I worked with this  fellow for two or three weeks last fall and I have  had him this spring. It is my set opinion that he   cannot be helped by changing his physical form in  batting. That cannot be done easily, in fact, not at  all. This player must hit with INTENT on every pitch and  continue to do so until the physical form of his batting  changes without him knowing it. He must hit the ball  back at the pitcher, - deliberately try to do that  very thing on every strike pitch. He may lose some   power but sooner or later his form will change and then  he can forget all about this thing I call 'hitting with  intent.' If Powers has sense enough to follow this  instruction, he might help this club right now, - that  is to say, during the coming season. And if he says he  will do it and further if he will do it, then he should  be played in every possible game during this exhibition  period.    If I had to go right now to Hawaii [XXXXX] for 154 games  and could take one or the other of two outfields,  namely, (1) Thomas, Del Greco and Skinner, or, (2)  Walls, Clemente and Powers, I would go with number (2).    It can be, of course, that Skinner could develop into an  acceptable outfielder. That is very hard for me to   believe.    For years I have felt that Del Greco might become a fine  major leaguer. I am compelled now to doubt it.    Besides, we should carry six outfielders until we are  compelled to cut one loose on account of the player   limit.      B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: April 2, 1956    PURKEY, BOB    Purkey looked to me like he had a lame arm. Was all tied up in the shoulder. But the last time out, he looked very much better. He is a pitcher rather than a thrower, and could help us very much if his arm is sound. We ought not be in too big a hurry to get rid of him. I would say to hold him until possibly the cut-down time.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: June 24, 1956  Hollywood, Cal.      Bob Purkey. Very competent doctors punctured his knee  several times. I have been told for years by Dr. Hyland and  confirmed by Dr. Bennett that tapping the knee was a doubtful,  if not a dangerous, procedure in most cases. I would not be  surprised if Purkey never recovers the full, normal use of his  knee. As far as I can discern, he is ready to pitch. His new  pitch, the knuckle ball, really knuckles, and if he gets control of  it, good usable control, he could help Pittsburgh.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 27, 1956    ATWELL, TOBY    25 Atwells will finish last in any major league race.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood-Seattle June 24, 1956    Dick Aylward. This fellow surely can do everything but hit. He has a fine arm and is a fine receiver. A lively and alert catcher, but he looks to me like a terribly poor hitter. I am not interested in him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Phoenix, Arizona  June 26, 1956    One Day Observation    Rosania (Outfielder with Douglas)    Right hand hitting outfielder. Very young. Sturdy built chap. He has good form at the plate and good power. If he can run and throw, this boy will attract a lot of attention.    Branch Rickey    BR/b    (Later) He can run, and he can throw. He's a great freshman prospect.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Phoenix, Arizona  June 26, 1956    Samford (Phoenix Infielder)    A below average runner, not a great arm. I don't  believe he is a prospect.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: June 24, 1956  Hollywood, Cal.    Roger Sawyer should be moved somewhere. He needs to be   worked regularly. Sawyer cannot get regular work at Hollywood.  He has come to be a side-arm pitcher. I think it is a very bad  mistake to give up overhand pitching, although he may advisably  vary his delivery to side-arm. Sawyer has a fine change up on his  fast ball, but never throws it. Whose fault it is, I do not know.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood-Seattle  June 24, 1956  Schult, Art. A great big man. Just a fair runner with  an average arm. Not as much power as his size would indicate.  I don't believe he is a major league prospect.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    SHACKLEFORD, RAY (Infielder)  Arm good enough. Might be interested, but watch  him at the plate.    June 19, 1956  No reason why he shouldn't hit. Have a further  look.    BRANCH RICKEY  BR/b    June 20, 1956  Side arm thrower altogether. Not a great arm.  BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    SETTLE, TED  I defer to the judgment of the other fellows. He may  have more stuff than it seemed.    BRANCH RICKEY  BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    SHELBY, BOB (Infielder)    Has a quick, short arm throw. Might play second   base, not third or short. Don't know anything about his  running speed.    June 19, 1956    Hitting form is good, and he shows power.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 20, 1956    SHELBY, BOB    6'4" tall, 198 pounds, right hander, pretty good speed,  fair curve, - nothing else, and I didn't have any luck helping  the boy very much. He is a nice fellow. He has pretty good  power at the plate. I have a great doubt that he could do   creditable work in professional baseball as a pitcher, - right now.  He might be a good boy to have in spring training.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 16, 1956    SHEPARD, JACK    Shepard has lost his appearance of leadership and possibly  his sense of it. Without his aggressiveness, his  assertiveness, his take-chargeness, he is a doubtful  major leaguer. Sooner or later, I believe Shepard  will come to that sort of leadership which distinctly  characterized his year's work at Denver.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    SHINN, JIM (Infielder)    Very good arm, - quite adequate to play anywhere.  He looks like an infielder.    June 19, 1956    Not very impressive as a batsman. Average runner  at that.    BRANCH RICKEY    June 20, 1956    I have not seen a real exhibition of his running  speed, but from what I have seen, he is a very ordinary runner.  BR/b    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    RAMOS, DAVE (Outfielder)    Good arm. Trajectory very bad. He can run, -   perhaps above average. Strikes at anything pitched.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Albuquerque, N. M.  June 27, 1956    One Day's Observation    Dick Shinnick (Lincoln Pitcher)    Tall, right hander. Has been in the organization  five years. He doesn't have baseball in his mind except as a  sort of a summer job to pay his way throught school. He has a good  fast ball, fair curve, nothing else. If he really wanted to be  a great pitcher, he might become one. He has no such interest.    Branch Rickey    BR/b    (Later) As a batsman, Shinnick ain't.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    SILVERMAN, RON (Outfielder)    Average runner. Good form at the plate. Very good  form and the kid has power. Make sure about his arm.    June 19, 1956    The boy has slow body reflexes. Has a fine  arm, overhand delivery, fine carry on every throw. Surely  the only position he could play on the infield, if any,  is third base. If he can run well above average, then I would  give him a chance to play professional baseball.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: June 24, 1956  Hollywood, Cal.    Dick Smith, at shortstop, is barely good enough for a   pennant winning club in the Pacific Coast League, - only barely.  He is a confirmed puny hitter, and it would be very easy to  over-estimate his running speed. He is not a slow runner,  neither is he a long strider. He may not really be as fast as he  is rated. The boy has no adventure as a base runner. He is   a nice person and the Hollywood club can possibly carry him for sometime to  come as an integral part of a good club.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood-Seattle June 24, 1956    Third baseman Milt Smith. Last year with San Diego,  purchased by Cincinnati and now in some off hand deal belongs to  St. Louis. He can run like the dickens and although a right  hand hitter, he hits to right field almost altogether. He either  has a very sore arm or he can't throw. No arm at all. I would  not be interested too much in him even if he could throw.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    SMITH, WALLY (Infielder)    Very cubbish, very green, immature, no coordination  as yet. He might acquire more ability in another year or two.  Out of consideration for the present.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    SORENSON, GARY (Infielder)    This boy is about 5'7" tall, and will weigh 160 pounds.   Only 17. He can run and he can throw and his form at the  plate is good. We would not lose any money if we can sign  him at $4,000 and he could go to some club right now, - and  should go to some club. His experience has been at   shortstop but he could probably play any position.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: One Day Observation Los Angeles Club June 17, 1956    Speake (Outfielder) Showed me no arm at all. If his  throwing in the fielding practice was in reality Speake's arm at  its best, he can't throw good enough to play in a Class C league.  He may have a sore arm.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: June 24, 1956  Hollywood, Cal.    R. C. Stevens This big, agile, right hand hitting  negro is a 'hitter-upper'. He can scratch more clouds than most  anybody. He has power enough to drop the ball out of the park on  occasion. He is a young fellow and his ownership should be  protected.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Albuquerque, N. M.  June 27, 1956    One Day Observation    Al Stringer (Lincoln Infielder)    This is the younger one of the two Stringers [?]. I don't  believe he can do anything. If you have a young infielder  anywhere, I would put him in here and give this chap his unconditional  release.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Albuquerque, N. M.  June 27, 1956    One Day Observation    Richard Stuart (Lincoln Outfielder)    This tall, right hand hitter, has very unusual  power. His running speed is only average, - if that. His  arm is good, but some people say it is only average, but in  my book, it is well above average. He has an excellent arm.  Dick is an eccentric, - perhaps born a bit short. The  only thing he thinks about or talks about is a home run. He  does not regard any other part of his play as important.  The date of this dictation is June 27th and Dick has now made  40 home runs to date in the Western League. He will probably  break this year the all-time record for home runs in professional  baseball.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    RAYA, RONALD (Catcher)    Heavy, but has very good action. Throws the ball quick, and arm seems to be good enough.    June 19, 1956    He has very good power too. Not as good as Mealey. Can't run a lick.    Shows me nothing to get excited about. He is too slow. He would not throw many men out on bunts or foul fly balls. Out for me.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 20, 1956    SURKONT, MAX    This player should have been disposed of also at the winter  meetings. Right now, several clubs in the National  League need pitching. But everyone is shopping for an  ace pitcher. The same identical procedure should be  followed as I have indicated elsewhere on Ward.   Exactly the same.    Ward, Surkont and Atwell should have brought to this club  $100,000. I made that very remark last summer and  I said it at the end of the season and I said it on more  than one occasion in the fall, and I tried to indicate  as strongly as I could that I could bring about these  deals but not once was I given other than the impression  I was to stay completely out of any effort in these  directions. And I choose to believe from information given  me by other clubs that those clubs were not supposed  further to discuss with me about players. Cincinnati,  Milwaukee and Chicago, but particularly Milwaukee and  Cincinnati, told me of conversations about which I know  nothing. In any event, none of the deals have been  made and we can possibly be in front of a compulsory  acceptance of the waiver price for these players.    It is not simply the loss of the money that encompasses  all my concern. It is the possible loss of playing  strength that might have come to us in these deals. That  could be something very real.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: April 2, 1956    SWANSON, ART (RED)    Swanson is a bonus player and when he grows up he might be  quite a pitcher. He has the deliberate approach to his  job and is a student of pitching. I have great hopes  for his comparatively early future.    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood-Seattle June 24, 1956    Outfielder Joe Taylor. A tall, rough, sea-going negro  who allegedly plays a great game when he is sober. He has a  reputation of being a complete rounder, - a fence screeching tomcat  with not enough females in sight. He even plays a good game, so  'tis said, with his snoot full.    This fellow can run and he can throw and he can hit the  ball 'a fur piece'. I don't know how old he is. So far as  I can find out, no one does. He is somewhere between 20 and 40.  Age doesn't matter very much because he is agile, fast, and obviously  full of confidence. He is presently hitting .325 with 24 doubles  and 16 home runs. Taylor bears such a vile reputation that I guess   I couldn't have the remotest interest in him, but he impressed me  very much as a player in the few games I saw him play.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: June 26, 1956  Phoenix, Arizona    One Day Observation    Billy Joe Thompson (Phoenix First Baseman)    A big, 6'5", right hand hitting first baseman.  He has power and he can run, but he has no adventure at all.  Gets no lead and doesn't try to get a break. Just stands  dead off any base.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Albuquerque, N. M.  June 27, 1956    One Day Observation    Kenny Toothman (Lincoln Infielder)    Just an ordinary player in every respect. I don't  believe he should be considered as a possibility for anything  higher than AA. His future depends upon his hitting.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 27, 1956    TRIMBLE, JOE    This young right hander has major league stuff. When he  really cuts loose on his curve ball, it is unhittable. He  has a good fast ball and a good knuckle ball which he seldom uses. He  has a variety of stuff and plenty of it. He acts to me  like a stage-fright kid. His liver shakes inside. He  reminds me of Friend in '51, '52, '53. He has the  mannerism of calm deliberation but it is not real. If and  when he becomes oriented, - he   certainly will be quite a pitcher.    Words or vocal encouragement will hardly help him in his  present state, and the poise he needs will not likely   come quickly. Pitching in high company and lots of it   is the cure, - sure and quick. The question is whether  or not we can afford to give him that kind of work.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: June 24, 1956  Hollywood, Cal.    Ben Wade. An old right hander, but a likeable chap.   He was told, in effect, when he left Pittsburgh a year ago that I was  responsible for his leaving the club. I did not have the remotest  thing to do with the decision to send him out. Nevertheless, he  has said uncomplimentary things due, of course, to his misinformation.    Clay tells me that if he had to let loose of a pitcher,  the first man to go would be Wade. That could be the correct  decision. I do not know. He is a non-prospect, and I think  Bobby Bragan is very wrong in asking for his assignment back to   Pittsburgh.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    WALLACE, KIM (Infielder)    Almost no stride, gives you all he got when he hits.  Level swing. See more of that boy by all means.    June 19, 1956    He has a quick arm, - a sound arm, not great velocity.  Second base, I guess, is his position. He can go professional  if he can hit. His future depends upon what he does with his  bat in his hands. He is the kind of prospect you would not  care to put any money into, i.e., a bonus. If he wants a job,  o.k.    Very young. Just can't get the bat against any  curve ball or any breaking ball. I am completely upset about  it.    He is just a boy. No power at the plate. I would  say undoubtedly not ready for professional ball.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 27, 1956    WALLS, RAY LEE    I don't care what Walls says, - he is not in physical  condition to play baseball on a winning major league club.  Between second and third on his three base hit, he practically  blew up. He could hardly finish. That is simply an  inexcusable physical condition for a major league  outfielder.    Nevertheless, in my book Walls can do our club or any  other club more good than Skinner in the outfield.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: Phoenix, Arizona  June 26, 1956    One Day Observation    Walton (Douglas 2nd Baseman)    Little fellow. He may have a good arm, but he doesn't  show it. Very average runner. This could be his league.    Branch Rickey    BR/b    (Later) Walton has much less than an average arm.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 23, 1956    RAYDON, CURT    This pitcher and no other pitcher whose exact ability   we know little about should be sent from this club at   this time to Hollywood. It is by no means certain   that Hollywood will not have a surplus of pitchers   with the addition of Murray and Green without sending   anybody else, and it may be that New Orleans or Williamsport   or some other club may need pitchers very badly. The   place to keep good surplus pitchers is in the hip pocket   of the Pittsburgh club, and then to be ready to deliver   quickly when the need appears. That goes for all clubs   but particularly Hollywood and New Orleans.    If you already have information that Hollywood definitely   needs pitching in addition to those now scheduled for   Hollywood, then of course O.K. on, for example, Raydon to   Hollywood. If you do not have this information, then   I would delay the move.    If Hollywood is to be 'aced' with a pitcher, then it surely   cannot be Raydon. There is no assurance that Raydon   can be outstanding pitcher in the Pacific Coast League.   He certainly does not carry the publicity assurance of   a Garber or a Munger or a Donoso or a Trimble or any one   of several others who might be available for Hollywood.   In other words, the sending of Raydon is a gamble, - first   because he may not be needed, and second, he may not be   good enough to ace the club. And there is a third   reason, namely that New Orleans would find in Raydon a   publicity ace and perhaps a real one, and the New Orleans   pitching staff surely will need some help. For all there   reasons I would hold Raydon at this time on the Pittsburgh   club.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; A-B
Transcription: March 20, 1956    WARD, PRESTON    This boy could have been disposed of surely at the winter  meeting. In fact, I know that the deal could have been  consummated at that time, and his marketing should have  been handled in such a manner that either, first, brought  about a favorable deal within the National League, and  second, upon waivers secured in the National League, a  money deal in the American League. This we also know  could have been brought about.    Player Ward should not have been brought to this camp this  spring and it never was in my plans that he should have  been brought to this camp this spring. The procedure  even now could be somewhat as follows.    A telephone conversation with every National League club who  might be inclined to claim Ward on a waiver request, in  which the club was told if a claim was to be entered, then  the Pittsburgh club would prefer not to ask waivers at this  time. And this statement would not be a bluff because  under the present circumstances if Ward is claimed at  $10,000 within the National League, we then know we have  a chance of making a much better deal. Then, indeed,  Ward should be held until the cutdown date on May 15th  when clubs will either have to waive or find themselves  in the position to offer a much higher consideration.  In my judgment, it is just too bad that Ward was not  disposed of before March 1st.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: March 27, 1956    WATERS, FRED    I think Branch, Jr. is dead right about this fellow. He  must simply pitch his way off this club. I would rather   have him than Littlefield. He has a better curve ball   and better control. He has a corking move to hold men   on and I don't believe for one minute that he is subject   to stage-fright.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: June 24, 1956  Hollywood, Cal.    Fred Waters should be retained right where he is.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    Welch, Jim (Outfielder)    OUT.    Branch Rickey    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Hollywood - Seattle June 24, 1956    Second baseman Artie Wilson. You can have him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    WISE, SAMUEL (Infielder)    He has an outfielder's arm and not too strong. Would   not give him any consideration anywhere in the infield, -   not at this time.    Jun 19, 1956    Shows very good arm and has body control.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Albuquerque, N.M.  June 27, 1956    One Day Observation    Joe Zavattaro (Lincoln Catcher)    Looks like he has a good arm. Knows how to put   his clothes on and has a good manner on the field. With the   bases full, he took three straight pitches right through the   heart of the plate. He never moved his bat off his shoulder.    Branch Rickey    BR/b    (Later) I doubt if he knows a good ball from a bad ball up at the   plate. I don't believe he is any kind of a good hitter, - not at all.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: June 24, 1956  Hollywood, Cal.    Curt Raydon is a one pitch pitcher, - a good fast ball, -  practically nothing else. He can't hold runners on. That is to  say, any base runner can get a good break, a running start. He  stands with every bit of his weight on his right foot. While he  is moving over getting ready to step, the runner is running. No  catcher born can shoot out the runner, not with Raydon pitching.  This chap needs a third pitch or perhaps I should say a second one, -  a usable effective something besides his fast ball. As he is  today, from the standpoint of the major leagues, he is not worth a  dime a dozen.    He is as bad a batsman as Bill Doak, possibly worse. He  should be downright ashamed of himself.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    REZO, BILL (Infielder)    He would have to be a corking good hitter and a good runner for me to have any interest.    June 19, 1956    Slow runner. I don't think so. Besides he can't run.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Hollywood-Seattle June 24, 1956      Shortstop Leo Righetti. He is hitting .300, - mirabile dictu. I wouldn't have him.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: March 23, 1956    ROBERTS, CURT    In any event, Roberts should not leave this club until cut down date, - and possibly not then.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Hollywood, California  June 18, 1956    ROGERS, ROCKY (Infielder)    Has a fine arm and good actions. If he can hit and run, he is definitely o.k. I like Rogers.    June 19, 1956    Look at him again.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: -2-    November 14, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago AL    BRICE - CON'T    Then with two men out and a runner on third, he hit the batter. Shows no control whatever or anything else.    I am thoroughly convinced that

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 8, 1962  Al Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Baltimore    BRICE, ALAN  He used the change-up on his curve ball very  effectively. He got it over and it upset the batsman's  timing. His fast curve ball which is more or less a  fast ball that curves was invariably outside. Not  one all day long was ever on the inside of the plate.  In fact, his regular curve ball was in the strike zone  very seldom indeed. His fast ball was good.  Certainly he should be with the Cardinal team in  spring training.    This fellow should be encouraged to use  his half-speed or change-up curve exclusively  as against the other breaking stuff. It  curves and has the effect of a corking change of  pace but more important than that, he controls the  pitch.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 8, 1962  Al Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Baltimore    BRICE, ALAN  He used the change-up on his curve ball very  effectively. He got it over and it upset the batsman's  timing. His fast curve ball which is more or less a  fast ball that curves was invariably outside. Not  one all day long was ever on the inside of the plate.  In fact, his regular curve ball was in the strike zone  very seldom indeed. His fast ball was good.  Certainly he should be with the Cardinal team in  spring training.    This fellow should be encouraged to use  his half-speed or change-up curve exclusively. It  curves and has the effect of a corking change of  pace but more important than that, he controls the  pitch.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 8, 1962    BUCHEK, JERRY No. 28  Right hand hitter. Well built boy. Form is  O.K. Not a long strider. Big end of the bat is  quiet. He gives evidences of ambition. He is by no  means what you would call a home run hitter.    I would say that change of speed pitching would  give BUCHEK the most trouble. I get the first  impression as I watch BUCHEK in the first batting practice  that he is very anxious, or perhaps tight, - not relaxed.  This impression could be very wrong but something has to  account for his low batting average last season.    If BUCHEK can run above average, he should be  regarded as a prospect. I would like to see the  complete figures of BUCHEK as a batsman covering his  entire professional career.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Baltimore    BUCHEK, JERRY  Is not a Cobb or Sisler even with his head as a  base runner. Left hand pitcher Short fooled him twice  very much when BUCHEK was running off first base and  then pinned him down flat almost on the bag when Gagliano  singled to right field. Then when Short threw to first  to hold Gagliano, BUCHEK went back to second base instead  of breaking toward third. BUCHEK has played long  enough in professional baseball to know better than that.  I doubt if BUCHEK has average speed as a runner. I  would like to see him in 50 yard dashes.    I am satisfied that BUCHEK will never be a major  league shortstop, unless, indeed, his fielding ability  would enable him to be carried by some power hitting, run  making club.    Against major league pitching, day in and day out,  this boy would be a helpless batsman. If I loved him  as I did my own son, I would have to say that it is  wasted time to [] watch him further as a baseball  player in this camp.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 14, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago AL    BUCHEK, JERRY  If BUCHEK plays today and runs and throws,  I wouldn't have him if he could play.  BUCHEK, JERRY (LATER)  In the dash running practice this morning,  BUCHEK said he couldn't take part in the running  because of a bad leg, but he started in the game at  shortstop and showed no signs of not running or any  injury whatever. Also, in the throwing contest  from the outfield, he couldn't throw because of an  ailing arm but he could play shortstop in the game  immediately following. In my book he is a 20 year old  boy off the field as well as on it.    I would assign him to a Class A League and let  developments take care of themselves. In fielding  his position in the pre-game practice, he went through  a lot of physical exertion in starting and running  that he would not have been subjected to in the races.  Obviously, he seems to lacks courage, just as he does up at the  plate.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 14, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago AL    BUCHEK, JERRY    If BUCHEK plays today and runs and throws,  I wouldn't have him if he could play.    BUCHEK, JERRY (LATER)    In the dash running practice this morning,  BUCHEK said he couldn't take part in the running  because of a bad leg, but he started in the game at  shortstop and showed no signs of not running or any  injury whatever. Also, in the throwing contest  from the outfield, he couldn't throw because of an  ailing arm but he could play shortstop in the game  immediately following. In my book he is a 20 year old  boy off the field as well as on it.    I would assign him to a Class D League and let  developments take care of themselves. In fielding  his position in the pre-game practice, he went through  a lot of physical exertion in starting and running  that he would not have been subjected to in the races.  Obviously, he lacks courage, just as he does up at the  plate.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Payne Field  Sarasota, Fla.  December 7, 1962  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox    BUCHEK, JERRY  Additional games simply add to my very positive  opinion that this boy is almost flabbergasted up at  the plate. For a young fellow, well built, good body,  good hands and a marvelous throwing arm, he gives the  impression of never being up to the plate facing a  pitcher before today. Surely he is a mental case.    Buchek runs not above average and the great  quandry to me, if the decision were left up to me,  is where he should play in 1963. If the decision  had to be made right now having only in mind the boy's  future and the possible contribution he might make on  a great club in St. Louis in future years, - I would be  compelled to send him to a lower league, Atlanta or even  Tulsa. His chance for the majors is the acquisition  of a new attitude at the plate. He is a self-made  victim of the pitch. He seldom, if ever, swings with  decision.    If he could be sent to a small league where he  could get batting confidence, - a sense of mastery of  the pitch, he might come to the majors. He is probably  a fine gentleman with splendid habits and plenty of  spunk and courage off the field. May be so. But he  is anything other than a spectacular compeititor in  uniform, - definitely because of his batting attitude.  It could hardly be anything else because his form at the  plate, starting with his initial stance, is good. He  does not have a power stroke but the boy is strong,  well built and good size.    He has had 2-1/2 years of professional experience  and now at 20 years of age he surely must be a much  worse hitter and with less promise than he was when  initially signed out of high school.    BRANCH RICKEY
