Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: A1 Lang Field  December 6, 1962  St. Louis vs. Milwaukee  St. Petersburg, Fla.    CARTY, RICARDO    A big Dominican Negro. Arm good enough,   good runner. Looks like a power hitter. Body   form good. Not much of an arm.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 8, 1962  Al Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Baltimore  BERTAINIA, FRANK (Baltimore Winter League Pitcher)     An 18 year old left hander, 6' tall. Lots of stuff. Good fast ball. Had a good change-up on it. Strictly overhand and a corking good 'downer'. Cocky, apparently full of confidence, - a sort of take charge guy. I really like him. He ranks in stuff with Stark and Jaster. If anything, he shows more stuff and challenge. If ever St. Louis gets a chance to make a deal with Baltimore, for heaven's sake try to get the contract of FRANK BERTAINIA.     His beautiful drop curve and his perfect change of pace, together with his fine fast ball makes him as fine a pitcher prospect as I have ever seen in many a day. Of course his lack of control is understandable, but if St. Louis had him, this boy would surely go to spring training with the general hope and my personal expectation that he would make the team in 1963.     I have seen all together eight games in the Florida Winter League, and the sum total of approximately fifty pitchers (repeaters of course, particularly from the St. Louis roster) and this 18 year old left hander is easily the best I have seen.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Al Lang Field  December 6, 1962  St. Louis vs. Milwaukee  St. Petersburg, Fla.    CARTY, RICARDO  A big Dominican Negro. Arm good enough,  good runner. Looks like a power hitter. Body  form good. Not much of an arm.    BRANCH RICKEY    Didn't show   a strong arm  Include him as a "throw in".

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 7, 1962  Payne Field  Sarasota, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox    CHERRY, JOE BOBBY (Chicago White Sox Catcher)  This boy did not catch today but he certainly  has one of the great arms anywhere in baseball and  he should be followed wherever he goes.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg  November 8, 1962    CLEMENS, DOUG NO. 49  He ought to hit. He has wrists. A fine  finish in his stroke. If he can run and throw,  surely he should be a major leaguer. What about  his weight?    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg  November 8, 1962    CLEMENS, DOUG NO. 49  He ought to hit. He has wrists. A fine  finish in his stroke. If he can run and throw,  surely he should be a major leaguer. [What about  his weight?]    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 9, 1962  Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Staff Meeting    CLEMENS, DOUG  Clyde King was heard to say that he was the  nearest thing to an over-strider.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis vs Baltimore    CLEMENS, DOUG    His body position at the plate is good. His  bat position is good. He has no hitch and his  stroke is on the level. I believe his running speed  is above average but I would like to see him in a  few sixty yard dashes.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis va Baltimore    CLEMENS, DOUG  His position at the plate is good. His  bat position is good. He has no hitch and his  stroke is on the level. I believe his running speed  is above average but I would like to see him in a  few fifty yard dashes.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 13, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    Observation of New York Mets    Hunt, No. 22, right hand hitter, good size boy, he is adventurous. Will take a chance on making the hard play or the great play. He hits with pretty good power and can run, - a fine runner, well above average. If you can include Hunt and Boyce in any deal with the Mets, it should be done.    Choo Choo Coleman is a power hitter in this (instruction) league. I believe a bit of mixed up pitching, seasoned with control, would cut down Cho Cho to size.    Branch Rickey    I like Coleman. Include him in any deal with Mets.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis vs Baltimore    COLLER NO. 30    The boy has a good arm.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 9, 1962  Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Staff Meeting    DENNIS, DON    Everyone in the camp discussion on Dennis was good. Apparently it is a matter of stuff, - whether or not he's got it. His manager last year says he has a good enough chance to go all the way.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 8, 1962  Al Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Baltimore    BERTAINIA, FRANK (Baltimore Winter League Pitcher)    An 18 year old left hander, 6' tall. Lots of stuff. Good fast ball. Had a good change-up on it. Strictly overhand and a corking good 'downer'. Cocky, apparently full of confidence, - a sort of take charge guy. I really like him. He ranks in stuff with Stark and Jaster. If anything, he shows more stuff and challenge. If ever St. Louis gets a chance to make a deal with Baltimore, for heaven's sake try to get the contract of FRANK BERTAINIA.    His beautiful drop curve and his perfect change of pace, together with his fine fast ball make[s] him as fine a pitcher prospect as I have [ever] seen in many a day. Of course his lack of control is understandable, but if St. Louis had him, this boy would surely go to spring training with the general hope and my personal expectation that he would make the team in 1963.    I have seen all together eight games in the Florida Winter League, and the sum total of approximately fifty pitchers (repeaters of course, particularly from the St. Louis roster) and this 18 year old left hander is easily the best I have seen.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Milwaukee  December 6, 1962    DENNIS, DON    A big boy, very young, right hander. Can throw pretty hard. Has great intelligence. I think he is a good fielder of his position.    In 1962, he pitched at Winnipeg. "All I had up there was a fast ball, no curve ball, nothing else." He has learned the curve ball in this Florida winter camp, - not great but it curves. He told me is working on a 'change up' off his fast ball. Seems to me to be the type that will learn from practice and instruction.    This boy should not be sent too high in 1963. He needs to be pitched a lot of innings, and where results will give him confidence.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 8, 1962    No. 16 (I Don't Know His Name)  If i were choosing up on hitters, i would pick him last.    Branch Rickey    DRUMMOND, LAMAR No. 16    There is nothing wrong with his form, although his stance, stroke, bat position does not at all indicate a home run hitter    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 13, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    DRUMMONDS, LAMAR    In the first place he cannot catch. On   a catchable foul ball, he never moved from his   position until he located the ball. Then he   arrived late and missed it. He throws quick.   Medium arm. No power.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 8, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.    DRUMMONDS, LEMAR    On first look, DRUMMONDS seemed quite ordinary   in every way, including arm, running speed, power,   and catching. But this fellow wears well. I don't   think he is any set-up at the plate at all. He is   a pest hitter, and occasionally with good power.    I think Harry Walker could afford to take him   as second string at Atlanta and surely he would be   quite acceptable as second man at Tulsa. It seems   to me that not much is expected of Drummonds on the part   of anyone. In my book, he will surprise more often   pleasantly than otherwise. He is a good journey-man   minor league player. If he would hit above .275 he   could conceivably go all the way, - but never great.    Now and then, he has a power stroke in his system.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 8, 1962  Al Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Baltimore    ETCHEBARREN, ANDY  Didn't see a better arm anywhere. He can  throw.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 9, 1962  Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Staff Meeting    FANOK, HARRY  By reports, does not have one angle of  delivery. Throws naturally from different angles.  According to Stanley Musial, the boy has better  control directly overhand. If so, it won't hurt  if he were told to go to that angle of delivery. I  would suggest that this boy be instructed in the  next game to use his curve ball fairly exclusively.  This fellow must be instructed to pitch his curve ball  in the game [predominently] more often.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 9, 1962  Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Staff Meeting    FANOK, HARRY  By reports, does not have one angle of  delivery. Throws naturally from different angles.  According to Stanley Musial, the boy has better  control directly overhand. If so, it won't hurt  if he were told to go to that angle of delivery. I  would suggest that this boy by instructed in the  next game to use his curve ball fairly exclusively.  This fellow must be instructed to pitch his curve ball  in the game predominently.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 7, 1962  Payne Field  Sarasota, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox    FANOK, HARRY  Here is a major leaguer if I ever saw one. He can  throw the ball hard and I mean hard, and he can throw  it overhand and repeat it overhand. As far as I can  determine, the boy has already acquired one groove for  overhand delivery, and that should mean control.  In other words, if he is not emotionally upset, or  domestically or financially or otherwise involved and  concerned while pitching, there is no reason for him  to be classified as wild. In which case, he should be  a regular pitcher on the Cardinal club without  any postponement whatever and most certainly without  long delay.    He has an overhand curve ball and when it is  pitched waist high or below it is a good curve ball.  He does not have finished control of this pitch but I  know of no reason why he should not have it readily.    Fanok does throw from other than overhand  delivery. He comes sidearm on occasion and perhaps  wisely so against certain hitters, but his effective  pitches generally speaking come from his overhand  delivery. He pitched some change-ups in his last  game but without control. Not one of these change-ups  were within the strike zone and below the waistline,  where, again, generally speaking, most change-ups  should go. I believe his so-called change-ups were  pitched off his curve ball. I have had no chance to  talk to him about it, but if the pitch is made as a  change off his curve ball, he needs to work on that  pitch considerably, - first to make it better, and,  second, to control it. Any change-up is a dangerous  pitch, - really a bad pitch if it is used without  control. His fast ball is not necessarily a dangerous  pitch or a bad pitch if it is not controlled. His fast  ball is not too hurtful wherever it is pitched, likewise  his curve. But a change-up simply must be under  control. Even poor pitcher-batters can lay off a  badly pitched slow ball. Such a pitch, therefore,  simply has the effect of putting the pitcher in the  hole.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 7, 1962    FANOK, HARRY (Continued)  As a pitcher, this boy shows all the signs of  being an added infielder.    He comes to a fielding position instantly  from his delivery, frequently moving his stepping  foot at the end of his delivery. This boy is  ready to pitch for the Cardinals whenever he really  believes he can. He should be given a lot of work  surely in spring training games.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 12, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    OBSERVATIONS  If St. Louis gets a chance to make a deal with New York, get catcher Boyce as a throw in.  BOYCE, BILL - NEW YORK METS    Fine arm and quick throw.  What club holds Boyce's contract?    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 7, 1962    FANOK, HARRY (Continued)  As a pitcher, this boy shows all the signs of  being an added infielder.    He comes to a fielding position instantly  from his delivery, frequently moving his stepping  foot at the end of his delivery. This boy is  ready to pitch for the Cardinals whenever he really  believes he can. He should be given a lot of work  surely in spring training games.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 7, 1962  Payne Field  Sarasota, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox    FEATHERSTONE, LEE (Chicago White Sox Pitcher)    Tall right hander. I don't know his age, but  he knows his way around. Fast ball not bad and his  curve is good but the control of his curve ball was  not good. He has change ups but these were pitched  in the general direction of home plate, - just that.    I would not turn 'thumbs down' on his  future.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 7, 1962  Payne Field  Sarasota, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox    FEATHERSTONE, LEE (Chicago White Sox Pitcher)    Tall right hander. I don't know his age, but  he knows his way around. Fast ball not bad and his  curve is good but the control of his curve ball was  not good. He has change ups but these were pitched  in the general direction of home plate, - just that.    I would not turn 'thumbs down' on his  future.    3 innings BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis va. Baltimore    FIREK, JAN    Takes two steps and winds up before he throws. His arm is plentty strong.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 13, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    FIREK, JAN  Very young right hand hitting outfielder who can throw hard. I don't believe he can do anything else in professional baseball at the present time. Doesn't impress me as a runner at all and a right hander's curve ball is a complete stranger to [this boy] him. He should be sent next year as low as possible.    I don't believe this boy will hit above .2[0]?0 in any professional league in 1963.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 13, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    FIREK, JAN  Very young right hand hitting outfielder who can throw hard. I don't believe he can do anything else in professional baseball at the present time. Doesn't impress me as a runner at all and a right hander's curve ball is a complete stranger to this boy. He should be sent next year as low as possible.    I don't believe this boy will hit above .200 in any professional league in 1963.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 14, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.    FIREK, JAN  FIREK left camp this morning unannounced. The boys tell me he can't run well. He is a long way from being a good hitter. I think he can throw. The club saved some money when he went home.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 8, 1962    GAGLIANO, PHIL NO. 64 (As a Batsman)    Tall boy. Well built. Has a strong swing. Right hand hitter. Doesn't over stride. Hand position is good. No faults in form. From the first workout for me, he looked like he was a dead left field hitter, - easily correctible. If this boy's power strokes do not go foul over much, then let him alone. If they go foul too much, the front foot should be anchored and move only the rear foot. I will have more on this fellow as I see more of him. I am simply registering my first impression.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis va. Baltimore    GAGLIANO, PHIL  Looks like a good boy in the field.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 9, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.    GAGLIANO, PHIL  I like GAGLIANO. I think he runs above average and his forearm is good. He is a hustler. I think he will become a fairly dependable hitter. He is the type of player who plays just as well in the majors as he does in the minors.    If this player goes to the Cardinal spring training camp, I should not be surprised if he is retained throughout the season with the parent club. If the number of players permit intra-squad morning games, Gagliana should be player at positions other than second, and particularly so in practice sessions.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Baltimore    BRICE NO. 61    He threw quite a number of curve balls in his warm-up, not one of them near the plate.    He is a big right hander, good speed, and I believe a darn good curve ball, - effective only if he can get it over. BRICE's curve has good velocity but out of 14 curves thrown in the sixth inning, three were over the plate and one was struck at, - not over the plate. The other eleven curve ball pitches were so far away, - up, down, and mostly outside, away from the hitter, that they were not even teasers. It is impossible for me to judge a pitcher who is no where near the plate.    Threw four or five with something taken off the fast ball, - perhaps intentional change of speed pitches, - not one over the plate.    In the seventh inning, he threw eight curves, two were strikes and one was a strike out pitch, the ball striking the plate or perhaps a little in front of the plate.    In the eighth inning, BRICE made 18 pitches. 10 were curves, 2 were good strikes and one bad one a strike out, and 7 would surely average two feet each outside, - always away from the batter. I would say that he had fairly good control of his curve ball, - two feet outside the plate, and practically every one of them below the waistline. This boy may be timid, - afraid he will hurt the batsman with the curve ball.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 8, 1962  Al Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Baltimore    THIRD BASEMAN FOR CHICAGO NO. 3    He can throw and field. Good form at the plate. Should hit.    BRANCH RICKEY    Upon further inquiry as to this fellow's name as his name was not on the Chicago Winter League roster, it was determined that it was RON HANSEN from the parent Baltimore Club.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 7, 1962  Payne Field  Sarasota, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox    HOAGLAND, THOMAS (Chicago White Sox Pitcher)    A 19 year old left hand pitcher. Good size, good delivery, fairly good fast ball and curve is O.K. Showed nothing else.    I would not be surprised to see HOAGLAND within the next few years a regular pitcher in the major leagues.    BRANCH RICKEY    3 innings

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 13, 1962   St. Petersburg, Fla.   St. Louis vs. Mets    OBSERVATION OF NEW YORK METS   HUNT, No. 22, right hand hitter, good size  boy, he is adventurous. Will take a chance on   making the hard play or the great play. He hits  with pretty good power and he can run, - a fine   runner, well above average. If you can include  Hunt and Boyce in any deal with the Mets, it should  be done.   CHOO CHOO COLEMAN is a power hitter in this (Instruction)  league. I believe a bit of mixed up pitching,  seasoned with control, would cut down CHO CHO to size.     BRANCH RICKEY     I like Coleman. Include him    in any deal with Mets.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 9, 1962  Staff Meeting    JESTER, LARRY  This boy is a bonus player. On account of having to stay with the Cardinal club all next year, it could not be too important that he be pitched very much down here to the exclusion of others who must be seen. The discussion seemed to develop in my mind that he ought to pitch overhand enclusively. That would give him his best curve ball. Comment indicated that he was a sure major leaguer.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 12, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    JASTER, LARRY    Good fast ball and a good curve. Smooth,   easy delivery on all pitches. Threw a couple of change   ups. Which Seemed to be off his curve ball. Never over   the plate. He probably has a usable change of pace   pitch, but if not, he must get it.    His youth, size, appearance, and 'stuff'   combine to make him a very fine prospect, - after   observation for three innings.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 12, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    JASTER, LARRY  Good fast ball and a good curve. Smooth, easy delivery on all pitches. Threw a couple of change ups. Seemed to be off his curve ball. Never over the plate. He probably has a usable change of pace pitch, but if not, he must get it.    His youth, size, appearance, and 'stuff' combine to make him a fine prospect, - after observation for three innings.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Milwaukee  December 6, 1962    JASTER, LARRY [*18 year old*]    Has good poise. Shows good control. His   fast ball is not great but it seems to be quite   alive. His curve ball is his pitch. He should   use it not only when he is in trouble, but he should   use it in advance of trouble. His overhand curve   ball is major league.    He should surely not be sent above B, if sent   out at all, and I really believe he would make it   quicker with a major league club if he were to pitch   his first full year in C or D.    This boy seems to lack pep. Moves too   lackadaisical. I wonder!!! I believe he [is a] has   adolescent ennui.    BRANCH RICKEY    [*9 coming 'prospect'*]

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Milwaukee  December 6, 1962    JASTER LARRY    Has good poise. Shows good control. Moves too lackadaisical. I wonder!!! I believe he is a adolescent ennui.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla  November 8, 1962      KOLB, GARY NO. 52    Left hand hitter with a bit of extended stride. Ought to have fine power on his pitches. He hits with authority on the pitch he likes and that pitch is probably best defined as leaving out all changes of pace. He is a vigorous, well built chap. My first look wants me to see more of him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis vs Baltmore    BRICE NO. 61    He threw quite a number of curve balls in his warm-up, - not one of them near the plate.    He is a big right hander, good speed, and I believe a darn good curve ball, - effective only if he can get it over. BRICE's curve has good velocity but out of 14 curves thrown in the sixth inning, three were over the plate and one was struck at, - not over the plate. The other eleven curve ball pitches were so far away, - up, down, and mostly outside, away from the hitter, that they were not even teaser. It is impossible for me to judge a pitcher who is no where near the plate.    Threw four or five with something taken off the fast ball, - perhaps intentional change of speed pitches, - not one over the plate.    In the seventh inning, he threw eight curves, two were strikes and one was a strike out pitch, the ball striking the plate or perhaps a little in front of the plate.    In the eight inning, BRICE made 18 pitches. 10 were curves, 2 were good strikes and one bad one a strike out, and 7 were surely average two feet each outside, - always away from the batter. I would say that he had fairly good control of his curve ball, - two feet outside the plate, and practically every one of them below the waistline. This boy may be timid, - afraid he will hurt the batsman with the curve ball.     BRANCH RICKEY    [*Early impression see later*]

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 10, 1962    OBSERVATIONS ON THE GAME AT CLEARWATER, FLORIDA BETWEEN ST. LOUIS AND BALTIMORE    I would like to see KOLB play a game at shortstop.  How did St. Louis get BRICE and what is his background. Can you get hold of his full professional statistics.    Get the full name of the umpire from George McDonald. Is an alert umpire, actively in the game, and I believe intelligent.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis va. Baltimore    KOLB, GARY  At third base, Kolb's arm is good. Body control is good.    This boy must be taught to run straight to first base and not fifteen feet out in four territory. He has a fine lead off first. He needs to be adventurous all the time. He is the kind of raw material out of which the St. Louis club should build a winner. When the pitcher threw to first base with KOLB on third, he instinctively broke twoard home, - the opposite of Buchek.    I wish so much that KOLB had extra base hitting power, but I am half sick thinking that he may not have it.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 13, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    KOLB, GARY    He knows more about holding a man on second   base instinctively right now than most shortstops   in the major leagues.     But, two buts, he didn't look good in the   seventh inning on the pop fly ball in left center.    BRANCH RICKEY    [*He explained this play later, -   very satisfactorily*]

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 13, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    KOLB, GARY    He knows more about holding a man on second base instinctively right now than most shortstops in the major leagues.    But, two buts, he didn't look good in the seventh inning on the pop fly ball in left center.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 14, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.    OBSERVATION    Apparently George Kissell is under   strict instructions not to play KOLB at shortstop.   [E]even if they want to keep BUCHEK in the game [and   let] KOLB could play short. Everybody admits that BUCHEK   has no chance to help the Cardinal club in 1963 and unlikely   in [or] 1964 at shortstop, and everybody admits that they   don't know at this time whether KOLB can do the   job or not at shortstop. Then what reason can   any intelligent man have for not playing KOLB at   shortstop and BUCHEK at third. I don't understand   it.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: [*Kolb*]  November 14, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.    ARMS  CLEMENS, LEWIS, WATTS, AND KOLB can throw  good enough to be major league. Everyone of them  needs practice in instinctive location of the  relay man. I believe at 270 feet that every one  of them can throw hard enough to permit the relay  man to cut off the throw or let it go, and if he  lets it go, the ball will carry to the home plate  for a probabl[y]e put out.    KOLB [never] seldom takes a step before throwing.    SHANNON did not throw in this practice  because of a slightly ailing arm, but every one  says that he has a very strong arm.    CLEMENS double steps at times and LEWIS  does invariably. WATTS does not have a step but  he has a full wind-up in throwing. In other words,  the ball is in his hands too long, and the same  criticism holds true when WATTS plays third base, -  on the long throw. His forearm throw is alright  at third base and his running speed is not at all  below average.    LONG, in the 270 feet throwing practice  threw vigorously and often. His ball curves but he  has a very strong arm and he would learn to throw  correctly without great delay. This fellow is  intelligent and has great body control and his running  is good and not simply "good for a big man."  He is an average runner in anybody's league, but he  is not in good wind condition. In his second 60  yard dash, he really couldn't finish. He was out  of breath. This boy should make training a dedicated  effort. It would pay him to read Paul O'Neil's  story in The Grantland Rice Award Prize Sport Stories  entitled "Duel of the Four-Minute Mile". He would  then understand how John Landy of Australia and Dr.  Roger Bannister of England trained for the four-minute  mile. I am not suggesting that Long should devote  himself to such tremendous rigid and exacting procedure

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: November 14, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.    ARMS - CONTINUED  that these gentlemen followed but it would be good  for him to know that physical fitness under pressure  would be worth all the effort he could give it.  He has a fine arm and he has good running speed,  and he surely will [be]come to be known, sooner or  later, as a power hitter. His mental attitude  toward hitting should come to that of Medwick, -  who went up to the plate from the very beginning with  the idea of hitting the first good strike zone pitch  and the next one and the next one if over the plate.  He was up there to hit and with nothing else in his  mind. Of course, a man with that determination  and policy will hit at some bad pitches, but he will  handle some of them too. LONG needs that attitude  very much. I don't believe this boy can finish a  three base hit with full speed.    This practice of outfielders throwing to  the plate back of the 270 feet mark should be  almost daily until they get the habit of hitting  the relay man. And, of course, the relay man must  locate himself according to the play, - closer to  or further away from the outfielder but the idea  of permitting the relay man to have usable discretion  as to whether to cut off or not must become fixed  in his mind, resulting in habit of putting the right  trajectory on every throw. These prospective  outfielders in this so-called instructional camp should  practice this throw in every pre-game workout.  They need not press to put more velocity on the ball.  Everyone knows that their arm is strong enough.  What everyone of them needs is correctness in the  throw itself, having in mind above everything else  that the relay man is given a choice on every throw.    All throws from outfielders in the pre-game  practice should have in mind the relay man and indeed  it would be well if in these pre-game practices that  a relay man would be placed for all outfield throws  to the home plate. It would be helpful to the  outfielders.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: Payne Field  Sarasota, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox  December 7, 1962    KOLB, GARY  I have an ever-growing conviction that this boy  can play anywhere that he cares to play. He could  become a major league catcher. I even doubt not that  he could become a major league pitcher. He is  aptitude par excellence. He has the instinctive physical  reactions of a winning competitor.    If the Cardinal club's greatest need were to be  in the catching department, I would recommend that he be  started as catcher. He would come early to the job  acceptably. His arm, speed of foot, base running  ability, quickness in starting and stopping, and his  obvious desire to beat you, - all these combine to  make him an exceptional player in whatever position may  finally be assigned to him.    KOLB should be presently kept at shortstop, and  should go south with the Cardinal team and played  regularly at shortstop with the first team in the early  camp games and indeed in the early exhibition games.    KOLB is not, right now, a finished shortstop,  not at all. But he can become one rapidly but not at all  without being played at that position.    I don't believe that this boy is weak against left  hand pitching, but it does occur to me that he might be  better against it if he hit from the left side of the  plate against left handers. He might develop very early  a greater power stroke hitting right handed against left  handers than he now [is] has against left hand pitching. This  suggested change-over could not hurt his present batting  ability in any respect and he could come to acquire the  habit of an easy and comfortable right hand stroke by facing  the pitching machine daily for as many as 500 pitches.  Within 15 days of such work, he would in all probability feel  at ease in swinging right handed.    In this connection, I am forced to believe that

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1964; E-K
Transcription: December 7, 1962  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox  Payne Field, Sarasota, Fla.    KOLB, GARY (Continued)  the Cardinal field staff does not regard the pitching  machine with that degree of respect that it is properly  entitled to have. This winter camp should have had two  pitching machines, with proper cage [instruction] instalation, enabling  pitchers and certain other players to spend not less than  two hours each day facing the machines.    Al Lang Field will not give ample space for this  much needed practice feature during regulation spring  training, unless a special time in the early forenoon is  alloted for such work. There is plenty of room on Al Lang  Field for the installation of the cages without any  interference whatever with the playing of games. I wish  to offer to the staff for study and filing a copy of  written observations supporting the use of the pitching  machine.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 14, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.   St. Louis vs. Chicago AL    BRICE  He pitched with abandon in his first two   innings. Then in the eighth, he seemed to be   tied up. He aimed the ball, held up on his   curve and I remarked about it on the first man   to face him and again on the second man. I   don't know whether he tired or not, but he   certainly lost his fast ball and aimed his curve, -   lost control and looked very amateurish.    With one man out and the bases full and a   right hand pinch hitter at bat, he had one strike   and the next three pitches were nowhere near the   plate. With three and one on the hitter, the   batsman struck at a ball inside on the ground.   In other words, BRICE looked like he was completely   through, - a sort of high school blow-up.   Very disappointing. He was 'poohed' both head   and arm. Then the batter took a very doubtful   third strike. I don't believe BRICE is a good   fielder of his position.    BRANCH RICKEY    BRICE (LATER)    This boy came back in the ninth inning   with the left hand hitting McCall, - helped out   on one strike, then promptly walked him on four   pitches. This boy McCall of Chicago AL looks   good in every respect. He can run and throw and   has occasional power at the plate. With runners on first   and second in the ninth inning and nobody out,   BRICE became very nervous in his gestures and   actions generally, perhaps because of anger, but   he certainly was nervous, - no composure whatever.    CONT

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  December 8, 1962    KOLB, GARY  This boy KOLB comes from a broken family. A  vigorous physically excellent father left the mother  with five sons and four daughters some years ago.  Gary is fourth from the top. The youngest is now a  junior in high school and a very great athlete; an  exceptional runner, a strong arm, - plays all sports.  This boy should be followed closely but discreetly  by Cardinal scouts and it could not hurt if Gary was  so regarded by the Cardinal brass that it would become likely  [quick] for this youngest brother to go nowhere other  than with the Cardinals.    Gary's next younger brother is in the army and  will not get out for two more years. The Cardinals  are interested in this boy, but the White Sox seem to  have developed the inside track and they have all but  signed him to a Chicago contract, - as an infielder.  It is a long story about his negotiation for a career  in baseball. The boy will be 23 when he gets out of the  army. He should have the attention of our scouting  staff also.    Gary met his wife Georgia when he played in the  Eastern League at Lancaster, Pa. Georgia is a  Lancaster girl and an only child and the father works  for the Hamilton Watch Company in Lancaster, Pa.  Georgia's mother is self-employed.    There are only two of the Kolb children  remaining with the mother, - a sister and the younger  brother referred to above. An 18 year old sister  lives in the same small town of Rock Falls, Illinois,  as does the mother, but lives with other girls elsewhere.  Fairly obviously there are some sad tag ends to the  overall Kolb family story.    All the facts, properly assembled, together with  acquaintanceship with Gary, leads one very firmly to  believe that he is a serious minded youngster with  fairly mature judgment in all directions, (his mother,  the family, his wife and four months old baby, and  particularly his baseball career). He is taking his  trial at shortstop very seriously. Because it is  possible that the greatest need of the Cardinal club

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 8, 1962    KOLB, GARY (Continued)  could be in the department of catching, this subject  was mentioned to Gary. He told me that he had  done some catching, away back when, and indicated  to me that he was not only willing to undertake it,  but believed he could do it. This was a gratifying  reaction on the part of the boy, - gratifying because  he accepts his potential in any direction with good  spirit.    It is a downright shame for our Cardinal club  with a need of added material in practically all  departments to give any consideration whatever right now to  Kolb's leaving the Cardinal team in 196[2]3. This boy  could come to feel that he is a member of the team,  belongs, full of confidence that he can play with  poise and efficiency whenever called upon and at  practically any position.    Finally, I make this positive recommendation:    KOLB, CLEMENS, AND OLVER should have two  weeks of change-over practice at bat with two pitching  machines, (two because in the event one machine breaks  down there would be no lost time) with a properly  installed batting cage. The location could be  anywhere, probably Homestead, - and without any necessary  publicity. Golf gloves must be available to these  boys, and practice periods of two hours forenoon and  afternoon. Only two employees are necessary and these  can be no older or better than the school boys, - "shaggers"  indeed, one of whom could and would operate the pitching  machine. The players themselves would understand the  operation of the machine after the first day.    Each boy should be provided with approximately  a dozen bats of his chosen model. A proper coach  should be assigned to take charge of this fifteen day  workout with proper seating behind the net and would  become the consulting umpire. This practice is  calculated not only to make the change-over swing  become easy and natural but the additional benefit of  close and more accurate determination of the strike zone,  beneficial indeed to all players. I am speaking out  of long experience at this point. I have never been  associated with any club in the major leagues that did  not very soon become among the top batting team of the  league, if not indeed first place.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 7, 1962  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox  Payne Field, Saraso a, Fla.    KOLB, GARY (Continued)    the Cardinal field staff does not regard the pitching   machine with that degree of respect that it is properly  entitled to have. This winter camp should have had two  pitching machines, with proper cage installation, enabling  pitchers and certain other players to spend not less than   two hours each day facing the machines.     Al Lang Field will not give ample space for this   much needed practice feature during regulation spring  training, unless a special time in the early forenoon is   alloted for such work. There is plenty of room on Al Lang   Field for the installation of the cages without any   interference whatever with the playing of games. I wish  to offer to the staff for study and filing a copy of   written observations supporting the use of the pitching  machine.     [*No   contradictions  in the  paragraph*]    BRANCH RICKEY

Only two employees are necessary and these  can be no older or better than the school boys, - "shaggers"  indeed, one of whom could and would operate the pitching  machine. Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: KOLB, GARY (Continued) December 8, 1962    The time of this workout should come, say,   two weeks before the reporting date of the St. Louis   club. The object of all of us, of course, is to   bring the St. Louis club, at the earliest possible   date, to a contending position for the pennant.    If upon further consideration additional players   should be exposed to this suggested practice, it must   be kept in mind that more than three batsmen to a cage   is ill-advised and if less than three to a cage, they   tire; the just couldn't take it.    The details of the practice should be self-observed  by the three players. At approximately the   12' mark from the batter, there should be a red tape   hanging vertically from top to bottom on each 50'   side netting (indicating fair from foul). And each   batsman's time at the plate should extend no longer   than three fair balls. He can take as many pitches   as he wishes which will include foul balls or missed   balls or bad pitches but does [not] include all balls   that clear the net or hit beyond the red tape on the   nets. Thus, the batsman at no time wearies because   of his length of stay and the two successive batsmen   outside the cage do not suffer ennui or impatience.    It is not necessarily incumbent that these   three batters, one or all, should stay with the change-over   position. It may be that the coach and the   batsman will agree (and it so sometimes happens) that   the batsman should stay with his original position   exclusively, in which case he will continue to define   the strike zone and even practice the technique of   hitting to the opposite field. This requires   knowledge on the part of the coach to instruct in that   technique. Or, indeed, all three batsmen can during   this period do much practice on both bunting to spots   and pushing or dragging the ball, - - - both for   sacrificing and bunting for hits.    All batsmen could be improved if they were   subjected regularly to this practice but I feel that   two of the boys could positively be helped for the   1963 season, with a possibility that it might [be]

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: KOLB, GARY (Continued) December 8, 1962    add something to the batting confidence and effectiveness  of OLIVER. This fellow has a mean bat and the  club should exhaust every possibility of improving his   hitting.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: [*-2-]  November 14, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago AL    BRICE - CON'T  Then with two men out and a runner on third, he hit  the batter. Shows no control whatever or anything  else.    I am thoroughly convinced that there was  reason for this pitcher's not having been used very  much regardless of his past manager or league  classification. He should go to AA, possibly AAA,  and have a good year before I would recommend him to  the Cardinal club for retention.    See later report of 12/8/62    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 8, 1962   Al Lang Field   St. Petersburg, Fla.   St. Louis vs Baltimore  MAJTYKA, ROY      If this boy can hit a bit, he could help   Harry Walker in Atlanta in 1963. He plays well   defensively most anywhere.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 9, 1962  Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Staff Meeting    MAULDIN, WELDON    The discussion developed that this boy should be made to pitch with some weight on his front foot if holding men on bases.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 7, 1962  Payne Field  Sarasota, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox    MCCALL, BRIAN (Chicago White Sox Outfielder)    This boy is indeed very impressive to me. He can throw and he can run and he is positively not a puny hitter. He can, on occasion, drive the ball a 'far piece'. He is prospectively very desirable.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Al Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  December 6, 1962  St. Louis vs. Milwaukee    NIXON, KEN (Milwaukee Club)    This fellow Nixon on the Milwaukee Winter League club is a promising pitcher. I would never waive on him. Include him as a throw in on any deal you might make.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 8, 1962    RITCHIE, FRANK NO. 25 [23]    A left hand hitter. I'll bet he can bunt. On my very first impression is that he would have a lot of trouble getting the bat and the ball together with great regularity. Bat position is good and he swings from "here." Surely this boy has power to his own field. It would be understandable if the opposing manager would put his left fielder in right field when RITCHIE was batting. Surely all his power is to his own field. If he can run and throw, don't quit on him.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  December 6, 1962  St. Louis vs. Milwaukee    ROBINSON, BILL (Milwaukee Player)    Tall, 19 year old outfielder. Has a very great arm and knows how to throw from the outfield. He can run. Get him in any deal you can. Left hand hitter and a good looking hitter.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 8, 1962  Al Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Baltimore      ROUSE, JIM (Baltimore First Baseman)    Big, tall negro with a lot of body control and a good arm.    (LATER) Is a lazy ball player. He runs when he wants to it looks like.    Power hitter deluxe.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 9, 1962  Staff Meeting      SADOWSKI, BOB    I cannot take this boy too seriously.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 8, 1962    SAUL, JIM NO. 32    A tall left hand hitting catcher. If he makes up his mind to hit the ball, he should have good power. The big end of his bat is not quiet, but the preliminary move of it is not enough to be hurtful. He does go back with it a bit. I wouldn't talk to him about it at the present time. Let him alone. On first impression, I do not believe he is distinctively a fly ball hitter. There is hazard, in the case of batsman SAUL at this stage of his career, in over-coaching. As a matter of fact, over-coaching is a common fault of most young minor league managers and this particularly applies when dealing with batsmen.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis vs Baltimore    SAUL, JIM    Arm is alright. His hard thrown ball curves right.    He is not a base runner. His batting form is good. He doesn't pull away or sag against a left hand pitcher.    Washburn was credited with a wild pitch in the fourth inning, - a fast ball outside and very low. Saul should have made a body dive and stopped it. He is quick enough and active enough. Then on the very next pitch he let a change of pace get by him for a passed ball and the runner scored from third base.    He is built for power, acts powerful, but leaves one with the feeling of "big man, little poop".      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 8, 1962    LEWIS, JOHN NO. 9    A tall colored boy. Left hand hitter. He has full completion in his stroke. Ought to have fine power. This full sweep indicates beyond any doubt or possibility of fine power hitter. If he can run and throw decently, I would take this boy on a first look. I would like to talk to the scout who has most observed him.    By the way, his stride is perfect and the direction of his stroke is very good. The finish is good. I would like very much to see him at the pitching machine. Lots of boys cannot perform when first facing the machine, - complain about it and object to it, but their aptitudes to the observer are very determinative with machine practice.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Milwaukee  December 6, 1962    SAUL, JIM    When this boy throws to second, his ball takes off to the east.    Saul is a three point catcher. First he catches the ball, then he adjusts his body and step, and then he throws. It isn't really that bad, but he will not throw out any good base runner.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 7, 1962  Payne Field  Sarasota, Florida  St. Louis vs. Chicago W.S.    SAUL, JIM    Big man, little poop, - but I don't know why.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 8, 1962  Al Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Baltimore    SAUL, JIM    SAUL can bring the ball to his ear when he throws, in which case his throwing form is good, but invariably he double steps. This is his only throwing weakness. He must not step. If we had one moving picture of him taking the pitch and throwing, he would see what is meant by double step. I don't recall seeing him make a single throw either in a game or in practice that he doesn't move the right foot a second time.    This boy to me is the mystery player in the Cardinal organization. He has good form, a good body and good action, and why he cannot be an outstanding player gives me concern.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 8, 1962  Al Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Baltimore    SAUL, JIM    I can't imagine winning a major league pennant with Saul as the catcher.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 8, 1962  Al Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Petersburg vs. Baltimore    SCRAGGS, JOHN (Baltimore Outfielder)    This boy has a fine arm. He could play center field in anybody's league as far as his arm is concerned.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 7, 1962  Payne Field  Sarasota, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox    SELSKY, STEVEN (White Sox First Baseman)    Left handed all the way. 19 years old. Good runner, good arm, - aggressive and ought to become a corking good fielder. However, gives signs of rank inexperience. For example, he will play a hard hit ball or perhaps a thrown ball as though he were a shortstop, - does not body check on such plays. He is a stranger at the plate with a bat in his hands, but his batting form is good. Scouts should follow this boy closely.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 8, 1962    NO.26 - (I Don't Know His Name)    This fellow would not have great power. Good looking form at bat. I believe his timing would enable him to hit all fields, but the change of pace pitch would reduce him simply to an arm swinger. That is simply a first impression.    BRANCH RICKEY    No. 26 (Later)    This boy's name is Shannon (Mike). No relation to Walter.    BRANCH RICKEY    SHANNON, MIKE (Later)    At the moment he interests me with a bat in his hands.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis vs Baltimore    SHANNON, MIKE    Mix up pitching seems to confuse SHANNON. I don't think this boy is ready for the Cardinals in 1963.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 12, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    SHANNON, MIKE    In the first inning, this boy SHANNON made a perfectly stupid play. No play at the plate on him at all, - runs into the catcher standing up, - misses the plate and of course was tagged out.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 13, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    SHANNON, MIKE    I don't know how this boy can handle the fast ball on the outside. Only one other boy in this camp stands as far away as Shannon, and he's a pitcher.    This boy has power, - very ample, and a corking arm. He ought to have an outstanding year with Atlanta in 1963 and I will not be surprised if he is not ready for the Cardinals in 1964 and the same thing goes for outfielder Clemens.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 13, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    OBSERVATION    Has anybody tried LEWIS at first base?      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 14, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago AL    SHANNON, MIKE    I think SHANNON should be put out for a year. If he hits a fly ball he loafs to first. And on the bases, he assumes that the play whatever it is is going against him and is nonchalance to play.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 9, 1962  Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Staff Meeting    STARK, CLINT    That's all poppy-cock.    Branch, Jr. prepared a list of 15 players who had lost their arms before they were 22. This boy [OK] has apparently a recurring sore arm or sore elbow or something wrong with him. He should be handled with great patience.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 12, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    STARK, CLINT    This boy is very young. A left hander with good size. Corking delivery. Shows excellent poise and plenty of stuff. If he doesn't hurt his arm or get sick of something, he will go into the majors early, and could conceivably be a 'quickie'. I like him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 8, 1962    NO. 22    As a hitter, he ain't. As such, he belongs in a league with Bill Doaks. He ought to go to the pitching machine hour on hour. He could afford to start at daylight.    BRANCH RICKEY    My 1st day    LATER No. 22 is Taylor, Charley, a pitcher.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 8, 1962    NO. 22    As a hitter, he ain't. As such, he belongs in a league with Bill Doaks. He ought to go to the pitching machine hour on hour. He could afford to start at daylight.    BRANCH RICKEY    LATER NO. 22 is TAYLOR, CHARLEY, a pitcher.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 9, 1962  Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Staff Meeting    STAFF COMMENTS ON TAYLOR, CHARLES (Not BR Dictation)    Got a chance. Good desire. Had pneumonia for four weeks last season. Manager thinks he has a chance.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 13, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    TAYLOR, CHARLEY    A big tall right hand pitcher, - very young. Seems to have a stiff elbow. He bends the elbow very little in all pitches. His fast ball is as straight as the ball can be thrown and his curve ball is not great, - not at all. He needs considerable minor leaguedom.    If he were my grandson, I would beg him to start a different career, - bookkeeper, filling station man, etc.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Milwaukee  December 6, 1962    TAYLOR CHARLEY    Didn't show the stiff elbow in the three innings he worked against Milwaukee on this date. Looked much better in every respect. Curve ball fairly effective, - not great. His fast ball is not great. He threw several changes of pace, - all off his fast ball.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 14, 1962    RON TAYLOR    Right hand pitcher, about 26 years old, 6'1" tall, 180 pounds. Right hand hitter.    Went through the AAA draft in 1960 and again through the AAA draft in 1961.    Has a fair curve ball, could and should be improved. His fast ball is not really great but he has good control of it and he uses it effectively. In fact, he has good control with everything. He throws a slider and has a change-up on his fast ball, - a corking good one, but he almost never uses it in a game. He is a fine fielder of his position and an exceptional all-around athlete.    He pitches mostly three-quarters, - sometimes also almost to sidearm. Seldom throws directly overhand but can do it.    Very recently, he received his University degree in Electrical Engineering, and it is believed by the Cleveland Club that if he does not make good in the majors in 1963, he will positively quit professional baseball. His habits are good and he is downright ambitious to pitch in the majors.    The early reports on this boy when he was with Reading indicate that he was not a major league prospect. Later reports give him a good chance.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 13, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    WALL, FRED    Left hander. Didn't have any control when he really let loose on the ball. Then he let up and they hit him. With a man on second, he turned his eyes away from second when he started his delivery. Too late.    LATER, SAME DATE    The boy simply has not sufficient control for anyone to judge him on. Fast ball seems to be pretty good, not great. His curve ball the same.     LATER, SAME DATE    This boy is simply having a bad day. If these Met batters simply would "take one strike", I believe Wall would walk almost every batter. All his changes are high.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 8, 1962    LONG, JOFF NO. 46    My first impression of this fellow LONG is that he would be better and look better if he could bring his weight not to exceed 190 pounds. Surely, he would be a first-class wrestler.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 7, 1962  Payne Field  Sarasota, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox    WALL, FRED    I saw him in three more innings today. About one out of every three of his curve balls is a good curve, - a usable major league curve. The job in front of this boy is to throw his curve ball all the time as he throws it some of the time. His control was very good and his fast ball not too much below average for a major league pitcher. In other words, I could see Wall in the major league with a third usable pitch, plus control. He needs additional minor league experience. With no early opinions too riveted.    There is no reason for holding him in spring training camp with the Cardinals team in so far as realizing any expectation of help from him during the 1963 season.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Land Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 8, 1962    WASHBURN, RAY NO. 42   Surely he is a definite over strider as a batsman and if so, he will never be a good one. My first impression is that he would bat 9th in every lineup. If you would throw him a change of pace in a major league game, he wouldn't even have his arms left to bat with. He has a good face.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 9, 1962  Staff Meeting    WASHBURN, RAY   Discussion on WASHBURN was most interesting. I get the very firm impression from all the comments that Washburn should be compelled to pitch the curve ball in accordance with Manager Keane's views. Why then shouldn't his pitching be controlled by the manager during all his games?    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis vs Baltimore    Washburn, Ray    A darn good fast ball and never far away from the plate with it. His curve ball is not bad, - good enough.    Washburn is never far away from the plate with any pitch. In the first two innings of his game against Baltimore. I was not able to call a single slider. It may be that I cannot tell the difference between his slider and his fast ball. May be not.    The difference in control between Washburn and short of the Baltimore club is indicated as follows:    Short is seldom over the plate except by inches. Washburn is never off the plate except by inches.    Washburn has a change of speed pitch apparently thrown off his fast ball, same delivery, and ought to be effective. Of course, he needs good control of the pitch. It would be a fine thing down here in these exhibition games if Washburn would work four or five innings where he wouldn't throw a single fast ball or slider. Simply limit himself to the curve and change up, - perhaps a fast ball occasionally, - one or two an inning.    He did not throw a single ball very far off the plate until the fifth inning. Then he had three of them.    Has major league stuff absolutely.    When Washburn becomes a 'knowing' pitcher or is handled smartly, he could surely be a winning pitcher for the Cards in 1963. He has the stuff to do it.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 14, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago AL    Washburn, Ray    They hit him in the first inning, - three hits. They didn't get much after that.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 8, 1962    Watts, Harry No. 1.    Colored boy. Right hand hitter. Stride is O.K. Power should be anything but puny. Bat position is good. He is a bit of a head swinger, and if so this would indicate that he might have a high strike out record against major league pitching. He cuts off his left eye in practically all power strokes.    Branch Rickey    Watts, Harry No. 1 (Later)    This boy on the basis of sheer power, I would estimate to have more of it than Shannon, for example.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Florida  St. Louis va. Baltimore    Watts, Harry    Arm is good.  Playing second base, backed up first base in the seventh inning on a play from the shortstop, and when Long caught the ball for the put out, he threw the ball back to Watts in foul territory. Is Watts as fast as Gagliano?    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 12, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets    WATTS, HARRY    He may be able to short arm, but he takes a lot of time to throw a man out at first base.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 13, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Mets    WATTS, HARRY    I give up on Watts as a runner. Clyde King is right. Buchek can outrun him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 7, 1962  Payne Field  Sarasota, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox    WEIS, AL (Chicago White Sox Infielder)    He is a tall, slim built boy, young. He can run good enough. Quick as a cat. Throws from any and every position and has a great arm. Defensively he is major league.    He does not look like a good hitter. In any event, no power. If he could hit .250 in the major leagues, he would be highly desirable and if I owned his contract, I would turn him around and make him hit left handed against right hand pitching. He should be included as a throw in in any deal with Chicago.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 9, 1962  Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Staff Meeting      LONG, JEFF    The general discussion on this boy would lead anyone to believe that he had a great chance as a major leaguer. Wealthy boy with a big bonus and genuinely anxious to make good.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 14, 1962    WHITFIELD, FRED    As an outfielder, he cannot throw. He is by no means a finished first baseman but his only chance to become a regular in the major leagues is at that position. Left hand hitter with real power and a good hitter, - an average runner.    If the Cleveland club made the initial approach on the deal, I believe you could get $25,000 in addition to Taylor for Whitfield.    If the initial approach was made by St. Louis, having in mind giving Whitfield even up for Taylor, then I think you should close the deal.    In all deals with major league clubs, it is highly advantageous to St. Louis if the other club expresses the initial interest in some player. The response can undertake negotiation on a sales basis. Usually continuing negotiations bring into the picture so called 'throw-ins', - resulting in a player deal plus cash, or to put it more accurately, it results in a cash deal plus 'throw-ins'.    My constant thinking about the building of the Cardinals is directed toward 1964 rather than 1963. I don't believe the Cardinal club has a remote chance for the pennant in 1963, - in fact I will be agreeably and happily surprised if it finishes above 5th place. I am convinced that Ron Taylor is a prospective major league pitcher. Therefore, he fits into my picture of a pennant winning club in 1964 or more probably 1965.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 9 , 1962  Staff Meeting    STAFF COMMENT ON WILD, JERRY (Not BR Dictation)    Good fast ball, major league curve.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 12, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Mets        WILD, JERRY    Fair fast ball. I doubt if it is a highly  usable pitch in the major leagues, but he has a good  overhand curve ball. If he could get it over  consistently, he could use it anywhere.    With a man on first base ( or perhaps anywhere)  in holding men on, it looked like to me that he placed  all his weight on his rear foot.    Wild's pitching career depends upon his curve  ball.    In the fifth inning, with two men out and the  bases full, on the next ten pitches there was one curve  ball and nine fast balls and he walked two runners over  the plate. Without dominent use of the curve ball,  he will not go anywhere. But with control of the   curve ball, he might go anywhere, - major league.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: December 8, 1962  Al Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Baltimore    WILD, JERRY    This boy has plenty of stuff, but it doesn't   mean anything. He gets nervous too easily and too   quickly, - no veteranship in him as yet. Simply   needs to get older and he will. We will have to wait   until that time comes.    He should go in 1963 some place, - anywhere,   where he can pitch with uninterrupted regularity.    His fast ball was more impressive today than   it was the other time I saw him.    His name is Jerry. It should have been Very.    He showed a good change up off his fast ball   today and three of them were very effective.     In the first three innings Jerry worked today,   he pitched seven change-ups, - six of them were   effective, - strikes, and one of them higher than the   waistline, - one was shoulder high and hit to right   field, - a fly ball for an easy out.     He is very impressive with his overhand   curve ball when he keeps it low. But he is full of   surprise with his spasmodic sudden estrangement from   control.    Jerry is very seldom over the plate with his   fast ball, very seldom.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 13, 1962  St. Louis vs. Mets    WILLIS, RON    The boy has a good change up but not any   control of it.    Tall right hander, 19 years of age. Very   average fast ball, - curve ball so so. Shows poise   and has good control. His off pitches are not far   away. He throws a change up without any change of   delivery whatever and much better control of it than   any other pitcher I have seen in this camp.    I don't believe Willis is a candidate for the   major leagues for a few years.    I may have spoken too soon about his control.   He really did have control for two innings but in the   sixth, he lost control and everything else with it.    As I said in the first inning he pitched,   I now repeat: He has an ordinary fast ball and an   ordinary curve ball.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  December 8, 1962  St. Louis vs. Baltimore  Al Lang Field    WILLIS, RON    If Willis were a Cobb or a Sisler, his bunting   form would be acceptable. But if he is an ordinary   pitcher trying to learn to bunt, he is completely dead   wrong. The first fundamental in learning to bunt on   the part of a man who cannot bunt is a simple thing but   not for some batsmen, namely the big end of the bat   must be the closest point toward the pitcher when the   ball leaves the pitcher's hands, and the bat must be   brought to that position simultaneously with the   batsman's step. (if indeed he does step)      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: Al Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 9, 1962  Staff Meeting    STAFF COMMENTS ON WILLIS, RON (Not BR Dictation)    He seems to pitch better in a jam, rather when he starts. Keeps the ball low.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Baltimore    LONG, JOFF    The surprising thing in this practice was the agility of Long. His arm is strong and he has good body control. He fumbled a few ground balls.    Short, the Baltimore left hand pitcher, used change-up curve balls on Long throughout the game very effectively. Then the big fellow 'took' the first ball through the middle. However, he singled through the hole in the seventh inning, - a fast ball.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
