Transcription: Lang Field  St. Petersburg, Fla.  November 8, 1962  MAJTYKA, ROY NO. 10 - First Impression    A well built boy, with snap and authority in  his swing. There has to be some good reason for his   hitting .254 at Billings that I don't know about.   I would like to see his all-time professional record   as a batsman.  BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 10, 1962  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis vs Baltimore      MAJTYKA, ROY    He is a puny up at the plate.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; A-J
Transcription: November 14, 1962  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Chicago AL    MAJTYKA, ROY    A puny hitter. Pretty good runner, pretty good fielder. A nice boy.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: April 13, 1963  St. Louis vs. Phillies    CALLISON, JOHN (Philadelphia Outfield)  TAYLOR, TONY (Philadephia Infielder)  AMARO, REUBEN (Philadelphia Infielder)    CALLISON and TAYLOR are fine major league players. TONY TAYLOR is a much underrated player and a very desirable man on any championship club.    AMARO, likewise, is an underrated player.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: July 23, 1963  Toronto, Canada  Toronto vs Atlanta    ANDERSON, "SPARKY" (Toronto Second Baseman)    Of not interest.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 29, 1963  Brunswick vs Moultrie    ANTHON, FRED (Brunswick Infielder)    I don't believe this fellow will go anywhere. Cannot do anything exceptionally and he is a puny hitter. If you were to be pushed for space on account of player limit, give this chap his unconditional release.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: August 2, 1963  Brunswick, Ga.    ANTHON, FRED    Every man took enthusiastic part in the running starts and also the 50 yard dashes this forenoon, - everyone except Anthon. He played nine innings last night, and he will play fourteen innings tonight but he could not take part in the dashes, - an ailing ankle. He looks to me like a below average runner.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    ARROYO, LUIS (New York Yankee Pitcher)    Have been well acquainted with this pitcher for many years. We don't want him at any price. I would rather have Shantz. We don't want Arroyo even if he has a tremendous year at Richmond.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    AUST, DENNIS    Almost any young pitcher may become a major leaguer, but this fellow is among the unlikely ones. Fair stuff. 22 year old right hander. Acts indifferent, has the reputation of being lazy. Unless he gets an additional pitch, - no chance.    I am told that Aust is a playboy; also that he favors a poor slider that hurts him much more than it helps him. Most sliders do.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: April 20, 1963  Philadelphia, Pa.  St. Louis vs. Philadelphia    AVERILL, EARL (Philadelphia Catcher)    Not a good receiver. I don't want him, - ever. Might be a pretty good hitter, - maybe so. That lets him out.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    AZCUE, JOE (Cleveland Catcher)    Young catcher, only 23, 6' tall, weighs about 190. Active catcher. Looks very good defensively. Right hand hitter. Doubtful power. A Cuban. Would take him as a 'throw in' anytime.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: August 13, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota    BAKENHASTER, DAVE    I was very anxious to see this boy but he was ailing and couldn't work out. In fact, he was not in uniform.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    BANKS, ERNIE (Chicago First Baseman)    Former shortstop, now first baseman with Chicago Cubs. Power batsman, home run hitter, 32 years old and has slowed up somewhat.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 2, 1963  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee        AARON, HANK    Surely one of the greatest hitters in baseball today. Can hit late with power, - good wrists. But in spite of his hitting record and admitted power ability, one cannot help think that Aaron is frequently a guess hitter. Will take three strikes down the middle and in fact frequently acts frozen on pitches. For years I have believed and I still believe that Aaron has more trouble with the breaking stuff. He stands close enough to the plate to pull the outside ball and does pull it. However, he is a foot length further from the plate than Frank Robinson of Cincinnati.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: April 22, 1963  Houston, Texas  St. Louis vs Houston    BATEMAN, JOHN (Houston Catcher)    Not a fast runner. I believe he is well below average. This boy can throw, a great hustler, and his form at bat is good.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    BATTEY, EARL (Minnesota Catcher)    A big colored catcher. Looks overweight, but has remarkable action. Quick and has power at the plate, plenty of it. Looks like he likes to play. I can imagine him in a World Series.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: March 15, 1963    BAUTA, ED    Does this fellow have a fast ball? And if he does, then it becomes important to ask whether or not he ever throws it.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: March 19, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.    BAUTA, ED    I have just read overy my previous report on Bauta. He should be seen further before any decision. If he can really throw a good fast ball and will do it, I think he will help our club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: March 31, 1963    BAUTA, ED    Several scouts who know this Cuban pitcher Bauta personally and professionally for years agree that his physical performance as a pitcher should have been much better than the records show. They agree that he is an awkward, uncoordinated hypochondriac, - always either ailing or something wrong. Some doubt that he has a great fast ball. He believes he is a bit stupid, - slow to learn anything. Howie Haak, who discovered Bauta, says that if he has a fast ball, he won't use it. I have seen Bauta in four performances, - a few innings each time and my limited observation would lead me to support the viewsof either D'Arcos or Haak or both.    Here is a big fellow, 6'3", who has had seven full seasons of pitching in professional baseball. Last year (1962) he pitched 32 innings for the Cardinals and walked 21 men. In the latter part of the season he pitched 46 innings for Atlanta and walked on an average of only three men to the game. His record at Atlanta was very good.    I deeply hope that further exposure of this pitcher before the opening of the season will enable management to know more of him.    This pitcher is past 28 years of age, - just the right time in years to become a good pitcher.    I tried very hard to converse with Bauta. He didn't seem to understand me and I certainly couldn't understand him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: September 2, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Los Angeles    BAUMANN, FRANK (White Sox Pitcher)    Left hander. He either had a bad arm the day I saw him or no speed. Fair curve ball. If he was sound when I saw him, then I don't want him.    BRANCH RICKEY    CC - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: August 6, 1963  New York, N. Y.  St. Louis vs New York Mets    BEARNARATH, LAWRENCE (New York Mets Pitcher)    I think this boy has a major league future as a pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    BEAUCHAMP, JIM    Tall, 23 year old, right hand hitting  player, originally an outfielder. Serious shoulder  dislocation has given him practically two years of  inability to throw. Arm is improving rapidly so he  says. He now throws without any pain whatever.  However, velocity is below average. He throws  naturally and I believe is arm will continue to improve    He can hit with power, - lots of power.  Mostly fly balls and can reach the fences easily.  The most impressive thing about Jim is his running  speed. He can really run, - long stride.    Good character, high intelligence. He is  scheduled to go with Benson to San Domingo this  coming winter. I hope Benson will play him at first  base. He surely can go major league.    At present his greatest weakness is the curve  ball. He misses it. It bothers him. He strikes  out on it. He needs to have a lot of curve ball  pitching in batting practice. I doubt if he can  help very much as a member of the Cardinal club in  1964, but sooner or later he surely will help any  major league club.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: July 23, 1963  Toronto, Canada  Toronto vs. Atlanta    BEDELL (Atlanta Outfielder)    Left hand hitting outfielder with Atlanta. This boy led the American Association in hitting two or three years ago. He didn't look like tonight that he would ever lead any league in any classification.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Winnipeg vs. Bismark-Mandan    BELTRAN, MARTY    Left hand hitter. This slim Negro looks like he can run, - above average. Hitting form is good. Batting position is good. I don't understand why he doesn't hit better in the Northern League.    BRANCH RICKEY    It might be good to have him go to the Florida fall camp.    Branch Rickey    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: September 11, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana  Indianapolis vs Atlanta    ACKLEY, FRITZ (Indianapolis Pitcher)    A good sized 26 year old right hand pitcher for  Indianapolis. Wide reputation and supporting record  as leading pitcher in the International League in 1963.  Shows good fast ball. Generally speaking, this boy is   a low ball pitcher. He does not impress me at all as a   control or spot pitcher. Curve ball is a weakling.  Small amount of break but good velocity. Seldom uses it.  Chicago regards him highly. I would not risk trading  any known player asset for Ackley, - except on my own  terms. There would be no trading negotiations.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    BERTELL, DICK (Chicago Catcher)    Chicago Cubs right hand hitting catcher. Over 6' tall (in fact all the catcher and indeed all the pitchers, every single one of the infielders, and the regularly playing outfielders are 6' or over, - mostly over). A major league catcher. He can throw. St. Louis could well afford to give both Sewatski and Oliver for Bertell, and then some more.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    BETHEA, BILL    Right hand hitting infielder from the University   of Texas. I doubt his mental ability in every   direction, although he lacks only six hours to get a   degree from the University. He is not a great   runner, only mediocre speed if that. Not a great arm, -   a good arm, and not a power hitter although he has the   reputation of being so. He cannot be a power hitter   with his present batting form and I don't believe he can   be changed. I would let him go to draft and personally   would be quite gratified to get the draft price for him.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 25, 1963    Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    BLANCHARD, JOHN (New York Yankees Catcher - Outfielder)    If Blanchard's habits were good and his team  relationship satisfactory, St. Louis could use him.  I would not take him unless I were permitted to have a  conversation with the player with results satisfactory  to myself.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: April 25, 1963  San Francisco, Cal.  St. Louis vs San Francisco    BOLIN, BOB (San Francisco Pitcher)    The boy has good stuff. I would like to have him. I would take this pitcher on waivers.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 2, 1963  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee    BOLLING, FRANK    32 years old, - a real pro. We have better  infielders. Not remotely interested.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 26, 1963  New York Yankees vs Minnesota    BOUTON, JIM (New York Yankee Pitcher)    Very good speed, and he has a great curve, -  a downer. Straight down. He looks like he is a  'pressing' pitcher. Bears down especially hard on  occasion. Gives the catcher trouble. I can imagine  that bases on balls and wild pitches could get him in  trouble. I think he stuff is good. He will give good  hitters low hitting percentage. Young chap, only 24,  good body control and lively. His great weakness right  now is due to his 'pressing', when he gets into trouble.   When veteranized, Bouton should be highly desirable.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: August 2, 1963  Brunswick, Ga.    BOWMAN, CLYDE    I have seen very little of Bowman, - only five minutes at first base in the pre-game practice.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: April 13, 1963  St. Louis vs. Phillies    BOYER, KEN    He stands too far from the plate too and will have an inordinate number of strikeouts against him on the curve ball pitched away from him by right hand pitchers. He is not as bad as Javier but he doesn't lack very much.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: May 18, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    BOYER, KEN    As a fielder, Boyer has two very real weaknesses,  and the worst one of the two is not his constant taking  thrown balls in front of the bag and away from the runner.  His great fault as a third baseman is that he will not  body check the hard hit ground ball. There never has  been a great third baseman or a fairly good one who couldn't  at least body check ground balls. Particularly is this  true when the bases are full or first and second occupied   with two men out. The body check enables the third  baseman to recover and surely to retire the runner on the  force at third. Boyer never body checks. I have never  seen him do it a single time.    It the Cardinals had a good third baseman who could  hit a lick, Boyer could be moved to the outfield.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: April 20, 1963  Philadelphia, Pa.  St. Louis vs. Philadelphia    DEMETER scored in the fifth inning from first  base on Siever's hit to left field. The retrieving was  deliberate, but Boyer's realy throw was 15' ahead of the   runner who slid into home and apparently kicked the  ball out of OLIVER's hand to the wall. It was most  certainly a gift run.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    ADCOCK, JOE (Cleveland First Baseman)    He is through. Not desirable as a gift.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 31, 1963    BRADDOCK, RON (Brunswick Outfielder)    Has a good arm and he can throw the ball  down and I believe from this time on he will.  I would turn him over. The boy can run good and  he has a very good arm. Is extremely conscientious.  Grieves over mistakes.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  August 2, 1963    BRADOCK, RON    A very conscientious boy with some age, - he must be 20 years of age. He has a good arm, - very good. He can run, - the fastest man on the Brunswick club at this time. He outran Julius Smith three times. It could be worthwhile to have Braddock in the Instruction Camp this fall. Right now it seems that no one considers Braddock as any kind of a prospect. It will be no surprise to me if this boy would go further as a batsman, beginning next year, than anybody else on the present Brunswick club. George doesn't play him very much, if any at all. He gives preference to the very slow runner like Hunter as a right fielder. If George Kissel does not positively disagree at the end of this season, then I recommend strongly that this boy Braddock should be invited to the Instruction Camp this fall.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: August 10, 1963  Billings, Montana  Billings vs Boise    BRAMLETT, JOHN    This boy is built like a wrestler, but he  is quick as a cat. He has strong forearms and  batting wrists like Williams. He can be fooled on  a pitch, hit late, and still reach the fence. Not  a fly ball hitter, - not at all. His bat interests  me very much. His arm is good. I would be easily  influenced by the manager's report at the end of the  season or indeed scouts who have seen more of the player.  On the basis of my observation, the player should be  invited to the Florida Instruction Camp this fall.    The player didn't run in the races due to  an alleged bad foot. However, in the game, he looked  like a good average runner.    BRANCH RICKEY    August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota    Fred Koenig, manager of Winnipeg, told me  that this boy resented discipline, repeatedly violated  the curfew rule, and was fined. Objects to any  interference with when, where, or how he goes or acts.  He should be thoroughly discussed before inviting him  to the Florida Fall Instruction Camp.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: March 9, 1963    BRANCH, HARVEY    This boy is not ready for high classification pitching. He should try now for an additional pitch.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: March 19, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.    BRANCH, HARVEY    Not ready for the Cardinals in 1963 either with stuff or experience. We should keep control of his contract if possible. He might go all the way.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: March 26, 1963  Clearwater, Fla.    Neither SADOWSKI OR BRANCH can help the Cardinal club in 1963.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: September 11, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana  Indianapolis vs Atlanta    BRANCH, HARVEY    Young left hand colored pitcher. Pretty   good speed and an effective change up curve ball. I   have never seen him use more than the two pitches.   With good control, the boy can go major.     He is tempermental, takes reversals badly.   Shows reaction, - even emotional reaction to errors,   home runs, bad decisions, criticism. Experience will   probably correct this fault. This boy should be discussed   in our organization meeting.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 31, 1963    BRAYER, DENNIS (Brunswick First Baseman)    He wears glasses and he should be in the   hands of a good eye doctor for an examination.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.   August 2, 1963    BRAYER, DENNIS    I believe the boy is below average in   running. Arm very average. The best thing about   him is his bat. That may save him. I would leave   him right on the roster of the Brunswick club.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: Billings, Montana  August 10, 1963  Billings vs Boise    BREEDEN, DANNY    Good arm, unfinished receiver, very   ordinary runner, might hit. I would invite him   to the fall camp in Florida and make a switch hitter   out of him immediately. Strikes me as a very   intelligent boy.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; T-Z
Transcription: September 10, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana      ALLEN, (Outfielder with Arkansas)    Rollie Hemsley at Indianapolis, Bill Adair at Toronto, Larry Shepard at Columbus, Kerby Farrell at Buffalo and Harry Walker at Atlanta all believe that outfielder Allen is the best major league prospect in the International League. A colored boy, very young, and belongs to Philadelphia. He has extraordinary power to all fields. Arm not great, but adequate. Highly desirable in any deal with Philadelphia. I am sorry not to have seen this boy in action, but rating given to the player by baseball men generally puts him immediately as a regular in any major league outfield. I would risk a heavy deal to have the Cardinals get this player.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  July 16, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs Senators    BREEDING, MARV (Washington Infielder)    I call him a minor league ball player. The bat   doesn't even swish. No power. Runs very good.   Left hand hitter. Good form at the plate.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    BREWER, JIM (Chicago Pitcher)    Left hand pitcher. A tall fellow. No   previous major league experience. 25 years old.   Did not impress me with 'stuff'.    I have not seen this pitcher enough to   have any positive opinion about him in any   direction.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: March 14, 1963    BRICE, ALAN    My former notes on Brice are correct. Player   might do alright at Atlanta. Go for the money   market with this fellow.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: March 19, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.    BRICE ALAN    I don't think he is a major leaguer upstairs. He is not ever in the pinch. Gets into trouble quickly and takes considerable time getting out. I would put him at Atlanta and hope to make a major league sale before the close of the 1963 International League season.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    BRIDGES, MARSHALL (New York Yankee Pitcher)    Left hand pitcher. Another right hand hitter but doesn't hit ever. Relief pitcher, - so-called. Colored boy, 6' tall plus, 27 years of age.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs. Chicago Cubs    BROCK, LOU (Chicago Outfielder)    Chicago outfielder. Left handed all the way. A good runner and a good power hitter. 23 years old. This boy is highly desirable on any major league club. He can do everything and should hit .300.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: March 22, 1963  Detroit vs. St. Louis  St. Petersburg, Fla.    BROGLIO, ERNIE    In the second inning in the game of this date against Detroit, after a double, Borglio walked three men. During this course of wildness, he threw three curve balls. At least three times he shook his head on Oliver's call, - then threw the fast ball. In other words, when Broglio gets into trouble, it is quite evident that he goes to his fast pitch, and apparently nothing can stop him. This fellow surely has to come to know that his chance to be a great major league pitcher depends upon his curve ball. When in trouble, he should go to his curve ball and stay with it. Let the fast ball be his occasional pitch. I do not mean to say that Broglio's fast ball is not fast. It is, but I believe he over-pitches it and I don't believe he has as good control of it as his curve.     I urgently suggest that the manager should control Broglio's pitching.     Broglio can shake off the catcher once, and twice, but when the same signal is repeated it must control, - because the third repeat signal simply means that the manager is calling the pitch.     B[ ]glio cannot hold any good base runner on first base. He takes too long to pitch. With a man on first base, Broglio must put more weight on his left foot.     Broglio has been pitching too long to have so many obvious faults. He MUST be dumb.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: April 18, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs. Pittsburgh    BROGLIO, ERNIE    Now and then, he holds men on. He should throw over to first base a great deal because he is not really good at the job. Most of the time, runners can get a whale of a break. Every pitcher on our club has to hold men close at first as we do not have any catcher with a great arm, and both Oliver and Sewatski, particularly the latter, run with the ball when they throw it. I don't believe Sewatski ever throws a ball to second base without taking three steps and he can't throw, - no power.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: April 19, 1963  Philadelphia, Pa.  St. Louis vs. Philadelphia    BROGLIO, ERNIE    I wish this pitcher would watch Curt Simmons follow his pitch. He almost always is completely balanced weight-wise after his pitch.    Also, FANCK could learn something by the same observation.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 3, 1963  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    BROGLIO, ERNIE    Out of 97 successive pitches made by Broglio  in the five innings, 19 were curves, and not one of  the curves was hit hard, but Pinson did hit one on the  ground safely past White. It is true that several  of the other 18 curve pitches were called balls, but  no one hit the curve ball foul or fair except the  Pinson hit and most of Broglio's curve pitches were  effective. Why Broglio is afraid to throw his  curve ball, I don't know.     Broglio simply cannot hold any runner on  first base. He takes too long to throw. Any  medium runner with normal lead and a quick break has  a good chance to steal second base on Oliver. He  cannot get the ball away quickly and he does not  have a strong arm.     With Broglio pitching and Oliver catching,  every average runner can easily steal. Not one man  in 20 attempts would be thrown out.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    ALLEN, BERNIE (Minnesota Infielder)    Tall boy from Purdue. Left hand hitter,  has power and I believe he can outrun Rollins. I doubt if he is a .300 hitter. Hit .269 in 1962. Not hitting a lick this year, but I would rate him above average for power.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  September 2, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs Los Angeles    BROSNAN, JIM (White Sox Pitcher)    Tall right hand pitcher. Let him write.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    BROWN, LARRY (Cleveland Infielder)    Cleveland shortstop. Right hand hitter, a youngster - not big. No power. I don't believe 25 Browns could finish in the first division.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: April 22, 1963  Houston, Texas  St. Louis vs Houston    BRUCE, ROBERT (Houston Pitcher)    A 20 year old right hander with the Houston Club and he has stuff. It seems to be that he presses, making a thrower out of himself instead of a pitcher. He is capable of winning in the major leagues, and I would not be surprised if he comes to be a good pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: GERRY BUCHEK  A bad ball hitter. And I mean a bad ball hitter. He doesn't   know what it means to "hold up" on a bad pitch, and he is just as   prone to hit at a bad pitch as he is to hit at a good pitch. Of   all the boys that I have had anything to do with for a long time,   this [speciman] boy would have two strikes on him most of the time end then  frequently finish up with a strike out.  His record over the full three years of his professional life   shows one base on balls to three strike outs. It seems obvious to  me that he has no confidence in himself at the plate. Hitting is the horse & confidence is the cart in most cases rather than the other way 'round. The pitcher   is his master. I doubt if he has ever experienced a moment when he  was even temporarily sorry for [the] any pitcher and it has resulted in   a confused batsman.    Gerry is only 20 years of age [and] with three years of professional   baseball behind him. He is big, strong, active, and with decently   normal power [for a major league hitter].    It has been said to me that Gerry is "not smart." I don't   agree with that opinion. In any event, he has tremendous physical   aptitudes against a Dudley machine and against very good speed  he will, with intent, hit 9 out of 10 balls [in] on the ground.  Also, with intent he will push or pull the ball with great regularity   and when he hits with intent either on the hit and run or simply  on the good pitches, he seldom misses the pitch.    The cure for strike outs, namely, hit every pitch with purpose,  [cures him instantly of striking out] has been adopted by Jerry with good results.    His power goes to all fields and when this boy becomes able   to feel that he can hit, he will hit and at that time he is a major   league hitter.    -more-

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Gerry Buchek - 2   Last fall in the Instructional League games in Florida, I   felt he was at least two years away from being a qualified major   league batsman. There was a hopelessness about his hitting. I am   greatly encouraged with the showing he has made here this past week.    Two weeks more in the batting cage and he may be an entirely   different boy at the plate, both [the] in attitude and in actual ability   and particularly this would be true if he could face a pitching   machine which was throwing various speeds with deflections.    [He] Jerry is a major league prospect. [This boy] He should surely not sit on the bench during the 1963  season. I may change my opinion about him subsequently before the   training season is over, but just now if this were the final day for   "cutting down", I would recommend that he be sent out on a 24-hour   recall optional agreement and not to Atlanta or Tulsa, not unless  one of those clubs actually needs him.    I would hope that he [be] would be placed with a stranger organization so that   he could be recalled within a few hours and not hurt attendance in   our own working agreement city. Then, have the optionee club, in turn,   option a player for the season to either Atlanta or Tulsa.    I now believe in Buchek. I believe he [can] might become a major   leaguer in another year.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Carmel  Buchek  Kolb  Cleeves  Gagliore  Maxville

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: April 2, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.    BUCHEK, JERRY    This boy was pitched a couple of days ago  in an inter-squad game, - a bad wet windy day. Did  fairly well. However, Harry Walker, manager of Atlanta,  thinks that at the end of the present year he can  improve Buchek as a batsman. This player has one more  year available on option. If anyone can improve Buchek  as a batsman, I can think of no one better than Harry  Walker for the job. Then, if Buchek is a continued  failure with a bat in his hands, the job of making a  pitcher out of him can be undertaken anew and with  hope. I approve this procedure. I will write  Buchek, - copy to Walker.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: July 23, 1963  Toronto, Canada  Toronto vs Atlanta    BUCHEK, JERRY    Hitting .288 on this date in the International League. I will be greatly surprised if this boy finishes in the International League season hitting .288. If he does, he is desirable on the Cardinals. A very different player than in 1962.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 11, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana  Indianapolis vs Atlanta    BUCHEK, JERRY    This boy is really growing up. He is an  entirely different batsman than he was a year ago.  An average runner, - if that. Great arm from all  angles. Good pair of hands. Unafraid.     Has good power, but strikes out inordinately.  Has 116 strike outs in approximately 500 times at bat.  He should be retained on the 1964 Cardinal roster,  having in mind general utility work, - anywhere.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 10, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana  September 10, 1963    BUFORD, DON (Indianapolis Infielder)    Colored infielder. He is a switch hitter, -  a good looking hitter with enough power. However  his two base hits reflect his running speed more  than [it does] his power. A very fast runner and has  adventure. I believe the boy could play anywhere.  Very desirable in the major league.    Arm good enough for outfield or indeed anywhere.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    ALLISON, BOB (Minnesota Outfielder)    A .275 hitter with exceptional power. Looks the part of a great athlete. Right hander all the way. He has everything it takes to be a long time major league regular.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 11, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana  Indianapolis vs Atlanta    BUFORD, DON (Indianapolis Infielder)    I like this fellow. However, his strikeout  record should be investigated. You cannot win  pennants with strike out boys unless indeed they have  excessive power.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    BUHL, BOB (Chicago Pitcher)    Fred Ankenman, Charlie Dressen, and  particularly Birdie Tebbetts, can tell you about  Bob Buhl. In any event, I wouldn't care to have him  on the club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: August 13, 1963   Bismark, North Dakota     BUKOWSKI, JOHN     180 pound, 6' tall, left hand pitcher from   Toronto. 20 years old, - a very good fast ball, not   great, but good. Has good control of it. A fairly   good curve ball and good control of that also. He   has a change-up on his fast ball, and a change-up on his   curve ball. The fast ball change is very good. The   curve ball chance is too much like the fast curve.   John is 25 years old in conversation.     He can throw a knuckle ball and a very good one.   It wouldn't hurt him to work on that pitch. I call him   a definite prospect. It couldn't hurt to take him   to the Florida Instruction Camp this fall.     BRANCH RICKEY   cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  August 1, 1963  Brunswick vs Thomasville    BURGER (Thomasville Pitcher)    20 year old, tall, right hand pitcher with  Thomasville. Belongs to Detroit. This big fellow  has a fine fast ball and a good overhand straight  downer. The curve is exceptionally good. In any  deal that might be contemplated with Detroit, it  would be enhanced greatly if Burger could be included.  One could afford to give a good deal for his contract.  He may be crude fielding his position or holding men  on.    BRANCH RICKEY    (LATER)    Can't hold men on at all. This boy has no  change-up and he needs it. He has a good arm but he  is simply a thrower at this time.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: August 6, 1963  New York, N. Y.  St. Louis vs New York Mets    ALTMAN, GEORGE    I would not give up on Altman at the present time, and I would not talk him down. He surely has potential in the market. The Cardinals' need of depth in outfielding is another reason for holding Altman. In any event, he should not be traded at low ebb. It is possible to change this player's thinking.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    ALVIS, MAX (Cleveland Infielder)    This player is in a class by himself. A 25 year old right hander who ought to do everything. He can run, - run like the dickens and he can throw and he has power. Looks and acts the part of a confident finished player. A half dozen Alvises on a club would win a pennant.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 17, 1963  Cleveland vs Kansas City    CAUSEY, WAYNE (Kansas City Infielder)    Best thing about this boy is a bat in his hands. Arm good enough, well below average runner and by no means a finished shortstop. No bolt of lightening on starting any place. Not a good pivot man. Fine batting form, and shows good power. Left hand hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: August 9, 1963  Billings, Montana    CAYLL, RON    21 years of age, 185 pounds, 6' tall, right hand   pitcher, - his fourth year. Has great control   of his 'regular curve', he calls it. The effect of this curve is a change of speed. It is a dandy.   He throws a much slower curve, - high trajectory, and   with good control. He also throws a change-up off his   fast ball with fair control. The boy has a slider, a   definite slider, not just an ordinary slider. It is a   usable pitch. His record over four years shows him   constantly improving in control, but the present year,   1963, shows an average of five bases on balls per nine   inning game. That's the biggest barrier between him   and the major league at the present moment. His   strike out record is very good. He does not have the   great fast ball that you look for initially in a major   league prospect, but his other stuff makes the fast ball   seem to be fast. In other words, his fast ball will not   keep him out of the major league. He can be a good   pitcher and should have special attention next spring, -   not on the side lines but in exhibition games. He is   a candidate for the Instruction Camp this fall.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: August 13, 1963  Bismarck, North Dakota    CECIL, EDWARD  A 21 year old right hand pitcher with Winnipeg. He acts like a veteran. Shows good control, and he has a fast ball and a pretty good curve. A first year player. I sincerely hope that the draft can be avoided. On first look, he is a promising prospect.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  September 2, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs Los Angeles    CHANCE, DEAN (Los Angeles Pitcher)    A tall, right hander with Los Angeles. Showed no control and not much stuff. Couldn't hold runners on first base and balks on practically every pitch with a man on first.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 27, 1963  Cleveland vs Kansas City    CHARLES, ED (Kansas City Infielder)    Darn good looking ball player. Can run, can throw, can field. Has some power, not great, but good. Looks good at the plate. I wish the Cardinals had him.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 3, 1963  Minneapolis, Minn.  Minnesota vs Kansas City    CHARLES, ED (Kansas City Third Baseman)    Can do everything major league style.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 4, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Kansas City    CHARLES, ED (Kansas City Third Baseman)    He can miss good pitches, - fast ball strikes,   farther than most. Batting form is not bad but he  looks definitely like a guess hitter to me. If George  Sisler could work with this boy, I think he could  become a much better hitter. He does not guess all  the time. With two strikes, he gets a piece of the  ball.    He has fine hands, a good arm and he can  run.    (See previous dictation)    BRANCH RICKEY    CC - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 27, 1963  Cleveland vs Kansas City    CIMOLI, GINO (Kansas City Outfielder)    Don't take him at any price, either minor or   major, - not even as a 'throw in'.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: June 17, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs N. Y. Mets      CISCO, GALAN    A big sturdy right hand pitcher. Pretty   good fast ball - pretty good curve. Has a change but   can't get it over - in fact doubtful control of   everything. With control he has a pretty good chance.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: August 6, 1963  New York, N. Y.  Cardinals vs New York Mets      CISCO, GALAN (New York Mets Pitcher)    A strong, well built, right hand pitcher with a good assortment of pitches.    He shows plenty of courage and pitching intelligence, but when he is in trouble, he presses and wild pitches and otherwise shows temporary frustration. He must be around 25 years of age. He graduated from Ohio State two years ago. I will not be surprised if Cisco becomes a very good pitcher in the National League. I would not make any trade for him having in mind he could help our club win a pennant in 1964. He would be more likely to lose the pennant for us if we were to put the eggs in his basket. In 1966, well, that could be different.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: April 19, 1963  Philadelphia, Pa.  St. Louis vs. Philadelphia    CALLISON, JOHN    This left hander is a good hitter. Can handle the inside pitch. Frequently looks bad on the left hander's curve. And then on two different occasions he handled a good curve from Simmons, both, however, above his waistline and not at all outside.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: March 15, 1963      CLEMENS, DOUG    Against really high class major league pitching,   Clemens is not ready. He needs another year in a good   minor legue.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: March 26, 1963  Clearwater, Fla.    CLEMENS, DOUG    Double steps on every throw.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 11, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana  Indianapolis vs Atlanta    CLEMENS, DOUG    I would keep Doug on the active roster of the   Cardinal club. If he makes the club o.k. If he doesn't   then next spring try to make a deal major league-wise   or outright his contract to Atlanta. Then undertake   to make a favorable deal with some major league club prior   to the next draft.    In the latter part of the present season   at Atlanta, he is hitting well over .300 - below average   in power, but not a puny and left hand pitching does not   bother him over much. This boy is timid, but a   gentleman, and really unafraid. He will slide anywhere,   anytime, with good adandon. He can run good average and   throw acceptably. He knows how. This player may not   make the Cardinal club as a regular player ever but I   believe that he will reach the major league market by the   end of the 1964 season.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Doug Clemens [*Was (This [was] written October 1962)?*] [*No?!*]    This player is a major leaguer. He is a timid fellow, or so it seems to me. Modest. A gentle man in manner, appearance and surely in fact. I speak of [him] [*his playing ability*] in this dictation only in respect to batting.  He has a level sweep of the bat wherever the pitch may be. His stride is [sharp] [*short*]. He has no "head swing" whatever, no hitch, both hands on the bat at the completion of every swing[, from][*. At] the time the ball leaves the pitcher's hand[. A][*, a*] coin placed on the end of [pitcher's] bat would not fall off. This boy is perfection in form and he has beautifully quick wrists. He gets unexpected power and [*is*] not at all confined to [any] one field.  The first two or three days I did not regard him as a good bunter -- not at all. Against the Dudley machine he is right now a very accurate and finished bunter. Against that machine the boy bunts for the spot and he also drag bunts [against that machine] with surprising skill.  Doug should hit .300 in the major leagues and without delay. And he will do just that provided that he is oriented; that he feels that he really belongs. I think he can play in 1963 on any major league club provided he has this sense of [*"*]at homeness.[*"*]  He may lack confidence in the lineup on a major league [game] [*team*], and if so, that is deeply regrettable. The boy has ability as a batsman to be a major leaguer.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: July 23, 1963  Toronto, Canada  Toronto vs. Atlanta      COKER, JIM (Toronto Catcher)    Right hand hitter and his form is good. He should hit. His arm is fair. He doesn't know what body checking means. Not a great arm, but throws right now. I think he would be a corker [for a club to own] on a AAA club.      BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 10, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana      COKER, JIM (Toronto Catcher)    As between Coker and Ricketts, I would take Ricketts on account of arm and catching ability. Coker has more power. It cannot hurt to get Coker on our catching staff. However, I would not give up any potentially good player in exchange.      BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: June 17, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs N. Y. Mets      COLEMAN, "CHO CHO"  This is June 17th when Coleman is hitting under .200. I think this catcher could be helped in his hitting.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: May 2, 1963  Cincinnati, Ohio  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee      COLEMAN, GORDY (Cincinnati First Baseman)      Plays first base acceptably and can hit the long ball but is just about as helpless a batter as I know [of] against left hand pitching. I prefer some other first baseman.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: March 10, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.      COSGROVE, AL  On the showing date, Cosgrove is more promising than Long. Long cost $85,000, Cosgrove cost $8,000. Long cost considerable scouting expense, Cosgrove cost practically no scouting expense.    Long is a patience tester. Cosgrove is three years younger than Long and I believe he will be in the major leagueat Long's present age.    Send Cosgrove to a low league in 1963.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: April 1, 1963    COSGROVE, AL    Of all the players drafted by the Cardinals in the last twelve months, Cosgrove, Harris, and Wallace were the tops. Harris goes to Tulsa, Wallace is gone, and Cosgrove should go to a small league under the best batting coach in the organization. He carries around with himself, both on and off the field, prospective greatness.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: April 13, 1963  St. Louis vs. Phillies    CALLISON, JOHN (Philadelphia Outfield)  TAYLOR, TONY (Philadelphia Infielder)  AMARO, REUBEN (Philadelphia Infielder)    CALLISON and TAYLOR are fine major league players. TONY TAYLOR is a much underrated player and a very desirable man on any championship club.    AMARO, likewise, is an underrated player.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota    COSGROVE, AL    A 19 year old left hand hitting first baseman, drafted last December on the recommendation of Benny Borgman. Player is now released to Cincinnati outright.    This boy was a reckless rounder. Manager Fred Koenig told me he was caught four different times with a woman in his room; that he was an abandoned drinker. Instead of suspending him, he fined him a gentle fine. Manager said the boy didn't care for anything. Was an open violator of all rules.    Another sample of bonus tragedy.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: August 13, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Winnipeg vs Bismark-Mandan    COSMA, MARIO (Bismark-Mandan Pitcher)    Well built right hander with Bismark-Mandan. Has perfect control of a very good fast ball and a downer curve. Takes charge - bosses everybody, - a rookie. This boy is 21 years old. He pitches with poise and apparent confidence of a veteran.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 31, 1963    COSMAN, JIM (Brunswick Pitcher)    Tall boy, right hander. Got good speed, good change-up on his fast ball, fair curve. Energetic, industrious, interested. His habits should be watched. The boy is definitely a major league prospect. He must not be given an unconditional release.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: March 19, 1963    COX, RON    Play him as much as possible, - in exhibition games. No adventure. See reports.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 11, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana  Indianapolis vs Atlanta    COX, RON    A waiver request on Cox would probably have no claims. If there were no claims, I believe he would not be drafted if his contract were assigned to Atlanta, - in which case I would let him go to draft, having in mind reducing the Cardinal active list to enable the club to draft. The Cardinal scouting staff has doubtless done a thoroughly comprehensive job scouting the minor leagues and first year players. I hope the Cardinal roster numerically will enable the dlub to daft extensively if it wants to do so.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: June 8, 1963  New York, N.Y.  St. Louis vs N.Y. Mets    CRAIG, ROGER    In the third inning today, with one man out, and Ken Boyer at first, Roger Craig threw eight times to first base, holding Boyer. I have not seen a single St. Louis pitcher throw as many as eight times to hold runners on first base in a whole game since the season began.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 2, 1963  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee    CRANDALL, DEL    (See full report in personal letter to Bing   Devine) A history of an ailing arm, probably   not recovered. A great gentleman, has leadership,   and I believe splendid managerial timber.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: August 9, 1963  Billings, Montana  Billings vs Boise    CRAYTON, LARRY    22 year old left hander. Has been pitching professionally for three years. Fair fast ball, fair curve, nothing great in either direction. No control. If Crayton was showing his best stuff, then he has no chance to pitch above Class C or D.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 31, 1963    DAMASKA, BILL (Brunswick Infielder)    I would see him for the season and take the opinion of his manager at that time as to his future.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  August 2, 1963    DAMASKA, BILL    A faster runner than Farrell, - much faster than Anthon. I would leave him with this club for next year. He strides pretty far and another year at Brunswick would not hurt him. I doubt very much if he is a major league prospect.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: May 8, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs Los Angeles    CALMUS, RICHARD (Los Angeles Pitcher)    Young, tall right hand pitcher on the Los Angeles Club. Got a fine curve and plenty of speed. Very impressive with his change-up on the fast ball. It is an excellent change and the boy is willing to use it. I like him very much. Include him, if possible, in any deal that might be made with Los Angeles.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 11, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana  Indianapolis vs Atlanta    DAMASKA, JACK    Pretty good man for Atlanta. In the same class with Kubiszyn.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963   Cleveland vs Minnesota    DAVALILLO, VIC (Cleveland Outfielder)    Left hand hitter, left hand thrower, - a little fellow, pest hitter, enough power. I will not be surprised if he becomes a regular in the major leagues. I would not waive on him.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 29, 1963  Brunswick vs Moultrie    DAVIS, DON (Brunswick Pitcher)    Plenty of speed and a good curve ball. A pure case of stage freight from the professional game. In this league, he should be pitched every fourth day and let him go several innings regardless of how he looks.    BRANCH RICKEY    It would be a good move to invite Don Davis to report to the Cardinal Club at Busch Stadium as soon as he returns to his home in Belleville this fall. Let him sit on the bench during the game and pitch batting practice. Let him get acquainted with the players and coaches.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  August 2, 1963    DAVIS, DON    Right hand pitcher from Belleville, Illinois. It could pay off very easily to take this boy to the Florida fall camp.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 29, 1963    DAVIS, ERNEST (Brunswick Outfielder)    He can run and I mean run. He looks like he might have a lot of power, - but he doesn't know the strike zone.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: St. Louis, Mo.  May 8, 1963  St. Louis vs Los Angeles    DAVIS, TOMMY (Los Angeles Outfielder-Infielder)    Anybody with change-ups should use them on this batsman. If he gets the pitch he is looking for, he is very dangerous. I downright believe that Tommy is looking for a fast ball after the change-up pitch. I have just seen him strike out four times in three successive games on the right hander's curve following a change of pace. This would somewhat indicate that Tommy Davis is capable of 'guessing' the pitch, - and I believe he does. I believe that most of his long hits are made off the fast ball. I would like to know the results of Milliken's summary on this point.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 2, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Los Angeles    DEBUSSCHERE, DAVE (White Sox Pitcher)    Shows no control of any pitch. A really remarkable delivery. If this boy had a change of speed off the fast ball and had control of it, he would need only two pitches.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 29, 1963  Brunswick vs Moultrie    DE LA CRUZ, RAMON (Moultrie Catcher)    Showed only an ordinary arm. Throws three-quarters. Wouldn't take him as a gift.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    DE LA HOZ, MIKE (Cleveland Infielder)    Not a big fellow, 25 years of age, got superb body control. Doesn't impress me as a power hitter or a high percentage hitter. Neither he or infielder Brown of the Cleveland club is the type of player we need.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Billings, Montana  August 10, 1963  Billings vs Boise    DeLeon, Felix    Right hand hitting, sawed off, colored boy. Runs medium, throws medium, and hits with power. This fellow was a most deliberate, easy going chap going up to the mark in the running races. Looked overweight and admitted it. Impressed me as a lazy fellow. Could be wrong. I don't think it would do any good to him or anyone else to have him come to the Florida Instruction Camp this fall. I don't think you would hasten his development at all. Besides, he probably has an earning job in Puerto Rico. Let him alone.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 2, 1963  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee    CARDENAS, LEO (Cincinnati Infielder)    Right now and for years to come a highly desirable shortstop, - fielding, running, throwing, and hitting, not great but enough.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 27, 1963  Cleveland vs Kansas City    DEL GRECO (Kansas City Outfielder)    Don't take him at any price, either minor or major, - not even as a 'throw in'.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 5, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Kansas City    DEL GRECO, BOBBY (Kansas City Outfielder)    Might be a fairly good man at Tulsa.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: April 20, 1963  Philadelphia, Pa.  St. Louis vs. Philadelphia    DEMETER scored in the fifth inning from first base on Siever's hit to left field. The retrieving was deliberate, but Boyer's realy throw was 15' ahead of the runner who slid into home and apparently kicked the ball out of OLIVER's hand to the wall. It was certainly a gift run.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    DE MOSS, FRANK (Amarillo Infielder)    Pretty good looking boy. No power.    BRANCH RICKEY    CC - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: March 19, 1963    DENNIS, DON    Hold title to his contract. Place him where he has a chance to make a good record.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: March 30, 1963  Hollywood, Fla.  Atlanta vs. Richmond    DENNIS, DON    Good size right hand pitcher. Pitched against Richmond this date. Showed nothing special either in speed or curves. With a man on second base, he started his delivery while looking at the runner. He did it three times in succession. That's bad. I don't believe he has pitched very much anywhere. I don't think he will help Atlanta in 1963.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    DENNIS, DON    A nice boy, - a gentleman. Curve ball is good and bad - breaks now and then. Fast ball is good. Monkeys around with a slider (as most youngsters are doing) and I would call his slider ineffective.    This fellow is a good runner.    His fast ball might bring him to the majors eventually if he gets a third usable pitch to go with it.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: August 13, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota    DEWS, ROBERT    I did not see him.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 2, 1963  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee    DILLARD, DON (Milwaukee Outfielder)    A big, strong 26 year old left hand hitting outfielder with Milwaukee. Observation, - one game, has power, percentage hitting is question.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    DONOVAN, DICK (Cleveland Pitcher)    A veteran pitcher and a good pitcher. Made   27 straight balks in one game. Never stopped on a  single pitch. Really has two positions as he pretended  to come set. He gets away with it. Opposing  manager doesn't object, - umpires completely unmindful  of any balk really. I think this is the prevailing  attitude throughout the American League. Donovan is  37 years old.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: March 15, 1963    CARMEL, DUKE    Carmel against right hand pitching will help the Cardinal club more than Clemens.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: New York, N.Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    DOWNING, AL (New York Yankee Pitcher)    A left handed colored boy. Hits right handed but doesn't hit. He is a strike out pitcher, but streaky wild. Got a lot of stuff. All business. Very young. Worth whatever you have to pay. No chance to get him.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 3, 1963  Minneapolis, Minn.  Minnesota vs Kansas City    DRABOWSKY, MOE (Kansas City Pitcher)    I would call his change up curve ball   effective if he got it near the plate. Good fast   ball and good control of it. His regular curve ball   is 'high-schoolish'. Breaks a little. I would   call it his weakest pitch.    I think he could help our club., - very much.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: March 14, 1963    DULIBA, ROBERT    A spot pitcher. Has an idea on every pitch. Fast ball just ordinary. Curve ball good enough. If this boy is a major league pitcher, it is in relief.    If he has good control, he might help in relief work.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: March 26, 1963  Clearwater, Florida    CARMEL, LEON "DUKE"  Got a good arm, a good pair of legs and a good bat and a good disposition. There should be a good "Dr. Dudley" at Busch Stadium to be used by Duke. This boy can be brought through on the Cardinal club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Tuesday, Forenoon,  April 2, 1963  St. Petersburg, Florida    CARMEL, LEON "DUKE"    I had a talk with Carmel this morning about his returning to the home run idea every time he goes to bat; that he should for God's sake, as well as his own, go to the plate more or less always, - hitting with intent. He knew what I meant and he agreed with me. "Yesterday," said he, "I swung three times, every one with the idea of a home run. Afterwards, I knew I was wrong."    I talked with him very earnestly about going to the cage every morning that he possibly could to hit against 'Mr. Dudley' "on good balls, - only good balls, - and only with intent." I told him in event his contract would be purchased by the St. Louis club, I would try to have 'Mr. Dudley' at Busch Stadium in St. Louis to provide continuing pitching opportunity for him.    This player is inclined to press on every swish of the bat and doing so is inclined to swing and miss on every fast ball pitched inside and below his belt line. If this batsman would entirely forget the home run idea, he could be a .300 hitter in the major league and with power.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: August 6, 1963  New York, N. Y.  St. Louis vs New York Mets    CARMEL, DUKE (New York Mets First Baseman)    This boy could become a great major league   ball player, - if, - if, -if, - he had a different   ancestry. [*no head*]    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: March 19, 1963    FANOK, HARRY    This fellow should be brought to 'taw'. He   should be made to throw his fast ball overhand, not   exclusively, but dominantly and should be worked on   diligently on a change-up off his fast ball. This is   important. Fanok can pitch in the major league and on   this club, pennant-wise. He must have constant attention.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: 4:30 P.M.  Monday, April 1, 1963  St. Louis vs. Phillies    FANOK, HARRY  Fanok pitched the last three innings. In the eighth inning, out of 24 successive pitches, 22 were fast balls. The other two were change-ups off his fast ball.  Obviously, catcher McCarver was instructed to pitch only  the fast ball and change-ups, - a directive that may have  had good purpose.    When he got a bit wild with his fast ball, he  dropped his delivery from overhand to three-quarters   and a couple of times even lower than three-quarters.    Fanok's body is built for good action, and should  be an alert fielder of his position. This boy has great  possibility of being a good pitcher on the Cardinal club   in 1963 but there is an equal if not stronger possibility   that he will be a disappointment.    I reserve an opinion on the probabilities until later If he should become an 'intelligent' pitcher with strike control and self-control, he will have arrived.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    FANOK, HARRY  Against Chicago tonight in relief, he was   simply a fast ball thrower. Other stuff seldom used   and not over when used.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 3, 1963  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    FANOK, HARRY    Fanok, in relief, was simply a thrower. One fast ball after another with no spot pitching intent at anytime. He simply reared back and threw hard and tried to get it over the plate. Nervous, pressing, impatient to pitch, but    Worst of all, with men on bases he brings both hands as high as his chin in a preliminary move before he pitches. Only a 'thrower' this evening.    I am afraid it will take a long time, possibly seven years, for this boy to become a master pitcher. It is just too bad because he has the stuff to make him great.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 29, 1963  Brunswick vs Moultrie    FARRELL, RICH (Brunswick Infielder)  Batting form is good.   BRANCH RICKEY    Brunswick, Ga.  July 31, 1963  I would have more of a look at him. His future probably depends upon his hitting.  BRANCH RICKEY  cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.   August 2, 1963    FARRELL, RICH    The Howe averages can do the 1963 scouting for me on this player.    BRANCH RICKEY  cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: August 10, 1963  Billings, Montana  Billings vs Boise    FAULKNER, WARDELL "ZEKE"    A colored boy, left hand hitter, as fast as Harris. Throws right, bats left. This   outfielder, Zeke Faulkner, shows gradual improvement in all directions. He is 21 years of age and completing his third year in the minor league.    It is said that the left hander's bother Zeke very much. If so, he should switch   hit. This boy could become a good pest hitter and a fine base runner. I would consider him for the fall camp in Florida.  BRANCH RICKEY    His arm did not strike me as great   at all but I can't say that it is below average.   His arm is strong enough. Should be advanced to a  higher classification club next year.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    FAULKNER, KEN (Armarillo Outfielder)    If colored outfielder, Faulker is a young kid, he should be followed up. He looks good at the plate and he can run.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 29, 1963  Brunswick vs Moultrie    FERREND, RAY (Moultrie Infielder)    Right hand hitter. Well built. Has power. Perfect form, - should hit.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1954; L-Z
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  August 1, 1963  Brunswick vs Thomasville    FINN, FRAN "MICKEY"    18 years old. Connecticut boy. 160 pounds. Right hand thrower, left hand hitter. He does everything well. Not a great runner, but a good runner. Not a great arm, but a good arm. Not a power hitter, but a good hitter. He has adventure. A team of Mickey Finns' would be a hard team to beat in any minor league. Hold him.    BRANCH RICKEY  cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: March 18, 1963  St. Louis vs. Detroit  Lakeland, Florida    EAGAN (Detroit Pitcher)      Left hand pitcher Eagan. Get him if you can.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  August 2, 1963    FINN, FRAN "MICKEY"    He is not a slow runner. Average. He makes the most of his speed. I would call him a good base runner.
