He has a head and he uses it. He has an average arm and he knows how to use that too. He is not set up at the plate. He is the Stanky type of ball player. The best all-around member of the Brunswick club.    I would hold him.    Under no circumstances, however, should he be invited to the Fall camp in Florida. He may hit around .300 in this Georgia League and if so, it would not surprise me at all if Mickey could play with Tulsa next year.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Winnipeg vs Bismark-Mandan    FINN, FRAN "MICKEY"    Here is a word that might be said to Mickey Finn. "The fast ball on the outside corner is very away far from you. You can hardly reach it and it really is a strike."    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: March 19, 1963    FIREK, JAN  A $12,500 bonus boy. He should be placed   outright. His record for 1963 will not sell him   and probably not draft him. Well built boy, big   and young. Made no great impression in any   direction. Should become a power hitter. Can he  run? Or throw?    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: March 30, 1963  Hollywood, Florida  Atlanta-vs-Richmond    FIREK, JAN  If this young right hand hitting outfielder were   to be played regularly on the Atlanta club in 1963, I   would be surprised if he would hit very much over .200  Further, I would not be surprised if he were to be high  up in the strike out records. He was born with good form  and has ample power. Should go to a low league.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: April 4, 1963    FIREK, JAN  If Firek is sent out an option from the Cardinal club, he should be sent to a low classification league. It is easy and helpful to promote a player but to demote a youngster constantly or even once during the season can be very discouraging and in any event delay the normal progress in the player's development.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: March 26, 1963  Clearwater, Fla.    FLOOD, CURT    Got a good arm. Knows how to throw. Runs with the ball everytime he gets it before he throws. Too bad. Otherwise, this boy approaches perfection, - meaning that he has pushed his ability up to his capacity.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: May 26, 1963  St. Louis vs New York Mets    FLOOD, CURT    I don't believe that Flood knows the value of a base  on balls, and most certainly he doesn't know how much it  would add to his own value if he got more of them. He  seldom takes the first pitch if it is close and he almost  never "takes" one and nothing and three and one. He commits  himself in advance to hit all cripples. Groat, White, Boyer,   Musial, Altman and others get more bases on balls than Flood  does. Most of them exceed him very much on the basis of  comparative times at bat. This criticism cannot be very   sharp or pointed because Curt is not a puny hitter. He rates  close to 50% on power, which offers pretty good argument  that he should hit the cripple frequently with men on bases.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: New York, N.Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL vs New York (AL)    FOILES, HENRY (Los Angeles Angeles Catcher)    A fine person. Right hand hitting catcher and of no interest to St. Louis.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    FRANCONA, TITO (Cleveland Outfielder)    Left hander all the way. Some power.  Let Cleveland keep him. We can't build a pennant  winning club out of Franconas'.  BRANCH RICKEY  cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: May 2, 1963  Cincinnati, Ohio  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee    FREESE, GENE (Cincinnati Infielder)    In culture, an alley production from the slums, but a good athlete. Ample power as a batsman, good average runner, arm satisfactory. A championship club can carry Freese but I don't believe 25 Freeses' would win a National League pennant.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: March 14, 1963    EDWARDS, JOHN (CINCINNATI)    A fine catcher. A perfect body checker, a good arm, and a power at the plate. He is game, - unafraid and apparently quite intelligent. I think he handles pitchers with good judgment and he acts, on the field, as if he were captain of the team. Haller is the only catcher in the National League in his class.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 2, 1963  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee    GABRIELSON, LEN    A 6'4", 23 year old left hand hitting infielder-outfielder-first baseman with Milwaukee. A good power hitter. I would guess him to be above 50% in this respect, and he stays off bad pitches. Knows the strike zone. He can run above average. St. Louis would do well to get Gabrielson in any player deal.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: March 19, 1963    GAGLIANO, PHIL    Hold to the opening of the 1963 National   League season. Then decide. Should go back to the   batting cage (to pivot front foot).    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: March 26, 1963  Gagliano, Phil  Good hands, quick arm, accurate, but not a great arm.  Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: July 23, 1963  Toronto, Canada  Toronto vs Atlanta    Gagliano, Phil    Hitting about .240. Terribly disappointing. This boy has to hit around .300 to be a major leaguer. He has very ordinary arm and only and average runner at best. I believe the Cardinal organization should pass him up as a prospect for its own team. He might go to the market.    Branch Rickey    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: September 11, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana  Indianapolis vs Atlanta    GAGLIANO, PHIL    I simply have to give up on Phil as a candidate for the Cardinal club. He does not have a great arm, - in fact it is ordinary. He does not have great legs, in fact they are not above average. He does not have great power, in fact he is below average. Most certainly I would let him go to draft at Atlanta, unless indeed a deal could be made prior to the draft for consideration above the draft price. I do not believe he will be drafted.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Phil Gagliano    A righthand hitter whose power in the [record book] scout reports has been to   the left field foul line. [Very definitely,] I can say without fear   of being in error, that this boy can be and probably is, a straight away hitter and   with reasonable power. [to all fields.] He knows how to pivot the   front foot and hit to right. Also he can hit with intent to pull   or push and get "hoped for" results. He is not a pun[e]y hitter.     His value at the plate could make him valuable as a utility   man, major league-wise in 1963. He wants to win. He would be a   spiritual addition to any club. He will acquire batting confidence   very easily. He has considerable of it right now.    It may be that the breaking stuff has been his trouble and   may continue to bother him [, but]. The Dudley machine gives me no   [opinion] help at that point. [but]     Phil has determination and courage, both  without stint.    I like him. He will give more reserve support   on the bench to the Cardinals, in 1963.   Play either Maxville or Buchek, but not   as much as Kolb, anywhere, -fielding   base running - bases or balls, or hitting  for percentage. I believe he will   lead Kolb on extra base hitting   percentage.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: April 16, 1963  St. Louis vs. Pittsburgh    GIBSON, BOB    With a runner on second base, he actually starts every pitch while he is still looking at second base. That makes a thrower out of him, and a wild one at that.    I don't believe he can catch men off first base and I don't believe he can hold men on first base. Any runner who wants to get a lead can do so and get a good break besides. He needs a lot of coaching. Undoubtedly Gibson has never had any instruction or practice in correcting his obvious weakness with men on bases.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 2, 1963  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee    GONDER, JESSE (Cincinnati Catcher)    Gonder has excessive power at the plate and a very strong arm, - not too accurate and the ball sails off to its right in its flight. That could be corrected. He is a big strong left hand hitting Negro.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: August 6, 1963  New York, N.Y.  St. Louis vs New York Mets    GONDER, JESS (New York Mets Catcher)    A big boy, colored, good body control, and very quick. He can throw. He has power, but he looks very confused against left hand pitching. I should talk to William Dewitt about Gonder. Eddie Leishman of San Diego could and would give us full information.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 4, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    GORYL, JOHN (Minnesota Infielder)    A infielder. Right hand all the way. Thirty years old. Not a big boy but a good all around player. I have no idea of his batting ability. I have seen him only four times at bat.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 2, 1963  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee    EDWARDS, JOHN    The Cincinnati club has the best catcher in the business. He is high class as a receiver, has a really great arm, a good batsman with power, and he can run with surprising speed. He is a big youngster and has marked competitive spirit an shows leadership in every direction.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: March 26, 1963    GRAHAM (No. 31) PHILLIES OUTFIELDER    Fine arm.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: April 19, 1963  Philadelphia, Pa.  St Louis vs. Philadelphia    GREEN, DALLAS    Right hand Philadelphia pitcher. In the   game tonight, every time he had 2 and 0 on the batter,   he came with the fast ball for the cripple. He had   good stuff on it but every time it was simply the   fast ball over the middle. If this is his general   practice, it is well for the Cardinal club to know it.    Green has a pretty good fast ball but he   pitches a lot of change-ups and he has a good one.   For example, to James in the second inning, the first   pitch was a change-up, the second a slow curve, the   third was a change-up and then a curve. His control   is uncertain. His regular so-called fast curve is   very ordinary. He pitches and acts like a chap with   very little experience.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    GREEN, GENE (Cleveland Outfielder)    Right hand hitter, has power. Can't run. I would not take him as a 'throw in'.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: New York, N.Y.  July 26, 1963  New York Yankess vs. Minnesota    GREEN, LENNY (Minnesota Outfielder)    Left hand hitting colored outfielder on Minnesota. He can run and he can pull the ball to his own field with great power.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: March 15, 1963    GREGORY, GROVER    Belongs in some league other than the National League.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: July 23, 1963  Toronto, Canada  Toronto vs Atlanta    GREGORY, LEROY    Left hand pitcher, 26 years old. A good overhand curve ball - breaks most of the time. Doesn't seem to have confidence in the pitch when he is in the 'hole'. Only a fair fast ball. he would have to get another usable pitch or perfect control to go to big.    BRANCH RICKEY    (Later - same date)  The only chance this boy has is a usable third pitch and spot control.    B.R.    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: April 13, 1963  St. Louis vs. Phillies    GROAT, DICK    If the ball is pitched inside, he can pull it with power. Very true. But on all outside pitching, the boy is practically restricted to right field hitting. He stands further from the plate than I have ever known him to do in past seasons. I think he stands 4" or 5" or perhaps 6" further away from the plate than he realizes. It may be unwise to mention this fact to the player, because he is hitting so well in his first three games. If he were to change anything presently, and then not hit, he would blame his advisor forever.    Therefore, I don't think a word should be said about it until he slumps because of wise pitching and I think the slump will come just as soon as pitchers with control keep the pitches, particularly the fast ball, on the outside. Then will come the time when he seeks advice to give it to him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: August 9, 1963  Billings, Montana  Billings vs Boise    GUTHRIE, DAVE    It just happened that I was seated directly behind the catcher in the grandstand when Guthrie was warming up prior to pitching in tonight's game against Boise.    He showed a fair fast ball, only fair, - a fair curve, only fair. He threw several change ups. Not one single pitch during the entire warmup was a really good strike. He had no control whatever. He had nothing to start with and couldn't throw what he had near the plate.    Judging him only on the warmup, I would class him as a non-prospect for a high school team.    Then the game started. The first batter hit the first pitch for a single to center. The next hitter flew out, followed by the next pitch, - a line drive against the left field fence for two bases. The following hitter, a Negro third baseman, Clark, let Guthrie pitch and immediately got three balls. Then came the first strike of the game, followed by a three foot outside pitch and he walked. With two out, a left hand hitting catcher named Newman hit the ball against the right field fence for two bases. Finally, after five runs scored, Guthrie was relieved.    This boy is only 20 years of age. He is big and strong. His strikeout record is very good. I don't believe he will be drafted at Tulsa or even in Class A. He has a hard time winning at Billings. I recommend he be left right where he is.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: September 10, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana  Indianapolis vs Atlanta    HACKER, WARREN (Indianapolis Pitcher)    I saw Hacker about ten or possibly eleven years ago. At that time, he was a knuckle ball pitcher and a good one and I thought then that he had a good major league future. But his control was wobbly. He is now about 37 years old and has the reputation and record of great control, having an assortment of pitches, including a controlled knuckler. In the International League, the Howe averages will show him on August 28, 1963, as having 99 strike outs and only 4 bases on balls.    This evening against Atlanta, he showed control and poise and was very effective against Atlanta batters. I think he might be a pickup on the market and if so, I would recommend that we take him for relief work.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    HALL (Minnesota Outfielder)    Tall, left hand hitting outfielder. Good arm and a lot of power. Didn't impress me as a good runner. Looks like change ups and slow curves tied him up. On the basis of total bases related to hits, Hall is surely above 50%. A young chap. Surely has high future value.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    Ellsworth, Dick (Chicago Pitcher)    Left hand pitcher, 22 years old, 6'4" tall. Good speed and good curve. Impresses me with nervousness. Probably a fine future pitcher.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  July 16, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs. Senators    HANSEN, RON (Chicago Infielder)    Good form at the plate. Ought to hit for extra bases and I don't see why he shouldn't hit for a high average.    Pitchers with changes of speed should keep Hansen at a low percentage. Hansen comes the nearest to being an over-strider than anyone on the Chicago or Washington Club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 27, 1963  Cleveland vs Kansas City    HARRELSON (Kansas City Outfielder)    Tall, right hand hitter, - must be 6'2" or 6'3". Great arm. Runs well. Has a lot of power. About 22 years of age. I would like to deal for him. Player may have some weakness I don't know about. He should be investigated. A deal with Kansas City might be made this fall. The boy may have some weakness in health, disposition, or even on the field, - that I don't know about. I want to follow Kansas City further.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: September 4, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Kansas City    HARRELSON, KEN (Kansas City Outfielder)    He seems to be a completely bewildered batsman. Hits at bad balls, takes good ones. If he is subject to major league options, without waivers, he should be put into a Class A league for 1964.    BRANCH RICKEY    BR/b    cc-Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: September 5, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Kansas City    HARRELSON, KEN (Kansas City Outfielder)    I doubt if Harrelson ever becomes a major league ball player. He cannot make decisions. I believe he is a permanent disappointment as a batter. He has a lot of power but it doesn't mean anything. He impressed me as a young possibility in my first game of observation. He is only that!    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: April 2, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.    Harris, Jim    Jim Harris is to be assigned to the Tulsa club. He has had an ailing arm for several days and his all around work in the training camp at Homestead has not been too impressive. This player should have been kept with the Cardinal club until the team starts north for several valid reasons, the chief of which would be acquaintanceship with major league managers and players and to give him confidence and desire so that he will orient quickly when he does come to the Cardinals with a good chance to play regularly on the Cardinal team. Harris, Cosgrove and Wallace are the three best youngsters I have seen this spring in the Cardinal organization. This is not meant to include Kolb who has been on the Cardinal roster and my opinions on this player have been recorded fully elsewhere. Possibly I should not have omitted Gagliano. This player was not included he has had three full years of professional baseball. The three boys mentioned, Harris, Cosgrove, and Wallace, have had only a part of one season. Harris at Tulsa will place him available during the coming season. I will be surprised if Harris is not advanced this year.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: August 10, 1963  Billings, Montana  Billings vs Boise    Harris, Jim    Harris should be invited to the Winter Instruction Camp in Florida this fall. The boy should go to the major leagues and will as soon as he becomes a good switch hitter.    Branch Rickey    (Later)    With proper coaching, this boy can become an improved right handed hitter, and if he gets the chance to become a left hand hitter against right hand pitching, he will go major league. he also has to become more challenging and adventurous on the bases. It doesn't matter what position he plays in the Florida Fall Camp, but it is important that he be played regularly and be required to hit left handed.     Branch Rickey    cc -- Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota    HARRIS, LEROY (Winnipeg Pitcher)  Pretty good fast ball, not great. Curve ball curves, not great. Has a change up on his curve ball and pretty good control of it. I doubt if he uses this change up curve ball very much, but he should.    Has a change up off his fast ball but it has entirely too much speed. He knows how to slow it up, but it will take considerable work.    Has a quick move with men on first base.    Big, strong chap, 21 years of age, left hander, weighs probably 185 pounds.    And now we come to a very important point. Leroy can throw a corking knuckle ball. It knuckles, - at times a floater type with enough velocity for deception - even catching it. He started this spring with the Tulsa club but somebody told him to forget it; that he had enough stuff without it. He should be encouraged to pitch that knuckle ball. Control of that pitch alone would bring him to the Cardinal club very easily. If he can get it over the plate, he doesn't need any other pitch.    BRANCH RICKEY  cc - Mr. Bing Devine    Dec 15 1963  Leroy Harris is now advised to give up the "knuckler." Very well you can have him - without the knuckle ball, he will be a long time reaching the majors. He does not have enough stuff without it to be of any special interest to me.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: March 30, 1963  Hollywood, Fla.  Atlanta vs. Richmond    HAYGOOD, CHARLES  Young left hand pitcher with a fine fast ball. Good enough to go anywhere. Curve looked very ordinary. A Newcomb curve, - 3" with speed. If this boy gets a good usable third pitch, he surely could go all the way. Haygood as a hitter, - AIN'T.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Winnipeg vs Bismark-Mandan    HAYGOOD, CHARLES    A drafted player. Let him go to draft in AA.    Talks and acts intelligent, an aggressive sort of pitcher, fair control. Needs a third usable pitch.    Frankly, this boy needs more stuff before he will help the Cardinal club.    BRANCH RICKEY    Haygood throws a change up curve ball. Very effective. He should use it more often.    BRANCH RICKEY    There is nothing to be gained by taking him to the Florida Instruction Camp. He is not a quickie in any sense.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: August 10, 1963  Billings, Montana  Billings vs. Boise    HEIMBIGNER, CRAIG  Right hand hitter. Acts like a confused batsman. Every pitch surprises him. Fair runner, and I believe he has a pretty good arm, but it will be considerable time before he is any kind of a dangerous hitter.     He has already received $7500 for signing a contract and he gets $2500 more if he is kept ninety days. On the basis of having only seen him in one game, I wouldn't give him $ .25. Whoever scouted him, of course, has seen much more ability in this boy than shown me in this day's work. I would not invite him to the fall camp.    BRANCH RICKEY  cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    ELSTON, DON (Chicago Pitcher)    Right hand relief pitcher with Chicago. I do not consider him a high class relief man as he is generally regarded to be. He lacked control the few times I have seen him. However, his earned run average has been uniformly good down through the years. He is 34 years of age.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 29, 1963  Brunswick vs Moultrie    HEMENDE, JOE (Brunswick Pitcher)    Left hander. No speed to speak of, fair curve, a very doubtful prospect. He would have to have the knowledge of Shantz, - also Shantz' variations of pitches if he were to go major league.    Of course, he must be retained on some club for another year. He has a chance to become a multiple stuff pitcher. He does have a change-up.    Hemende does not have a great fast ball. Has a good change off the fast ball. Make him use it. Hemende's best pitch is the low overhand curve.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 2, 1963  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee    HENDLEY, BOB  A 24 year old left hander, good size, good speed, and a corking curve. Carries around with him a change of speed pitch but seldom uses it. I wish St. Louis owned his contract. He has a better future than his past.    Right hand hitter and stands up to the plate with confidence. His batting record in 1962 shows he is under .200 with something like 60 times at bat, - too few to make final judgment but surely he is a good pitcher-hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: August 13, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Winnipeg vs Bismark-Mandan    HERRMANN, FRED    A high school curve. Nothing else.    BRANCH RICKEY    27 years old. Fine control, pitched like a veteran but showed no stuff.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  July 16, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs. Senators    HERSHBERGER, MIKE (Chicago Outfielder)    Gets a fine lead off first base. Held it and used it against a left hand pitcher. Bat is not far back at anytime. Can't be a power hitter. Looks like he had a corking arm. I doubt if he has any adventure in his soul.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: September 2, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Los Angeles    HERSHBERGER, MIKE (White Sox Outfielder)    Right hand hitting outfielder, about 6' tall, 185 pounds. Big man, little poop. His stroke indicates no power. Acts like a guess hitter. Either can't run fast or wouldn't. I would rather have several of what we have got.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: August 6, 1963  New York, N.Y.  St. Louis vs New York Mets    Hickman, Jim (New York Mets Infielder-Outfielder)    A very tall, right hand hitting outfielder with a lot of power. A pitcher with changes of speed surely could make him look bad. If not, then he is a potential great hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY    The most indifferent ball player I have seen in sometime. No lead, no break, no nothing. The exact opposite of hustle.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amaillo    HILGENDORF, TOM    Left hand pitcher. Did not show me great stuff, but he has pitched a few sensational games and attracted attention, particularly from Huston.    He is not draftable at Atlanta. I would put him right there.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc- Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  July 16, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs. Senators    HINTON, CHUCK (Washington Outfielder)    He can run, has good form at bat. Tall, slim Negro. I don't know whether he can throw or not but he looks like he has every other asset.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: June 17, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs K. Y. Mets    HOOK, JAY    Right hand pitcher with the Mets. He has high standing with the Cardinal brass. I don't think he is a first division major league pitcher. In the first place, he has no third pitch. Besides, he doesn't show great speed. He does have a good breaking curve but in the two games I have seen him, the so-called good curve went anywhere and everywhere.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: St. Louis, Mo.  May 8, 1963  St. Louis vs Los Angeles    HOWARD, FRANK (Los Angeles Outfielder)    All that I said on Tommy Davis foes for Howard. However, Howard is much weaker than Tommy Davis on change ups, especially slow curves.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1962; L-W
Transcription: August 13, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota    Erickson, Dale    Did not see. He was disabled.    Branch Rickey  cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; Undated
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago Cubs    HUBBS, KEN    A tall, well built right hand hitting infielder, 21 years of age. Corking ball player. I cannot understand how Chicago can be in second division with men like Hubbs, BROCK, WILLIAMS, and practically their entire lineup of youngsters with only one really experienced player on the club, namely Banks.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; Undated
Transcription: March 14, 1963    HUNT, KEN (Cincinnati Pitcher)    Big as a house. Slow movement. Fast ball very ordinary, curve ball the same. With the stuff he showed me, I don't understand how we got on a major league roster. He must have been ill today.    (LATER)    An unimpressive show of stuff in the three innings he worked, but our boys didn't hit him at all. Oliver got a long home run and Musial singled. Otherwise, Hunt was master.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; Undated
Transcription: June 17, 1963  St. Lous, Mo.  St. Louis vs N.Y. Mets  Hunt, Ron  A pretty good ball player. Arm is O.K. Legs O.K. Bat O.K. I don't believe 25 Hunts will win any major league pennant.  Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; Undated
Transcription: August 6, 1963  New York, N.Y.  St. Louis vs New York Mets  Hunt, Ron (New York Mets Infielder)  Now there is a ball player that wants to win. Good arm, not great. Good runner, not great. Good power. His capacity and ability meet. I see no reason why he will not become a .300 hitter in the National League. If there is any chance to make a winter deal for this player, do it.  Branch Rickey  cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; Undated
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 29, 1963    HUNTER, MIKE (Brunswick First Baseman)  Looks overweight and I think he would have trouble reducing. Big, strong right hand hitter with power. Not a good runner, - certainly not.  BRANCH RICKEY    Brunswick, Ga.  July 31, 1963    The only change in God's world for Hunter to stay in baseball is at catching. He cannot play anywhere else, and if he can't catch, he ought to be told to go into some other business.    BRANCH RICKEY      Brunswick, Ga.  [XXXX] August 1, 1963    cc- Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; Undated
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  August 1, 1963  Brunswick vs Thomasville    HUNTER, MIKE    A big fellow. Mike Hunter is married and has a baby, and will have another right away. He can't run a lick and he can't get down to give signals as a catcher on account of his heavy legs. He has a good arm. He can throw in practice with great accuracy. He is a power hitter but he strikes out ever more than a power hitter ought to.    Somebody should have a good talk with this boy about his future. If he were my grandson, I would advise him to quit the professional game.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; Undated
Transcription: April 11, 1963  St. Louis vs. Mets    JACKSON, ALVIN (NEW YORK METS PITCHER)    Jackson, left hand pitcher of the Mets, can really field his position. He is all over the place.    He has an effective curve ball and good control of it. I think he has pitching 'guts'. Unafraid.    When he first came up to the Pittsburgh organization, I thought he had limited stuff and was a very doubtful major leaguer. I now regard him as a good major league pitcher and I would like to see him on the St. Louis club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; Undated
Transcription: May 25, 1963    JACKSON, ALVIN    Colored left hand pitcher with the New York Mets. In the hands of an intelligent catcher who knows how to talk to a pitcher and who knows what to call for, and where it should go, this boy would surely be a winning pitcher. I wish our club could make a deal for him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; Undated
Transcription: April 13, 1963  St. Louis vs. Phillies    JAMES, CHARLEY    Intelligent. Gentle man. Not adventurous in any respect in either fielding or particulary, I would say, as a base runner. He is exactly the opposite of Minoso, for example, in taking advantage of errors or half-passed balls, etc.    On this date, I believe that 25 players all named James would finish in second division. I hope I may be able to change my mind on this boy.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; Undated
Transcription: April 20, 1963  Philadelphia, Pa.  St. Louis vs. Philadelphia    JAMES, CHARLEY    He seems to be a better hitter on pitches off center. I don't think he is a smart batsman at all and I doubt very much if he can hit .250 if played regularly against all pitchers. He takes good pitches and hits at bad ones frequently, indicating that he is guessing the pitch. He is not a chance taker, either in the field or on the bases.    25 James' would finish in second division.    I would be inclined to trade him for any really good pitcher. Either Kolb or Lewis in left field will win more games for the Cardinals and Carmel, against right hand pitching, would surely be much more valuable. In all parks, but particularly St. Louis, I wold not worry about losing James. Lewis, Kolb, Carmel, and Musial would give us ample protection in the outfield.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; Undated
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 27, 1963  Cleveland vs Kansas City    Esposito, Sam (Kansas City Second Baseman)    Good utility man on a second division club. Our club not interested.    Branch Rickey    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: March 10, 1963  St. Petersburg, Florida    JASTER, LARRY    Good fast ball, good enough for the major league. Curve is a 'drop', has two - fast and slow, - no control but there is no obvious reason for lack of control. He should have it. Does not show much fight, - indifferent. He might simply become a 'first and fifteenth player'.    Jaster's change up off the fast ball is just about his best pitch. No pep, no life, no interest. Maybe this boy has hookworm. If there were no bonus consideration or restrictive rules to consider, then this boy should be placed in Class D for one year, - better in E.    It is a terrible handicap to the Cardinal club and a very regrettable circumstance for the development of Jaster himself if he is to be kept on the active list of the Cardinal club during the season of 1963.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: March 19, 1963    JASTER, LARRY    Should be sent out on option to a small club. I think he can make the major leagues and become a pennant pitcher some day. I don't believe he has capacity to become a Commission Office, - not even the 'gimp' or go to make a Top Sargeant, but he can become one whale of a Private digging a ditch. It is possible that he may have a streak of aggressiveness not yet revealed. We must not let him get away.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    JASTER, LARRY    A tall, left hand pitcher, very young. To watch him or to be about him, one gets the impression that he doesn't give a damn. Nothing makes any difference; that he doesn't care anything about baseball. However, in conversation, the boy is entirely different. He wants to make good in baseball, not interested in anything else, so he says.    He has stuff, really good stuff and he can throw almost all the pitches.    If he thinks right and thinks decently, he surely will go to the majors and can be a major league pitcher for many years.    He looks good at the plate and could easily become a good hitter. Has good fielding action, especially for a boy so tall. He must e 6'5".    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: March 15, 1963    JAVIER, JULIAN    If Javier cannot be turned over as a left hander against right hand pitching with improvement, then I risk the written opinion that before the Cardinal club wins a pennant, somebody will replace Javier as the second baseman on the Cardinal club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: April 13, 1963  St. Louis vis. Phillies    Javier, Julian    The batting practice for Javier against Mr. Dudley should be required and she should be made to give scheduled time every day hitting left handed until a new position becomes natural. It will not take long. 30 minutes a day for 10 days of close practice against the machine will, I believe, enable this boy not only to be willing to hit left handed against right hand pitching, but he will want to do it.    I still insist that he is practically helpless against the curve ball pitching of right handers. He would be dangerous against such pitchers only when the pitch is started at him or well over the inside. It is almost criminal negligence not to require this boy to apply himself as a left hand hitter against the Dudley machine.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: April 20, 1963  Philadelphia, Pa.  St. Louis vs. Philadelphia    JAVIER, JULIAN    Jaview can be pitched to!! I don't believe he can hit . 200 against any ordinary right hand pitcher with control. This fellow has nothing at all to lose if he were to bat left handed against right hand pitching right now. As a matter of fact, any good left hander with control and a bit of knowledge will also keep Javier to a very low hitting percentage. I think he is a no good hitter against any kind of intelligent pitching, either right or left.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: September 3, 1963  Minneapolis, Minn.  Minnesota vs Kansas City    JIMENEZ, MANNY (Kansas City Outfielder)    Can't run or wouldn't run. Of no interest. I wouldn't want him at Atlanta.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: April 22, 1963  Houston, Texas  St. Louis vs Houston    JOHNSON, KEN (Houston Pitcher)    A great big right hand pitcher, considerable age, master of a half-dozen deliveries, even on occasion, but rarely, he comes underhand, but from that position on up he is a master of all deliveries.    No fast ball, ie., not really fast.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 8, 1963  St. Louis vis Los Angeles    FAIRLEY, RON (Los Angeles Outfielder - First Baseman)    I have seen Fairley in six games this year and he has hit for a high average against St. Louis in these six games. However, I have not seen Fairley look good on a single change up. There is nothing in his stride, swing, or timing that would mark him as weak on change-ups. He is a power hitter but definitely likes fast stuff.    He never gets a lead or a break as a base runner.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 27, 1963  Cleveland vs Kansas City    KIRKLAND, WILLIE (Cleveland Outfielder)    Power hitter. Strikes out a great deal   and predominantly a fly ball hitter. He can run, - good   enough. Thirty years of age. Colored boy. Tries   hard. Will take him only as a 'throw in' and   Cleveland does not regard him cheaply. Forget him.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: August 10, 1963  Billings, Montana  Billings vs Boise    KNOWLES, OTTO    A .275 left hand hitter in Class A. Fine   boy, 22 years of age, a veteran. Coached by Fred   Waters at Pensacola, Florida. You can let him go to   draft.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: March 26, 1963  Clearwater, Fla.    KOLB, GARY    Will throw more runners out than any outfielders   on the club. Throws quicker, trajectory lower, with as   much speed as Flood.    Kolb simply must not take a couble step in   throwing from the outfield. He has a quick arm and he   has enough intelligence to know better. Sometimes he   does, - not often.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: April 13, 1963  St. Louis, Missouri      KOLB, GARY    Kolb as a catcher can out-throw anybody   we have on our club. He will throw quicker than anyone   of them with much more speed and more accuracy. He will   outrun any of our present catchers and on the basis of   playing 162 games, Kolb will out hit percentagewise any   catcher we now have. I urge management to option this   player on a one day optional recall to a small classification   club where he will catch say 25 or 30 games, and then under   observation, the club will know whether he can mechanically   do the job.    In the meantime, the club can recall him within   24 hours if the player is needed.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs. Chicago    KOONCE, CAL (Chicago pitcher)    22 year old right hand pitcher. Has good   stuff, poor control.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: August 9, 1963  Billings, Montana    KOZNEN, DAVID (?) (Billing Legion Pitcher)    Big right hand pitcher. Just graduated   from high school. Pitching successfully in American   Legion baseball. Shows only fair speed, fair curve,   and fair control. The boy is very young.    In the old days, I would sign him up to a   Class D contract. I wouldn't consider a bonus.    The boy learns very quickly. I would give   a good deal to see him in a game. I suggest he be   followed closely and if he continues to win in the   American Legion, try to sign him.      BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: April 11, 1963  St. Louis vs Mets    KRANEPOOL, EDWARD (Mets Infielder-Outfielder)    A young giant of a fellow. Average runner   if that. Good arm and last fall in the Instruction   League in Florida, he tore the cover off the ball in   batting practice but hit almost not at all in the   game. He reminded me very much of our first baseman   Long.    It is not too difficult for me to imagine   this fellow as a regular major leaguer. Power hitting   and confidence can easily follow orientation in his   case.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: June 17, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs N. Y. Mets    KRANEPOOL, ED    I would take him on a future risk. He is a   big boy and very young. He is active, quick, and has   power, but seldom pulls the ball to his own field.   He might become a real major league player.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    KRUG, CHRIS    Right hand hitting catcher. Tall boy with   a very good arm. Well below average runner and a   very poor hitter. No power, no nothing. Bad form   with a bat in his hands. He will never hit as is.   Good on bunts and foul flies. I would let me go to   draft at Atlanta and be much pleased if some major   league club would take him.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: March 14, 1963      KUBISZYN, JOHN    He was a great basketball player at the   University of Alabama. Fair arm, ordinary runner.   No adventure. Extra bases doubtful. Has no power   stroke.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: July 24, 1963  Cleveland, Ohio  Cleveland vs Minnesota    KAAT, JIM (Minnesota Pitcher)    Tall left hand pitcher. Looks like an athlete and acts like one. He can throw hard and he has a good curve, - a corker most of the time. Stress does not agree with him. He is a young chap and ought to become a fine pitcher. I would take him in any deal. He would certainly be a regular pitcher on the St. Louis club.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: September 11, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana  Indianapolis vs Atlanta    KUBISZYN, JACK    High class, 'run of the mine', right hand   hitting infielder in minor league.    BRANCH RICKEY        cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Winnipeg vs Bismark-Mandan    LABOY, JOSE    A strong arm, a good pair of hands, and   power at the plate. I am not sure about his running   speed. He may be below average.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 2, 1963  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee    LARKER, NORM    32 year old left hand hitting first baseman.   No speed. Cardinals not interested.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 27, 1963  Cleveland vs Kansas City    LAU, CHARLEY (Kansas City Catcher)    Don't take him at any price, - either   minor or major.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: September 4, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Kansas City    LAU, CHARLEY (Kansas City Catcher)    Lau loses many a strike for his pitcher.  He carries every close one away from the plate. He  could easily be corrected.    Branch Rickey    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: September 2, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs. Los Angeles    LEE, DONALD E. (Los Angeles Pitcher)    Tall right hand pitcher, - son of Thornton  Lee. Showed only fair stuff, good control,  particularly with the side arm curve ball. I would  class him as a pretty good AAA pitcher.    Branch Rickey    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: July 23, 1963  Toronto, Canada  Toronto vs. Atlanta    LEJA, FRANK (Toronto First Baseman)    A very big boy, left hand hitter, playing   first base for Toronto. Apparently a pull hitter   and with a lot of power. Very ordinary runner.   (Later) I believe he is a below ordinary runner.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: April 30, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs Milwaukee    LEMASTER, DENNIS (Milwaukee Pitcher)    Tall left handed Milwaukee pitcher. Has a good  fast ball and a corking curve. Doesn't have anything  like perfect control of the curve ball but it is so good  that batters help him out constantly, - hitting at bad  curve ball pitching. He has a change-up, either a  knuckle ball or a medium speed screw ball or something.  This must be verified. This boy has three distinct  effective pitches. He would help our club very much.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: March 19, 1963    LEWIS, JOHNNY JOE    It has been said to "play this fellow in   early games could only increase the problem." The   answer to that remark is if Lewis can increase the   problem very much, he might indeed solve it. He has   been given almost no chance whatever. A modest fellow   to the point of being a Negro inferiority complex case.   If he ever comes to the place that he feels that he is   an independent human being, he might become a regular   major league outfielder- hitting, fielding,   everything.    Doubtless he will be sent to Homestead very   shortly. The sad part about this decision is not   that he is going to Homestead, but that he is going to   Homestead without anyone really knowing why. What is it   that he doesn't do favorably? What is it that   he cannot do? What has this player done or not done that   gives anyone the right to be positive about his ability   in any direction? My three weeks of close observation   of Lewis has not added to or subtracted from a former   estimate. His appearance in the batting case (done at   my request) has indeed confirmed my belief that the boy   has good power, - also that he knows the strike zone   better than most.     Lewis needs acquaintanceship; at homeness;   orientation; a self estimate of existence.    Management has said that when you want Lewis   you have to look for him. Of course you do and until   the time comes when this boy really thinks that he   "belongs", - is worthwhile, until that time you will   always have to look for him when you want him. He is   not too far removed from the aegis of a slave-Negro.   In my judgement, he should have been given a lot of front   line work, played in games until we had reason either to   hire or fire him. We don't have any reason for any   decision on this player. Nobody knows.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: September 11, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana   Indianapolis vs Atlanta    LEWIS, JOHNNY    Left hand hitting outfielder. He can run and  he can throw and he can hit with power. A self-conscious  Negro, presently convinced of his inferiority.  Orientation is his problem. When this player gets   acquainted and feels that he belongs, he can play major  league. I would put him on the Cardinal team for 1964  and keep him with the team for the whole season if possible.   He might be of great value in 1965 to the St. Louis club.  It could pay off to endure Lewis for one year regardless  of his stage fright, -- hoping that at the end of one   year he would get over it.    He has a good change of hitting as a Cardinal   in 1964 as does Altman. He will run with Altman and  will out-field and out-throw him, plenty. This boy  should be given extended batting practice against left  hand pitching. If unresponsive, I would switch hit him   against left handers. However, I believe that with  practice, he will improve. A firm policy on Lewis is  necessary.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc -- Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: August 6, 1963  New York, N. Y.  St. Louis vs New York Mets      KANEHL, ROD (New York Mets)    Batting form is good and his stride is good. Well built, good size, right hand hitter, - versatile player. Change ups bother him a lot. He has played a number of years. Should not be so bad in timing, be he is. I would take Maxvill. I hope we never take him for the Cardinals, except as a "throw in".    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: August 10, 1963  Billings, Montana  Billings vs Boise    LIGUORI, JOE    He can't run, and has a very ordinary arm.  Poor receiver, not a power hitter. In fact, in  batting practice and in one game, he gives me the  impression of being a poor hitter. If player limit  presses, then give him an unconditional release.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc -- Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: April 22, 1963  Houston, Texas  St. Louis vs Houston    LILLIS, BOB (Houston Infielder)    You have to like Lillis. He gives you all  he's got and has high intelligence, great spirit,  good arm, fair runner, not much power at bat and not  a high percentage hitter. St. Louis should not take   him in any deal. He could be carried by a pennant  winner but not safely in the first line.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: August 10, 1963  Billings, Montana    LIMKE, DICK     Right hander, with a fine delivery. About  6'2" tall, 185 pounds, good fast ball. Unless he  is emotionally unstable, the boy has fine control.  Curve ball has a change of speed effect and he has  very good control of it. This chap should have no  trouble with control, - none at all.     Far advanced on his first workout. It would  be highly desirable, if management can find a chance to  do it, - to pitch him as much as possible the rest of  the year.     I would like to see Ron Plaza's written  report at the end of the season. It is possible that  this boy should be invited to the fall instruction  camp. It really depends upon Ron Plaza's report.     I like Limke, - on a first and only workout.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    LINDSEY, BEE    Right hand hitting outfielder. He looks   good and does nothing. I don't believe he will   ever hit for extra bases and I doubt if he is a   percentage hitter in the small minors. He would not   be drafted anywhere.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    LINZ, PHIL (New York Yankee Infielder)    I think Linz (right hand hitting infielder)   is a major leaguer. Young fellow, good size, but slim.   Doubtful power but prospectively a major league ball   player. I wish the Cards owned his contract.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  July 16, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs. Senators    LOCK, DON (Washington Outfielder)    Right hand hitter. Good form at the plate.   The bat is well back. Should be a power hitter. Runs   average. A hard ball to Lock in center field on the   ground, - this fellow played it with one hand. He must   not give a damn.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    LONG, DALE    No interest.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: March 10, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.    LONG, JEFF    Looks the same as last Fall in winter league   play. Strong, has power, no hit. Bat and ball never   get together except in practice. He mystifies me.   Surely he should become a good percentage hitter, and,   if so, with unusual power.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: New York , N. Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    LOPEZ, HECTOR (New York Yankee Outfielder)    As bad as we need outfielders, he would not be   the man I am looking for. Fair hitter, with power.   Right hander all the way. Well past thirty. No go.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: September 3, 1963  Minneapolis, Minn.  Minnesota vs Kansas City    LUMPE, JERRY (Kansas City Infielder)    Infielder, 30 years old. Left hand hitter,   averaging through the years about 40% extra base   hitting. Not above average runner, good fielder.   Bears good reputation as a team man. Would not   hurt any good club. Very definitely cannot hit,   run, throw, or field with Boyer.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: July 23, 1963  Toronto, Canada  Toronto versus Atlanta    KAZANSKI, TED (Toronto Infielder)    Pretty good looking ball player. Right   hand hitter and on the basis of form, he should hit.   Fair runner, good arm, good size, and would be a   corking man for Atlanta in 1964.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: September 4, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Kansas City    LUMPE, JERRY (Kansas City Infielder)    Lumpe is a good ball player, - thirty years  of age. I happen to know that the Los Angeles Dodgers  want him very much and will give a high price. If  St. Louis could make a deal for Lumpe, we might get  a pitcher from the Dodgers. Lumpe is not  hustling over much for Kansas City. Doesn't run hard  on apparent put outs.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: July 30, 1963  Brunswick, Ga.     KELLEY, WILLIAM A.     Tall boy, 6'2", 180 pounds, right hander   from Rogersville, Alabama. No speed. Rotation   not fast and about three-quarters. Control of fast   ball excellent.     Change of pace off his fast ball is very good.   Follow through repeats, angle of delivery repeats,   and change in timing very good. Curve ball in   itself has the effect of a change of speed. Probably   good control of everything.     Right now a doubtful pitcher in Class D. Just   without a lot of stuff.     Aptitude test on change up off curve ball very   bad. I don't believe the boy has any aptitude. A   very doubtful prospect on the basis of a sideline   showing. "Pitchers can fool you" - no doubt about   it, but if I had to be pushed off the boat or give a   decision, it would be that this boy will never be in   the major leagues.     He got $3500 to sign a contract. With one   workout from me, he would not get $35.00.     BRANCH RICKEY     cc- Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo      KERNEK, GEORGE     A well built, left hand hitting first baseman  who is not ready for advancement. Good size, shows  no power. A pretty good hitter and might eventually  go the the majors. I would let him go to draft at  Atlanta.       BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: July 24, 1963  Cleveland, Ohio  Cleveland vs. Minnesota        KILLEBREW, HARMON (Minnesota Outfielder)       A big right hand hitter with as much distance power  as any man in the game. Strikes out a great deal. I  would not be interested in obtaining his contract in any kind  of a possible trade. I don't want him at the price.       BRANCH RICKEY           cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: New York, N. Y.   July 26, 1963   NewYork Yankees vs. Minnesota  KILLEBREW, HARMON      The high hard inside pitch he misses. I   wonder if he every hits it. Change ups take away his   power.       BRANCH RICKEY     cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    KIRKLAND, WILLIE    A left hand hitting Negro outfielder. Can   run, strikes out, weak against left hand pitching,   very weak. Having in mind our set-up in St. Louis,   I would not take this fellow on the waiver price.   However, not too old, - about thirty.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: Dal Maxvill  A puney hitter and I mean just that.  I hate to say it, but he has almost no power whatever as a  major league batter. If he were to play 162 games with the Cardinals  in 1963, I don't believe he would have 10% of power on the basis of  figuring power with only [a] the number of base hits and the extra base  hits involved. The slugging percentage in the book doesn't give  at all any sort of accurate judgment on power. The book relates  the extra hits to the number of times at bat. In order to get  accuracy on sheer power, the extra hits must be related to the  number of hits. I repeat that on this basis that Dal would not  exceed 10%.  He is a righthand hitter. I have turned him over to the left  side and he gets the bat and the ball together very well. I believe  his batting percentage lefthanded against righthand pitching would be  just as high this coming season as his righthand hitting will be   against lefthand pitching.  I strongly suggest that wherever he [is] may be he should be urged to   bat from both sides of the plate.  I do not believe this boy has an outside chance to help the  Cardinal Baseball Club to advance in [his] its potential position in the  1963 campaign.  I understand full well this player's unusual intelligence. [and]  His apparent power of self analysis plus his industry might fool me and  he might become a pest hitter, although fairly limited to singles.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: March 14, 1963      MAXVILL, DALE    This boy is very surely a fine fielder and an  average runner. He is as quick as a cat, alert as a  fox, but most certainly he has no power.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: March 26, 1963        MAXVILL    [Mechanically] Fielding O.K., arm quick and accurate. [Adequate,]  [but] Not a Boyer arm.      25 Maxvills' will finish in the second division,  but he could be carried by any  contending club - pennant-bound

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)          McBRIDE, KEN (Los Angeles Angels Pitcher)    Corking pitcher on record and general  reputation. Good speed, good curve, - pretty good  control in games I have seen him. An effective  pitcher. Makes good hitters look bad. This 27  year old right hander is desirable. He shows poise  and command.    BRANCH RICKEY          cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: March 15, 1963        McCARVER, TIM    Does not know how to "body check."    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: March 26, 1963        MC CARVER, TIM    Arm adequate - good enough. Better than  Oliver's. I think he will hit .250 or better and  with more power than he has shown heretofore.          BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: March 26, 1963          Tom MC CARVER      Arm adequate - good enough. Better than Oliver's.  I think he will hit 250 or better  and with more power than he  has shown heretofore.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: August 6, 1963  New York, N. Y.  St. Louis vs New York Mets        McCARVER, TIMMY    25 McCarvers' will win every pennant in the  National League, year in and year out.      BRANCH RICKEY            cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  July 16, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs. Senators        McCRAW (Chicago First Baseman)      Colored boy. Well built, 6' tall, left hand  hitter. Looks like a power hitter but a striker-outer.  He is a good runner.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago        McDANIEL, LINDY (Chicago Pitcher)      27 year old, right hand pitcher on Chicago.  He joins Face in relief work.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: August 10, 1963  Billings, Montana    MAJOR, TOM    6'1" tall, weight about 175 pounds, right hander. Speed enough, a 'roundhouse curve' - no quick break. Not adequate, but usable. Keep it. He must have a third usable pitch. I believe he can get a change up on his curve ball. He should practice it at not more than 30'. He has a change up on his fast ball. Direction of rotation is not directly back toward him. It is a crooked pitch. It does not change speed. It is usable if he has control. I believe he can get, without too much time, a change up on the curve ball. Aptitude is medium. Desire is good.    He has never tried a slider. Has never tried a knuckle ball. He should try both.    He must get a usable third pitch.    Not a candidate for the Instruction Camp this fall. His challenge is simply in the field of control.    His finger manipulation is perfect. Angle of delivery and finger placement repeat.    In Tom's case, it is a matter of intent and concentration. His physical set up should give him control. He must become a spot pitcher.    Right now, nobody can tell [you] how far he can go or whether he could go or not.    This boy is late starting on intensive work in getting any control but it is my judgment that he has to start right there.    He has an experience of a sore arm on the point of the shoulder, probably due to over pitching or perhaps press pitching or to the change in the angle of delivery. Right now his delivery is free and smooth and his step and follow through satisfactory. I know of no reason why the boy cannot come to be a control pitcher. If he has a recurring ailment on the shoulder, he should baby it, - stop short of pain always. I don't know this boy's future. I don't think anybody knows.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: August 1, 1963  Brunswick, Ga.  Brunswick vs Thomasville          McNAMEE, BILL (Brunswick Pitcher)      Left hander, - four years of professional  experience. Fair fast ball, good curve, - threw  nothing else.    He has just come out of the army. However,  I don't believe he is major league bound.        BRANCH RICKEY          cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: August 10, 1963  Billings, Montana  Billings vs Boise          MEISCHNER, OTTO    A big right hand pitcher with a good curve  ball, 22 years of age. Got good stuff, poor control.  Class A batters wouldn't hurt him. If he is completely  sound at the end of the season, I think he should come  to the Florida Instruction Camp this fall.      BRANCH RICKEY          cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; F-L
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 2, 1963  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee          MENKE, DENIS (Milwaukee Infielder)      I find no record of him as a runner or as  a hitter. He is a big boy with a good arm and has  power at the plate. Observation in three games  leaves me with a very favorable impression. He is  an all-around athlete. Looks like he can play  anywhere. I like this player.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota          MINCHER, DON (Minnesota First Baseman)      A fine looking ball player, - left hand hitter.  He made to or three plays at first base in the game at  Cleveland this evening that were very exceptional.  He looked great as a fielder, and he has power to his  own field. I liked everything about him on my first  impression. Not below average runner.      BRANCH RICKEY        cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 26, 1963  New York Yankees vs. Minnesota            MINCHER, DON (Minnesota First Baseman)        Change ups bother him badly. He may get over  it but it is his greatest weakness right now. He  takes the slow ball or swings on it weakly. Apparently  the league knows this weakness. The pitch in varied  forms was given to him repeatedly in the three successive  games I saw.        BRANCH RICKEY          cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: March 23, 1963    MINOSO    In my judgment, Minoso is just as good a player  as when St. Louis got him from Chicago in exchange for  Cunningham. He can still run and he can still throw, -  and if we should adopt the policy for this season of  "pennant or bust", then I would not dispose of Minoso  at the present time. Wait and see! June 15th will  give a better price.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: March 23, 1963          MINOSO        In my judgment, Minoso is just as good a player as  when St. Louis got him from Chicago in exchange for Cunningham.  He can still run and he can still throw, - and if we should  adopt the policy for this season of "pennant or bust", then  [I believe Minoso should be retained on this club.]  I would not dispose of  Minoso at the present time -  [give] wait & See! June 15 will  give a better price x

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Tuesday, Forenoon,  April 2, 1963  St. Petersburg, Florida    MINOSO, MINNIE    The Mets are interested, so is Houston, but  neither club is ready to deal right now. I told  Bing that in view of Johnny Keane's dislike of the  player the deal with Washington would have to be made,  although I still felt, I told him, that the market  would show a high cash value before June 15th than it  does now. The purchase of Burke compels the apparent  reduction of another player and under the circumstances  I suppose it has to be Minoso. Therefore the deal  with Washington will probably be concluded any day.  Of all the old 'spavs' who are not calculated, in my  opinion, to win a pennant for St. Louis, Minoso comes  the nearest qualifying for retention. Good-bye Minoso.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: July 31, 1963  Brunswick, Ga.            MISCISCO, DANIEL (Brunswick Pitcher)      Left hander, weight 170 pounds, 5'10"  tall. Could easily weigh 200 pounds. He has to  watch his weight closely. This boy has perfect  habits. I hope to God he keeps them. He is a   perfectionist. He can learn anything simply by  being told. He should not try to pitch the new   change of pace curve ball this year. He might do  it, but he might get a sore arm out of it.  George Kissell should see to it that the boy never  practices this new change of pace curve over the  40' distance this year. That is very important.    He has a good curve ball and he has a  change off this curve ball of his own, but there isn't  enough difference in velocity between the two  pitches. He has control of his alleged change of  speed curve. He steps the same all the time and  he has more aptitude than any boy I have worked  out on the Brunswick club. He gets the idea  instantly and can put it into effect. In my book,  this chap is a definite prospect. Might become  a Spahn. He is that type, - intelligent-wise  and aptitude-wise. I like him.    My final advice on this chap to his manager  now and in the future and organization-wise is to  watch his weight. I think he could pitch at 164  pounds better than at 175 pounds. He is leggy.  An only child and for all the tea in China comes from  a good family. I congratulate whoever found him.      BRANCH RICKEY        cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: August 2, 1963  Brunswick, Ga.          MISCISCO, DAN      He can't run but he is quick. He is a  pitcher right now, - not a thrower. He has both  intelligence and guts. He could probably pitch  upstairs effectively in 1964. If he had great  spped or say sufficient spped, this chap could be  a quickie for the majors. It may be that he does  not have enough speed to ever make it. He should be  given a very thorough trial as a pitcher.        BRANCH RICKEY          cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
