Transcription: April 13, 1965  St. Louis vs. Phillies    MAHAFFEY, ART (Philadelphia Pitcher)    Pitcher Mahaffey has stuff, plenty of it. He makes balks, plenty of them too. Managers, coaches, and players should be prompt, loud, and persistent in calling attention to umpires on Mahaffey's failure to hold long enough.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: September 5, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Kansas City          MONTEAGUDO, AURELIO BING    He has a lot of speed, and apparently great  control. He threw 12 successive fast balls almost  exactly one foot over the batters' heads. He  may have a curve ball. He never threw any. Showed  more speed than any pitcher I have seen in the  American League, including Drabowsky. Very nervous  boy. First appearance in the major league.        BRANCH RICKEY          cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: August 9, 1963  Billings, Montana        MONTGOMERY, FRANK      Slim boy, about 6'1" tall, and will weigh  170 pounds. Left hander. I believe the boy has  enough speed to go places. He has a curve ball. He  has a change-up on his fast ball. It is my opinion that  he does not have control of anything. He has physical  control of the ball - almost perfect. If you place a  baseball in the middle of home plate, I will enter this  chap as a favorable candidate to hit that ball on a  given number of pitches against any young pitcher you  may name. He has arm control, - very good. There  isn't any way to estimate his future because of his  lack of control and it is something that he can get, -  if he wants to enough. He should practice spot  pitching constantly with every pitch he has.    He is a one legged pitcher. That is not  really bad but it is not really good. When he delivers  any pitch, his right leg is straight up and his body  straight up also. The left leg has been attached to his  body from birth but he just lets it dangle. It hardly  comes down to the ground. He must come to know that he  cannot do anything with the ball after it leaves his hand.  At that instant, he must sense that he is now a fielder.  That will give him a new position.    I think this boy has three pitches. I don't  believe he is a 'quickie', - meaning that I don't think  he will come to the majors in one year, but the  organization should not quit on him. It is my judgment  that he will walk a lot of men in professional baseball  and he will do it for another year, - maybe two.    An intelligent boy, good habits, good  background. Lacks one semester from graduation at  Mississippi State at Starkville. I don't believe this  boy can be helped over much by bringing him to the  Instruction Camp this fall in Florida. He knows what  he has to do to become a pitcher.        BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: June 17, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs N. Y. Mets          MORAN (New York Mets Infielder)      I would never accept him as a throw in in any  deal. With me, he is second division from top to toe.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: August 6, 1963  New York, N.Y.  St. Louis vs New York Mets    MORAN, AL (New York Mets Infielder)    Right hand hitting infielder. In thinking,   throwing, running, and hitting, a good minor league   ball player. 25 Morans' would finish in last place.   He would probably do a good job at Atlanta.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: New York, N.Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    MORAN, BILLY (Los Angeles Angels Infielder)    Highly regarded in the American League.   Right hand hitting infielder. About thirty years old.   Six or seven years ago, I didn't think Moran was a major   league prospect. At that time, I didn't regard him   as a power hitter at all, but he has developed into   a pretty good hitter and about 40% power. Plays   everywhere and is smart. He is not the type for   St. Louis to deal for in any winter trade. 25 Morans'   would never win a pennant.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 29, 1963  Brunswick vs Moultrie    MURRAY, CHARLIE (Moultrie Outfielder)    Murray is completely unacquainted with a left hander's curve ball. He might get acquainted with it some day, in which case he might be quite a player.     Just about the most helpless man I have ever seen against left hand pitching. He couldn't make good on the Lucasville High School team if all pitchers were left handed.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: St. Louis vs. Chicago  Sarasota, Fla.  March 25, 1963    MUSIAL, STAN    There isn't any doubt about Stan's hitting ability. He can still hit, but I don't believe he can hit as he formerly did, either percentage-wise or power-wise. The dismal unwelcome fact is that he cannot run a lick. I am trying to think of someone in baseball today as slow a runner as Musial. I simply cannot think of anyone.    I regret the candid necessity of saying that I believe that Carmel or James or Kolb in left field will win more games for St. Louis in 1963 than Musial. Furthermore, the public will tearfully agree to this last statement before the year is over if Stanley continues to play as a regular left fielder.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: St. Louis vs. Chicago  Sarasota, Fla.  March 25, 1963    STAN MUSIAL    There isn't any doubt about Stan's hitting ability.   He can still hit, but I don't believe he can hit as he formerly   did, either percentage-wise or power-wise. The dismal unwelcome   fact is that he cannot run a lick. I am trying to think of   someone in baseball today as slow a runner as Musial. I   simply cannot think of anyone.    I regret the candid necessity of saying that I   believe that Carmel [and] or James or Kolb [alternating] in left field will   win more games for St. Louis in 1963 than Musial. [Frankly,   I believe that James in left field and playing regularly   will do us more good than Stanley.] Furthermore, the public   will tearfully agree to this last statement before the year   is over if Stanley continues to play as a regular left fielder.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: April 16, 1963  St. Louis vs Pittsburgh    MUSIAL, STAN    Read my spring training reports. The possibilities not only become probabilities but the probabilities have already become history.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: April 25, 1963  San Francisco, California  St. Louis vs San Francisco    Musial, Stan    In the seventh inning of the game today in San Francisco, with two men on, he gave them a run. Didn't reach the ball in time to make a quick throw and even then the runner outran the ball. Positively looked helpless at the plate. Struck out twice against a right hander and then popped up to the first baseman in the ninth inning.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    MAJTYKA, ROY    A very average runner. A good arm, not great. Plays equally as well at second, third, or short. A very useful utility man in AAA. I would not bring him to the major league roster at all. If somebody wants to draft him at Atlanta, o.k. He won't be drafted.     I would call him a money player, - good when the chips are down, - either in the field or at bat. A desirable organization man. I know him.     BRANCH RICKEY     cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 8, 1963  St. Louis vs Los Angeles    MUSIAL, STANLEY    In the seventh inning withone out, Howard hit a fly ball to left field. Groat could have easily caught the ball and should have got it. However, Musial took it. Tommie Davis scored easily standing up. It was a gift run.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: May 18, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    MUSIAL, STANLEY    With Spencer the first man up in the third inning against Cincinnati, he delayed on a fly ball to left field. It was a really high fly ball. Musial didn't come within 10' of it. Spencer scored. The ball would have been caught by any average running outfielder.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: August 6, 1963  New York, N.Y.  New York Mets vs. St. Louis    MUSIAL, STAN    John continues to play Musial. The Mets run in the first inning was due to Musial's weak arm on the throw to third. He can't run, he can't field, and he can't throw. 25 Musials' would finish in last place, below the Mets.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: June 17, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs N. Y. Mets    NEAL, CHARLES    Looks like he is through. Plays indifferently Don't take him in any deal.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: March 19, 1963    NEEMAN, CAL    An old player, good arm, fair runner, and a good catcher. No hit. A gentle man.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: August 10, 1963  Billings, Montana  Billings vs Boise    NEWCOMER, JACK    Right hand hitter. Not a power hitter and a pretty good runner. Arm very good. He would have to become a minor league .300 hitter to go major.     This player should be discussed in the fall meeting. More extended observation should control. It might be advantageous to have this boy go to the fall camp in Florida.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.   July 30, 1963    NEWTON, DOIN     Twenty one year old left hander from West  Plains, Missouri. Has two children. Fair speed, -   not [a great fast ball]. Has a very good curve ball  and he has a change up on this fast ball that is very  good, - and apparently good control of all three  pitches.   I think this boy has unusual aptitude. He  can learn to do something with the ball simply from  conversation. I believe he can acquire very   quickly a change up on his curve ball. This additional  pitch frequently causes lame arms but not if it is  learned at not to exceed thirty feet. This boy might   be a good pitcher. I would hold him.       BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois   July 16, 1963   Chicago White Sox vs. Senators      NICHOLSON, DAVE (Chicago Outfielder)     Big fellow, - lot of power. Doesn't know how   to throw from the outfield.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: September 2, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Los Angeles    NICHOLSON, DAVE (White Sox Outfielder)     A very big right hand hitting outfielder.   A completely bewilldered batsman. If the ball is  pitched where he is swinging, fences make no difference.  He has power. If properly pitched to by an ordinary   major league pitcher with control, this batsman should  not hit over .100.    He handles himself very clumsily in the outfield  in the several games I saw him and indifferently in the   fielding practices.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing DeVine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: September 5, 1963   Chicago, Illinois   Chicago White Sox vs. Kansas City    NICHOLSON, DAVE (Kansas City Outfielder)     I do not understand how Manager Lopez  can keep Nicholson in his regular lineup. Doesn't  look like a good outfielder, average arm, below   average runner. 25 Nicholsons on the same club  would finish last in any good minor league.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 2, 1963  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee    MATHEWS, EDDIE    Left hand hitting third baseman with Milwaukee is unpredictable. He can look very bad against a certain pitcher and will slump for a period of several games. He will look bad on changes of speed and then wallop a slow ball out of the park. He is simply a good percentage batsman with a great power. Not at all effective against left handers as he is against right handers. Not now in any possible market and not likely that he ever will be. Not a base stealer.     BRANCH RICKEY.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio   May 3, 1963   St. Louis vs Cincinnati    NUXHALL, JOE (Cincinnati Pitcher)     Left handed Cincinnati pitcher. Fine  control, good stuff. To Burke and Groat and the  other boys who stand too far from the plate, he  pitched with great consistency on the outside and  with complete effect.   It has been many a day since I have seen  any pitcher with finer spot control. More than that,  he knew why/where he wanted to throw it. I don't   believe there were more than three or four pitches  from Nuxhall in the entire game above the waistline.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: April 13, 1963  St. Louis vs. Phillies    OLDIS, BOB (Philadelphia Catcher)    I've known this boy for several years. He is one of the best receivers in the game. Not an accurate thrower and in my opinion never has been. I say this regardless of his reputation as a fine defensive catcher.     A very ordinary hitter in any league and a double play runner.     Under no circumstances would I take Oldis in a deal.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: March 26, 1963    OLIVER, GENE    Unless his arm is sore, he does not have a strong arm.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: April 2, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.    OLIVER, GENE    Catcher Oliver must have an ailing arm. He   cannot throw a ball hard, and this ailment, whatever it is,  may effect his apparent inability to throw the ball  overhand. Invariably on practically every throw, - even  the toss back to the pitcher, is from a little above a  three-quarters delivery. He is not a quick thrower.  Very deliberate. With Broglio pitching, any average  speed runner, with an ordinary lead and break, should be  able to steal second. If Oliver's arm is sound, then he  cannot throw.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: April 11, 1963  St. Louis vs Mets    OLIVER, GENE    What is the purpose of objective of a catcher  backing up first base on balls hit to the infield?  The answer, in all cases, is the retrieve a wild throw.   Well, if the purpose is worthy, if really it pays to   retrieve, then the retrieving should be done correctly  and with energy and without handicap.    Why catchers back up bases and particularly  first base with a mask on, I don't know. What protection does a mask give a catcher 40 [ ] in back of first base when he is chasing a wild ball? What  obstruction is it that can hit him in the face on  such an occasion? Nevertheless, Oliver invariably  runs all over the place with his mask still on. I am  so glad that he doesn't stop to pick up the hitter's   bat and carry it along as an extra handicap.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: April 20, 1963  Philadelphia, Pa.  St. Louis vs. Philadelphia      DEMETER scored in the fifth inning from first  base on Siever's hit to left field. The retrieving was  deliberate, but Boyer's realy throw was 15' ahead of the  runner who slid into home and apparently kicked the  ball out of OLIVER's hand to the wall. It was most  certainly a gift run.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: April 25, 1963  San Francisco, California  St. Louis vs San Francisco    OLIVER, GENE    Positively will not or doesn't know how to  body check a low pitched ball. He plays every dirt  pitch as if he were a shortstop. He looked helpless  with a bat in his hands. Struck out three times.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: May 25, 1963    OLIVER, GENE    Everyone says that Oliver's arm has improved. I believe it has improved, but it is very far from being a strong arm, and he cannot throw even at short distances. He actually threw out Kranepool at second on a questionable decision. The ball was 9 feet high and 'Andy over'.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: March 19, 1963    OLIVO, DIOMEDES    42 years of age. 22 years of age in strength   and stuff. Has pitching savvy and fine team attitude.   A game saver and a morale builder. Good for two or three   more years. Maybe.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Afternoon, April 19, 1963  Warwick Hotel  Philadelphia, Pa.    OLIVO   I was strong for the inclusion of Olivo in the recent Pittsburg-St. Louis deal. However, this 45 year old very pleasant gentleman is bound to reach the precipice of his value sooner or later and probably sooner. In yesterday's game, he had nothing at all. There should be close observation to discover deterioration well in advance of the time when his record of the year proves it. If Olivo fails to impress us the next two relief days, it could well be that he should be one of the three to be disposed of not later than May 7, 1963.   Over indulged sentiment is the most insidious disease a manager can have, and that statement is to be given careful consideration when closely examining the work of players on the Cardinal club other than Olivo.   Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    MATHEWS, NELSON (Chicago Outfielder)    A 6'4" right hand hitting outfielder, 21  years of age. Has power. Very desirable.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  July 16, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs. Senators  OSBORNE, LARRY (Washington First Baseman)   Below average runner. Left hand hitter, almost and over-strider. I might want him at Tulsa. He can be pitched to by anybody with a variety of pitches. Against good pitching in the major league, I would call Osborne a .240 or .250 hitter, but of no interest to St. Louis in any kind of a deal.   Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: September 2, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Los Angeles    OSINSKI, DANIEL (Los Angeles Pitcher)    Right hander, thirty year old. Fast ball   looked pretty good. Curve ball went everywhere. He   does not have the stuff that the Cardinals need to win   a pennant.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  July 16, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs. Senators    OSTEEN, CLAUDE (Washington Pitcher)    Left hand pitcher with Washington.   Unimpressive. Fair fast ball, fair curve. Run of the   mine.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Bismark-Mandan vs Winnipeg    MAY, RUDLOPH (Bismark-Mandan Fitcher)    Colored left hand pitcher with Bismark.  Belongs to the Twins. Good fast ball, and a good  straight downer. Showed courage and control.  I would guess him to be 6'2" tall, and will weigh  180 pounds. A very interesting rookie.    BRANCH RICKEY    Only 19 years of age. In any possible  trade with Minnesota, try to get this player.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: July 23, 1963    Toronto, Canada   Toronto vs Atlanta      MAXIE, LARRY (Toronto Pitcher)     Tall, 22 year old, right hand pitcher. A  very good fast ball and so-so curve. Threw several  change-ups off his fast ball with good effect. He  is not a major league pitcher right now. He is not  good holding men on. There is no question but that  this fellow could become a major leaguer.       BRANCH RICKEY          cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: March 26, 1963        MAXVILL, DAL    Fielding O.K., arm quick and accurate. Not  a Boyer arm.    25 Maxvills' will finish in the second division,  but he could be carried by any contending club - pennant-bound.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  September 5, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs Kansas City    PETERS, GARY (White Sox Pitcher)    Left hand pitcher with Chicago. Fairly good fast ball and a darn good curve. Showed good control. A rookie. He is a major league pitcher.    Stands up to the plate well. Actually looks like a good hitter.    This chap is a pitcher, not a thrower. He is a good fielder of his position. He is a fine athlete.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: September 2, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Los Angeles    PHILLIPS, (White Sox Pitcher)    Saw him only in two innings. Showed nothing, including control.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: August 10, 1963  Billings, Montana  Billings vs Boise    PIERTRI, WAYNE    Injured foot but saw him in one game. Played first base. Switch hitter. Looked very good left handed. This boy should be invited to the fall camp in Florida. Has some power. High class gentleman.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: St. Louis, Mo.  May 18, 1963  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    PINSON, VEDA (Cincinnati Outfielder)    I don't think Pinson is a good hitter at all against the left hander's curve ball and if any left hander would come sidearm, Pinson is at the water bucket. He doesn't have any liking for the fast ball in tight or the curve ball away from him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  July 16, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs. Senators    PIZARRO, JUAN (Chicago Pitcher)    Tall colored boy, and a great curve ball and fine speed, - as good as they come. Has a good change up on his curve ball but seldom uses it. Doesn't have to.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: March 15, 1963    PLASKETT, ELMO (Pittsburgh)    This boy may not be a great receiver, but he is much improved. He can throw and brother he has plenty of power at the plate. He would help the St. Louis club very much.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  July 16, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs Senators    PIZARRO, JUAN (Chicago Pitcher)    Tall colored boy, and a great curve ball and fine speed, - as good as they come. Has a good change up on his curve ball but seldom uses it. Doesn't have to.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: August 10, 1963  Billings, Montana  Billings vs Boise    POLITTE, CLIFF    Tall, left hand pitcher, - fourth year in professional baseball. A good fast ball and a good curve. He made only one impression on me in the one game I saw him - a few innings, - he pitches in the general direction of North. The strike zone is anything the catcher can reach. He might become a good pitcher someday. He is now 22. He COULD go major before he is 30. He could.    He does not act, look, or speak like a man with very much sense. If he ever gets control, he would surely be a fine pitcher.    He has enough stuff to merit invitation to the Florida fall Instruction Camp.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: September 3, 1963  Minneapolis, Minn.    POST, WALLY (Minnesota Outfielder)    Forget him.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: September 3, 1963  Minneapolis, Minn.  Minnesota vs Kansas City    POWERS, VIC (Minnesota First Baseman)    Good fielder, graceful, quick, - and alert. Unpredictable hitter, - looks bad on a pitch and then hits the same one out of the park.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 29, 1963  Brunswick vs Moultrie    PALKO, BILL (Moultrie Pitcher)    Right hand pitcher. Looks about 19 years of age. Good fast ball, and his curve ball has fine speed. Has excellent movement holding men on first base. His quick throw to catch men off first is the best I have seen in the major or minor leagues this year. Follows his pitch. Should be a good fielder.    The Brunswick batsmen were so tender and rookie-ish they could not help me to judge the pitcher's stuff. However, Palko impressed me as a very definite prospect.    If and when, if ever, he gets control, this boy will be quite the pitcher. I would like to have him. He is a 'press' pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: September 5, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Kansas City    RAKOW, ED (Kansas City Pitcher)    Very unimpressive to me in every way. Some baseball men regard Rakow very highly. I would rate him as "the run of the mine". I would not claim him on waivers.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Winnipeg vs Bismark-Mandan    REESE, DICK (Bismark-Mandan First Baseman)    Left hand hitter, - looks like a corking good hitter and with power. Very aggressive.    Any kind of a deal with Minnesota should have in mind inclusion, if possible, of first baseman Reese and pitcher May.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: September 6, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    RICHARDSON, GORDON (Tulsa Pitcher)    Let him go to draft.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; M-O
Transcription: March 30, 1963  Hollywood, Florida  Atlanta vs. Richmond    RICKETTS, DAVE    Turn over hitter, - colored. Catcher. Perfect form at the plate left handed and should hit right hand pitching plenty.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: July 23, 1963  Toronto, Canada  Toronto vs Atlanta    RICKETTS, DAVE    Colored boy, catcher, 6'2" tall. Hits right and left. Wears glasses. Can throw. Looks like a good receiver. Can't run. Not a power hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: September 11, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana  Indianapolis vs Atlanta    RICKETTS, DAVE    A tall, 26 year old, ambitious colored catcher. Switch hitter. Quick arm, fairly strong, but not great. Ricketts is not at all a power hitter (about 30% in AAA) but he is not a striker-outer either. If Kolb becomes a regular on the Cardinal club (and he should), he can become sufficiently good as a catcher to fill in quickly as an emergency catcher, in which case, I would recommend Ricketts as second string catcher to McCarver and go with the two catchers at the start of the 1964 season. This move would enable the Cardinal club to take on additional bench strength in other positions.    Harry Walker is especially strong on catcher Coker. If this player can be secured at a fairly nominal cost, then o.k. Ricketts could then be optioned again on a quick recall.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc. - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    RODGERS, ANDRE (Chicago Infielder)    Infielder. Right hand hitter. He can throw and he can run. Power so-so, say between 30% and 35%. Improved fielder. Not an adventurous runner. Takes no lead and gets no break. About 28 years old. I consider him a good hitter, close to .300    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    RODGERS, BOB (Los Angeles Catcher)    This boy looks great in every way. He is a big fellow - comes from Delaware, Ohio. Should become a corking good hitter. He can throw and has very good action for a two hundred pound youngster. He hits right and left and looks dangerous with power on either side. Highly desirable. Would go the route to get him.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    ROLLINS, RICH (Minnesota Infielder)    A well built infielder, a young fellow, with not above average running speed. Good arm, ought to hit. I believe he will. I would rate him about a 40% power hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: September 3, 1963  Minneapolis, Minn.  Minnesota vs Kansas City    ROLLINS, RICH (Minnesota Third Baseman)    Rollins has almost perfect form at the plate, - in every respect. He is not a puny hitter but you would not call him a power hitter. Desirable in any trade, but hardly available.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: September 3, 1963  Minneapolis, Minn.  Minnesota vs Kansas City    PASCUAL, CAMILO (Minnesota Pitcher)    With a man on first base, he has a completely waster preliminary movement on every pitch. Can't hold men on at all.    Change up on his fast ball is very effective. Corking curve. Got all kinds of stuff.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota    ROMANO, JOHN (Cleveland Catcher)    Right hand hitter with power. A major leaguer. About thirty years of age. Desirable.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 31, 1963    ROMEO, MIKE (Brunswick Pitcher)    Tall boy, 19 years old, left hander. Could become a corker in holding men on base. Fast ball fair enough. Curve ball fair enough. Has a change up possibly very good off his fast ball. Needs a lot of work. You can't throw this boy in the waste basket. He has to be seen further.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: May 2, 1963  Cincinnati, Ohio  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee    ROSE, PETE (Cincinnati Infielder)    A fine fielder in every way. A good runner, a good arm, and has good power. Percentage hitting yet to be determined.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: March 19, 1963    SADECKI, RAY    Several National League clubs are high on this fellow. His attitude toward this club could be his secret handicap to his rendering capacity service. I do not care to have an opinion until I know him better. Undoubtedly a major league pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 4, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.    SADECKI, RAY    Because of his late reporting and lack of condition, I have delayed passing my opionon on this player. I have now seen him in four games.    I believe he is a major leaguer right now. He is a pitcher not a thrower. His fast ball is good enough and his curve ball is better. He has change ups.    With a runner on first, his right knee movement is good, putting him in a heads-I-win-tails-you-lose position as against the base runner. Until I saw him throw to first base off this movement, I was not sure that he was not handicapping himself with an unnecessarily slow delivery. I don't think any runner can get a break on Sadecki, - and he should not hesitate to throw fairly often to his first baseman. No one should talk to him about his move or even mention it other than complimentarily. Let him alone.    If Ray were to become a scholarly student of batsmen, (like Shantz for example or indeed most of the great pitchers) he might become a really GREAT pitcher.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 20, 1963  Philadelphia, Pa.  St. Louis vs Philadelphia    Manager Gene Mauch had quite a talk with home plate umpire Chris Pelekoudas, - demonstrating SADECKI'S knee action when pitching with a runner on first base. Pelekoudas agreed with Mauch and during the game acted as though he wanted to call a balk on every pitch. He struck poses, squarely looking at the first base umpire, acting with disgust that the first base umpire didn't call the balk. Sadecki's move is perfectly legitimate in every respect.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 20, 1963  Philadelphia, Pa.  St. Louis vs. Philadelphia    SADECKI, RAY    He has a fine change-up and I think he should use it more than he does. He should be counseled to use this change-up more than he does with particular emphasis on keeping it low. When he does use it, it is frequently above the waistline.    I don't believe SADECKI is a set-up at the plate. He really tries to hit    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    SADECKI, RAY    Is about as much a high ball pitcher as Bauta is a low ball pitcher, and in respect to pitching policy, I prefer Bauta. Sadecki has a good fast ball and a good curve. he needs a third pitch that he can and will use. I believe he does have a good change of speed pitch but he may not have control of it. In any event, he very seldom uses a change up, and the very few I have seen him throw were not controlled. I call him a thrower at the present time, - not a pitcher.    He would be a great pitcher in high school circles. He should be a good pitcher in the majors. Unless I miss my guess, he is not really smart.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: May 18, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    SADECKI, RAY    In the fourth inning against Cincinnati with Robinson at bat, Sadecki thew two change ups, both off the fast ball. One of the change ups was called a strike. Then he struck Robinson out on a low outside fast ball. This pitcher has a good change up. I mean it has deceptive velocity with identical fast ball delivery. Millikan agrees with me that his change up is an effective pitch, but that he seldom gets it over. This would explain why he seldom uses it. In other words, he doesn't have a usable third pitch.    I have said on several occasions that Sadecki had a great move to first base. Well, he does have if he would use it. He raises his left leg with a very slight pause in pitching to the plate. If with that same pause, he would throw to first, he would catch many men off and no one could get a break. However, I now observe that when he does throw to first base, he raises the leg in a complete 'tip=off' and the runner is standing on first base when Sadecki throws the ball. In other words, when Sadecki intends to throw to first, he actually telegraphs it well ahead of time.    He must throw to first base of the same left leg move that he makes when he pitches home, otherwise the base runner acquainted with the facts of Sadecki's delivery, as I have outlined above, Sadecki would be easier to steal on that Broglio or any other pitcher on the Cardinal club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: May 25, 1963  St. Louis vs N. Y. Mets    SADECKI, RAY    In the first two innings against New York today, he threw several change of speed pitches and they were either a slow curve or a change up. He was very effective. I am still of the opinion that this boy has major league stuff and can win. he is a pressing pitcher when he gets in trouble. He simply tries to over power his way out of it. He has not yet learned the value of varying speeds in pitching. When this boy becomes 'veteranized' he will be a good pitcher.    He threw a run away by simply not sliding at the plate, - he came in straight up and touched himself out shoulder high. Absolutely inexcusable. I don't believe he was in a sliding pit during the entire spring training.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    PATTERSON, JOE    Let him go to draft where he is. Nobody will take him.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: August 8, 1963  New York, N. Y.  St. Louis vs New York Mets    SADECKI, RAY    Sadecki against the Mets in New York today had no speed, no curve, no control of change ups, - in fact, no nothing    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: March 18, 1963  Lakeland, Florida  St. Louis vs Detroit    SADOWSKI, BOB    Has pretty good stuff. He does not put batters on the defensive or bewilder anyone. I don't think he is ready to win right now on the Cardinal club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: March 19, 1963    SADOWSKI, BOB    Pitchers like this fellow can give early critics quite a surprise. I think his ear with the Cardinals in 1963 would be only so-so, - 50-50, if that. He would be a better pitcher for the Cardinals in 1964 if could establish a corking year in 1963 at Atlanta.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    SADOWSKI, ED (Los Angeles Angels Catcher)    Right hand hitting catcher. One of the Pittsburgh Sadowskis'. About 33 years of age. Of no interest to St. Louis.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: March 26, 1963  Clearwater, Fla.    Neither SADOWSKI OR BRANCH can help the Cardinal club in 1963.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 30, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs Milwaukee    SAMUEL, AMADO (Milwaukee Infielder)    Young infielder. Can run, has some power. Will probably be a turn-over hitter. Good information said a very fine prospect. Right hand hitter, ordinary power.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: July 23, 1963  Toronto, Canada  Toronto vs Atlanta    SAMUEL, AMADO    TALL, 6'1", right hand hitting shortstop on the Toronto club. (Negro) Has a good arm. Good medium runner. I would not call him a fast man at all. If I owned his contract, I would make hit hit left handed against all right hand pitching. I would be pleased to take him as a throw-in in any deal with Milwaukee.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    SANTO, RON (Chicago Infielder)    Chicago infielder, right hander, hot and cold. Wants to win. Fine arm. Played 604 innings in 1962. 60% power hitter. Not a base stealer, but who is? Desirable on any club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: August 6, 1963  New York, N. Y.  St. Louis vs New York Mets    SCHREIBER, TED (New York Mets Infielder)    Well built, good size, right hand hitting infielder. Stands well up to the plate and his batting form is good. He doesn't know the strike zone. He seems to be a take charge guy, - a self appointed captain.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    SCHULTZ, BARNEY (Chicago Pitcher)    35 year old, right hand pitcher with Chicago.   Strictly a relief pitcher. Pretty old to be   considered desirable for St. Louis and not very   highly impressive to me. Just so so.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Winnipeg vs Bismark-Mandan    PATTON, MEL    Let him go to draft.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Winnipeg vs Bismark-Mandan    SCOTT, VIC    The boy is quick and he has a fine arm. He is not afraid to throw. Looks good at the plate but   doesn't hit. He is eager and intelligent.    BRANCH RICKEY    He is a switch hitter and actually hit right handed against right hand pitching and at least once   hit left handed against left hand pitching. I don't believe he will be drafter because his percentage   record as a batsman is so bad. I like him.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 27, 1963  Cleveland vs Kansas City    SEGUI, DIEGO (Kansas City Pitcher)    A good fast ball and I believe a satisfactory curve, - not too sure about his control. Throws no changes. A Cuban but he looks colored to me. A right hander. Moves his right elbow back (when holding runners). Any smart base runner with average speed can steal. Very active boy in fielding his position. I think he can become a major league regular pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: March 19, 1963    SHANNON, MIKE    Doubtless he will be sent to Homestead.   Shannon is in the same boat with Lewis except that   Shannon is a white man,--walks about as if he were   both aggressive and independent. If anyone has been   able to know whether he can outrun this one or that one,   I don't know when that try-out took place. The   strength of arm is equally a mystery to me. Whether   he has aptitude to learn to slide skillfully, no one   knows as far as spring training is concerned.   Up to this date, the sad thing is not that Shannon will   doubtless go to Homestead, but the regretful part is that   no one knows WHY, that is to say, no spring trial or   experience has added dependable information,--good or   bad.    This simple conditioning program does work   out in so far as it enables the Groats', the Boyers',  and the Shantz', and a few others to get into good   physical condition. These boys are fixtures on this club   before they came to spring training.    But there are 30 unknowns in this camp and   the primary and most beneficial job is to determine with   as much exactitude as possible the comparative abilities   of these unknowns,--first for immediate service, and,   secondly, for future service. The Groats' el al take   care of themselves.    If you were to ask Lewis and Shannon what this   spring training meant to them, I really wonder what that   reply would be. Of course it is highly beneficial for   acquaintance. Do they leave this camp with more   confidence about their major league future, or less   confidence?    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 4, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.    SHANTZ, BOBBY    Bobby has three curve balls and I mean that each   is distinctive, it is different, and I believe he can   choose one of the three with different purpose. One is   a curve ball the same as any left hander has. Just a   curve ball and he can throw that curve ball with better   control than any other pitch he has including the fast   ball. He will also throw it when he in the hole or   indeed anytime he thinks the batsman is taking the pitch.    He then throws a looping change of pace curve, a   roly-poly trajectory that throws power hitters out of   gear.    Then he throws his strike out curve, - some speed   on it and a very quick break. He uses it on right   hand hitters and to strike out left handers.    It may be that Shantz's showing this spring is   a streak performance out of line with his recent records.   It is hard for me to understand how any club needing a   reserve pitcher would be willing to let him go. Even   if I believe that the Cardinal club would not be a pennant   contender before 1965, I would hold Shantz. I have no   reason to belive that his present ability will deteriorate   within the next two or three years. He pitches without   effort, no pressing, and warms up quickly.    Only yesterday evening after pitching two innings   in the regular game against the Mets, he pitched for 15   minutes in a post game batting practice for Burke. Burke   wanted to practice hitting against a left hand pitcher and   Bobby volunteered. Bobby is 37 but that fact apparently   creates no fear in his mind about over-use of his arm.   If the Cardinal club had 10 pitchers, each man as effective   and reliable in his role as Shantz is in his, I would   change my views immediately about the Cardinal winning a   pennant in 1963. His willingness to work should not   be abused. Keep him as fresh as possible.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: March 19, 1963    SHANTZ, ROBERT    Knows how to pitch and has a curve ball that gives left handers a whale of a lot of trouble It seems to me that his sharp breaking curve ball doesn't have constant repetition. He should help the club in the bull pen this year.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: June 17, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs Mets    SHERRY, NORM    If the New York Mets would give this player to St. Louis, the first quick job for St. Louis would be to give him right back.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 27, 1963  Cleveland vs Kansas City    SIEBERN, NORM (Kansas City First Baseman)    Would not take him at any price, - either minor or major.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: September 3, 1963  Minneapolis, Minn.  Minnesota vs Kansas City    SIEBERN, NORM (Kansas City First Baseman)    Old player, - got power. Very average runner.    See previous report.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: March 14, 1963    SIMMONS, CURT    This is March 14th as I dictate this memorandum. He has stuff, - a sweeping curve ball with some speed. He had a good fast ball, not really great, but good. If Simmons had a knuckle ball or a third pitch, that really would do something. He could, without a doubt, be a very fine pitcher in the National League. His control was excellent.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: March 23, 1963    SIMMONS, CURT    During the winter, there was some talk of   making a deal for pitcher Simmons. It was my   understanding that both Bing and Johnny would like to   deal the player. I did not believe at that time the   deal was desirable simply because of Simmons' showing   in the fall games.    Later, Bing told me he was cutting Simmons'   salary thus and so and that Simmons would doubtless be a   holdout. I urged him to hold to the salary he had   offered and if possible compel Simmons to be a holdout, -   that if he were advertised as a holdout it would be   ample reason for the market to understand why he was   "gettable."     I insisted that waivers should be asked on   Simmons alone, - no one else included. I believed this   procedure might produce either a desirable deal or a   fair money price for Simmons.    Waivers were subsequently asked, but Simmons   was one of a number on the same waiver list. Moreover,   his salary was compromised and he was not a holdout.    Now I suggest National League waivers be asked   on Simmons, - but not until we find out further about   his pitching on the St. Louis club.    If he wins his first game or say his second,   he might be claimed on waivers by one or more National   League clubs resulting in a favorable trade or sale.    Simmons can do a pretty good job for a major   lague club in 1963, but I believe this player should be   dealt whenever a favorable deal can be made.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles vs New York Yankees    PEARSON, ALBIE (Los Angeles Angels Outfielder)    Left hander all the way, 27 years old. He can run and field, - a pest hitter without power, but valuable.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 4, 1963    SIMMONS, CURT    I suggest that National League waivers be requested immediately on this player.    Dictated at a time when it was proposed to trade Simmons for Buhl.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 13, 1963  St. Louis vs. Phillies    SIMMONS, CURT    It may be that Curt needs an extra days rest between assignments. However, I know of no reason why he is not as good a pitcher as he ever was. If so, he should be pitched with as much regularity as possible.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 19, 1963  Philadelphia, Pa.  St. Louis vs. Philadelphia    SIMMONS, CURT    A control pitcher if I ever saw one and he seems to trust his control fully. He pitches to spots, it seemed to me, all the time, - maybe too much, and if so, this accounts for his walking six men in the game. I think Simmons could use his beautiful half-speeder more than he does and especially against power right hand hitters with two strikes.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    SLAUGHTER, STERLING (Amarillo Pitcher)    Right hand pitcher with Amarillo. Belongs to the Chicago Cubs. Small boy, looks well under 6' tall, weighs not above 150 pounds. I saw him pitch only one game but I would recommend a draft of $8,000, - if indeed he is subject to draft.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: August 9, 1963  Billings, Montana    SLOAN, MIKE    5'11" tall, 180 pound California boy. Just came 19 - in love, and he is going to marry her. O.K. Left hander. Control of his fast bal could be improved. He has two curve balls and both are good and he showed me good control of both pitches in the workout. He puts great effort into his delivery, ending up in a completely non-fielding position. He could become, if he has intelligence and will work on it, a Spahn in holding men on first base. I believe he will learn it. It appears to me that he has good aptitude. Nelson Burbrink is to be congratulated for signing this boy. He should, in spring training, be pitched as regularly as possible in games. He is a candidate for the Instructional Camp in the fall.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 31, 1963    SMITH, DENNIS (Brunswick Catcher)    5'7" thick legged boy. Arm may be a little better than Spencer's, but nothing to take him anywhere.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: August 2, 1963  Brunswick, Ga.    SMITH, DENNIS    Very average arm, very average power. A 'leggy' boy with deceptive running ability, meaning that he is an average runner. The best thing about him is his spirit. He wants to beat you with a bat, with his arm, with his legs, and with his head. An ideal competitor. I would not consider him for advancement to any higher league next year. Let him stay right where he is. Irving Howe will scout him for us from here on out, as he will most of the boys on the Brunswick Club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 31, 1963    SMITH, JULIUS (Brunswick Outfielder)    He can run, I am sure, above average, and he has a good arm. He takes a double step with the ball invariably, but I believe he is teachable.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: August 1, 1963  Brunswick, Ga.  Brunswick vs Thomasville    SMITH, JULIUS    I don't think he can hit to his own field at all. I don't believe he will hit very much over .200 with Brunswick. If he could hit, he could go anywhere.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 29, 1963  Brunswick vs Moultrie    SMITH, TOM (Brunswick Catcher)    Can't run a lick. Big and strong and should hit. He can throw. He is a brother of Hal Smith. Tom should have a lot of sense. His hitting form is very good.    BRANCH RICKEY    Brunswick, Ga.  July 31, 1963    Arm good enough, - not great, but good enough, - as good as McCarver's, perhaps better.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: August 13, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota    PEARSON, CHARLES    I did not see him. Is disabled.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  August 1, 1963  Brunswick vs Thomasville    SMITH, TOM (Brunswick Catcher)    Occasionally he will hit the long ball. He has good form at the plate and he is a big man, but generally he does not swing with power. Looks like a feeble 'swisher' most of the time.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 11, 1963  St. Louis vs Mets    SNIDER, DUKE    Has slowed up enough that unless he hits over .300 and with power, he is not a first division ball player. He can outrun Stanley but who can't? I doubt if Snider at the present time can hit percentagewise as well as Musial and I doubt further that he can register as much power.    I would not claim him on waivers even if the St. Louis club needed a left hand pinch hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: June 17, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs N. Y. Mets    SNIDER, DUKE    Has slowed up. Age is really overtaking him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: August 13, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Winnepeg vs Bismark-Mandan    SORENSON, DICK (Bismark-Mandan Pitcher)      A big left hander, another rookie with Bismark-Mandan. Unimpressive.    The Bismark-Mandan club has eight rookies on the pitching staff of ten men. Seven rookies played in the game.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 31, 1963    SPENCER, ROOSEVELT (Brunswick Catcher)    No arm - ordinary arm. No prospect as a major league catcher. He would have to hit .500 and he is not a .300 hitter. Not a major league prospect in any respect.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  August 2, 1963    SPENCER, ROSY    If we need a place for another player on the roster of the Brunswick club, it could be provided by giving Spencer an unconditional release. He has desire, - plenty of it, but not much else. He is a colored boy, right hand hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    SPIEZIO, ED    After seeing him in batting practice and only   two full games, I am amazed to learn that he has been at   bat about 200 times at Tulsa and is hitting only about   .240. It is ununderstandable. His position at the   plate is above criticism and he shows power in all   directions, left, right, and straight away. The curve   makes no difference to him. He will hit a good curve   over the left center field fence and will hit a low curve, -   a line drive in the right field corner. I think his   arm is average. He does not seem to be shifty as a   third baseman. He doesn't get the 'jump' on the ground   ball either to his right or left. He might go to the   outfield. It could be a very great loss to the Cardinal   club to lose this boy by draft. It could be. I can   think of him becoming a really great hitter in the majors, -   an outstanding hitter. For a new man, a rookie, he looks   prospectively very promising as a batsman.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 26, 1963  New York Yankees vs Minnesota    STANGE, LEE (Minnesota Pitcher)    Right hand pitcher on Minnesota - about 27 years old. Good fast ball, not great. He has a curve. I don't think it is a great one either. He has a change of pace curve that really changes. It throws the batter off timing - control very good. Has a very slow movement holding men on. I think he is a good fielder of his position.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: March 19, 1963    STARK, CLINT    A great young pitching prospect with a physical hazard. Too bad. Hold him awhile. See him further.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 4, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.    STARK, CLINT    The most regrettable disappointment of anything that has happened to the Cardinal organization is the bad elbow condition to Clint Stark. Clint has unequalled stuff in every direction, great energy and desire. Size and age combine with a pleasing personality to make this chap as great a pitching prospect as I have seen in years and years. Several calcium deposits give him a troublesome arm and ruin his control. The doctors are hopeful but not too sanguine about his recovery, but want to give the boy time before eventual surgery which they believe is probably unavoidable.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: September 4, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Kansas City    PENA, ORLANDA (Kansas City Pitcher)    An athletic Cuban. Can field his position. Can hold men on base. A sort of chap that can do everything well, if he wants to enough. Puts on an appearance of indifference, - doesn't care what happens. I believe he has 'temper', - impulsive, gets mad quick. If he took pitching seriously (or if he does) he should be (and is) a worthwhile pitcher.    If this boy has enough sense to respond to instruction, I would like to have him.    Pena is a pretty good pitcher just as he is but I think he could be better.    In a warm up, he made a number of change of speed pitches. Could have been aknuckle ball, or an attempted fade-away, or a fork ball. In the game he never threw a single slow ball.    This chap is a competitor.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine    P.S. It's a fork ball.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    STARK, CLINT    I hope he will be put to the open draft at Atlanta, preferably Tulsa. He would not be drafted. He has major league stuff all over the place. Just too bad about his calcium elbow.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 22, 1963  Houston, Texas  St. Louis vs Houston    STAUB, RUSTY    Very young, very big, got good action, fine arm, good form at the plate. I believe he is a good hitter. He may be only nineteen years of age with no professional experience (possibly a half a year) but he is 'at home', full oriented. I like this player and I wish St. Louis had him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: Indianapolis, Indiana  September 10, 1963  Indianapolis vs Atlanta    STEPHENS, GENE (Indianapolis Outfielder)    Left hand hitting outfielder, about 31 years of age. I knew this boy as an outfielder with the Boston Americans for several years. Never a great hitter, - never for percentage or power. Back to the minors on account of a bad knee requiring an operation. Player now sound, and is hitting .302 in the International League in 1963.    Walker regards him as more desirable for the Cardinal club for immediate service (1964) than Lewis. I do not. The question on Lewis is orientation. He has to become acquainted, - the quicker the better. Stephens can run pretty good, but Lewis will outrun him. Stephens has a very good arm, but Lewis can out-throw him. Stephens has some power - not great, but Lewis' power exceeds him in my book. If we could get Stephens on a waiver price, then o.k. Otherwise, no. 26 Stephens' would finish in second division.    Not only do I prefer Lewis to Stephens, but I would also prefer Clemens to Stephens. Let somebody else take Stephens.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: September 3, 1963  Minneapolis, Minn.    STIGMAN, RICHARD (Minnesota Pitcher)    A tall 27 year old left hand pitcher, formerly   with Cleveland. Ths boy has stuff, - good stuff,   and he is a good pitcher. He would be desirable   to the Cardinals in any trade.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 22, 1963  Houston, Texas  St. Louis vs Houston    SUDOL, ED    For some years, I felt that Ed Sudol was not an   umpire of good judgment. He is not sure of himself.   He is erratic on balls and strikes and he will call a   strike on a batsman when the batsman clearly holds up.   I don't believe in my dictated notes from year to year   that I will average an umpire criticism once a year and   perhaps I ought not offer criticism. However, if   I had to rate umpires in the National League, Sudol would   come at the bottom.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: September 2, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Los Angeles    PETERS, GARY (White Sox Pitcher)    Tall, left hander, has two curves, - both are good. The first one breaks sharply and if controlled, he should be a fine pitcher against all hitters. A very good fast ball.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: March 30, 1963  Saturday evening  Miami, Florida  St. Louis vs. Baltimore    TAYLOR, RON    I have just witnessed the pitching performance of  Ron Taylor against the Baltimore club, - a night game in  Miami.    What I have said previously in dictation reports  goes double. This boy, without a third usable pitch, is  a second division major league pitcher and should not be  retained. He has high intelligence and could easily learn  this third pitch. It could be a knuckle ball, preferably  just that.    Ron does not have an over-powering fast ball.  Neither does he have a tremendous curve. He does have  good control of both pitches. This pitcher should be told  the exact facts, viz, "you are headed for the minors.  Work hard and immediately on an additional pitch which you  can and will use." And when mention is made of using a  third pitch, it does not, in my mind, mean that this  third pitch is just thrown now and then, - only  occasionally. It should be a pitch that may dominate his  pitching.    I am very sure that Ron Taylor could become a very   great pitcher in the major leagues if he were to believe  as I do that a third pitch is both necessary and   acquirable.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: Tuesday, Forenoon,  April 2, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.    TAYLOR, RON    Howard Pollet, the pitching coach, came to me  after the meeting this morning and said he would like  to talk to me about pitcher Ron Taylor. So he did. He  said Taylor was a mental problem to him, Pollet; that  when he talked to him on occasion about acquiring an  additional pitch that the fellow would break out with  profuse perspiration. The rather extended talk with  Pollet finally developed into straight questioning on my  part of Howie's belief having to do with Taylor's major  league future.    Mr. Rickey: "Do you believe this boy can acquire  a third usable pitch?    Pollet: I do.    Mr. Rickey: How soon?    Pollet: It may take some time.    Mr. Rickey: What do you mean by that?    Pollet: Weeks, - possibly two or three months.    Mr. Rickey: Do you think we ought to be patient  with this fellow?    Pollet: I do.    Mr. Rickey: Do you think he can become a regular  major league pitcher?    Pollet: He has a good chance. His curve is  much improved. His fast ball is not  over-powering, but he has  extraordinary control. And, Mr. Rickey,  you are so right in insisting that the  boy needs and must acquire a third  usable pitch. He is working very  hard to get a change up off his fast  ball. Also, he is working even  harder to perfect a 'fork ball'."

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: 2.    I told Pollet that I agreed with him fully about Ron  Taylor and encouraged him to give constant attention to  helping Taylor with his experimental pitches.    Howard asked me if I would like to talk with the  boy and I told him I would be pleased to. Accordingly,  he arranged for Taylor to meet me immediately after the  game today.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 3, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.    TAYLOR, RON    I had the visit (scheduled by Pollet) with Ron  Taylor last evening. Johnny Keane, Howard Pollet  and everyone have Ron Taylor sized up just about  right. An intelligent man, extremely conscientious.  I believe he worries about himself. Every little thing  has exhaggerated meaning. He reminds me of Groat in  this respect.    Pollet has the full confidence of Ron Taylor  and Pollet will do a good job in helping this boy  acquire a usable third pitch. The pitcher does not have  Fanok's fast ball but his curve ball is better and is  good.    Contrary to reports, Taylor states with very  real earnestness that his only ambition is to make good  as a major league pitcher. I believe him. Further,  I believe he can do it. His unusual control of a fairly  good fast ball (not great) and a curve quite good enough  make him a conditional major league prospective regular.  Not very many major league pitchers have Ron Taylor's  unusual control.    He is working on a firk ball, also a change up.  I believe he will get an additional pitch. He should  be one of the Cardinal's ten pitchers during this season.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 13, 1963  St. Louis vs. Phillies    CALLISON, JOHN (Philadelphia Outfield)  TAYLOR, TONY (Philadelphia Infielder)  AMARO, RUBEN (Philadelphia Infielder)    CALLISON and TAYLOR are fine major league  players. TONY TAYLOR is a much underrated player  and a very desirable man on any championship club.    AMARO, likewise, is an underrated player.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: March 19, 1963    THACKER, MOE    BIG man, little poop. A sad case of a   man who can catch and throw, - shows good action.   Can't get the ball and bat together. As bad as   Buchek hitting bad balls and taking the good ones.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: September 11, 1963  Indianapolis, Indiana  Indianapolis vs Atlanta    THACKER, MOE    Big, right hand hitting catcher. Cannot hit, cannot run, good arm - nothing great. Cannot catch. I don't believe he would be drafted at Tulsa. Surely he should be cleared from the active list. Nice boy.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1956; A-P
Transcription: April 11, 1963   St. Louis vs. Mets    THOMAS, FRANK (METS OUTFIELDER)    He is still a good man to trade. Unless   there would be a profitable cash market in sight for   Thomas' contract, I would not want to see the St. Louis   club pay a nickel to get him.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: June 17, 1963   St. Louis, Mo.   St. Louis vs N. Y. Mets    THOMAS, FRANK    For a good man years, he has been a good man   to get rid of. He is through.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: August 6, 1963  New York, N. Y.  St. Louis vs New York Mets    THOMAS, FRANK (New York Mets Infielder-Outfielder)    Don't ever trade for Thomas with any idea of   keeping him on the major league club. He is a positive   anesthetic. 25 Thomas' will finish right near the bottom.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: September 3, 1963  Minneapolis, Minn.  Minnesota vs Kansas City    TARTABULL, JOSE (Kansas City Outfielder)    23 years of age, colored fellow, left hand  hitter. No power. Batting form is good from top  to bottom. Great runner. Commands a good lead  and gambles on the break. He ought to hit against  right handers. I have not seen him against a left  hander.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    THOMAS, LEE    Left hand hitter, played first base, - lot of   power, and looked like a very good hitter - and is a   very good hitter.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    TORRES, FELIX (Los Angeles Angels Infielder)    Thirty year old right hand hitting Cuban.   Pretty good hitter, pretty good runner, pretty good arm.   Thirty Torres' - second division. St. Louis doesn't   want him.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: Cincinnati, Ohio  May 2, 1963  Cincinnati vs Milwaukee    TORRE, JOE    Right hand hitting catcher. He can throw   and he can run, - good enough. About 40%   extra base. Not available right now in any deal and   even if he were on the market, he would cost more than   he is worth.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Winnipeg vs Bismark-Mandan    TORRES, VIC (Winnipeg Shortstop)    Can make the play in the hole very well.   Body control is made for it and so is his arm.     BRANCH RICKEY    I don't believe he will be drafted.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    TOTH, PAUL (Chicago Pitcher)    Right hand pitcher, 28 years old, run of the   mine major leaguer, but a whale of a lot better major   league pitcher than Harvey Branch right now.   But the deal of Branch for Toth is not bad because   of difference in age and experience.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: March 18, 1963    TRIANDOS, GUS    Triandos can't run as fast as Musial.     April 3, 1963    Yes, I believe he can.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: April 30, 1963  St. Louis, Mo.   St. Louis vs Milwaukee    UECKER, BOB    A young catcher on the Milwaukee club, with   a very great arm. None better.
