Ordinary runner.   Form at the plate good and really looked good against   left hand pitcher Simmons.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.   July 29, 1963  Brunswick vs Moultrie    VAN, JOHN (Brunswick Pitcher)    An inexperienced, very young, 6'3" left hander   from California. Has good stuff. Good fast ball,   and a very good curve. Exceptional control of the   curve ball. He throws it three feet on the outside   of the plate from every left hand batter. That   particular pitch will not miss the same spot by 6".   If he gets into trouble at all, he makes it immediately   worse, - becomes wild and presses and shows emotion.   An error upsets him, and he shows it. He has no third   pitch. If he gets a usable third pitch, - a knuckle   ball or even a change up, off either the fast ball or   the curve ball, I could see him in the major league   as a pitcher, right now.     He is more of a boy than his age indicates.   The club has already invested $8,000 in him. He is   certainly worth the additional $2500.     Van had four strike outs when he really gave   four bases on balls. The fourth pitch was nowhere   near the plate in three cases. This could indicate   a lot of stuff or the lack of ability of the batsmen   and does not permit anyone to draw that conclusion   safely.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.    August 2, 1963    VAN, JOHN     One of two pitchers on the Brunswick club   that might be considered for the outfield is Van.  He can run. Is very tall, very young, - really an   adolescent. I would put him into the Florida   Instruction Camp.      Branch Rickey    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: August 13, 1963   Bismark, North Dakota   Winnipeg vs Bismark-Mandan    VAN, JOHN     This tall California left hand pitcher has a   long way to go to become a major league pitcher.   When I saw him in Brunswick, I thought it might   help to let him go to the fall Florida camp.   I think we should give our time to some other   pitcher who has a chance to come quicker. He   really lacks stuff.      BRANCH RICKEY    (Later)      Van can't hold runners on any base,   particularly first.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: Cleveland, Ohio  July 24, 1963  Cleveland vs Minnesota      TASBY, WILLIE    No future, - no high present value. Right hand all the way. Don't take him as a 'throw in'.     BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: July 24, 1963  Cleveland, Ohio  Cleveland vs. Minnesota    VERSALLES, ZOILO (Minnesota Infielder)    A slim Negro shortstop, left hand hitter. Can  run, a great arm, fine fielder, gets a great lead off first  base but shows no adventure. Holds a bigger lead than  Wills even against left hand pitching. His stolen base  record is simply based upon this speed. This boy's  position at the plate is good and his batting form is good  and he should hit with a respectable percentage. I would  not call him a home run hitter but he has power enough  for a 50% extra base hitting average, - based on relation  of total bases to hits. It is entirely possible that  there is no better shortstop in either league for the next  several years.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: September 7, 1963   Tulsa, Oklahoma   Tulsa vs Amarillo    VICKERY, LOU     Left hand pitcher. 21 years of age, with   two or three years experience. Very surely he would   be drafted at Atlanta. He has several pitches.   Vickery has a good chance to go to the major leagues   eventually.     With a man on first base, every pitch is a   balk. He never stops at anytime.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: New York, N. Y.   July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    WAGNER, LEON (Los Angeles Angels Outfielder)     He does everything. A 29 year old left hand   hitting outfielder. Has power. Has been a member   of several major league clubs, - big boy, colored.   In our present position in St. Louis, Wagner would be   desirable regardless that he was previously a member of   the Cardinal club.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: March 30, 1963    WALLACE, DON     22 year old, left hand hitting shortstop. Very   good speed and a very good arm. Smooth fielder, -   smart. Not an extra base hitter but not a striker-outer   either. He is a pest hitter. I will not be surprised to   see him make the major leagues.     This player was drafted in December of 1962 from   the Baltimore organization. Following a brief period   of spring training with the Cardinals, he was turned back   to Baltimore.     I could never let a player of this sort go for   cash, - having played only 89 games of professional   baseball at Aberdeen. Led the Northern League in hitting   his very first year at .325. I was not consulted about   his release and did not know anything about it until the   deal was made.     The draft price on Wallace was $8,000. I understood   the Baltimore organization gave the player a very sizeable   bonus for signing. I happen to know that this club was   very happy to have him returned. If our information was   sufficiently reliable to justify the draft (and it surely   was) what additional information was obtained that the   draft information was no good? And by whom? Who made   the decision that Wallace was no good? When was it made?   And why? What did the boy do in two weeks or what did   he not do to cause his dismissal without discussing it with   the staff? Why was his sale held as a secret from me?     Wallace could have been optioned for three years.   He should have been optioned for at least one until we   knew his value and his future.     When Bing informed me about the sale of Wallace   he said he was under pressure to get a man off the club's   roster limit. Well, if so, why not any one of several   non-prospects, several of whom have been outrighted. If   a previous agreement had been made with Baltimore to draft   from and return the player to Baltimore, - the move would   be understandable.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: Chicago, Illinois  July 16, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs. Senators    WARD, PETE (Chicago Infielder)    Big boy, looks young. Has a lot of power.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: April 22, 1963  Houston, Texas  St. Louis vs Houston    WARWICK, CARL (Houston Outfielder)    An outfielder obtained by Houston from St.   Louis. He is not an over-sized man, but he can run   above average and he can throw about average and he   is a fine defensive outfielder. His value and his   future depend upon his hitting.    He is a gentleman in every respect. In fact,   he is a practicing Christian. He would not hurt any   club needing an extra outfielder.    25 Warwicks' would not win a National League   pennant but it would be a club pretty hard to beat.   25 Lillis' would be always well down in second   division.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: March 25, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago  Sarasota, Florida    WASHBURN, RAY    Washburn had grand control. In fact, both the   curve ball and fast ball seemed to go where he wanted to   pitch it. In the sixth inning after Cunningham hit the   home run, he threw two changes of pace in succession.   These were the first changes I observed and he never   threw another one.    He was very effective and perhaps didn't need a   third pitch but it is a living cinch he didn't throw   any.    I don't believe he is the Walter Johnson type of   pitcher who doesn't for example, need anything other than   a fast ball. I am not ready to say he is an over-powering   pitcher. On the contrary, I think he should practice a   great deal upon his control of the change-up.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: April 10, 1963  St. Louis vs Mets    WASHBURN, RAY    With two and nothing on catcher Coleman in   the first inning, Washburn came through the middle   with a fast ball which Coleman hit back through the   box. Washburn didn't follow his pitch in any   respect. He was out of position to field any kind   of a hit and, of course, the ball went by him and   should have been fielded easily. Washburn seemed   surprised that the ball would be hit back at him.    Washburn needs the pitching practice I have   written about under the caption of "The Dressen-McGraw   Pitcher Fielding Practice."    In the third inning with two men out, Washburn   again pitched the fast ball through the middle to   Coleman, - two strikes and no balls, but - - - - - -   Coleman swung hard and missed.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: April 22, 1963  Houston, Texas  St. Louis vs. Houston    WASHBURN, RAY    This boy is tremendously anxious to win   and when things don't go right, I believe he gets   nervous very quickly. He is a rugged chap and   doesn't weaken in late innings. In the third   inning tonight in the game with Houston, he walked   three men in succession with one man out. There may   have been one curve ball in the three walks, -   everything else fast balls and invariably above the   waistline, - high.    I think Dick Groat and our captain-third   baseman, Ken Boyer, both of whom know the emotional   nature of Washburn, should have gone to him much   sooner than they did. Neither went to the mound   until he had walked the third man. Surely they could   have noticed that after every pitched called a ball,   Washburn would hold his glove up for the return throw   from the catcher, - would then walk toward the catcher   with his glove extended, saying by gesture, "give me   the ball, - give me the ball." Washburn was   really on the rocks emotionally and a lot of time should   have been taken with him and neither Groat nor Boyer   paid any attention to him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: March 30, 1963  Hollywood, Florida  Atlanta vs. Richomd    WATTS, HARRY    I think he knows the strike zone pretty good.   He gets a fair lead off first and his a quick breaker.   He has more adventure and chance taking as a base runner   than his leg speed may justify. There is every   evidence that this fellow would easily be on a winning   club. If he were a first year player or a second year   player in professional baseball and now say, only 20   years old, I would rate him as something more than a   possibility for a major league.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: March 10, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.      TATUM, (Mets Pitcher)    Right hand pitcher Tatum of the New York Mets. He has good control and his curve is o.k. Only fair speed. In three inning observation, doubtful major leaguer.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    WATTS, HARRY    Let him go to draft right where he is.   He would not be drafted from Atlanta and probably   not from Tulsa. He is as good right now as he ever   will be, possibly better.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Davine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: Chicago Illinois  July 16, 1963  Chicago White Sox vs. Senators    WEIS, AL (Chicago Infielder)    Right hand hitter, runs well. The very picture   of a single hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: September 5, 1963  Chicago, Illinois  Chicago White Sox vs Kansas City    WEIS, AL (White Sox Infielder)    Looks like a minor league ball player at   the plate and indeed everywhere else.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Davine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: May 18, 1963  St. Louis, Missouri  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    WHITE, WILLIAM    Left hand hitter. First baseman. Over 6'  and weighs about 195. Above average runner. Not   a strong arm but he has a lot of power with a bat in   his hands. He strikes out. All power hitters strike   out but Bill strikes out more than he should and it is   not surprising. His bat position should give him a  real problem in timing the pitch and I believe it does   give him frequent trouble. But he is hitting and with   power and nothing should be said to any batsman who is   doing well. Let him alone. However, he mystifies   me with his ability because of his stance. At the time   the ball leaves the pitcher's hand, Bill's bat is in a   positive perpendicular position. His hands are in   front of his left shoulder and of course in order to   get the power which he really has, he must go back   with his hands and particularly with the big end of the   bat. That doubles his problem in timing because he   is going in two directions, - backward and then forward.   His bat position should be such that the big end of the   bat is at the farthest point back of him at the time   the pitch starts. And it should be very quiet so that   a coin paced on the end of the bat would not fall off   until the forward motion starts.    A moving picture of Bill's batting stance   would show exactly what I mean. If he will simply   flex his wrists even though his hands are in front of   his shoulder, it would help surely about striking out.   And if his hands were back of his shoulder, then surely   his power would be increased.    I know of only one or two great batsmen who  have what I call this preliminary batting fault. Jackie  Robinson had it but he corrected it very largely by  pushing his hands out away from his body and placing  them well back of his shoulder. And then he got the  habit of that position.    However, nothing should be said to anyone about  it as long as Bill is going as he is.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Winnipeg vs Bismark-Mandan    WICKER, FLOYD    $18,000 boy. Originally an infielder in  1962 at Billings. In 1963 at Winnipeg, continued  as third baseman. Didn't hit. Changed to pitcher.  Right hand thrower, left hand hitter.    He was scheduled to work out with me as a  pitcher prior to tonight's game. Could not because  of a knot in his back. However, played center  field in the game and took full fielding practice.  Threw splendidly to third and home. Showed strong  arm.    On the basis of my short look, you can have him  either as a pitcher or as an infielder or as a competing  athlete.    Hitting against left hander May of the Bismark  club, Floyd was pitiful. He surely must be a much  better prospect than he is showing right now.  It could be a good move to make a pitcher out of him.      BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: April 4, 1963  St. Petersburg, Fla.    WILD, JERRY    A final word on Jerry Wild. He has been sent  to Homestead. I would very much have preferred to have  seen him pitch in the Cardinal games; - as many as times  as possible, before the Cardinal club went north. Now,  Jerry should be followed closely by the Cardinal  management. He might make a great showing immediately  wherever he is placed, and if so, he would not face a  very great challenge to make the Cardinal club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    WILD, JERRY    Anybody who really knows Jerry Wild, apart from  his record, might draft him. He has the basic stuff  to go major. Most unsophisticated ball player in my  acquaintance. Jerry seems to me to be mentally  slow as well as physically inept. He is a 'backward'  fellow. I hope we can bring him up.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: St. Louis, Missouri  May 1, 1963  St. Louis vs Chicago    WILLIAMS, BILLY (Chicago Outfielder)    Left hand hitting, right hand throwing,  24 year old, outfielder with Chicago. This fellow  has perfect form at bat, good power. I class him  among the best hitters in the National League.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: New York, N. Y.  July 25, 1963  Los Angeles (AL) vs New York (AL)    WILLIAMS, STAN (New York Yankee Pitcher)    Right hand pitcher, tremendously big boy, about  27 years old. A lot of stuff, unpredictable control  and usually faulty. He might settle down when he  gets past thirty. I don't vote for Williams. I would  rather bring up my own wild kids.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: August 10, 1963  Billings, Montana  Billings vs Boise    WILLIS, RON    See previous comments.    Willis has more speed than I have previously  reported. Curve ball so so and almost all of them  above the waistline. Threw several change ups - most  of them high and off the strike zone. A couple over  the plate very effectively. Pretty active fielder of  his position and has a remarkable throw to first base.  He can really hold runners on the bag.     Not a set up at the plate. Has good  power.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: March 30, 1963  Hollywood, Florida  Atlanta vs. Richmond    Taylor, Charles    A big boy with a good fast ball. Pretty good  curve. Shows fairly good control. His change up is  effective and he seems willing to use it.    He has a very good movement with a runner  on first. Holds him on and throws quickly.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  July 31, 1963    WILSON, LONNIE (Brunswick Pitcher)    Pretty good fast ball, fair curve. He can  get a good change up off his fast ball. You  mustn't cut him loose. He might become quite a  pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: Brunswick, Ga.  August 2, 1963    WILSON, LONNIE    This boy Wilson has a good arm. He can run, -  well above average. He is tall - well built.  George Kissell says that the boy has power at the bat  and that he uses Wilson as a pinch hitter on the  Brunswick club. If the boy has any kind of batting  ability he should be given serious consideration for  the Instruction Camp next fall.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: April 22, 1963  Houston, Texas  St. Louis vs Houston    WOODESHICK, HAL (Houston Pitcher)    A left hander on the Houston club. Has a   change-up, a corking curve, and a very great fast ball.  Nervous, no control, and is 30 years old.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: September 3, 1963  Minneapolis, Minnesota  Minnesota vs. Kansas City    WYATT, JOHN (Kansas City Pitcher)    Heavy built, right hand colored pitcher on  the Kansas City club. Side arm all the time. Curve  has velocity, very little break. Fair fast ball, -  good control. American League reputation of being  a fine relief pitcher. Didn't show me any exceptional  stuff in any direction.    I would rather have Bowsfield, Drabowsky,  Wickersham, Segui and indeed several other Kansas City  pitchers in preference to John Wyatt.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: Billings, Montana  August 10, 1963  Billings vs Boise    YOUNG, DON    Only 17. This fellow can run pretty good,  maybe above average. Can throw alright and has power  at the plate. The curve ball from the right hander  is completely strange to him and he is undoubtedly weak  on all kinds of breaking stuff, but evidences great  dissatisfaction with his failures. I believe he has  spirit and a good future. He should be invited to the  Florida fall Instruction Camp.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: April 23, 1963  Houston, Texas  St. Louis vs Houston    ZACHARY, CHRIS (Houston Pitcher)    Barely nineteen years old. Right hand  pitcher. Very first year of professional experience.  Fine fast ball and a pretty good curve. Shows no  experience whatever. If St. Louis can get this boy  in any kind of a deal, I would take him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: August 12, 1963  Bismark, North Dakota  Winnipeg vs Bismark-Mandan    ZELLER, BART    A big, strong right hand hitting catcher,  21 years old and a rookie. He didn't show a great  arm, - in fact, the other catcher, Scott, showed  better. This boy worked out pitchers with me  and I saw him catch only one game. He had a  helpless day at the bat. I would be surprised if  he were drafted.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: September 3, 1963  Minneapolis, Minn.    ZIMMERMAN, JERRY (Minnesota Catcher)    A catcher, 29 years old, right hander.  Good receiver, good arm, good defensive catcher.  A puny hitter if there is one in major league   baseball. Not desirable.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: September 7, 1963  Tulsa, Oklahoma  Tulsa vs Amarillo    TAYLOR, CHARLES "CHUCK"    Right hander. Another young pitcher who  likes to throw a slider. It is a very ineffective  pitch. He throws a change up on his curve. It is  very good and highly useable when controlled. I  have seen this fellow in several games, - in the Fall  Instruction Camp in 1962, - this spring, - and in the  present Texas League season. He impresses me as a   'back door' pitcher. He has thinking ability but  it gets him into trouble. He is a 2-0 pitcher.  I think he can go major league, but he is far from  being ready for the Cardinals. He doesn't lack guts.  He seems to be a high class gentleman, - with  conversational sense.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: March 14, 1963    TAYLOR, RON    Has good speed and plenty of curve. He threw  nothing else. Positively needs a third pitch. If he  had a change of pace as good as Owens, he would be   wonderful.    OWENS (Cincinnati pitcher) has a great change  up off his fast ball. In the five innings he threw  that change up not less than 15 times. Owens does not  have either the speed or the curve that Ron Taylor has,  but Owens emphasizes beyond merit both his fast ball and  his curve ball. Apparently Ron Taylor gives a batsman  very little trouble on an adjustment to varying velocities.  If he doesn't have a change-up or indeed any other usable  third pitch, then it is just too bad.    I do not believe this boy can help the Cardinal  club unless he gets a usable third pitch.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: March 18, 1963  St. Louis vs. Detroit    TAYLOR, RON    The boy simply has no usable third pitch. On  rare occasion he will throw some wobbly something or  other, - could be a knuckle ball or fork ball, but shows  no control of it - whatever it is.    I can think of no reason why Ron Taylor could  not acquire immediately a usable change of speed pitch,  perhaps off his curve ball, but most certainly he could get  a change up off his fast ball.    I told Pollet all about this several days ago.  If Taylor shows no real interest, I would like to know  about it.    Taylor cannot help any club to win a pennant  in 1963 in his present state of "stuff".    I was very strong for the deal that brought him  to St. Louis from Cleveland. My information was sound in  that he does have an adequate fast ball and has a good   curve and beyond question has a chance to become a fine  pitcher in the major league.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: March 19, 1963    TAYLOR, RON    See my reports. If this player cannot  get an effective change of pace pitch, send him  to Atlanta.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: May 1, 1964   St. Louis, Mo.   St. Louis vs Pittsburgh      BAILEY, BOB    He reminds me of Buchek at the plate. Bewildered, confused. Probably doesn't guess on the pitches but he surely acts like it. He may know the strike zone but he doesn't pay too much attention to it. He takes good ones and hits bad ones with abandon. He has power, - good batting form. He could become surely a corking hitter and he should.        BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.   March 10, 1964   Intra-Squad Game    BAKENHASTER, DAVID     Right hander. Very young. Came out of   Dublin, Ohio High School in June of 1964. Showed   good speed and a good curve and a lot of "know how".   In appearance and attitude he could have been a   veteran pitcher. This boy has native poise and   is indeed a pitcher by nature. If he has enough   stuff, he could make his ability meet his capacity   very quickly. Showed only a fast ball and a curve,   nothing else, but both pitches were very good.        BRANCH RICKEY        LATER    Most unfortunately, this boy falls away   over toward first on most pitches. I say   unfortunate because he is otherwise so finished   and without any pitching faults.        B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; C-D
Transcription: March 18, 1964   St. Petersburg, Fla.   St. Louis vs Detroit   "B" Game      BAKENHASTER, DAVE     Not finished at all in holding men on first base.         BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 15, 1964   Rock Hill, S.C.   Rock Hill vs Shelby      BANE, Jim     20 years old. Tall, right hand hitting infielder. Didn't show me anything, - arm or legs or at bat. He got $12,000 to sign a contract. After seeing him in three games, I would't give him a cent.        BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: April 7, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    BEDELL, HOWARD    He should help Tulsa but surely nothing  higher.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 11, 1964  Raleigh, N. C.  Raleigh vs Burlington    BELTRAN, MARTY    Tall, slim Negro outfielder, left hand hitter.   A confused batsman. Right now, not good with a bat in  his hands. He needs instruction, whether he wants it  or not. Pretty good runner. Showed me only an  ordinary arm.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: May 4, 1964  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs Philadelphia    BENNETT, DENNIS    Corking curve ball, good speed. He throws change ups. Had no control of them, and he had no control of his curve ball against the Cardinals on this date.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: Sarasota, Florida  July 18, 1964  Sarasota Rookie League    BISHOP, William    This boy has two curves, - a velocity three quarter's downer and a change up curve. Both exceptionally good breaking pitches. Very disappointing speed. Pitches from all angles. You can't turn thumbs down on this fellow. Give him control of his two curves and he may go anywhere in spite of his dipsy-do fast ball. Hold on to him. I shall be surprised if some major league club does not take this boy at $8,000.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs Denver    BLACKABY, Ethan (Denver Outfielder)    Left hand hitting outfielder. Pretty good arm. Fair speed. Very average power. I would not class him as a prospect.    BRANCH RICKY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: September 14, & 15, 1964  Rochester, N.Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    BLEFARY, CURT    21 year old, left hand hitting, right hand throwing outfielder. Drafted by Baltimore from the New York Yankees, - now on option to Rochester. Good runner, good arm and a mean bat. Knows the strike zone and has power. I wish St. Louis owned his contract.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs. Denver    AARON, Tommy (Denver Infielder-Outfielder)   Colored outfielder-first baseman. Not a kid. Good physical set-up. Has power. Any pitcher with some assortment bothers him. A liability if he were on the Cardinal club.     BRANCH RICKEY    cc-Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: Flint, Michigan  May 21, 1964    BLIGHT, JAMES    A 'bespectacled', 6'3" right hand pitcher from Central  High School in Flint, Michigan, - will weigh about 180 pounds.  This boy has good speed and fairly good control of it. He has  a curve that really breaks half the time. Even when it doesn't  break very much, it could be good pitch because of its velocity.  He seldom uses his curve ball. He would be a strikeout pitcher  deluxe, in high school circles, if he would use his curve ball.  This chap is past eighteen. Shows a good deal of finish. Shows  no change-ups of any sort although I am reliably told that he has  change of speed pitches. I think that this boy is mentally,  physically, morally and spiritually headed toward the major leagues.    Gene DeSautel has done a lot of work with this boy. I  surmise that Gene is his marketing agent when it comes to talking  terms. Quite openly, Gene is his adviser and consultant and either  directly or indirectly the boy will be controlled by Gene DeSautel.    I know Gene DeSautel. He has worked for me in the years  gone by, - was the regular catcher at Columbus, Ohio for one full year  when St. Louis owned Columbus. Gene is a smart person and a forthright  gentleman. I had considerable conversation with Gene about  this young pitcher. It is quite evident that a good campaign has  been carried on to advertise Blight. In any event, several major  league clubs have been following this pitcher for sometime past.  The build-up started in 1962 and whoever gets the contract of Jim  Blight would not be disappointed if the player could be retained.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: James Blight -2-    Our own scout, Mozzali, knows the player and supports DeSautel's  estimate of the player's ability. My conversation with  DeSautel and my visit with Mr. Blight, Jim's father, leads me to  believe quite positively that both Gene and Mr. Blight expect a big  bonus. With what I know about the Cardinal club in the signing  of first year players for 1965, this boy Jim Blight might be worth  a competitive bonus and retention by the Cardinal club. He is  a bigger, stronger pitcher than most pitchers you will see in  high schools anywhere.    On a first look, he is more impressive than Briles.    Mr. Blight told me that his boy had never thrown the   curve ball "prior today". That was amazing to me until Gene  DeSautel told me that the boy just learned the curve ball this  present season under his (DeSautel's) tutelage. His curve is  now and then a corking curve, - good velocity and a quick break.  Jim is bound to go places in the major leagues, and is worth  a competitive bonus figure if there is any way to retain him.  That's the problem and that's the challenge to our policy of  signing first year men.    He lost his game in this championship contest, - losing  to Midland 6 to 5, - horrible support. His club plays three  more games. I would like to have Bing in the picture immediately.  I would like him to find out directly from DeSautel what Gene's   relationship is with the player and whether or not he, DeSautel,  is in position to act as our agent in signing the player. A

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: James Blight -3-    liberal sum could be paid to DeSautel on condition that St. Louis  gets the contract. I suggest this first step simply because I   believe DeSautel may have a binding arrangement with Mr. Blight  and the boy to handle all negotiations. If so, we should deal first  with DeSautel. If negotiations resulted in a St. Louis option  exercisable on a given date subsequent to his last high school game,  then I would like to go with Bing to see the player again.   Jim Blight is a fine prospective major league pitcher,  ranking high with all the boys we have seen in recent times.   If an arrangement could be made in this Jim Blight case  similar to the one Bing has proposed in deal with Leonard Boyer  whereby the boy spends this summer on a gentleman's agreement  basis in the Basin League, then and in the event I would be willing  to enter the substantial bonus field in our effort to get the player.  This boy is not a 'hope so' player, - one of the 'might be's'.  Excluding some physical disability or an act of God, this boy is sure  to find a place as a regular on some major league pitching staff  surely within two or three years. He can't miss.   If an option can be arranged, that would give us exclusive  rights. We would then be able to see the player in all three of his  remaining game and I would have the change to work with him  privately. Under the circumstances and in the surroundings on the  occasion of my visit, I didn't think it advisable to further in  conversation with Mr. Blight or DeSautel that I did go at that time.  I would like very much to have a private workout with Jim Blight.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: James Blight -4-    and I hope we can get an option on almost any terms that would enable  us to go the full route on a complete investigation of the player.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs Denver    BOCCABELLA, John (Salt Lake City First Baseman)    A big boy, 23 years old, right hand hitter, below average runner, and has great power at the plate, but in the two games I saw him, he struck at everything. Chases curves, doubles up on change of pace pitching and strikes out on the fast ball. Arm so so.    I am told he is a bonus player from Santa Clara College.    His extraordinary power at the plate may carry him all the way. He should be followed.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 23, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Houston    BOND, WALT    A very tall 27 year old left handed hitter. Colored. Never has hit consistently for a good percentage anywhere. Has power.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: April 1, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Philadelphia    BOOZER, JOHN    A big, tall right hand pitcher with Philadelphia. About 28 years of age. A Wofford College boy who looks like he has everything required to become a pitcher. He surely would be a regular pitcher if were a member of the Cardinal team. I like him. I would give Hughes, Craig, and Burdette, - all three for Boozer.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 18, 1964  Sarasota, Fla  Sarasota Rookie League      BOST, Robert  Very young, tall, sim Negro. Would have power on his pitch. Don't believe he will hit for percentage professionally anywhere. Hard to judge running speed because the ground is very soft. The entire group of managers nd scouts should know exactly the comparative running speed of every player in the organization.    Nobody really knows the running speed of anybody. No one believes in races. This characterizes all Cardinal training camps.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs Denver      BOWMAN, Ernie (Denver Infielder)    Right hand hitting infielder, formerly with   San Francisco. Corking fielder. A sorry spectacle   at bat in the Pacific Coast League.      BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 17, 1964  Tampa, Fla  St. Louis vs Cincinnati      BOYER, KEN    He looks overweight to me. He runs overweight and the fact undoubtedly is that he IS not the runner he used to be. He should be built up for a big trade at the end of the present season.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: August 19,1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo    Ackley, Florian "Fritz"    In due course, pitcher Ackley should be carried on the Cardinal reserve list of forty players.    Branch Rickey    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: May 18, 1964  St Louis, Mo.      BOYER, LEONARD  Left hand hitting infielder. I guess him   to be about 6'2" tall and weigh 180 pounds. This   boy just came 18 years of age less than a month ago.   Not above medium runner. A good arm not at all   great. Nothing like his brother Kenny. Eventually   this boy would show good power at the plate. At   the present time that is the best thing about him.    Leonard comes from a family of great   athletes. Cletus, the Yankee third baseman, did not   look like a hitter at all when he first came up.   Leonard should improve in running and probably in   throwing. He may go major league in due time.   I think he has a good chance.    Twenty five years ago, I would not give him   any bonus whatever. Today, by custom he is entitled   to it and by circumstances he will get it. I would   fix the price around the $8,000 mark.    The boy will not help any major leaue club   in 1965. In all probability the major league club   that signs this player will lose him in the first year   draft. That feature, if true, should determine the   range for the bonus.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: May 18, 1964  St. Louis, Mo.      BOYYT

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 15, 1964  Rock Hill, S. C.  Rock Hill vs Shelby    BRADDOCK, Ron    I saw him in Brunswick, Ga. late in the 1963   season. He is almost 22 years of age. He can run and   he can throw hard, really hard. He didn't look like   a hitter, so Hal Smith has changed him from an outfielder   to a pitcher. That is good.     Hal says this boy is learning a curve ball.   He should be pitched for a year, possibly longer, on a   small classification club. Needs pitching instruction   and he would be very happy to have it. This chap   is extremely conscientious, - grieves over his mistakes,   and could be a so-called psychological problem. His   fast ball makes it worth our while to hold on to him.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: BRADDOCK, RON    He throws hard. He throws everything hard. He has just come 22 years of age. He was an outfielder until a few months ago. He has learned a curve and it curves. He has learned a slider and he really has a slider, - in fact two of them, - one with the effect of a change of speed and the other is not easy to catch, - at least Ryba had difficulty with it. The fellow has enough stuff and he must be pitched in the fall camp to a fair you well. He might be advanced in this very camp to be a part of a winning team in Jacksonville in 1965. The only reason this boy could not pitch for the Cardinals is his lack of control and I believe that he can get it quicker, sooner, and faster than most.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 13, 1964  Winston-Salem, N. C.  Raleigh vs Winston-Salem    BRAMLETT, John    Just another good small classification player. His running, hitting, throwing probably marked him as a high school star, but nothing more than that.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: October 9, 1964  West Palm Beach, Fla  St. Louis vs Milwaukee    BREEDEN, HAL (Milwaukee First Baseman)    Left hand thrower, right hand hitter. Tall boy. Power at the plate.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: April 7, 1964  Homestead, Fla.  Tulsa vs Denver      BRILES, NELSON    Fast ball good enough for anybody. Change of pace a very effective pitch. Curve ball so so. Control looked very good. A definite prospective major leaguer. I think he can make good at Tulsa in 1964. However, he should be placed somewhere to get as many innings under his belt as possible.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 14, 1964  St, Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Mets      BROGLIO, ERNIE    With men on first base, his starting movement on the pitch is very slow. Broglio cannot hold runners on first base and he never will until he puts his left foot farther front. He must put some weight on the front foot.        BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 23, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Houston      BROGLIO, ERNIE    In the game against Houston this date in St. Petersburg, Kasko led off with a single. With Fox hitting on the hit and run, Kasko had the bag stolen almost before the time McCarver got the ball. Again with two and two on Fox, Kasko had the bag stolen without any slide. Fox's foul sent him back. Broglio simpy cannot hold anybody on.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 23, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Houston      BROWN, HAL "SKINNY"    Right hander, - 39 years of age. Control pitcher de luxe. Change of speed pitcher all the way. Knuckleball, screwball, slow spinner, pretty good curve, no fast ball but effective because if its speed illusion has compared with his other stuff.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: September 16, 1964   Rochester, N.Y.   Rochester vs Jacksonville     ACKLEY, FRITZ    A major league fast ball. His curve has   good velocity and it curves. If he had perfect   control of these two pitches, he could go major without   anything else. But he does not have that kind of   control of either pitch. Therefore, he needs a third   usable pitch together with a willingness to to throw it.   He pitched 5-1/3 innings against Rochester this evening   and showed a change-up curve ball three times and all   three were effective both as to control and deception.   I cannot understand why he will not use this third   change-up pitch more often. It is my understanding that   this player is to come to the Cardinal club to finish up   some previous deal with the Chicago Americans. That   is good. He should be retained by the Cardinal club   for spring training in 1965. I should like to visit   with this fellow and come to know more about him.      BRANCH RICKEY     cc - Mr . Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: August 17, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  International League All-Stars vs Cleveland      BRUBAKER (Syracuse Pitcher)    Right hand pitcher with Syracuse. He has a curve ball and I mean a curve ball and he looked like he had control of everything. Fast ball good enough. I wish we could make a deal for him.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 10, 1964  Intra-Squad Game      BUCHEK, GERRY    Still impresses me as a bewildered batsman. His body is major league. I doubt if his mind is. He is very young.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: April 3, 1964  Ft. Myers, Fla.  St. Louis vs Pittsburgh      BUCHEK, GERRY    Opposing pitchers should keep the fast ball in on him or away from him. He is almost exclusively a fast ball hitter. Breaking stuff bothers him. A left hander's curve ball will strike him out.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: April 25, 1964  St. Louis, Mo.      BUCHEK, GERRY    This boy cannot hit a left hander's curve ball from the three-quarter delivery. The pitch breaking down and into him strikes him out. I don't think he can hit that pitch in batting practice even if he knows it is coming.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: April 4, 1964      I would keep Gagliana, Kolb, Maxvill, and Buchek, any one of whom could play the outfield if necessary. I would send out Shannon, Clemens, or both before I would send out any one of the four above named.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 14, 1964  Salisbury, N. C.  Rock Hill vs Salisbury      BUDD, Mike (Salisbury Outfielder)    22 year old left hand hitter. Recently finished Wake Forrest. Mike can run and he looks like a very good hitter, with power. First year player. I would select him at the draft price, - provided he can throw. Mike Budd should be on the Cardinal draft list.       BRANCH RICKEY      Somebody has since told me "Mike can throw."    B. R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 30 and March 31, 1964  St. Louis vs Chicago White Sox  St. Pete and Sarasota, Fla.      BUFORD, DON    This colored boy's stance, bat position, hand movement, level sweep of bat and stride, - everything about him at the plate is good. His bat is as far back as he can get it to start with and he should have great power. He can run. He is 27 years of age. There must be something wrong with the chap or surely he would have been in the major league sometime ago. Buford is a switch hitter.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: Philadelphia, Pa.  May 14, 1964  St. Louis vs Philadelphia      BUNNING, JIM    Can't field his position at all. Every delivery   ends up with is right foot 7 or 8 or 10 feet toward first   base. I don't see how he could field 'free' bunts on the   third base line.    I think it was Stengel who told me that Bunning   was inclined to tire in his later innings. I have seen   him in three games this year and Stengel's criticism would   hold good in those three games. He is a good looking   pitcher for three innings, - a strike out pitcher. And   he succumbs to adversity. Never let up on him. He can   be beat.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs Denver      BURDETTE, Fred (Salt Lake Pitcher)    A 28 year old right hand pitcher. Showed no speed in the two innings. In fact, no nothing.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: April 3, 1964  Ft. Myers, Fla.  St. Louis vs Pittsburgh      BURDETTE, LOU    Started the game today in Fort Myers against   Pittsburgh. I continue to believe and to say what I   have believed and said for the past year, viz, that this   old pitcher is 'through' and has been through for more   than a year. He can't help anybody win a pennant on a   major league club. He is a liability; never an asset.    If the Cardinal club can get anything at all,   it should take it. Otherwise, he should have his   unconditional release. It would be better to give   somebody $46,000 to take over his present contract than   it would to keep him. The liability is not confined   simply to $46,000 (his salary). The real liability is   seeing him in any intelligent effort to win.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 25, 1964  Bradenton, Fla.  St. Louis vs Kansas City    AKER, JACK    Right hand, 23 year old boy, first year with   major league club. He has good speed. Can throw   overhand but throws usually below three-quarters, -  almost sidearm. He has a fast curve which is just   so-so but has a slow curve that is a dandy change of  speed pitch. This player does not have an impressive   minor league record, but I believe he is a major league   pitcher. His record of bases on balls may be due to  temperament or stage fright. In any event, it does not   show control.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 14, 1964  Salisbury, N. C.  Rock Hill vs Salisbury      BURDIN, Joe (Salisbury Pitcher)    21 year old right hand pitcher, 6'2" tall and weighs about 185, with a darn good fast ball. Curve only so so. Threw a few change ups, possibly intended to be so called sliders, - none near the plate. First year pitcher. This boy might become quite a pitcher. He should be followed.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 18, 1964  Sarasota, Fla.  Sarasota Rookie League      BURROUGHS, Jacob    Right hand thrower, left hand hitting Negro outfielder, - only eighteen. Looks good running around. Up at the plate he looks like would hit but doesn't. If the final statistics show him good, - then I would bet that he is good.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 18, 1964  Sarasota, Fla.  Sarasota Rookie League      BUSSANICK, John    A 19 year old right hand hitting first baseman. Hold on to him. I believe he was a good pickup.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: May 1, 1964  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs Pittsburgh      BUTTERS, THOMAS    A big right hand pitcher. Came from Ohio Wesleyan. Branch told me he had a good knuckler. He didn't show it. He did show a good fast ball and a pretty good curve, and was effective against our club. I would like to own his contract.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 15, 964  Rock Hill, S. C.  Rock Hill vs Shelby      BYRD, Charlie  A 20 year old left hand hitting outfielder. No power. I am not sure about his arm and running speed but I doubt if either is above average. It doesn't hurt to hold on to him. He might give balance and respectability to some minor league club.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs Denver    ALOMAR, Santos Conde (Denver Infielder)    Colored shortstop. He can run, really run.  A good arm but not great. Has fine body control.  Can throw from all positions. I will not be surprised  if the boy goes major league. Everything depends upon  his hitting ability. Does not look like he will weigh  over 140 pounds, may be a bit heavier. Very young,  about 20.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 15, 1964  Rock Hill, S.C.  Rock Hill vs Shelby  ANTHON, Fred  A 22 year old right hand hitting infielder from St. Louis. I cannot believe that he is a major league possibility. He might become a very good Class B player.  BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 15, 1964  Rock Hill, S. C.    ARCIA, Jose    A 20 year old Cuban right hander from Batabano.  He has pitched two years with small classification  clubs for a grand total of 165 innings. He is a Negro.  Two managers in the Western Carolina League told me very  positively that the boy had no chance to go anywhere.  His two year record supports their opinion. I didn't  see him pitch, nor have a chance to work him out.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 23, 1964   St. Petersburg, Fla.   St. Louis vs Houston      ASPROMONTE, BOB    26 year old, tall right hand hitting third baseman. Should hit but doesn't. 25 Aspromontes' will finish well down in the second division.       BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: Leon "Duke" Carmel -- 2     The inside pitch below his beltline gives him serious trouble even from the Dudley machine. It could be true that he has been so disadvantaged for 5 years in playing the outside pitching that when the ball comes inside he has consistently either taken the pitch [and] (perhaps a called strike), or has hit it on the handle and this causes him to be unable to handle the inside pitch.   He frequently misses it altogether.   He is married and has several children -- comes from an economically/low family on the other side of the tracks in Brooklyn. Married to a very charming and lovable wife. Knows nothing except baseball and would give his soul to make good.   He has the sympathy of his manager and coaches and he certainly has mine.   I am simply non-plussed as to how to help this fellow.   At the present time, he should be kept at the pitching machines constantly.   Manager Keane tells me that we do not have at present any acceptable substitution at first base; that Duke Carmel can do the fielding job splendidly; that is, his arm [is very good] and, his running speed, [very good] and his fielding - all very good.   A left hand pinch hitter is highly desirable on the Cardinal Cub and Duke's power to right field makes the right field roof at Busch Stadium as easily reached by Duke as most boys make singles.   It is sorrowfully tragic to have him fail, but he certainly cannot help this club as a batsman with his present rating.   I hope that in three or four weeks from now I can write a different story.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 30 and March 31, 1964  St. Louis vs Chicago White Sox  St. Petersburg & Sarasota, Fla.    Carreon, Camilo  Well built, good size, right hand hitting   catcher. Below average power, fair runner, quick arm   and good enough. I would prefer him very much to   either Ricketts pr Coker.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 11, 1964  Raleigh, N.C.  Raleigh vs Burlington    Cecil, Edward  Pretty good fast ball. Not great at all. Curve ball does   curve, but certainly not a strike out pitch. Right hander.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 11, 1964  Raleigh, N.C.  Raleigh vs Burlington    Chasteen, Edwin  A 6'4" right hand hitting boy with power. Fairly good running speed and a very good arm. He shows energy and desire.  Chasteen broke into the game as a right hand pitcher. He got his unconditional release from somebody and the Cardinal organization picked him up as an outfielder. He is certainly inexperienced as a batter. Various pitches foot him completely and make him look bad.  Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 13, 1964  Winston-Salem, N.C.  Raleigh vs Winston-Salem      CHASTEEN, ED    Chasteen has temper. In the last inning, he swung hard at two fast balls through the middle. In fact, he 'pressed'. Then he took the left hander's curve through the middle and put on an act. I think this boy's problem is above his neck.    Sooner or later, he must be moved closer to the plate.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: September 14, 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville      CHRISLEY, NEIL    Not good enough to be desirable for AAA. If the Jacksonville roster needs clearance, he should be outrighted elsewhere.      BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Robert L. Hoswam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 11, 1964  Intra-squad Game    Coker, Jim  A very ordinary arm. In practice he throws without stepping. Very good. He gets the ball away with good throwing form. Very average arm, if that.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 18, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Detroit  "B" Game    Coker, Jim  He can't run and his arm is ordinary. Occasionally he will give a power stroke. He has hit effectively behind the runner a few times. If he hits over .250 in the major leagues, I will be surprised.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 18, 1964  Sarasota, Fla.  Sarasota Rookie League        <u>COLBERT< Nathan</u>    An 18 year old negro right hand hitting first baseman from St. Louis. A change of pace runner. That is bad. He could be a surprise in a sixty yard race. Very quick bat, very short stride, commands the plate, but was not at all impressive (in two games) at the plate. A big boy, well built. We must go along with him.        BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo      COLEMAN, "CHO CHO"    Catcher with Buffalo. Belongs to the Mets. He can   run. He can throw and in my judgment can be made into a much   better hitter. I think he is better than everything we have in   the Cardinal organization except McCarver. If we can pick him  up in a deal or at a reasonable price - say $10,000 or thereabouts,   I would take him. The boy will undoubtedly go to draft in AAA.   Unless Pacheco or Laboy or somebody like that comes to the front   this fall at the instructions camp, - as a catcher, I would like  to have staff discussion on Coleman.        BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 17, 1964  Tampa, Fla.  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    CAMPBELL, JIM (Cincinnati Catcher)    This boy catcher on the Cincinnati club   has a bat position like Johnny Lewis, - only much  worse. I doubt very much if this boy attracts  any attention as a major league batsman. I  think he will strike out about three times for  every base on balls. As a batsman, he has a  spot weakness on the fast ball pitched inside  to his letters and he is certainly not at hom  on breaking stuff.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 13, 1964  Winston-Salem, N.C.  Raleigh vs Winston-Salem    COLETTA, Chris (Winston-Salem Outfielder)    This fellow is a good looking ball player. Left hand hitter. He can run, and he is very aggressive. Everything about him looks major, particularly with a bat in his hands. I would like to have him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 18, 1964  Sarasota, Fla.  Sarasota Rookie League      CONSTABLE,, GARY    6' 4", 19 year old, right hand hitting catcher with surprising agility, - active, very likely a good receiver. On not one throw in practice and during the game did he show a strong arm. I don'tknow enought about him to vote.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 15, 1964  Rock Hill, S.C,  Rock Hill vs Shelby      COSMAN, Jim    Right hand pitcher. A corking good prospect for any major league club. If Jim pitches another great game or two for Rock Hill, he should be moved to Tulsa or surely as high as some AA club immediately.  I think this recommendation is very important.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: PEARSON  This big, right hander is an emotional cuss. An umpires decision or a wild pitch or what not, - anything and everything upsets him. He shows some sort of physical reaction on almost every called-ball pitch.    His job is to get control of his mind.    Never stops in his delivery with a runner on first base, - balks all the time.    23 years of age, but shows less poise than a rookie.    I believe the size of Pearson's hat is 6-1/4.    I doubt if there is anything the staff can do to help this boy in this camp. Some kind of a psychiatrist might help. I doubt it.      HARRIS  Harris is not ready at all for a game. Don't play him for a couple of weeks.      DAVIS  I don't like him as a batter. He give every evidence of a guess hitter. He takes perfect strikes and then is a goose for the the wild pitch. As a Cardinal prospect within any reasonable future time, you can have him.      COSMAN  No control of his curve ball. With men on base he has a quick throw. Starts his arm first. However his delivery is terribly slow. Anybody can steal on him. He must divide his weight. Cannot field his position.    I doubt very much that his early coming to the Cardinals can be helped very much in this camp.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 10, 1964  Intra-Squad Game      COX, RON    As a third baseman, he does not know how   to run a man down. He has probably never heard   of a false motion.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 11, 1964  Intra-Squad Game      COX, RON    Favors the leg very obviously when running.  Actually limps. He is a pretty good runner  even with the limp.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 18, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St Louis vs Detroit  "B" Game    COX, RON  He is a big boy but has never shown me anything  especially good in any direction. I have never  seen him above average in running. Arm good, not  great. Seems to have good power and his batting  form is O.K. but he just doesn't hit. I think he  lacks adventure both in the field and on the bases  and everywhere else. He seems never to stand out  with exceptional play in any direction.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 16, 1964  Jacksonville, Fla.  Columbus vs Jacksonville    COX, Ron  Has a very good arm. Not above an average runner. I think he is below, but managers and scouts call him average. Everybody, it seems, is high on Cox. He never hits when I see him. Batting form is good.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo      COX, RON    This right hand hitting, tall outfielder gives just enough promise to cause our scouts and managers not to give up on him. He may not be a guess hitter, but he acts like one. I recommend that we ask waivers on Cox and if he is claimed, withdraw. If not claimed, outright his contract to Jacksonville and let the player go to draft. I would rather have Warwick or Shannon than Cox, and I am far from being enthusiastic about [e]ither of these two boys. I prefer Warwick over Shannon.    BRANCH RICKEY      August 19, 1964    Cox has a very strong arm. Hasn't the least idea how to throw from the outfield. Has been playing for three years professionally and throws 'andy over'.    B. R.      cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: September 14 and 15 , 1964  Rochester, New York  Rochester vs Jacksonville      COX, RONALD    I had a long visit with Cox. He is negative in every way. He has size, youth, and physical qualifications. He professes faith and confidence in his future, however in a very quiet and subdued manner. He can run fast enough but I doubt very much if he would ever elect to steal a base. He can throw with great velocity but regularly his throw indicates a desire for distance. Almost every throw from the outfield shows high trajectory. I have never seen either in practice or in a game any throw from him that could be cut off by the relay man. He is a good outfielder.    He has power at the plate but he is continuously fooled, confused, bewildered by varying pitches. It is my judgment that he is a .260 hitter and only that with Jacksonville or anywhere else. I seriously doubt if the boy will ever become a regular major league player in any position. He confesses quite candidly that he feels that his weakness is against right hand pitching; states that he has great confidence against left handers; feels that he can play first base even better than the outfield. The right hander's breaking stuff wrecks him.    This boy should go to Hollywood and hit in the cages as much as three hours every day, accompanied by two other batsmen. (An ample number of batsmen's gloves should be in Hollywood on opening date). It is possible that shifting this boy to left hand hitting against right hand pitching would make a different player out of him. He should be fully exposed to that experiment.    There is no aggressiveness in him. There is no "come on boys, let's beat them" in his system. He is a clean thinking and clean living fellow, - a native of Columbia, Missouri and has a full senior year's work ahead of him in order to get his university

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 17, 1964  Tampa, Fla.  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    CAMPBELL, JIM (Cincinnati Catcher)    This young catcher on the Cincinnati club  has a bat position like Johnny Lewis, - only much  worse. I doubt very much if this boy attracts  any attention as a major league batsman. I  think he will strike out about three times for  every base on balls. As a batsman, he has a  spot weakness on the fast ball pitched inside  to his letters and he is certainly not at home  on breaking stuff.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: COX, RONALD -2- 9/14 and 15/64    degree at Missouri. He was married to a Portsmouth, Virginia girls six months ago, - happily married. I do not know how he got up courage to propose. I wish he might be willing to report to Hollywood.      BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 16, 1964  Lakeland, Fla.  St. Louis vs Detroit    CRAIG, PETER  An awfully big man. Right hander. Good fast ball. Showed no curve, - had the effect of a change. Control only so so. He had two and O and three and one constantly. Not very impressive.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 16, 1964  Lakeland, Fla.  St. Louis vs Detroit    CRAIG, ROGER  Excellent control with varied stuff.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: April 25, 1964  St. Louis, Mo.      CRAIG, ROGER    A smart, resourceful, courageous pitcher. His fast ball ain't. He has just about good enough stuff to stay on the team and get beat. I don't believe he is a dependable pitcher on a first division club.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: April 6, 1964  Homestead, Fla.      DAMASKA, WILLIAM    My dictation on Bill Damaska of August 2, 1963 still stands.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo    DAMASKA, JACK    This right hand hitting infielder is a pretty good  ball player. I believe him to be a good average runner, a good  arm, - not at all great. Should play second base. Fine body  control. Not erratic. A very good man at the plate. Chokes  the bat. Occasionally follows the side arm curve, striking  out. He is a very good man at Jacksonville. A pennant winning  minor league player. I would not bring him to the Cardinals  now or ever.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: September 14 and 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    DAMASKA, JACK    My last report on Damaska still holds.  Some major league club might draft him from  Jacksonville. So what? It must be said that this  boy is always right where he ought to be in or out   of uniform. He is really a winning player.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: April 6, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    DAMASKA, WILLIAM    My dictation on Bill Damaska of August 2,   1963 still stands.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: July 15, 1964  Rock Hill, S. C.  Rock Hill vs Shelby    DAVIS, Ernest (Billy)    A very tall, 20 year old, right hand hitting  Negro outfielder. He can run and he can throw. He  cannot hit. I cannot put my finger on why. Billy  is a striker-outer, a low percentage batsman with power.  Last year at Brunswick. Keep him on a small club for  another year or so.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R

He shows  some sort of physical reaction on almost every  called-ball pitch.    His job is to get control of his mind.    Never stops in his delivery with a runner on first base, -  balks all the time.    23 years of age, but shows less poise than a rookie.    I believe the size of Pearson's hat is 6-1/4.    I doubt if there is anything the staff can do to help  this boy in this camp. Some kind of psychiatrist  might help. I doubt it.    HARRIS    Harris is not ready at all for a game. Don't play him  for a couple of weeks.    DAVIS    I don't like him as a batter. He gives every evidence  of a guess hitter. He takes perfect strikes and then  is a goose for the wild pitch. As a Cardinal prospect  within any reasonable future time, you can have him.    COSMAN    No control of his curve ball. With men on base he  has a quick throw. Starts his arm first. However  his delivery is terribly slow. Anybody can steal on  him. He must divide his weight. Cannot field  his position.    I doubt very much that his early coming to the Cardinals  can be helped very much in this camp.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs Denver    CAMPBELL, Ron (Salt Lake City Infielder)    A big boy, 24 years of age, a pretty good   arm and a quick bat. I have no figures on him and   I don't know his background, but on a two game look,   we should follow up on him.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; M-R
Transcription: March 30 and March 31, 1964  St. Louis vs Chicago White Sox  St. Petersbur and Sarasota, Fla.    DE BUSSCHERE, DAVE    A tremendous man. Right hand pitcher with  good speed and a high velocity curve. I don't believe  he is yet a control pitcher. Should become a corking  good major league pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 30 and March 31, 1964  St. Louis vs Chicago White Sox  St. Petersbur and Sarasota, Fla.    [*White Sox*]    DE BUSSCHERE, DAVE    A tremendous man. Right hand pitcher with  good speed and a high velocity curve. I don't believe  he is yet a control pitcher. Should become a corking  good major league pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: April 6, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    DeLEON, FELIX    Wouldn't change a single line of what I  wrote last summer.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Buffalo vs Jacksonville    DENNIS, DON    A nice boy. Pretty good fast ball, no assortment.  Not ready for the major league by any manner or means, and unless  he gets an effective additional pitch, he will never go major.    (Later)    He should go to the draft at Jacksonville.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: September 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    DENNIS, DONALD    A tall, courageous right hand pitcher.  He is young (22 years of age) and he has a good fast  ball, - a sidearm pitcher.
