Delivery repeats exactly  and he should have good control. I believe he does  have good control. Shows me no pitch worthwhile  other than his fast ball. If he would acquire other  usable pitches, he could go major league. At the  present time, he cannot help the Cardinal club.   What he might do at the end of another season, no  one knows. But he has size and youth and strength  and quite apparently a good heart. I do not know  anyone on the Cardinal staff, high or low, who believes  that Dennis can help the Cardinal team in 1965.  However, his protection should be discussed at the coming  annual meeting.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: Detroit, Michigan  June 5, 1964  Hamtramck Legion    DERAS, ART (Third Baseman)    6'2" tall. I am told that he weighs 190 pounds.  He looks 215 pounds to me. His arm is good. Seems to  be accurate but there was no occasion where the arm was  tested. If I could see him in the 270' outfield throwing  tests, I would know very definitely whether his arm is   above average.    His running is good, - not at all impressive as  a speedster, - just average. Form at the plate is good.  He has a high percentage batting record and undoubtedly a  power hitter. He shows power. He shows all signs of   aggressive play. Not quite a 'holler' guy but he belongs  in the cheering section at that.    He will be 18 [*surely 19*] this coming September. He has a  good chance of becoming a better runner.    This chap has an especially fine record as a  pitcher. He has averaged 15 strikeouts per nine inning  game for the past two years and his coach told me that  his earned run average was practically nothing. My  interest in this player at this time would be directed  toward his pitching. That could be it. Then if his  batting held up as the scouts apparently think it will,  he could easily be changed to some other position.    I am not in favor of any high bonus for the   simple reason that the first year player rule would  handicap our club in 1965 very much. We would either  lose him for $8,000 or we would have to hold him on our  team and he is not ready to help the Cardinals, - not  now.    Right hand hitter. Bat well back and quiet,   short stride, level sweep. Batting box position  is very good. I see nothing whatever wrong with his  form. His head goes toward the pitch with every swing.  He should be a good hitter, and his form supports his  record for power.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: July 14, 1964  Salisbury, N. C.  Rock Hill vs Salisbury      DERAS, Art    I saw this boy in a high school game in  Detroit some weeks ago. He had perfect batting form.   In the game tonight, he looked like he had a case of  cramps, - came out of his shell late. Showed no  power. I believe he will become a good hitter, a power  hitter, someday. Surely he will come to be a bit  relaxed. I hope that management will not advise him about  his batting or change him in any respect until, per chance  he gives up.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: July 15, 1964  Rock Hill, S. C.  Rock Hill vs Shelby      DERAS, Arthur    In the batting practice, he should hit every  pitch with intent, particularly try to pull the ball to  left field. He is a give up mess at the present time.  He will not be eighteen until later this year. I think  that this boy will become a great batsman someday, and  eventually will go major. Under the present rules of  baseball he is a throw away investment of any bonus  above $8,000.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: October 9, 1964  West Palm Beach, Florida  St. Louis vs Milwaukee        DERAS, ARTHUR    He must watch his weight. Not yet 18 and surely he is already overweight.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: April 7, 1964  Homestead, Fla.      DIAZ, MARIO    He can throw. I saw him at the plate four times in one game, but he was unimpressive as a batsman. Very much so.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: July 14, 1964  Salisbury, N.C.  Rock Hill vs Salisbury    CAMPISI, Sal    A 21 year old right hand pitcher. A Benny  Borgmann product. A fair fast ball, and a fair curve, -  a straight downer. Only two pitches, nothing else  attempted. Salisbury knocked him around pretty  vigorously with fifteen hits or thereabouts, - and  plenty of extra bases, in seven innings. He was as  cool as a cucumber all the way. He finished as he  started, no better, no worse. I doubt this fellow's  major league future but must certainly he must get  an additional usable pitch to go anywhere.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: July 11, 1964  Raleigh, N. C.  Raleigh vs Burlington      DIAZ, Roberto    Stands entirely too far from the plate. All he has to hit with at anytime is his forearm. I don't see how he could have any power whatever.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: July 13, 1964  Winston-Salem, N. C.  Raleigh vs Winston-Salem      DIAZ, ROBERTO    He can run like a son-of-a-gun. If he hits he will be a good ball player. He can throw. No power.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 4, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Mets Inter-Squad Game      DILLON, STEPHEN (Mets Pitcher)    Left hander. Saw him only from bleacher position. Looked to be fast. Not afraid to throw a slow curve and he had control of it.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: April 4, 1964  Homestead, Florida      DOWLING, DAVE    A left handed pitcher from the Northwest. A University of California boy. Pretty good speed and darn good control of it. Has a straight downer curve and it curves and he showed very good control of that pitch in his warmup. Has a change up on the fast ball. It is a dandy but he tips it off very late in his delivery. A batsman can know that it is a change up immediately when the ball leaves the pitcher's hand. It is a late tip off but nevertheless it is a tip off.    This boy finishes his pitch on the left foot. It seldom comes up even with the right foot (his stepping foot) when the pitch is finished. But it does come up in time to make a fielding pitcher out of him. He does not talk or act like a kid. It seems to me that he could learn to pitch out of conversation. He has control and a variety of pitches. I forgot to ask him his age. I guess him to be 23. He might be a quickie, - meaning that he showed me enough stuff and control to start in AAA.    Not very often does one run across a free agent pitcher as finished as this boy.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo      DOWLING, DAVE    This left handed youngster has hit tonight very freely.   He needs the Florida 'instruction' camp very much. It might do   wonders for him. He needs to master the knee 'pause', - an easy   thing for this particular pitcher to learn. He is an amateur   on the pitcher's mound, a perfect neophyte in the art of pitching.   He doesn't know much but he has a lot of stuff. He is a major   league prospect. However, he should be left at Jacksonville where   it is to be hoped that he will pitch regularly.        BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: April 4, 1964  Homestead, Florida    CARLTON, STEVE    A very tall left handed pitcher-well built boy. Long,   slender strong hands. A good fast ball, straight   as a string but good velocity. A fair curve and   decent control of it. He has a change up on his   fast ball which is really a change of pace curve and   this chap has the most remarkable control of this   particular change up that I have seen in a long   time. Steve has an intelligent face, fine eyes set   far apart, and intelligent conversation. He can   learn to hold men on the first base beyond any doubt.   Good aptitude.    His delivery is not deeply faulty in the   sense of becoming a fielder. He is not out of   position badly to go either direction ,-right or left.   I like this boy. I would not be surprised to see him   in the major league. In fact, I will be surprised   if he doesn't go to the major league, - and perhaps   sooner rather than later. He lives in Miami. His father   works as a maintenance man for Pan American.   Graduated last June and will be 19 years old this   coming December.    Whoever manages him should let him alone.   Don't [t]ry to over-instruct him. He simply needs to   pitch.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: Hollywood, Florida  October 19, 1964    CARLTON, STEVE    A very good fast ball. It is major league. His curve ball is also major league but Steve shows a serious lack of control of his curve. He is fairly lucky to get the curve ball pitch within the strike zone anywhere. He needs a lot of game work.    His change up on the fast ball is his best pitch. His delivery on this change up is identical with his fast ball pitch.    He can go major the very minute he has anything like decent control.     At the present time, he should not be given or coached to get a different change up. As he develops and is able to use what he has, he may come to the place and probably will that will permit him to do as he pleases on all his pitches. Now his challenge is strictly on control, spot pitching at the strings and really low spot pitching in his games, - here at Hollywood.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo        CARMEL, DUKE    Having a great year at Buffalo. Our scouts and   field men should be very careful in judging Buffalo players, -  on account of park size.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: [1964]    Leon "Duke" Carmel     I hope my later report on Duke Carmel will read differntly  from this one. This is a tragic case of a fine physical speciman  and a most likable person failing as a major league player.   He has had 5 full years in professional baseball and he is now  25 years of age, and he has always hit left handed and has always  hit from the same batting box position. His rear foot - the left one -   the toe of his left food is 28" from a line drawn at right angles to  the plate position. He could not reach the outside of the plate with  both hands on the bat and yet he has held that position for 5 full  years.   Las year he hit .243 at Jacksonville. He is a power hitter --  plenty of power particularly, of course, to right field, but he hits  the long ball to left also.   He shows no aptitude whatever to the suggestions made by  Manager Keane or Vernon Benson or anyone else.   To draw a comparison, when Buchek was turned from a righthand  hitter to a lefthand hitter - on the first 12 pitches he made contact  on every pitch and continued to get the bat and ball together  almost without exception. When Duke was turned over from a lefthander  to a righthander, he missed the first 11 good pitches and hit the 12th  and missed the next 6 -- and I mean he missed them. He was not   swinging hard. He was instructed to just simply get the bat and  ball together as though he were in a pepper game. He simply could  not hit the ball at all.   He did better hitting left handed when told to hit with "intent"  meaning pulling or pushing the ball but not at all to compare with  either Gagliano or Buchek.      -more-

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 23, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Houston    FOX, NELLIE    37 years old. Can do everything pretty good.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: April 4, 1964      I would keep Gagliana, Kolb, Maxvill, and Buchek, any one of whom could play the outfield if necessary. I would send out Shannon, Clemens, or both before I would send out any one of the four above named.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 10, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    GAGLIANO, PHIL    Not a great arm, but a good arm. Not a great runner, but a good runner. Not a great hitter, maybe a good hitter. 25 Gaglianos' will finish in second division in 1964 and in my judgment in 1965. Later? May be!    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo    GAGLIANO, PHIL    This boy is a fine gentleman, - a pretty good ball player - hitting, running, and throwing. I would ask waivers on him immediately and if claimed would withdraw. Then be ready for the market. If the price is right, let him go. If unable to make a deal prior to the December draft meeting, we should consider letting the player go to draft, particularly so if our reserve list is very tight.    BRANCH RICKEY      August 19, 1964    I doubt if he understands that he is a shallow outfielder when he plays shortstop. He has no remote concept how to hold a runner on second base. He is not what you would call a power hitter in any respect, although he will give you the occasional long ball. I don't think the Cardinal club should count on him at all for 1965. I would not take him to the spring training camp. We have got to have better stuff than Gagliano to win a pennant.    B. R.    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: September 14 and 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    GAGLIANO, PHIL    Very positively cannot make the play in the hole when he plays shortstop. He does not have that kind of an arm. I think he can run good average. He is versatile - can play really any position. May be a major league prospect. His greatest asset is his probable future ability at the plate. He might come to be a major league percentage batsman with medium power. I would not be worried about his loss to some other club. He is claimed on waivers, a possible deal should be explored. We should not hold him cheaply. He is a better man on the Cardinal club in 1965 than James or Warwick or Maxvill or even Buchek. He does not have the potential that Buchek has. Buchek has a better arm, - much better, and more power at the plate. I think Phil will outhit Buchek percentagewise in the major league.    This player should be discussed at our annual meeting on Thursday, October 1st.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 4, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Mets Inter-Squad Game    GARDNER, RICHARD (Mets Pitcher)    Left hand pitcher. Loose as a goose. Looked like he had a good curve ball. Not as fast as Dillon.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: October 9, 1964  West Palm Beach, Fla.  St. Louis vs Milwaukee    GARRETT, CHARLES (Milwaukee Second Baseman)    In the first inning, he made a very good play. He can cover the ground. If he can hit, he is a pretty good boy.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 14, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Mets    GIBSON, BOB    A very real pitcher. When trying out young players, it is a great idea if management, and scouts and coaches would keep in mind Bob Gibson as a model for comparison and rate the prospect's stuff accordingly.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 30 and March 31, 1964  St. Pete and Sarasota, Fla.  St. Louis vs Chicago White Sox    GIBSON, BOB    Has often impressed me as being subject to panic when he is in the "tight", particularly in his fielding. With a man on second in fielding the sacrifice bunt, he is likely not to get the ball at all. He will look at third and fumble the ball or hardly touch it or if the ball is hit back to him in a tight score game with two outs and a runner on third, he is prone to throw the ball into the right field stands. And with a double play in order, his haste to get a runner at second base makes him very erratic.    I don't believe that Gibson pitches his very best all the time.    BRANCH RICKEY    He is a great pitcher.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs Denver    GOLDY, Purn (Denver Outfielder)    Tall, well built right hand hitting outfielder. A striker-outer at the plate.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo    ESPINO, HECTOR    A big, strong, rugged 23 year old right hand hitting Mexican. Arm ordinary, running speed below average. As a first baseman, he is very sluggish. With a runner on first, he will not cover over five feet of ground. We will know more about him at the end of the season.    Jacksonville has until October 1st on payment of $25,000 if the player is kept on or after that date. If retained at that time, the club has to pay an additional $35,000 if and when player is retained 90 days on a major league club. Unless I have good reason to change my mind, I would not give $2500 for this player.    BRANCH RICKEY    August 19, 1964    I don't know who recommended this boy but if it was one of our regular scouts, he should be fired. Can't run, can't throw and can't move.    B. R.    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam    [*Bob: - If & when it is decided not to exercise the options -- notice should be given as early as possible, & a diffrent deal might be encurged. I suggest you talk with Houston in advance about Their interest. He can't run & he cannot Throw _   BR*]

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 4, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Mets Inter-Squad Game    GONDER, JESSE (Mets Catcher)    Left hand hitter. Stands far back of the plate. Good batting form. Has power. Average runner. Arm good enough. Gives the impression of 'not giving a damn'. He drops a lot of balls and he didn't go after them when he missed them.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: July 18, 1964  Sarasota, Fla.  Sarasota Rookie League    GORDON, Mike    A 20 year old right hand hitting catcher. This boy can throw. His batting box position is good. One time he will swing with abandon, then he comes with a half-hearted wave of the bat. Seems to be fooled early and often. His hitting could improve with experience. I would look at him further.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: July 15, 1964  Rock Hill, S. C.  Rock Hill vs Shelby    GRAY, Charles    A 6'3", 200 pound Negro left hander, 25 years old. He did not show me great stuff, although he beat Shelby 4 to 1 last night. His control was so so. He would have to get a good knuckle ball or some additional usable third pitch for me to consider him a major league possibility.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 21, 1964  St. Petersburgh, Fla.  St. Louis vs Kansas City    GREEN, DICK  23 years old. Small fellow. He can run and he can field. I don't believe he is a power hitter and I don't believe he is a good hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 23, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Houston    GROTE, GERRY    He has a great arm and impressed me as a good receiver. He is a first year player 21 years old. He might become a player of considerable interest as a major leaguer.    BRANCH RICKEY    (LATER)    Has a great arm, but terribly inaccurate.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: April 6, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    GUTHRIE, DAVE    Right hander, 6'1" tall, 195 pounds, fast ball very ordinary, not great at all, but seemed to have very good control of it.    He has a slider. The effect is a fairly fast curve ball breaking about three to four inches but it really does slide. It is a usable pitch for this chap.    The strength of this pitcher lies in his curve ball when controlled. It is a sweet pitch. It is a Koufax pitch, a Broglio pitch, a Shantz pitch. Guthrie has it. However, I say very positively that he doesn't have usable control of this exceptionally good pitch. If he had so-called perfect control of this curve ball, he could go all the way. Without control of this curve ball, I doubt if he could ever go major league. His job is to acquire control of the curve. If he does, I think he might pitch anywhere, - right away.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 4, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Mets Inter-Squad Game     HAAS, WILLIAM (Mets First Baseman)    Tall, left hand hitter. Good form at the plate. Quiet bat, normal stride.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 10, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    HAGEN, DONALD    A right hander, average size, free movement, and looks like he has pretty good stuff. He has the worst follow through in pitching form of any man I have seen in years.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 18, 1964  St. Petersburgh, Fla.  St. Louis vs Detroit  "B" Game    HAGEN, DONALD  Instruction and practice has obviously   improved this player's follow through. He still   falls away toward first base but he is not as   bad as he was. He still comes up to his ear   with both hands starting his pitching movement, -   with a runner on first. He has pretty good   stuff and he is very aggressive.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: July 11, 1964  Raleigh, N. C.  Raleigh vs Burlington    HAGEN, DONALD    A 5'9", 155 pound right hand pitcher. Pretty good fast ball and a pretty good curve. He has a fine velocity curve ball, - a 3/4 downer. Almost never over the plate. It is his best pitch. He has good speed, and a corking good pitcher in the Carolina League.    Every pitching delivery ends up falling toward first base.    I don't believe he should be protected from the draft by the Cardinal club regardless of his statistical record at Raleigh. Let him go to the draft at Jacksonville.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 18, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Detroit  "B" Game    FAUL, BILL (Detroit Pitcher)    Right hand pitcher. Stocky built boy. Not tall but looks like a two hundred pounder. He can throw hard and he has a beautiful slow curve ball. He throws it with full force and it really curves. A very deceptive pitch. He was usually wild, - unusually wild and usually wild inside. He knocked down a number of batters in his six innings and plunked two solidly. If this boy had control, I think he could pitch anywhere.    I am told that this boy is completely eccentric. If he has any sense, he would stay in the majors.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: July 11, 1964  Raleigh, N. C.  Raleigh vs Burlington    HARRIS, Jim    As good a defensive man, probably, as there is in our organization. As fast as Maxvill but more power at the plate. Can't hit more than .200 against good right hand[ed] pitchers even in Class D. He says it hurts his arm to hit left handed against right hand pitching. Which arm? You can have him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: July 13, 1964  Winston-Salem, N. C.  Raleigh vs Winston-Salem    HARRIS, Jim    Probably the quickest major league prospect on the club. However, his future is minor league. It hurts his arm to bat left handed against right hand pitching. Which arm? A major leaguer but POOH with him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: PEARSON    This big, right hander is an emotional cuss. An umpires decision or a wild pitch or what not, - anything and everything upsets him. He shows some sort of physical reaction on almost every called-ball pitch.    His job is to get control of his mind.    Never stops in his delivery with a runner on first base, - balks all the time.    23 years of age, but shows less poise than a rookie.    I believe the size of Pearson's hat is 6-1/4.    I doubt if there is anything the staff can do to help this boy in this camp. Some kind of a psychiatrist might help. I doubt it.    HARRIS    Harris is not ready at all for a game. Don't play him for a couple of weeks.    DAVIS    I don't like him as a batter. He gives every evidence of a guess hitter. He takes perfect strikes and then is a goose for the wild pitch. As a Cardinal prospect within any reasonable future time, you can have him.    COSMAN    No control of his curve ball. With men on base he [is] has a quick throw. Starts his arm first. However his delivery is terribly slow. Anybody can steal on him. He must [deivid] divide his weight. Cannot field position.    I doubt very much that his early coming to the Cardinals can be helped very much in this camp.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: July 10, 1964  Durham, N. C.  Raleigh vs Durham    HARTLESS, Leon    Big left hand hitting outfielder with Durham. Has power. Looks like a good outfielder. Impressed me very much as a good looking ball player. Saw him in only one game.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo    HERNENDEZ, EVELIO    Right hand pitcher. A 'dart thrower', Clyde King calls him. He is just that. He doesn't belong on the Jacksonville club in 1965.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: September 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    HERNANDEZ, Hoevelio    I have seen him three times, - altogether five innings. He looked unimpressive in all directions. I do not have any positive opinion about his future. He should be discussed at our coming annual meeting.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 4, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Mets Inter-Squad Game    HICKMAN, JAMES (Mets Outfielder)    Right hand hitter with power. Looks at the ball after he hits it and finally decides to run. Then loafs.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo    HINSLEY,    Young right hand pitcher with Buffalo. He has a whale of a lot of speed.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: August 19, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo    HINSLEY (Buffalo Pitcher)    Has high class speed. A very young right hander. A fine prospect. Drafted by the Mets from Pittsburgh.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: September 14, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    HOBBIE, GLEN    I wish we could make a deal somewhere or other than would give us more than the waiver price. If claimed, we should undertake to make a deal with the claiming club at some figure exceeding the waiver price and this should be done before October 15th. In my book, he is not a major leaguer and he should be disposed of for cash if indeed we cannot get some player for him. If New York is interested, a deal should be made.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 17, 1964  Tampa, Florida  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    FANOK, HARRY    He still goes up to his ear with both hands on practically every pitch when supposedly holding runners on base.    Either consciously or sub-consciously or even unconsciously his arm is bothering him whether it should or not. In the three innings against the Reds in Tampa on March 17, 1964, he didn't cut loose.    He simply cannot hold runners on first base. A peg-leg could steal on him. Harry has a good curve and a darn good change of pace pitch.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs Denver    HOLDENER, Lou (Salt Lake Catcher)    A big fellow. No arm, no run, no hit. A handicap to Salt Lake City.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: Sarasota, Fla.  July 18, 1964  Sarasota Rookie League    HOUSE, Dick    I don't think he can hit a lick and even if he does get the ball and bat together, neither would go very far. He does not have a great arm. I can't imagine him ever catching a major league game.    BRANCH RICKEY    An 18 year old right hand hitting catcher.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 10, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    HUGHES, RICHARD R. H. Pitcher    He has a good fast ball and a darn good curve and he has changes of speed and is not afraid to use it. He impressed me very favorably in his first workout. His delivery carries him completely toward first base. He could hardly field any ball hit to his right, - or back through the box. I think this fellow has good stuff. He has the bad fault of raising both hands to his ear before he pitches, - when holding men on.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: March 17, 1964  Tampa, Fla  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    HUGHES, RICHARD    He goes up to his chin with both hands when holding runners on base.    He lets the catcher do all his pitching. Hughes does not have Walter Johnson's fast ball but he does have a pretty good curve and a corking change-up. If Hughes has good enough control and knows his hitters and has some pitching sense, I think he could be an acceptable major league pitcher. The first of these time will tell, and the second he certainly can get, - the third I do not know about. But, if he lets Ricketts do his pitching, I would say he has very little sense.    In his three innings against Cincinnati in Tampa on March 17, 1964, he had no control. He was one and nothing, two and nothing, three and one, three and two all the way, all the time, - except when some Cincinnati rookie would hit at bad pitches.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: April 1, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.    HUGHES, RICHARD    I think this fellow should be sent out on option. I don't think he can help us. And this brings me to remark that if Washburn and Fanok are disabled, our pitching staff is not deep. Humphreys at this writing is a "keeper".    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: September 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    HUGHES, RICHARD    This tall, right handed 26 year old pitcher is not ready for the major league. In the first place, he had no control of anything in his last game. His curve ball is uncertain. Now and then it will break splendidly. About one half of the time, it shows no deceptive deflection and he is wilder with his curve than he is with his fast ball. He may have change of speed pitches. I have never seen them.    If he is claimed on waivers, I would let him go. If he is not claimed on waivers, I would assign his contract immediately to Jacksonville and let him go to draft. Natively he has good stuff, enough indeed but he is far from being ready for the Cardinals.    If he is not claimed on waivers, at $20,000, most assuredly he would not be drafted at $25,000.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 11, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    HUMPHREYS, BOB    Humphreys has pretty good stuff. Not the "stuff" that Hughes has. I risk the very early opinion that Hughes will come quicker to and last longer in the major leagues than Humphreys.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1955; A-B
Transcription: April 1, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Philadelphia    HUMPHREYS, BOB    I don't think Humphreys is ready to help our club or any major league club. He might be a pretty good pitcher someday. I doubt it. He should be sent out on option.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 18, 1964  Al Lang Field    HUNTER, JASPER (Gibbs College)    Fair arm. Good runner. Good form at the plate.    (later( Arm good enough.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 6, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    HUNTER, MIKE    No good as a ball player.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 14, 1964  Salisbury, N. C.  Rock Hill vs Salisbury    PARLIER, WILLIAM (Salisbury Outfielder)  20 years old, six footer, big boy. Switch hitter with power on either side. This boy should be scouted further.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 6, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    IGNASIAK, TERRY    Right hand boy, good size, good delivery. Didn't impress me greatly with his fast ball. Curve fair. Change up very good indeed as far as velocity is concerned, - also so far as delivery was concerned. However, he did not have good control of his change ups. It will be interesting to follow this first year player wherever he goes. Nobody can say right now that he doesn't have a change to become a good pitcher.    He has the fine quality of throwing all pitches with the same delivery.    And he can hold men on base surely because he throws so quickly. If he loses his job wherever he may be sent, it will be because of his lack of control. If his manager can get him through the non-control stage, the boy could surprise us.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: September 14 & 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    JACKSON, LOUIS (Rochester Outfielder)    Left hand hitting outfielder. Colored boy from Louisiana. No good. He swings "north." Home run or nothing, - usually nothing.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 17, 1964  Tampa, Florida  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    JAMES, CHARLEY    Any pitcher, right or left, with good stuff and good control reduces Charley James to a .250 hitter, at most. He can be pitched to.    A lot of power if he gets his pitch. James is a highly intelligent gentleman and his general intelligence makes it hard for me to believe that he is a guess hitter. But he has all the actions of it at the plate.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 25, 1964  Bradenton, Fla.  St. Louis vs Kansas City    JAMES, CHARLIE    If James is the regular left fielder for 162 games, we will have a hard job winning a pennant. On every fly ball, - however easy to catch, he will take the double step in throwing. And -- he doesn't have a great arm, - far from it in my book.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: Flint, Michigan  May 21, 1964    JASTER, DANIEL    Left hand pitcher, 6'2" tall, 190 pounds, 17 years of age, from Midland, Michigan. Will be 18 in September, 1964.    His brother, Larry, now 20, is now with Jacksonville in the Cardinal organization.    Speed is good, not great but good. Just about identical with Larry's.    I sat about eight feet behind the catcher for seven innings as he pitched against the Central High School team of Flint, Michigan. The Flint team is made up of fine athletes, better hitters by far than the average high school team. Daniel struck out seven and walked four in the seven inning game. In the first four innings, he threw only three curves, only one of which was close to the plate. In the fifth inning, he threw three or four curves and in the sixth inning, getting into trouble, he pitched a half dozen or more curves. Not more than two curve pitches during his entire fifth, sixth and seventh innings were within the strike zone. Daniel does not have control of the curve, - not enough to be highly usable against high school teams.    His fast ball is well above the average speed of young players and his strikeouts generally were the result of hitting at bad balls. He gave up six hits, one of which was a home run over the centerfield fence, - a 400' distance by a left hand hitter.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: Daniel Jaster -2-    Daniel is a well built athlete, with good coordination. Is active, alert. Has good delivery and can field his position. He has a corking move to first base; comes to a complete pause with his left knee and in the course of the delivery can throw either to first base or to the home plate, legitimately.    I watched Daniel in the batting practice, which was short, and four times at bat in the game. He was easily the best looking batman on his team, and that statement could mean a good deal because the opposing pitcher was a right hander with exceptional ability and Daniel is a right hand hitter.    He shows no emotion under stress and there was a lot of emotion in this game. The kids showed more nervousness from the catcher to the center fielder, including both, than Daniel did.     The Midland team won six to five.    After the game, I visited with his mother and his stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Byrd. We discussed Larry at some length. He gave his mother $10,000 out of his St. Louis bonus and has not been profligate with the rest of it.    There were fifteen or maybe twenty scouts observing the game and because of Larry's bonus and reputation, Daniel has been followed this past year and particularly in Detroit last summer by several clubs from both the American and National Leagues. The general expectation of a big bonus to Daniel is obviously shared by Mr. and Mrs. Byrd. I discussed with them the advantages of Daniel's being in the same organization with Larry and there can be no doubt that the boy prefers St. Louis on equal terms offered elsewhere.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: Daniel Jaster -3-    The boy is definitely a major league pitching prospect with a big, strong, active body, born only 17-1/2 years ago.    In the olden days when we had Class C and D Clubs, he could by the end of his first season in C or D doubtless become a winning pitcher. I would not dare to send him above that classification in his first assignment. His control would not support it, - neither would his 'stuff', except his fast ball. (Not once in the seven innings did he throw a change of speed pitch).    He could not now help Tulsa or Jacksonville. He would indeed be very crude and nervous in either place. If he were to be signed by the St. Louis club, it would be necessary for him to be retained on its active list in 1965 or lose him at $8,000. He does not now have the control such as Bakenhaster has and I think baseball people who know both players would generally agree that Bakenhaster is a much quicker prospect than Daniel.    I met Daniel's coach. He was simply a salesman, - "better than Larry, etc. etc."    I cite the Bakenhaster comparison simply to imply that the Cardinal club can find and probably will find [corking] quicker prospects as first year men than Daniel. Dowling is far ahead of Daniel in poise and control, know how, and stuff.    If it were not for the draft rule on first year players, I would be willing to go into the competitive market for Daniel's contract. I do not recommend a high bonus for Daniel. It simply means a handicap to the Cardinal club in 1965 or the loss of the player at $8,000.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: Daniel Jaster -4-    If some other club gets him, and doubtless that will happen, then such club will be under the same handicap. It must keep him on its own so-called active list or lose him to some other club at $8,000. I would rather see the Cardinals in a position to take the player on a draft claim in 1965 than I would to see the club take the money loss itself.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: October 9, 1964  West Palm Beach, Florida  St. Louis vs Milwaukee    JASTER, DANIEL    All base runners can run on him. Hands are not set for quick delivery. Has a good arm. Plenty of stuff. Runners take off when he raises his knee and he doesn't start his pitch with his arm until the knee is as high as his hands. Daniel needs to divide his weight and then start his arm first. Daniel has no fast curve, - at least he didn't show any.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: October 10, 1964  Hollywood, Fla.    JASTER, DANIEL    This strong, rugged, 6'3" left hander has a pitching problem in more than one direction. In the first place, he has a lot of stuff - a fast ball, a curve, a change up on the fast ball, etc. He needs control of the curve ball before he ever pitches in very high company. It is not controlled at the present time. He just throws a curve.    The biggest problem with this boy is holding men on base. To begin with, he dangles his right leg. He puts no weight on it. In the second place, he has a slow movement of his lower limb and the knee comes very slowly up and around. Then when the knee starts forward, he starts his pitch with his arm. By that time, the man has stolen second base. Of course, my description sounds worse and is worse than the actual performance, but the exaggeration simply emphasizes the boy's biggest problem in becoming a pitcher.    First of all, he must put weight on his right leg in taking his pitching position with a man on first and he must put enough weight on that leg that he cannot take the long, slow sweep with his right knee. This weight balancing process might correct somewhat the fault but I don't believe it will cure him altogether. The boy is inclined by habit surely to move the knee up and back and around very slowly, permitting the runner to break. If he were to hold the knee in a short stop in the course of his delivery and go either to first or home with it, he could retain that slow movement and I believe that this is the procedure for him to follow. It will take some time for him to perfect any delivery to hold men on. He has good stuff and has a lot of patience. He should be pitched a lot before next October 1st. Daniel will probably lose most of the games he plays in this instruction league. I think it will take a long time for him to become a major league pitcher. He has so much to learn.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 16, 1964  Lakeland, Fla.  St. Louis vs Detroit    FISHER, FRED (FRITZ)    Left hander. University of Michigan boy. Pretty good fast ball, fair curve, and showed good control. I would like to see more of this boy. He might be a pretty good pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: Hollywood, Florida  October 19, 1964    JASTER, DANIEL    This left hand pitcher can control the pitch if he wants to enough. Give him a spot object and he will come pretty nearly hitting it.    His fast ball is good enough. His curve ball is pretty good, - not great. His change up off the fast ball is exceptionally good and he has better control of that pitch, strange to say, then he has of either the fast ball or the curve.    I must work with him alone with no other pitcher for an extended time at the earliest possible date.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 11, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    JASTER, LARRY    This boy surely can become a fine pitcher. When he gets some finish, - holding runners on base, fielding his position, knowledge of batters, pitching with control purpose, etc., - he can go to town.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 26, 1964  Clearwater, Fla.  St. Louis vs Phillies    JOHNSON, ALEX    Colored boy. Right hand hitter. He is weak in the field of timing. Changes of speed bother him very much.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: September 14 & 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    JOHNSON, DAVE (Rochester Infielder)    Tall, slim, right hander now playing second base. 21 years old. First year player. Good looking fielder. Good batting form. A major league possibility. Try to include him in any possible deal with Baltimore.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 14, 1964  Salisbury, N. C.  Rock Hill vs Salisbury    JOHNSON, Raymond (Salisbury Catcher)    A right hand hitting rookie catcher on the Salisbury club. 18 years old. He can throw. He looks good at the plate and looked to be an average runner. This boy should be followed closely. I believe later this boy will go major.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: August 19, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo    JONES, CLEON (Buffalo Outfielder)    A colored, right handed outfielder. Belongs to the Mets. He can really run and he can really throw, and he has good power. This player should also be discussed at the fall meeting.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 6, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    KELLEY, WILLIAM (Rock Hill Pitcher)    I observed him again today in several innings against the Winnipeg club. What I said last July 30, 1963 still goes.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 14, 1964  Salisbury, N. C.  Rock Hill vs Salisbury    KNIPPLE, Ed (Salisbury Infielder)    First year player, 19 years old. Right hand hitter. He has a good arm and he can run. This boy should be scouted carefully.    The Salisbury club lists twelve first year players. Our very best scouting talent could be assigned very properly to the Salisbury club until downright dependable information is in our draft office.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: September 14, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    KNOWLES, DAROLD (Rochester Pitcher)    Left hand pitcher. 22 years old. Has stuff. Will surely go all the way.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 2, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Dodgers    KOUFAX, SANDY    In the first three innings in his game with the Cardinals on this date, more than half of his pitches were slow curve balls. How Taylor and Hughes and Fanok or indeed anybody can watch Koufax constantly pitch the changes of speed and not understand that they too could pitch effectively with their own changes of speed pitches is beyond me. Broglio and Shantz do pitch, for example, the slow curve frequently (Broglio not enough however), - but Fanok and Taylor could almost instantly be really great pitchers if they would use the curve ball more. This boy comes the nearest to perfection in pitching of anyone in either major league at the present time. He has more speed than Spahn and almost perfect control of a slow curve, - that really curves. He also has an exceptional fast ball and occasionally throws a change up off the fast ball. He has four pitches, - four different pitches and the best thing about Koufax that really makes him a great pitcher is the fact that he uses all four, - three of them constantly. There are several pitchers in the league and several on our club who have an assortment of pitches but they seldom use more than two, viz, the curve and fast ball.    This fellow has so much stuff and has such perfect control that I am almost compelled to believe that the way to beat him is to let everybody hit every cripple even to the point where our extra base hitters would hit with three and none. Koufax is not likely to walk anybody and men like James and White could, on occasion, be permitted to hit even three and none with nobody on the bases. This is the first time in six odd years that I have ever said anything of this sort about an opposing pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 14, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Mets    FISHER, JACK    Right hander, formerly of Baltimore and San Francisco. Showed no control and no stuff but he did have a crazy balk move. I don't believe Fisher is a good major league pitcher, - now or ever.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 4, 1964    I would keep Gagliana, Kolb, Maxvill, and Buchek, any of whom could play the outfield if necessary. I would send out Shannon, Clemens, or both before I would send out any one of the four above named.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 11, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    KOLB, GRAY    The only really high class catcher's arm in the organization. He throws correctly, is accurate, and the spin is fast and absolutely vertical. He is perfection itself as a throwing catcher.    I doubt if he is a finished receiver. With no experience I do not know how he could be. He is a finished outfielder , - unafraid of the fence or anything else. He lacks confidence and this he might get with continuous game play.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 17, 1964  Tampa, Fla.  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    KOLB, GARY    On this date, the boy will not take a strike. Stands too far from the plate. Hits most strike zone pitches to left field. This boy should be a straight away hitter with power to right field. He really knows the strike zone and if he would hug the plate a bit, he would become a base on balls man, - and immediately. He can out-throw most anybody on the squad and a well above average runner. He is a quick mover and can play almost anywhere.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: Gary Kolb    All that I have said for Clemens goes for Gary Kolb. However, for the sheer application of power Clemens has more of it. Clemens will hit more fly balls than Kolb. Gary is definitely a line-drive hitter.    I don't know whether Kolb has what I call "competitive guts" or not. If he has, he could go major league as a batsman in 1963.    Kolb will strike at less bad pitches than Clemens. One would not call either of them a "bad ball" hitter. Yet either of them can get the bat and the ball together on almost any pitch within range when they swing with intent.    I am hopeful that both Clemens and Kolb can be used extensively in the spring exhibition games both in "intra-squad" and scheduled games -- Clemens in the outfield, and of course, Kolb at short.    Kolb is a finished bunter and he knows how to lay off of a bad pitch when a sacrifice is in order. He can spot bunt better than anybody I have seen at the plate in a long time, and he can drag but along with the very best. He gets away from the plate with excellent agility. Faster, indeed, in that movement than Clemens, and I must add, for the sake of my own record, that no one I know about can push or pull the ball better than Kolb.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 18, 1964  Sarasota, Fla.  Sarasota Rookie League    KRESS, Henry    A tall, very slim, boy. Left hand hitter. Played second base. He had a very bad day. Erratic, stupid, and scared both in the field and at bat. It is not fair, however, to judge a boy on what I believe was his first field trial. He is 21 years of age. Our scouts and managers will record on him much more dependably.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: Philadelphia, Pa.  May 14, 1964  St. Louis vs Phillies    KULP, RAY  Young right hander with a lot of stuff. I don't think he knows much about pitching as yet, but there should be no big scores against him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: June 27, 1964  St. Louis, Mo.    FLOOD, Curt    Best hitting form of any man on the Cardinal club. Hornsby would probably say that Flood's position in the batting box is a few inches too far forward.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 16, 1964  Lakeland, Florida  St. Louis vs Detroit    FREEHAN, BILL    He is a fine looking ball player. He can do everything, - run, throw, and catch and his form at the plate is A-1. He is an unfinished catcher. Seldom "shifts" and seldom body checks.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: September 16, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.    LeMAY, RICHARD    An intelligent, high class fellow. Native of Cincinnati, now lives in California. Has been to three or four colleges. Lacks more than a year of finishing. Has a great desire to finish at San Jose University.    He needs to make his so-called fork ball his dominant pitch. It could take him to the majors.    An intelligent left hander about 26 years of age. He could be a 'cutie' by perfecting his delivery with a runner on first with a distinctive peak pause of his right knee. He understands. I would like to have him for ten days at Hollywood.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 10, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    LEWIS, JOHNNY    We have got to do something about his bat position. He does not exactly 'hitch' with the bat, - instead he moves his body front and away from his batting position. His hands should be moved at least 6" farther back.      BRANCH RICKEY      LATER    I doubt if this fellow can help us in 1964. I doubt it. His bat position is positively bad.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 14, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Mets    LEWIS, JOHNNY    Gets no lead off bases. Very far from being an adventurous base runner.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: September 14 and 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    LEWIS, JOHNNY    This left hand hitting colored outfielder can run and throw and has power. He is completely without any confidence whatever against left hand pitching. Any curve ball, - high, low, inside, or outside strikes him out. I doubt if he can hit .100 against left hand pitching and he will strike out against left hand pitching more than 50% of his times at bat.    He is definitely a negro who has been properly characterized as having a racial inferiority complex. He has shown improvement in this respect but still lacks. It is perfectly silly to permit this boy to continue his left hand hitting against left hand pitching. He should go to Hollywood and hit right handed against left handed pitching, - indeed all pitching until the right hand hitting form becomes habitual. He might really become a very great player.    I have formerly believed that the fellow should be regularly played in winter baseball. I am now opposed to it, - preferring the Hollywood assignment this fall. I believe he should be required to report to St. Louis as soon as possible after he finishes at Jacksonville. We would have the chance to talk with him and I believe we would be able to convince him that he should go to Hollywood. He gets rusty if benched and I don't believe he would be worth a nickel to us in 1965 with his present weaknesses.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: September 14 and 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    LIPSKI, ROBERT    Probably do alright as our second string catcher in AAA in 1965. Not going anywhere and has no market value.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 18, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Detroit  "B" Game    LONG, JOFF    For the first time in two years I have been looking at Long he has hit the long ball in games. He has fine power and a fine body and control of it. He has been a complete mystery to me. I would like to see Long make good. He has a lot of 'so-called' potentials. He has been consistently a "big man little poop" hitter, that I had almost given up on him. If he can hit as he has in the last few games, he will go major.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 3, 1964  Ft. Myers, Fla.  St. Louis vs Pittsburgh    LONG, JOFF    He does not hit breaking stuff. I don't think he would hit it very well in the batting practice if he knew it was coming. He is a fast ball hitter and a low percentage hitter against good pitching. He has never faced assorted pitching very much. He needs more experience at the plate to become a helpful major leaguer. I doubt if he can help our club in 1964 as a pinch hitter, but I prefer Long to Shannon.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 11, 1964  Raleigh, N. C.  Raleigh vs Burlington    LORTSCHER, Dennis    A very tall, right hand pitcher with Burlington. Smooth delivery. A pretty good fast ball and at times a sharp breaking overhand curve. He has all the appearance of a fine prospect. I don't know his age but he looks young and active. I don't believe he is any kind of quick prospect but with his size, strength, and probable youth, I am not turning thumbs down at all. He can run.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: St. Petersburgh, Fla.  March 10, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    MASTERMAN, RICHARD    Tall, left hander. Showed nothing. Not a good fast ball, an ordinary curve, and no control. It was his first workout and of course the boy cannot and should not be judged on this initial showing.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 6, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    MASTERMAN, RICHARD    Young left hander of good size and good action. Showed only an ordinary fast ball but a corking good curve, - it breaks. Showed no control of anything. I would call him a base on balls pitcher. In addition to his good curve ball, he has a good change up on his fast ball. In other words, he has a good change up and a good curve and no control, and again I would call him a base on balls pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 11, 1964  Raleigh, N. C.  Raleigh vs Burlington    LABOY, JOSE    He is perfection in all seven points of batting form, and he has power. He should hit in any league. He can't run, - below average. I believe his arm is good enough. Not great.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 7, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    MASTERMAN, RICHARD    Left hand pitcher, - drafter last November from Baltimore. Last year with Bluefield. Pitched very little. The boy has a good fast ball, - that is to say that it is alive. It is not straight.    His curve is good. It curves with regularity. Control doubtful.    He has a change up on his fast ball. It has a darn good effect. I believe he is an intelligent pitcher.    My previous observation of this boy at St. Petersburg and here at Homestead didn't give me a favorable impression. My observation was too limited. This chap is a lot better than I thought he was. He should have a good trial, - given plenty of work. He is assigned to Winnipeg. Ron Plaza might have to have considerable patience with this pitcher in his early games. I will not at all be surprised if he comes through as a definite major league prospect at the end of the year.    He is 6' tall, - weighs about 185.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 4, 1964    I would keep Gagliana, Kolb, Maxvill, and Buchek, any one of whom could play the outfield if necessary. I would send out Shannon, Clemens, or both before I would send out any one of the four named above.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: St. Peterburg, Fla.  March 11, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    MAXVILL, DAL    A nice boy. Nice every way but just not a major league batsman.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 14, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Mets    MAXVILL, DAL    The Cardinals don't believe in races but if the time when this boy Maxvill comes into competition with the men on the Cardinal baseball club, he surely will outrun most of them. I regard him as an above average player.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 2, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.    MAXVILL, DAL    If Groat were to get hurt, Maxvill would play shortstop for me. If Maxvill is up with men on bases in a tight game, even in the early innings, a pinch hitter could be used for Maxvill, then come to Buchek.    Maxvill is capable of making the great play, the spectacular play. He is dependable. He can run. He has great defensive strength from all angles. He will outhit Buchek for percentage but not for power.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 10, 1964  Raleigh, N. C.    MAY, Rudolph (Portsmouth Pitcher)    This colored left hand pitcher is a cinch to go major league. I would like to have him on the Cardinal club right now.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: May 1, 1964  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs Pittsburgh    MAZEROSKI, BILL    I wouldn't claim him on waivers. He is 'leggy', - heavy hipped. Has lost running speed. He doesn't care enough.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: September 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    McCORMICK, MIKE (Rochester Pitcher)    Left hand pitcher, 26 years old. For six innings showed a good fast ball and a corking curve. Fine control of both. This boy came from Pasadena High School to the major league at 18 years of age. Has never been in the minor league until the present season. He can help us. Has a history of a damaged arm.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: May 1, 1964  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs Pittsburgh    McFARLANE, ORLANDO    Right hand hitting colored catcher. He can run. He can throw. He has power and he should hit. He needs a counselor and a boss. 25 McFarlanes could win any pennant in any league, - provided they wanted to enough.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: Sarasota, Fla.  July 18, 1964  Sarasota Rookie League    MEIER, John    Right hand pitcher, 21 years old. In the five innings he pitched today, he showed me no speed, no curve, NO CONTROL, no anything. This boy must get control of what he has plus an additional usable pitch. Otherwise, I would not be interested in him for a minor league club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: September 14 and 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    LABOY, JOSE    This colored right hand hitting third baseman has splendid batting possibilities. My earlier observation rated him well below average in running speed. I believe that rating is in error. He is below average, but not very much.    He can throw, - a really strong arm and very quick. He has a forearm quickness and strength that would make him an ideal second baseman, and he has the long throwing power as well.    He has changed his open stance considerably in the batter's box and his pivot foot is several inches further away from the plate than it was during the past season when he was with Raleigh. If he holds to this open stance, he surely should move his right foot to the inside line of the batter's box.    He was hitting around .390 at Raleigh up to the time of a real fracas in Rocky Mount a couple of weeks before the close of the Carolina League season. The opposing pitcher, filled with obvious venom after a damaging homerun, threw at Jose, - also Chasteen. The next time at bat, Jose bunted and the pitcher fielding the bunt roughly tagged [at] Jose en route to first base. Jose was carrying the bat with him and quite deliberately struck the pitcher with the bat a second time in the midriff and laid the pitcher out. Arrest followed and jail, - a fine and a probational jail sentence. After that affair, the player went from .390 in the next dozen games to .360, making only one hit in the next nineteen times at bat.    With Jacksonville, he finished the season with about a .270 average.    This experience may have changed his batting position at the plate. His manager, George Kissell, feels very strongly that it did affect the boy's hitting. This affair to me is very surprising and disappointing.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: September 14 and 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    MENA, RIGOBERTO    An under-sized right hand hitting colored infielder. He can throw pretty good, run pretty good, and is cocky at the plate. Gets a piece of the ball. Not a power hitter, but he is not puny either. He might conceivably help Jacksonville next year.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 24, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Kansas City    MONTEAGUDO, AURELIO    First year, right hand pitcher, 5'10" tall, weighs about 185. A lot of speed and had a record at Portland last year of more than four strikeouts to each base on balls. Fair curve. Looks like he throws it over his thumb. He had control for two innings and then 'poohed' out. I would follow this player very closely. I think he can go major league. He needs a change up.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo    MORGAN, JOE    An excellent player in Jacksonville. The Jacksonville club in 1965 can be built around players like Morgan, Damaska, Will, Ricketts, Gaglano, and Cox as a sort of veteran nucleus of a pennant winning club in the International League. The Jacksonville club in 1965 could be a strong developer of players for the 1966 Cardinal club. We should not permit the Jacksonville club to be loaded down very much further with veteran players or even young players limited to AAA ability. It would be well if the Jacksonville club could be given additional power at the plate. Then load it up with prospective pitchers, - no spaves.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs Denver    MORTON, Bubba (Denver Outfielder)    Colored outfielder. Not a prospect.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: October 9, 1964  West Palm Beach, Fla.  St. Louis vs. Milwaukee    NEWMAN, DANNY (Milwaukee Catcher)    An enthusiastic, hustling 'humpty'. Cannot throw, - at least he didn't. I doubt if he can do anything.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 15, 1964  Rock Hill, S. C.   Rock Hill vs Shelby    NEWTON, Doin (Leo)    I worked this boy out in Brunswick, Ga. on July 30, 1965.    His record with Rock Hill so far this season shows that he gave 6.3 bases on balls per nine inning game. He will be 23 years of age in September. He is left handed and not very big, say 5'9". I know him, - also his wife.    He is not a first year man. He struck out 63 batsmen at Brunswick last season in 61 innings, and his record at Brunswick shows better control than he has this season. his earned run record in 1963 was very good. It seems to me that casual analysis of statistics indicate that we should hold on to this boy further.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: August 17, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  International League All-Stars vs Cleveland    NORTHRUP (Syracuse Outfielder)    Left hand hitter. Big boy. Perfect batting form. Should have great power. He can run and I am told that he has a good arm. I would like to make a deal for this fellow.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 15, 1964  Rock Hill, S. C.  Rock Hill vs Shelby    O'BRIEN, Phil    Did not see him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 23, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Houston    OWENS, JIM    He has a good fast ball and a high velocity curve and it curves. He throws a change up off his fast ball, - not too slow but very effective. On this date, he had excellent control of everything.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 11, 1964  Raleigh, N. C.  Raleigh vs. Burlington    PACHECO, Edwin    This boy is surely a prospect. Good arm, good running speed. Knows the strike zone. He stands farther back from the plate than any man I have seen in a long time, - very young. Colored Puerto Rican. He should be followed closely.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: LABOY, JOSE  -2-  9/14 and 15/64    Jose is reporting to the Hollywood camp on Monday morning, October 5th. I had a long visit with him at which time I knew nothing about the Rocky Mount assault. In the course of this visit, I discovered that the boy is very positively upset with homesickness. He has an understandable devotion to his mother to whom he gave all of his $5,000 bonus and sends her regularly most of his current salary check. He is in love with a girl in Ponce, Puerto Rico, - hopes to marry her shortly. He writes to her and receives from her a letter almost daily. He needs to go home for two or three days. It will make him a different person and a different player. I told him that the club would send him to his home as soon as he is through at Jacksonville and would pay his expenses back to the Hollywood camp.    My personal observation of this player leads me to say unequivocally that he is the best immediate prospect for the Cardinal club we have anywhere in our minor league organization. He will gladly lend himself to a new position, - either catching or first base or anywhere.    His fielding at Jacksonville has been excellent. His batting just so-so.    BRANCH RICKEY    CC - Mr. Robert L. Howsam    [*Jose may be a slow orientier - I hope not. BR*]

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 13, 1964  Winston-Salem, N.C.  Raleigh vs Winston-Salem    PACHECO, Ed    I think Pacheco's manager would render a real service to this player if he would place him closer to the plate. He can't reach the outside of the plate with his bat from his present position. The boy's heel is only a few inches from the outside line of the batter's box.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 23, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St Louis vs Houston    PACIOREK, JOHN    Tall, well-built 19 year old boy. Form is good at the plate.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 18, 1964  Sarasota, Fla.  Sarasota Rookie League    PALMER, Larry    Hits and throws right. A pudgy, roly-poly, overweight, 16 year old boy. Two years from now he could be 2" taller and weigh ten pounds less than he does now. The book says he is 5' 10". He is not as tall as I am and I'm 5' 9". The book says he weighs 180 pounds. He looks 190 pounds or better to me, and I am somewhat known as a good guesser on the weights of baseball players. A good many young athletes from 16 to 18 or even a year or two older have a weight problem. This boy would be a very active guard on his high school team, a good blocker around end. As a major league baseball prospect at the present time, he belongs on a high school football team.    Larry Palmer and Mel Ott come from entirely different sort of ancestry.
