I don't think anyone can tell right now what kind of a runner or batsman Larry will be two years hence. He may be worth holding on to. He has no promise of distinction at the present time as a thrower, runner, or hitter, - not as I saw him in two games.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 14, 1964  Salisbury, N. C.  Rock Hill vs Salisbury    PARLIER, William (Salisbury Outfielder)    20 years old, six footer, big boy. Switch hitter with power from either side. This boy should be scouted further. This boy was, I believe, #3. If so, he is impressive. I may have him "mixed up" with some other player.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 6, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    PATENAUDE, JERRY    This boy has had considerable experience. I would not estimate his fast ball as exceptional, - only ordinary. Has a curve and throws change ups. I don't think he is a quickie for the major league and while I would not say that he may not possibly be a major leaguer, he surely is in the doubtful class. He might get a knuckle ball or something and be entirely different. I doubt if he can go [boh] both ways in fielding his position. His finished delivery is very faulty in this respect.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: PEARSON    This big, right hander is an emotional cuss. An umpires decision or a wild pitch or what not, - anything and everything upsets him. He shows some sort of physical reaction on almost every called-ball pitch.    His job is to get control of his mind.    Never stops in his delivery with a runner on first base, - balks all the time.    23 years of age, but shows less poise than a rookie.    I believe the size of Pearson's hat is 6-1/4.    I doubt if there is anything the staff can do to help this boy in this camp. Some kind of a psychiatrist might help. I doubt it.    HARRIS  Harris is not ready at all for a game. Don't play him for a couple of weeks.    DAVIS  I don't like him as a batter. He gives every evidence of a guess hitter. He takes perfect strikes and then is a goose for the wild pitch. As a Cardinal prospect within any reasonable future time, you can have him.    COSMAN  No control of his curve ball. With men on base he [is] has a quick throw. Starts his arm first. However his delivery is terribly slow. Anybody can steal on him. He must [deivid ] divide his weight. Cannot field his position.    I doubt very much that his early coming to the Cardinals can be helped very much in this camp.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 13, 1964  Winston-Salem, N. C.  Raleigh vs Winston-Salem    PEARSON, Charles    A right hander. Takes charge. Showed poise. His fast ball is very good, and he has two curves, both good. Uncertain control. The umpire gave him a bad time this evening. Pearson's curve ball fooled the umpire more than it did anyone else. The bad calls on Pearson's curve gave Winston-Salem the first inning run. I would like to have the chance to work Pearson privately. I believe his 'crooked stuff', plus pitcher 'guts' and a good showing of sense surely make[s] this fellow a probability. I shall follow his record with much interest. Every now and then he comes side arm very effectively.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 30 and March 31, 1964  St. Louis vs Chicago White Sox  St. Petersburg and Sarasota, Fla.    PETERS, GARY    Tall, slim, left hand pitcher with a great change of speed curve and a good fast ball. Excellent control. He is a major league pitcher in all directions. It took him four or five years to "come". I'd like to know why.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 11, 1964  Raleigh, N. C.  Raleigh vs Burlington    PIETRI, Wayne    A good athlete. I believe above average runner. If the boy hits, he might go places.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 13, 1964  Winston-Salem, N.C.  Raleigh vs Winston-Salem    PIETRI, Wayne    He caught a foul fly ball 50' beyond first base. The man on third beat the throw home. The throw was 20' from the plate but the player would have beat the throw even if it was accurate. I wonder about his arm.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 15, 1964  Rock Hill, S. C.  Rock Hill vs Shelby    LAIOLO, Harry    A finely built big boy. Right hand hitting catcher, 20 years old. A pretty good arm, not great, but better than McCarver's, for example. Not a humpty runner and he is a good receiver. His arm is quick. His batting form is not bad. He is unafraid and he has 'guts'. He should be used this year as much as possible. The club did not hold batting practice for four straight days. I am not sure about his power. He is big enough and active enough to have everything.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: September 14 & 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    PIGNATANO, JOE (Rochester Catcher)    An old catcher. Positive liability above Class "C".    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 18, 1964  Sarasota, Fla.  Sarasota Rookie League    PITTS, Gaylen    This boys interests me very much. He is 18 years old, a 6'1" right hand hitting infielder, with a good arm, - just exactly how good I don't know. He can run well above average and he doesn't look or act like a stranger at shortstop. At the plate, I just don't know. He walked twice.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 13, 1964  Winston-Salem, N. C.  Raleigh vs. Winston-Salem    POLITTE, Cliff    I had a talk with this boy this afternoon. He pitched seven innings this evening against Winston-Salem, perhaps the best hitting club in the Carolina League. Gave two hits, three bases on balls and struck out four. I don't believe the boy 'bore down'. He simply tried to get the ball over the plate. However, he would throw four successive pitches to the pitcher at bat, and not one of the four within three feet of the plate. It may be that Stanky has given up on this pitcher in which case that would be his reason for instructing George Kissell to 'bull pen' him. It is very difficult for me to give up on this player. But he didn't look like he did - (stuff-wise) a year ago. His won and lost record is bad. His statistical record is very good.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: October 9, 1964  Hollywood, Florida    POLITTE, CLIFFORD    I don't believe that this boy has the GREAT fast ball that I formerly thought he had, but it is good. His curve ball is excellent, but even in my workout with him on the sidelines, the control of his curve was faulty indeed. If he had spot control of his curve ball, very few batters in the major leagues could hurt him.    His change up off his fast ball is a bit too fast but it is his best control pitch. This boy is a mystery to me because he does not control either the fast ball or his curve ball but does control his change up. Why one and not the other?    I have just been informed that his contract has been assigned outright to Indianapolis. Therefore, there is no point in keeping him longer in the camp at Hollywood.    We should follow his work at Indianapolis next summer very closely. I think the boy can go major league.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City  Salt Lake vs Denver    POPOVICH, Paul (Salt Lake Infielder)    Doesn't impress me in any direction as a professional baseball player. He must be a better player than he looked in the two games at Salt Lake City. Showed no power at the plate in batting practice and didn't look like a contact hitter in the games. Well built, well below average runner, good arm - not at all great.    (Later) I am told that this boy is ailing with a bad leg. However, even with a good leg I am not interested.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 16, 1964  Jacksonville, Fla.  Columbus vs Jacksonville    PRIDDY, Robert (Columbus Pitcher)    This right hand pitcher belongs to Pittsburgh. Good stuff, no control. When control is in trouble, he lets up. When he is not in trouble with his control, he 'presses' and gets into trouble. He might become a good pitcher [at thirty] later.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 21, 1964  Bradenton, Fla.  St. Louis vs Kansas City    REYNOLDS, TOM    Young fellow, well above 6' tall and he can run and he looks like a real hitter. Arm good enough. Colored boy. I like him. 22 years old. Has good form at the plate. Has good power. I would claim this player on waivers.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs Denver    RIBANT, Dennis (Denver Pitcher)    Looks about 5' 11" tall, about 165 pounds, right hander, 22 years old. A pretty good curve ball, a definite slider, and fine control. He is a pitcher not a thrower. His fast ball is average. He is a nervous boy, - very aggressive. Wants to get three men out with one pitch. He uses all his stuff.    His pitching statistics for Denver in 1964 should be given attention. He is a competitor deluxe.    I believe this boy is the most completely nervous pitcher I have ever seen in the professional game. He doesn't go 'up in the air', he is already there. He starts up 'in the air'. If this boy could and would avoid throwing his fast ball in the dead strike zone, I believe he could help a major league club.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 17, 1964  Tampa, Fla.  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    RICKETTS, DAVE    I don't think he will hit enough to help our ball club, - not a lick. He is a big man and undoubtedly a fine gentleman, but in my book he is a puny hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 11, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    RICKETTS, DAVE    I don't believe this boy is good enough ever to be a major league catcher. He cannot hit either right or left handed enough, and he lacks power. And he is not a good receiver. With Ricketts catching, there will be a lot of so-called wild pitches which should really be called passed balls.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 30 and March 31, 1964  St. Louis vs Chicago White Sox  St. Pete and Sarasota, Fla.    LANDIS, JIM    His stance at the plate is alright and his step seems to be short but his bat movement gives the effect of a hitch and change of speed pitching, particularly the curve ball, makes him look 'strikeoutish'. I don't see how he will ever hit for a high percentage.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 1, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Philadelphia    RICKETTS, DAVE    Why he lies down with his right leg spread out on the ground, I don't know. I have never known him to call for a change of speed pitch. 25 Ricketts on the same club would compete for last place and the same thing goes for Coker.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N. Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo    RICKETTS, DAVE    About the same as previously recorded. A pretty good catcher. Hits to the opposite field. Scant power.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: September 14, and 15, 1964  Rochester, New York  Rochester vs. Jacksonville    RICKETTS, DAVE    This fine colored gentleman has intelligence and desire and nothing else. He cannot run, his three-quarter arm has excessive trajectory and he has no power at bat. He is of managerial type and could be a valuable scout without any doubt in our negro production field.    We should ask waivers on Ricketts and if claimed, let him go. If not claimed, his contract should be assigned outright to Jacksonville immediately.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 17, 1964  Tampa, Fla.  St. Louis vs Cincinnati    ROBINSON, FRANK (Cincinnati Outfielder)    A change of pace pitch upsets Robinson, - either the change up off the fast ball, or, particularly the slow curve.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 30 and March 31, 1964  St. Louis vs. Chicago White Sox  St. Pete and Sarasota, Fla.    ROBINSON, FLOYD    Left hand hitting colored outfielder.  Can run. He is 28 years old and he has good power.   His plate position is entirely sound. He seems to   be a good bad ball hitter and he is not too choosey   on the size of the strike zone.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: September 14 and 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    ROCHESTER CLUB  Marvin Breeding  Steve Demeter  Gino Cimoli  Joe Durham  Joe Altobelli    Not desirable anywhere. All playing with Rochester in 1964. Not going anywhere.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs Denver    ROOF, Phillip (Denver Catcher)    A tall, slim boy about 6'3" tall, 23 years of age, weighs about 190 pounds, right hand hitter. Pivot foot from the plate is as far as Groat's. He acts completely inexperienced at the plate. Right now I don't think he will hit good right hand pitching even in the small minors. He has a good cut. If he connects on his pitch, he has ample power.    Bow-legged as the dickens, but so was Honus Wagner, Lave Cross, and Don Gutteridge's legs were not straight.    He has no pep, seems indifferent. He may not be lazy but he certainly acts like it.    As a possibility for the Cardinals, I would prefer him to Coker or Uecker, or Rickets. The best point about him is his ability and habit of throwing without stepping. He gets the ball away very good. The worst bad thing about him is his running.    He has a good arm, stronger than most. It is the only present qualification for the major league.    This boy is tall enough that I think he might reach the outside of the plate with the end of his bat. It would require a lot of leaning.     If this boy could be played somewhere every day for 150 consecutive games, he might improve as a batsman.    He doesn't care whether he takes batting practice or not.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 18, 1964  Sarasota, Fla.   Sarasota Rookie League    RUBERTO, John  An 18 year old right hand hitting catcher. He does not have a major league arm and he does not have a major league bat. He is not built for a runner, but he looks better in that department than he does in the others.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs Denver    LANDRUM, Don (Salt Lake Outfielder)    Landrum is Landrum.      BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: May 1, 1964  St. Louis, Mo.  St. Louis vs Pittsburgh    LAW, VERNON    His fast ball was as good as ever and he had good control. He can pitch in the major league. We ought not waive on him.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 10, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    LEMAY, RICHARD    A pretty fair curve ball but in this first workout in spring practice he showed very ordinary speed. His control was good. Tall boy, left hander. Showed no change-ups. I believe Lemay has a good move in holding men on.      BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: July 13, 1964  Winston-Salem, N.C.  Raleigh vs. Winston-Salem    SCOTT, Victor    Right hand hitting catcher. A good little minor league player. A very likeable boy. I wish him well.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 17, 1964  Tampa, Fla.  St. Lous vs. Cincinnati    SECRIST, DON (Cincinnati Pitcher)    Big, tall, left handed, first year player. Fair speed, fair curve, fair control. Showed nothing special to me in any direction. I don't believe this chap can field his position. Slow moving, - clumsy.    This boy showed all signs of stage fright. If so, I should not make any sort of final judgment.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: March 21, 1964  Bradenton, Fla.  St. Louis vs Kansas City    SHANNON, MIKE    I like Shannon, - off the field. He has been married five years, - five children. Domestic situation very unsatisfactory.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 2, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Los Angeles Dodgers    SHANNON, MIKE    I don't think that Shannon can help this club very much as a batsman in 1964. I think that Long will do a much better job pinch hitting than Shannon.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: April 3, 1964  Fort Myers, Fla.  Cardinals vs. Pittsburgh    SHANNON, MIKE    As a defensive outfielder, I don't think he can compare with Kolb or even Warwick or Clemens, - although I think he has a better arm than either Warwick or Clemens. I don't think Shannon locates the fly ball as quickly or as accurately as any one of the three others, particularly Kolb.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: Sarasota, Fla.  July 18, 1964  Sarasota Rookie League    SHIMERDLA, Charles    Right hand pitcher, tall boy, a first baseman. Excellent form at the plate. Should hit. A 'righty' all the way. Takes a three foot lead off third base, - could be three and a half. I just don't understand how any boy can live 18 years in Omaha, Nebraska and have no more adventure than Shimerdla has in him. He has good action and looks like a fine athlete. Go along with him for awhile.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: Sarasota, Fla.  July 18, 1964  Sarasota Rookie League    SHIMERDLA, Charles    Right hand pitcher, tall boy, a first baseman. Excellent form at the plate. Should hit. A 'righty' all the way. Takes a three foot lead off first base, - could be three and a half. I just don't understand how any boy can live 18 years in Omaha, Nebraska and have no more adventure than Shimerdla has in him. He has good action and looks like a fine athlete. Go along with him for a while.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1953; A-R
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 11, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    SIMMONS, CURT    Pretty good speed. Darn good breaking curve. Good fast ball, - not great but only god. Throws change-ups. In every sense a pitcher. Fine control.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: July 18, 1964  Sarasota, Fla.  Sarasota Rookie League    Sinnott, Bryan    A 6' 6" right hander - allegedly a pitcher. Weighs 220 pounds and not a pound overweight. I don't know about this pitcher's stuff. He did not pitch. I saw him at bat in the practice. He has great power with little effort, - more power, I believe, than Chasteen, - more than Laboy. This fellow would not pitch another game for me at Sarasota. He has a good arm and he can throw the ball very hard. He would play the outfield until I was very sure from my own personal observation that he could not become a good outfielder. I don't know about his running. I saw him run from home to first twice. He looked below average and he is probably below average. I don't know whether he can catch a fly ball or not but we ought to find out about it. We do not have anybody in the entire organization who hits better form or more power than Sinnott. He may not be able to hit breaking stuff at the present but he would certainly get the chance from me to learn to hit breaking stuff.    I talked to Fred Keonig before the game today about playing this fellow in the outfield. It was admitted be everybody, I thought, that Palmer, for example, was not a major league prospective outfielder, yet Palmer played the entire nine innings and Sinnott didn't even appear as a pinch hitter in a game that was lost up until the eighth inning.    This Sinnott gives me the chance to say a word on camp management. There should be a policy at Sarasota or indeed everywhere on our minor league clubs to bring every boy to his potential. I have seen an 18 year old high school boy who thought he was and everybody considered him to be a catcher. He went to the major league as a shortstop. I am sure I can cite fifty notable cases where young pitcher have become regular major league players in some other position. The school days of Roderick Wallace, Hal Chase, George Moriarity, Cy Seymour and many others of that era and later such notables as Babe Ruth, George Sisler, Pepper Martin, Chick Hafey, Lefty O'Doul and many others of

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: Sinnott, Bryan -2- July 18, 1964    that era, - - all of them were schoolboy pitchers and early professional pitchers but the records of all of them make little or no reference to pitching.    Now this chap Bryan Sinnott may be a complete bust as an outfielder but we have no positive knowledge about it. He should be given a quick and thorough trial. There isn't any question about his power hitting ability or about his batting form. He tears the cover off the ball with an apparently easy normal swing. There may be great potential in this fellow but we don't know anything about it. Any manager who is not awake and alive and anxious to find out and develop the possibilities of players in all directions should not be one of our minor league managers. Let him do something else.    For sixty years I have been directing one or more baseball clubs in one field or classification or another and in those sixty years I have never directed a subordinate by commands. I have followed closely the policy of suggestion, - a sort of platonic approach to a policy and I have had conformity to the suggestion process, - almost without exception over those years. If management is not disposed to adopt a suggested move, I have found it necessary, in case of opposition, to get rid of him; in case of complacent inaction or lethargic conformance, I would demote him. Usually in that event conversation and explanation followed. The manager would be restored to his job but never again would he fail to follow a positive suggestion. That is exactly the way I would handle Mr. Fred Koenig. (For instance, I think Fred Koenig is a close observer of players and a good judge of talent but with no imagination whatever).    The same criticism applies in the case of John Van at Rock Hill. I don't know that John Van can be an outfielder. Likewise, I don't know that he can't become an outfielder but I do know that his ability in some directions [that] fully warrants our finding out right now the facts about his outfielding potential. It is slothful and unthinking [managers to be comatose when facing the development of young players.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 11, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    Sadecki, Ray    He has a bad habit of raising his left foot in almost every pitch. It is just too bad. If he is called to account on this point in a game, it could upset him. Probably would.    In this first inning, he showed no speed, no curve, no nothing. Nothing over the plate. Very wild.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: Sinnott, Bryan -3- July 18, 1964    (Incidentally, Fred Keonig told me yesterday that he did not believe that Bryan Sinnott had enough stuff to be a prospective major league pitcher. If he believed that, then he should have greater reason to try this fellow out in some other [direction] position.)

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: Detroit, Michigan  June 5, 1964  Hamtramck Junior Legion    SKIZYKIACZ, RAY (Catcher)    235 pounds, 6'4" tall, good arm, throws sidearm but he has a strong arm. He has good position at the bat, hits the ball with power.    I don't think anybody is looking at him or knows anything about him but I suggest that "Mo" Mozzali follow through on him. It is possible that he could be signed for no bonus whatever. I would like to see him have a chance on our low classification club.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: April 6, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    Sloan, Mike    I think this boy can get a change of pace pitch off his fast ball that he will control absolutely and it would be a very effective pitch. It seems to have the effect of a semi-knuckle ball but he shows remarkable early control of the pitch. His curve ball has no marked velocity. It is a change of speed pitch in itself but it curves.    He has improved very much in his follow through on delivery. He should be able to field his position O.K.    He is going with George Kissel. That is good. This chap must have a thorough trial.    Branch Rickey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: April 7, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    JAMES SMART  230 Freeman Street  Coral Gables, Fla.  Telephone Highland 8-7857    Right hand pitcher, 5' 11" tall, weighs about 185 pounds, 17 years old. His fast ball is a heavy ball and knocks your glove off. Spins very slowly. Not much velocity at all. Curve ball so so. Throws it over his thumb. This boy can throw a change up on his fast ball, - just about as good as Erskines and he can control it.    He has quit school. He was a senior in [ ] High School in Miami. His class graduates in June. No one can talk contract with him until after that time. It might be worthwhile to follow the boy in his games between now and June 15th through either a local bird dog or the territorial scout.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: July 15, 1964  Rock Hill, S. C.  Rock Hill vs Shelby    SMITH, GUS (August William Smith)    A 22 year old right hand hitting outfielder from Lodi, California. A first year player. Let him go to draft but don't hold him.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: April 6, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    SMITH, JULIUS (Rabbit)    What I said in two dictations a year ago still goes. No change of opinion.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 16, 1964  Lakeland, Fla.  St. Louis vs Detriot    SMITH, WILLIE    Left hander, - colored boy. Shows inexperience.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: July 13, 1964  Winston-Salem, N .C.  Raleigh vs Winston-Salem    SNOW, BOB (Winston-Salem Pitcher)    University of Oregon boy. Right hand pitcher, big delivery, overhand all the time. Corking curve, but not consistently good. Didn't always break. Fast ball good, not great. Might become quite a pitcher. He might.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 18, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Detroit    SPARMA, JOE    A big, young, right hander. First year player with a lot of speed. Curve ball just so so at best, and no control of it.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: July 15, 1964  Rock Hill, S. C.  Rock Hill vs Shelby    SPECKENBACH, Paul    A 19 year old right hand pitcher. 6'2" tall. Reputed to have received $100,000 for signing a contract.    Hal Smith told me that this pitcher, prior to last evening, had pitched nine complete innings in four outs, walking 29 players and striking out, I believe, only four or five. This boy has a recent history of a sore arm, - back of the shoulder. He now states that he has no pain whatever when he throws. Surely the sore arm has left him with mental damage. He appears timid, - reluctant to talk about his trouble but quite apparently very anxious to make good in baseball. He should be handled with great patience, placed on the very lowest classification club possible and pitched with positive regularity regardless of results.    He shows no fault in delivery other than possibly leaving the impression that he is not throwing his very best. It is easy for me to believe that when he first signed up he had plenty of stuff. I don't believe conversation will do him very much good. I tried that. However, he is responsive and very cooperative with his various bosses. It is impossible for him to do all the things various people have advised him to do. He should not be told very much of anything by anybody. Let him alone, but don't try to dispose of his contract. Hold on to him.    I saw him pitch two complete innings. He walked three and struck out two, and gave up three hits. Originally, he must have had a great fast ball. It is still pretty good. It is thrown without very much effort. His curve is a change of pace pitch, thrown, usually, in the general direction of north.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 14, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Mets    Sadecki, Ray    In his first three innings against the Mets, didn't show fast balls or curves. Showed nothing, including control. I don't believe he was bearing down at all.    During 1963, I regarded Sadecki as one of the better pitcher-hitters in the league. The boy has no batting faults at the plate on form and swings with confidence. This boy either is or should become a good hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 11, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    SPIEZIO, ED    He throws quick but velocity is less than average major league.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March , 10, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    SPIEZIO, ED    Running off third, he takes no lead   and with a pitcher move to first base, he goes   back toward third which shows inexperience if not   dumbness. This boy does not have great running   speed and he does not have a great arm. He does   not have great power. He might become a corking   good hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 14, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Mets    STALLARD, TRACY    Tall right hander with good speed and a good curve and he throws change-ups. He had good control for four innings, - gave us one pooper hit. The boy pitched with courage and apparent confidence. In the fifth inning he apparently lost his stuff, particularly his fast ball. I think he can become a very good major league pitcher.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 16, 1964  Lakeland, Fla.  St. Louis vs Detroit    STANLEY, MICKEY    Right hand hitter. Can run.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 4, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Mets Inter-Squad Game    STEPHENSON, JOHN    I don't believe he has a good arm, - at least he never showed it.    (LATER)    This boy can throw.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: July 14, 1964  Salisbury, N. C.  Rock Hill vs Salisbury    STONE, Gary    A very young right hand hitting catcher, above average arm, not a humpty runner. Our averages show him hitting .285 and he strikes out only once every six times at bat. He was a completely bewildered batsman in the game tonight. He doesn't know anything about a strike zone. He never heard about it. He is going to college for three more years. That is good.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 11, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    TAYLOR, RON    Cannot hold men on base.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: May 8, 1964  New York, N. Y.  St. Louis vs New York    TAYLOR, RON    In the sixth and seventh innings, he threw two curves, - everything else fast balls. I was not sitting in a position to be absolutely accurate in calling the pitches but quite apparently McCarver or Taylor had any confidence in Taylor's curve ball. However the first and second outs in the seventh inning were made on curve balls.    Obviously it never occured to McCarver or Taylor that the pitcher had a change of speed pitch.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: April 7, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    TEEM, THOMAS (Tommy)    Tall, 6'5", [left] right hander, first year boy, 20 years old. A good fast ball, not great but good enough. He has an adequate curve and he has a corking good change up on his fast ball. There is a slight difference in some of his deliveries on these pitches but he can correct everyone of them.    This boy will go as far as his control will carry him. If he had perfect control of his three pitches, he could go all the way.    I don't believe that his manager in 1964 should undertake to give him an additional pitch. He doesn't need it at the present time and if his control improves, it is possible that he will never need an additional pitch.    I wish I could put this fellow on the strings.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: April 7, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    TEEM, THOMAS (Tommy)    Tall, 6'5", left hander, first year boy,   20 years old. A good fast ball, not great but good   enough. He has an adequate curve and he has a   corking good change up on his fast ball. There   is a slight difference in some of his deliveries   on these pitches but he can correct everyone of   them.    This boy will go as far as his control will   carry him. If he had perfect control of his three   pitches, he could go all the way.    I don't believe that his manager in 1964   should undertake to give him an additional pitch.   He doesn't need it at the present time and if his   control improves, it is possible that he will never  need an additional pitch.    I wish I could put this fellow on the strings.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 18, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Detroit    SADECKI, RAY    Started the game this date in St. Petersburg against Detroit. Had no fast ball, no curve, no anything, but worse than that he had no control of any pitch. His pitching was completely amateurish. There isn't a pitcher in our camp, including Masterman, that hasn't shown more stuff than Sadecki showed today. He is sick or has a sore arm or he doesn't give a damn, - one of the three, - or perhaps all three. That is how he looked and acted.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 16, 1964  Lakeland, Fla.  St. Louis vs Detroit    THOMAS, GEORGE    An outfielder. Right hander. White boy with a very strong arm. Hits with good power in practice.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: July 15, 1964  Rock Hill, S. C.  Rock Hill vs Shelby    TIGETT, Jack    A 6'2", 21 year old, right hand hitting first baseman from Rice Institute, I believe. Does not look impressive as a batter. Has played very few games as a professional. Runs average.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: April 7, 1964  Homestead, Fla.  Tulsa vs Denver    TOLAN, ROBERT    Can run above average, can throw above average, power pretty good. Should help Tulsa.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: October 9, 1964   West Palm Beach, Fla.   St. Louis vs Milwaukee    TORREZ, MICHAEL      When he starts his windup, he brings the  ball to his waist and then starts again. Very bad.  This break up in his delivery takes up added time.  Apparently it is habit. Too bad!     He must get a third pitch and go to the  strings with his fast ball.     With a runner on first or second, Mike  takes the position of hands down full length. He  would pitch quicker with his hands at his waistline.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: Hollywood, Florida  October 19, 1964      TORREZ, MIKE    Work as I could on this fellow, I could not get him to throw a good fast ball. He showed no speed. In fact, I didn't get the speed effort out of him. He was very diappointing. He will pitch within two days in a scheduled game. If he shows no speed in that game, he will indeed be disappointing.        BRANCK RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: September 1, 1964    TORREZ, MIKE    A very tall, right handed, straight overhand pitcher. Fine hands and exceptional speed. Every fast ball goes a little south of northeast. He cannot throw a straight fast ball. Indeed, his fast ball is a dandy, - very unusual.    He has a velocity curve ball. It breaks and he shows pretty good control of it. He has no change ups on anything, but undoubtedly he can learn the change up on the curve ball very easily. I did not work him on the change up on the fast ball. Mike said he had worked on a change up off his fast ball but stated that he had no success with it. His demonstration proved it. The fellow's delivery is not bad. It is pretty good. I think he could field his position without very much suggestive change in delivery, perhaps not any at all.    He reminds me very much of Drysdale in the fact that he has reserve speed in his pocket. He can really throw harder when he wants to.    He is a nice boy. He is worth going into the competitive market to get him.    I am told that his boy is 6'6" tall. I doubt that height but he is plenty big. Has a nice manner, - Mexican ancestry. I would give this boy considerable money He is going to Detroit for a workout. If possible, get him to promise to return here before making any commitment whatever. Get his father to make the same commitment.      BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Robert Howsam  cc - Mr. George Silvey

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N.Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo    TOTH, PAUL    He is big enough, old enough, strong enough to be a good pitcher. He is not big enough, old enough, or strong enough to be a major leaguer. You can have him.      BRANCH RICKEY      cc- Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: September 14, 15, 1964  Rochester N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    TOTH, PAUL    He should be given his [unconditional] outright release to Jacksonville immediately. It would be a gutter pickup of $25,000 if he were drafted.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: St Petersburg, Fla.  March , 11, 1964    VEAL, COOT    In the two days I have seen this boy in games and practice, I believe he would be a good man in a Class A league. I doubt if he could stand out as a good player above that classification.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: April 4, 1964  Homestead, Fla.  Jacksonville vs Denver    VICKERY, ANDREW (Jacksonville Pitcher)    This left hand pitcher will be 23 years of age next August. He has a good curve and an assortment of pitches. Shows good control. I don't understand why he has been pitched so few innings in the past two years.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 30 and March 31, 1964  St. Louis v Chicago White Sox  St. Petersburg & Sarasota, Fla.     SADECKI, RAY  This is the fourth time I have seen him in a scheduled game pitching this spring. Better control than previously but still not good, - not at all. His fast ball is very ordinary and simply a thrower with his curve, - when it curves.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: April 7, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    WAITE, FRANK    I don't believe he can hit or throw, - good enough in any direction as a major league prospect. I doubt if he can help Tulsa.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: April 7, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    WATTS, HARRY    A darn good utility man at Tulsa.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: April 2, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Dodgers    WERHAS, JOHN (Dodger infielder)    Infielder, right hand hitter. As a batsman his form is good and he has a record of good power. He is not slow, - perhaps above average runner. His arm is good.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: June 29 and 30, 1964  Salt Lake City, Utah  Salt Lake vs Denver    WHITE, Jesse (Salt Lake City Outfielder)    Colored outfielder. Right hand hitter. Can run. A fair arm. No power.    His position in the batting box is very good and his bat position is good. I doubt if he has very much power, if any, and his throwing from the outfield in practice was very ordinary.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Bing Devine

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 23, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Houston    WHITE, MIKE  A right hand hitting infielder. Form at the plate is O.K. His father was Jo-Jo White. He might hit for a good average, but I doubt that he has very much power. He is 26 years old.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 10, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    Wild, Jerry  With control of his curve ball, he would be  quite a pitcher. Without control of his curve ball,   he ain't. He umpires all his pitches; much affected  by bad-calls. He has a good move to first base, -  very good. He is still a boy pitcher, - just a boy.  He cannot help us in 1964 nor ever unless and until he  gets poise and control.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: August 18, 1964  Buffalo, N.Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo    WILL, ROBERT  Left hand hitting outfielder-first baseman. Corking player for Jacksonville. Should be left right there.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: September 14, and 15, 1964  Rochester, N. Y.  Rochester vs Jacksonville    WILL, ROBERT    Probably a good man to build around in AAA. A veteran left hand hitting outfielder-first baseman.    BRANCH RICKEY    cc - Mr. Robert L. Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 23, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Houston    WILLIAMS, WALT    A 20 year old colored right handed hitting outfielder. Has good form at the plate. A short sawed-off fellow. Built like a wrestler. At 100[ feet away handwritten], he looks like a 200 pounder.    BRANCH RICKEY    (LATER)    Williams is fast. He can really run.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 23, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Houston      WILLIAMS, WALT    A 20 year old colored right handed hitting outfielder. Has good form at the plate. A short sawed-off fellow. Built like a wrestler. At 100' he looks like a 200 pounder.    BRANCH RICKEY    (LATER)    Williams is fast. He can really run.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: April 20, 1964  St. Louis vs Houston  Houston, Texas    SADECKI, RAY    In 1-2/3 innings against Houston on this date, he allowed six hits, four runs, gave one base on balls, failed to cover first base in an infield tap, also failed to back up the home plate properly on a throw from center field. However, he looked far better than any previous time this year. Fast ball was better and his curve ball really curved several times. He threw two change ups, - one hight to Aspromonte for a base hit and the other one was good. He was close to the plate all the time. Several pitches were called balls which might have been called strikes.    Sadecki showed very much improvement, but he still lacks his stuff and control that he showed the last part of the 1963 season. I would strongly recommend to management that he be put out on a one day option recall and made to earn in the minors a starting chance again in the majors.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: October 9, 1964  West Palm Beach, Florida  St. Louis vs Milwaukee    WILLIAMSON, CHARLES    This eighteen year old, left handed pitcher shows a lot of finish. Only fair fast ball but a corking change up off his curve and very good control of it. A very good move in holding men on base.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: Hollywood, Florida  October 19, 1964    WILLIAMSON, CHARLES    A very young left hander. Shows fair middle of the road eighteen year old stuff. No control in his first two games in Hollywood. Has a change up. It really is a change up, and he had better control of the pitch that anything else. However, he tips it off, - slows up his delivery on the pitch - not exactly a holding up of the delivery but a hesitation.    He needs to go to the lowest classification baseball club we can find for him in 1965. He does not act scared to death. Not at all.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: July 11, 1964  Raleigh, N. C.  Raleigh vs. Burlington    WILLIS, RONALD    Tall, slim right hand pitched, 22 years of age. Good fast ball. Had good velocity curve but never over the plate. His fast ball is good enough, - no control of it. However, if he had control of his fast curve, then his fast ball would be just wild enough to be good. He has a slow curve and it is a dandy. It is his very best pitch. He has good control of it. He does not use it enough.    As soon as he gets poise and control, he can go major.    He can field his position and he can run.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: [1964]    WILLIS, RON    This right handed chap is a potential "quickie". He can throw four pitches and on the sidelines showed good control. His fast ball is very good. Also, his curve is better than average. Willis has a slow curve, - a usable slow curve. He must be pitched considerably this fall and not particularly held to three innings at all.    This boy should go to the Cardinal camp next spring and the General Manager should insist upon his being pitched with considerable regularity in the spring exhibition games. It is more than possible that Willis can help the Cardinal club itself in 1965.    This boy can run and he has enough intelligence if given practice as a hitter to become more than a setup XXXXXXXXXXXXXX[crossed out typing] with a bat in his hands.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: April 6, 1964  Homestead, Fla.    WINTER, KENNETH    Tall, slim right hand first year pitcher from Carmi, Illinois. Fair fast ball, fair curve, showed no control. Didn't work him out but saw him pitch in Winnipeg-Rock Hill game this date. Not impressive. I would call him a run-of-the-mine high school pitcher. It could be that he is better than he showed.    BRANCH RICKEY    (LATER)    I believe this boy has a better future than I thought he had when I first wrote about him. We should see more of him.    B.R.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: Sarasota, Fla.  July 18, 1964  Sarasota Rookie League    WINTER, Ken    A 19 year old right hand pitcher. 6' 3" tall. He pressed on fast pitching. His control was so bad that I don't care to record an opinion.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 10, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    WITHROW, RAY    I don't believe this big fellow will ever do much with breaking stuff, particularly changes of speed.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 11, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    WITHROW, RAY    He will have his good days but he will have a lot of bad ones up at the plate. Against good pitching, even left handers like Simmons, I don't believe Withrow would hit .200. When it comes to timing, he is a novice. I believe he might set a record in strikeouts as a regular on a major league team.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 23, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Houston      WYNN, JIM    Young colored player. Right hand hitter.   Plays both infield and outfield. Not a big boy.   He can run and he can throw. In 1964, his second   year professionally, will tell about his improvement   as a hitter.    A short hitch. Shouldn't bother him a bit.   Keeps the big end of the bat well back and quiet.    BRANCH RICKEY    (LATER)    A right hand pitcher with a curve ought to   keep Wynn in the .200 class, - not above. He   starts to jack-knife on the side arm curve ball. I   don't think he likes right hander's curves from any   direction.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 10, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    YOUNG, DON    This big youngster is a long way off. He is not yet acquainted with any pitch.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: August 19, 1964  Buffalo, N.Y.  Jacksonville vs Buffalo    SAMUEL, (Buffalo Infielder)    This colored infielder (on option to Buffalo from the New York Mets) is much improved as a batsman. Breaking stuff still bothers him but he shows considerable power to his own field. He can play any infielder position. The fact that this player now wears glasses could account for his improvement in hitting. This player should be discussed in the fall meeting, October 5th and 6th. I believe he will out hit and outrun Buchek, - more power than Gagliano.    BRANCH RICKEY      cc - Mr. Robert Howsam

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 18, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  St. Louis vs Detroit  "B" Game    YOUNG, DON    This boy certainly has power and a good body. He can run and he can throw but he is positively "green" with a bat in his hands.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: April 7, 1964  Homestead. Fla.    ZELLER, BART    Can???????t throw. Can???????t run. Can???????t hit.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: March 4, 1964  St. Petersburg, Fla.  Mets Inter-Squad Game    SAMUEL, AMADO    Doesn???????t look to me like a power hitter.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; C-D
Transcription: St. Petersburg, Fla.  March 11, 1964  Intra-Squad Game    SCOTT, VICTOR    Arm average. Good hustler. He would have to hit a lot to be seen regularly in the major league.    BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; E-J
Transcription: WATKINS - Just about what I said on previous report. Good fast  ball. Gives the impression of knowing how to pitch. Has two or  three different deliveries. Has good deal of finish. Not a kid.  If he can get $10,000 he should take it. On the other hand, he might be a good pticher in our organization. I like him but I am not willing to pay the ten thousand.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; E-J
Transcription: WENTZEL - Outfielder    An older fellow, big, strong. This fellow also gives you his   very best. Not young. Sewell says he is a good man to have around, - a   good team man.    THOMAS - Outfielder    He can DO EVERYTHING. Perfect form at the plate, and a lot of  power. Should be able to hit any kind of pitching. Both Joe Brown and  Rip Sewell tell me he is a good fellow on the club, - a team player, wants  to win. Runs in and out from his position all the time, and his interest  is just not put on. I think he really means it. I have never seen him  throw the ball low enough to any base or the home plate. He is an "Andy-  Over" thrower, yet his arm is strong. If he would throw the ball down,   he might then be accurate with it. Sewell says he is accurate, but he has  never shown accuracy to me. He is a distance thrower. Can run good  enough, and he never loafs. I like his potentialities.    He, too, is not daring. He assumes, for example, that the outfielder  is going to get the ball, and he doesn't overrun the base as far  as he should. There are a lot of things he doesn't know. He could stand  a lot of correct coaching; illustrustion: When running off third base  with a runner on first, - every time the pitcher threw to first, he started  back to third. He should, with great daring, start for home. If a wild   throw is made to first, or missed, he could easily score, but he is back on  the bag. In other words, he moves exactly in the wrong direction on this  play. He shifts very short distances on the different batters. This   may be due first to lack of knowledge of the hitters, or, second, it can be  that the opposing team, in the few games I have observed, all hit to the same  spot.    "Whom the Lord loveth, he chasteneth.", and great players whom  management would like to see in Pittsburgh are to be found fault with if  they are not as good as they should be.    And, finally, one more possible criticism. With the score  nothing to nothing, and a runner in scoring distance, he fails to take a  chance. On a short fly ball that he could have caught, I am sure, if he  had made a dive, he failed to do so. He, too, may not have championship  adventure in his soul. I do not know about it.    If this team had a couple of ace pitchers, they could make a big  stir in the Southern League race, and easily go into the play-offs, and  that is my fault. I want everybody to do their best to help me find these  pitchers.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; E-J
Transcription: James Blight -2-    Our own scout, Mozzali, knows the player and supports DeSautel's estimate of the player's ability. My conversation with DeSautel and my visit with Mr. Blight, Jim's father, leads me to believe quite positively that both Gene and Mr. Blight expect a big bonus. With what I know about the Cardinal club in the signing of first year players for 1965, this boy Jim Blight might be worth a competitive bonus and retention by the Cardinal club. He is a bigger, stronger pitcher than most pitchers you will see in high schools anywhere.   On a first look, he is more impressive than Briles.   Mr. Blight told me that his boy had never thrown the curve ball "prior today". That was amazing to me until Gene DeSautel told me that the boy just learned the curve ball this present season under his (DeSautel's) tutelage. His curve is now and then a corking curve, - good velocity and a quick break. Jim is bound to go places in the major leagues, and is worth a competitive bonus figure if there is any way to retain him. That's the problem and that's the challenge to our policy of signing first year men.   He lost his game in this championship contest, - losing to Midland 6 to 5, - horrible support. His club plays three more games. I would like to have Bing in the picture immediately. I would like him to find out directly from DeSautel what Gene's relationship is with the player and whether or not he, DeSautel, is in position to act as our agent in signing the player. A

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; E-J
Transcription: James Blight -3-  liberal sum could be paid to DeSautel on condition that St. Louis  gets the contract. I suggest this first step simply because I  believe DeSautel may have a binding arrangement with Mr. Blight  and the boy to handle all negotiations. If so, we should deal first  with DeSautel. If negotiations resulted in a St. Louis option  exercisable on a given date subsequent to his last high school game,  then I would like to go with Bing to see the player again.  Jim Blight is a fine prospective major league pitcher,   ranking high with all the boys we have seen in recent times.  If an arrangement could be made in this Jim Blight case  similar to the one Bing has proposed in deal with Leonard Boyer  whereby the boy spends this summer on a gentleman's agreement   basis in the Basin League, then and in that event I would be willing  to enter the substantial bonus field in our effort to get the player.  This boy is not a 'hope so' player, - one of the 'might be's'.   Excluding some physical disability or an act of God, this boy is sure   to find a place as a regular on some major league pitching staff  surely within two or three years. He can't miss.  If an option can be arranged, that would give us exclusive   rights. We should then be able to see the player in all three of his  remaining games and I would have the change to work with him  privately. Under the circumstances and in the surroundings on the  occasion of my visit, I didn't think it advisable to go further in  conversation with Mr. Blight or DeSautel than I did go at that time.  I would like very much to have a private workout with Jim Blight

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; E-J
Transcription: Hames Blight -4-    and I hope we can get an option on almost any terms that would enable us to go the full route on a complete investigation of the player.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; E-J
Transcription: Leon "Duke" Carmel  I hope my later report on Duke Carmel will read differently from this one. This is a tragic case of a fine physical specimen and a most likable person failing as a major league player.  He has had 5 full years in professional baseball and he is now 25 years of age, and he has always hit left handed and has always hit from the same batting box position. His rear foot -- the left one -- the toe of his left foot is 28" from a line drawn at right angles to this plate position. He could not reach the outside of the plate with both hands on the bat and yet he has held that position for 5 full years.  Last year he hit .243 at Jacksonville. He is a power hitter -- plenty of power particularly, of course, to the right field, but he hits the long ball to left also.  He shows no aptitude whatever to the suggestions made by Manager Keane or Vernon Benson or anyone else.  To draw a comparison, when Buchek was turned from a righthand hitter to a lefthand hitter -- on the first 12 pitches he made contact upon every pitch and contunued to get the bat and ball together almost without exception. When Duke was turned over from a lefthander to a righthander, he missed the first 11 good pitches and hit the 12th and missed the next 6 -- and I mean he missed them. He was not swinging hard. He was instructed to just simply get the bat and ball together as though he were in a pepper game. He simply could not hit the ball at all.  He did better hitting left handed when told to hit with "intent" meaning pulling or pushing the ball but not at all to compare with either Gagliano or Buchek.  -more-

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; E-J
Transcription: Leon "Duke" Carmel -- 2  The inside pitch below his beltline gives him serious trouble even from the Dudley machine. It could be true that he has been so disadvantaged for 5 years in playing the outside pitching that when the ball comes inside he has consistently either taken the pitch and perhaps a called strike, or has hit it on the handle and this causes him to be unable to handle the inside pitch.  He frequently misses it altogether.  He is married and has several children -- comes from an economically low family on the other side of the tracks in Brooklyn. Married to a very charming and lovable wife. Knows nothing except baseball and would give his soul to make good.  He has the sympathy of his manager and coaches and he certainly has mine.  I am simply non-plussed as to how to help this fellow.  At the present time, he should be kept at the pitching machines constantly.  Manager Keane tells me that we do not have at present any acceptable substitution at first base; that Duke Carmel can do the fielding job splendidly; that is, his arm is very good and his running speed very good.  A left hand pinch hitter is highly desirable on a Cardinal Club and Duke's power to right field makes the right field roof as easily reached by Duke as most boys make singles.  It is sorrowfully tragic to have him fail, but he certainly cannot help this club as a batsman with his present rating.  I hope that in three or four weeks from now I can write a different story.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; E-J
Transcription: Daniel Jaster -3-    The boy is definitely a major league pitching prospect with a big, strong, active body, born only 17-1/2 years ago.  In the olden days when we had Class C and D Clubs, he could by the end of his first season in C or D doubtless become a winning pitcher. I would not dare to send him above that classification in his first assignment. His control would not support it, - neither would his 'stuff', except his fast ball. (Not once in the seven innings did he throw a change of speed pitch).  He could not now help Tulsa or Jacksonville. He would indeed be very crude and nervous in either place. If he were to be signed by the St. Louis club, it would be necessary for him to be retained on its active list in 1965 or lose him at $8,000. He does not now have the control such as Bakenhaster has and I think baseball people who know both players would generally agree that Bakenhaster is a much quicker prospect than Daniel.  I met Daniel's coach. He was simply a salesman, - "better than Larry, etc. etc."  I cite the Bakenhaster comparison simply to imply that the Cardinal club can find and probably will find quicker prospects as first year men than Daniel. Dowling is far ahead of Daniel in poise and control, know how, and stuff.  If it were not for the draft rule on first year players, I would be willing to go into the competitive market for Daniel's contract. I do not recommend a high bonus for Daniel. It simply means a handicap to the Cardinal club in 1965 or the loss of the player at $8.000.

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; E-J
Transcription: Daniel Jaster -4-    If some other club gets him, and doubtless that will happen, then such club will be the under the same handicap. It must keep him on its own so-called active list or lose him to some other club at $8,000. I would rather see the Cardinals in a position to take the player on a draft claim in 1965 than I would to see the club take the money loss itself.     BRANCH RICKEY

Item: Branch Rickey Papers: Baseball File, 1906-1971; Scouting reports; 1963; E-J
Transcription: Player Weaknesses for Florida Winter League Program    Johnny Lewis    Work on fielding, Doesn't charge ball, plays ground balls safely first. Should work on getting better jump on ball in outfield.    Uppercuts ball. His ball is low and away. Has trouble with the high pitch. Needs shorter stroke. Is too far from plate and takes too many pitches.
